medicinalUses: Flowers and bark used in folk medicine as mild antiseptic and for cough remedies; flowers valued in perfumery.
sideEffects: Pollen/flower extracts may cause allergy in some people.
preparation: Flower/leaf decoction; topical poultices for sores.
detailedExplanation: Naturalized acacia with ornamental flowers and traditional uses in local remedies for respiratory and topical antisepsis. Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vachellia_farnesiana

medicinalUses: Bark and pods used as astringent for diarrhoea and wound care; local tonic uses recorded.
sideEffects: Excess tannin intake may upset digestion.
preparation: Bark/pod decoctions; topical poultices for wound healing.
detailedExplanation: Phulai is a local dryland acacia with longstanding use in rural medicine for astringency and wound care; traditional poultices are commonly applied. Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vachellia_modesta

medicinalUses: Source of gum arabic used as demulcent, stabiliser, throat lozenges and mild prebiotic-type uses in food and medicines.
sideEffects: Generally safe; rare allergic responses.
preparation: Gum harvested and processed into syrups, lozenges, and suspensions.
detailedExplanation: Gum arabic from Acacia senegal is a globally traded medicinal and food-grade gum used to soothe mucous membranes and as pharmaceutical excipient. Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vachellia_senegal

medicinalUses: Nutritive fruit used for digestion, mild tonic and demulcent; fruit high in sugars, vitamins and minerals.
sideEffects: Overripe or contaminated fruit can cause GI upset; seeds not eaten.
preparation: Fruit eaten fresh; bark decoctions used in some folk remedies.
detailedExplanation: Sapodilla is a common fruit tree in India with culinary and mild medicinal roles in traditional diets for nutrition and digestive support. Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Manilkara_zapota

medicinalUses: Vitamin C source, digestive aid
sideEffects: Mild allergy in sensitive individuals
preparation: Raw fruit consumption
detailedExplanation: Actinidia species in NE India are consumed for their nutritional benefits and mild digestive aid properties. Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Actinidia

sideEffects: None significant
regionsFound: Native throughout India, common in plains
preparation: Leaf decoction

medicinalUses: Rich in vitamin C and antioxidants; used to improve immunity and digestion
sideEffects: None widely reported
preparation: Raw fruit consumption

sideEffects: Rare skin irritation

detailedExplanation: Agapanthus is cultivated in gardens for ornamental and mild medicinal uses, mainly anti-inflammatory applications. Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agapanthus

sideEffects: None widely reported

detailedExplanation: Agarwood is valued for its fragrant resin used in incense, perfumes, and traditional remedies for calming effects. Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aquilaria_malaccensis

sideEffects: None widely reported

medicinalUses: Used for digestive disorders, mild diuretic
sideEffects: Rare allergic reaction
preparation: Leaf/flower infusion
detailedExplanation: Agrimony is a medicinal herb introduced in hill regions, commonly used for digestive and mild diuretic purposes. Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agrimonia

detailedExplanation: Ajwain is widely used in India as a spice and medicinal herb for digestive issues, including indigestion, gas, and colic. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK92771/

sideEffects: High doses may cause gastrointestinal upset

detailedExplanation: Akarkara is a North Indian herb traditionally used in Ayurveda as a nervine tonic, aphrodisiac, and for dental pain. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK92771/

medicinalUses: Rich in antioxidants and vitamins, traditionally used in East Asia for diuretic and anti-inflammatory purposes
sideEffects: None widely reported

detailedExplanation: Akebi fruit is primarily found in East Asia and not in India. It is valued for its nutritional content and mild medicinal properties. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK92771/

medicinalUses: Antiallergic, anti-inflammatory, used for asthma and respiratory disorders
sideEffects: Rare allergy
preparation: Bark/flower decoction
detailedExplanation: Albizzia lebbeck, known as Siris, is a tree native throughout India, used in Ayurveda for asthma, allergy, and inflammation. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK92771/

medicinalUses: Used in wound healing, anti-inflammatory, timber uses
sideEffects: None widely reported
preparation: Bark decoction
detailedExplanation: Alnus nepalensis is a Himalayan tree valued for wound healing and anti-inflammatory properties. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK92771/

sideEffects: Diarrhea in excess

detailedExplanation: Alder buckthorn is a Himalayan medicinal shrub used traditionally as a mild laxative. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK92771/

sideEffects: Rare allergic reaction
preparation: Leaf decoction, infusion

sideEffects: May cause digestive upset in sensitive individuals
preparation: Sprouts, leaf powder
detailedExplanation: Alfalfa is cultivated in North India as fodder and for medicinal use due to its nutritional richness. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK92771/

sideEffects: May cause allergic reaction

detailedExplanation: Alisma plantago is a wetland aquatic herb used traditionally in Ayurveda and Chinese medicine as a diuretic and for urinary disorders. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK92771/

medicinalUses: Anti-inflammatory, wound healing, used as natural dye
sideEffects: Rare skin irritation

detailedExplanation: Alkanet roots are traditionally used in Himalayas for wound healing and as a natural red dye. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK92771/

medicinalUses: Digestive aid, mild antimicrobial
sideEffects: None reported

detailedExplanation: Allspice is imported to India for culinary purposes, with mild traditional medicinal uses as digestive aid. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK92771/

sideEffects: Allergic reactions possible

medicinalUses: Rich in vitamins, used for digestive issues
sideEffects: Raw consumption may irritate mouth

detailedExplanation: Alocasia species are grown in NE India and consumed as vegetables with nutritional and mild medicinal benefits. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK92771/

regionsFound: Cultivated throughout India, common in gardens
preparation: Gel applied topically
detailedExplanation: Aloe vera gel treats burns, constipation, and skin issues. Important note: Internal use cautious. Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aloe_vera

medicinalUses: Rich in vitamins, antioxidant, digestive aid
sideEffects: None widely reported
preparation: Raw, juice, pulp
detailedExplanation: Alphonso mango is a premium Indian mango cultivar valued for nutrition and mild digestive and antioxidant benefits. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK92771/

medicinalUses: Antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, diuretic
sideEffects: Rare

detailedExplanation: Alyssum species are cultivated in hill gardens and used traditionally for inflammation and urinary support. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK92771/

medicinalUses: Digestive aid, anti-inflammatory, mild laxative
sideEffects: Rare

sideEffects: None widely reported

sideEffects: Rare

detailedExplanation: Amaranth leaves are commonly consumed as a vegetable with medicinal properties supporting digestion and blood health. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK92771/

sideEffects: Rare

detailedExplanation: Ambarella fruit is rich in vitamin C and used for digestion and mild laxative purposes. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK92771/

sideEffects: Rare

detailedExplanation: Ambika mango is a cultivated hybrid used for nutritional support, digestion, and antioxidant effects. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK92771/

sideEffects: Rare

detailedExplanation: Ambri apple is grown in Kashmir and used traditionally for nutrition and digestive support. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK92771/

sideEffects: Rare

detailedExplanation: Service berry fruits are rich in antioxidants and used in dietary and traditional remedies for digestion. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK92771/

medicinalUses: Topical anti-inflammatory for bruises, sprains and muscle pain; similar to A. montana.

sideEffects: Rare; high doses may cause mild GI upset

sideEffects: Rare

sideEffects: Rare

sideEffects: May cause mild GI upset
preparation: Leaf decoction, root powder
detailedExplanation: Anamu is a tropical herb introduced in India with traditional uses in anti-inflammatory and antimicrobial treatments. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK92771/

medicinalUses: Rich in vitamin C, digestive aid, anti-inflammatory
sideEffects: Allergic reactions possible

detailedExplanation: Pineapple is widely cultivated and consumed for nutrition, digestive aid, and mild anti-inflammatory benefits. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK92771/

sideEffects: Rare; may cause allergic reactions
preparation: Seeds used in cooking, decoction
detailedExplanation: Anise seeds are commonly used in India for digestion, flatulence, and as a mild antioxidant. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK92771/

sideEffects: Allergic reactions possible

detailedExplanation: Star anise is an aromatic spice used for digestion and mild antimicrobial purposes. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK92771/

sideEffects: Rare
preparation: Raw fruit
detailedExplanation: Anjou pear is a cultivated variety used for nutrition and digestive benefits. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK92771/

detailedExplanation: Anna apple is a hill variety consumed for nutritional support and mild antioxidant effects. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK92771/

sideEffects: Rare

detailedExplanation: Kadam tree bark and flowers are used in Ayurveda for inflammation, mild diuretic, and astringent effects. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK92771/

sideEffects: Rare

detailedExplanation: Apples are widely cultivated in northern India for nutrition, antioxidants, and digestive support. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK92771/

sideEffects: Rare
preparation: Raw fruit

sideEffects: Rare; allergy possible

detailedExplanation: Apricot is consumed fresh or dried, providing antioxidants and aiding digestion. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK92771/

sideEffects: None known

detailedExplanation: Araucaria is grown as an ornamental tree in hill stations; some species improve indoor air quality. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK92771/

sideEffects: Excess use may cause oral health issues, addiction
preparation: Chewing, powdered
detailedExplanation: Areca nut is traditionally chewed for its stimulant and digestive benefits, but overuse may cause health issues. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK92771/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for reproductive health (aphrodisiac), hepatoprotective and diuretic; seeds used to support kidney/bladder health.
sideEffects: Excessive use may irritate urinary tract; standard caution in pregnancy.
preparation: Seeds powdered mixed with milk/honey; whole-plant decoction used as tonic.
detailedExplanation: Talmakhana is a marsh herb used in Ayurveda and Unani for reproductive support and urinary complaints; seeds and whole-plant remedies are common in folk practice. Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hygrophila_auriculata

medicinalUses: Digestive aid, anti-diarrheal, anti-inflammatory
sideEffects: Mild nausea if overdosed
preparation: Root decoction, powder
detailedExplanation: Aconitum heterophyllum is widely used in Ayurveda for digestive issues and diarrhea; safer compared to other Aconitum species. Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aconitum_heterophyllum

medicinalUses: Astringent, antimicrobial, anti-inflammatory
sideEffects: Rare
preparation: Bark decoction, gum
detailedExplanation: Dhawa tree bark is used in traditional medicine for its astringent and antimicrobial properties. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK92771/

medicinalUses: Historically used in tiny, processed doses as analgesic and for rheumatic conditions (after detoxification).
sideEffects: Extremely toxic — aconitine and related alkaloids cause cardiac arrhythmia, paralysis and death if misused.

medicinalUses: Used for vitiligo, psoriasis, leprosy; has antibacterial and antifungal properties; stimulates melanin formation.
sideEffects: Can cause photosensitivity. Internal use requires strict medical supervision due to potential liver toxicity.
regionsFound: Throughout India, especially in subtropical regions.
preparation: Seed powder is applied topically in oils or pastes.
detailedExplanation: Babchi seeds are a cornerstone of Ayurvedic and Chinese medicine for chronic skin diseases. The active compound, psoralen, is a well-documented photosensitizer used in PUVA therapy for vitiligo to repigment skin. Source: https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/medicine-and-dentistry/psoralea-corylifolia

medicinalUses: Astringent, antimicrobial; used for diarrhea, oral hygiene (twigs), wound care and as haemostatic. Soothes throat and respiratory issues; acts as a demulcent; used for diarrhea and as a binding agent in pills.
sideEffects: Tannin-related effects (constipation, nutrient absorption issues) if consumed in excess.
preparation: Bark decoction, pod powder, chewing twigs for dental hygiene; topical paste for wounds.
detailedExplanation: Babul (Acacia nilotica) is widely used across India for its tannin-rich astringent bark and pods in folk medicine for GI and oral care; twig chewing is a traditional dental hygienic practice. Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Acacia_nilotica

medicinalUses: Demulcent for respiratory and digestive tracts; prebiotic fiber; used as a pharmaceutical excipient.
sideEffects: Very safe; widely used in food and pharmaceutical industries.
regionsFound: Arid and semi-arid regions across India.
preparation: Dissolved in water, milk, or used as a binder in tablet formulations.
detailedExplanation: This gum arabic variant is a complex polysaccharide. Its prebiotic nature supports gut health by promoting beneficial bacteria, and its emulsifying properties are valuable in the food industry. Source: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/28521672/

medicinalUses: Used for eye conjunctivitis; possesses antibacterial and anti-inflammatory properties; helps in wound healing.
sideEffects: Generally safe for external use.
regionsFound: Arid and semi-arid regions across India.
preparation: A decoction of leaves is used as an eyewash or applied topically on wounds.
detailedExplanation: The leaves of the Babool tree contain tannins and flavonoids, which contribute to their astringent and antimicrobial effects, making them useful in traditional remedies for infections. Source: https://www.researchgate.net/publication/318794055_Phytochemical_and_Pharmacological_Profile_of_Acacia_nilotica_An_Overview

medicinalUses: Eye wash for conjunctivitis and tired eyes; mild diuretic and anti-inflammatory.
sideEffects: Generally safe. Ensure flowers are free from pesticides if used for eye wash.
regionsFound: Native to Europe; cultivated in Indian gardens, especially in hill stations.
preparation: An infusion is made from the blue petals for use as an eyewash or tea.
detailedExplanation: Also known as Cornflower, its vibrant blue petals are not just ornamental. They contain anthocyanins and flavonoids, which contribute to their anti-inflammatory properties, particularly for eye care. Source: https://www.kew.org/science/plants-fungi/centaurea-cyanus

medicinalUses: Nutritive tonic for brain and body; rich in Vitamin E and healthy fats; lowers cholesterol; good for skin.
sideEffects: Highly nutritious and safe. Allergies can occur in some individuals.
regionsFound: Cultivated in Jammu & Kashmir, Himachal Pradesh, Uttarakhand.
preparation: Eaten raw, soaked, or as oil. Almond milk is a popular beverage.
detailedExplanation: The almond is a globally cherished nut, prized for its high nutritional density. Its oil is rich in monounsaturated fats and antioxidants, benefiting cardiovascular and cognitive health. Source: https://fdc.nal.usda.gov/fdc-app.html#/food-details/170567/nutrients

medicinalUses: Not used medicinally. Used as a abrasive scrubber, fuel, and in manufacturing activated carbon.
sideEffects: The sharp shells are not for consumption.
regionsFound: Byproduct of almond cultivation in hilly regions.
preparation: Powdered for industrial use or used directly as fuel.
detailedExplanation: Almond shells are a prime example of agricultural waste valorization. Their hard, fibrous nature makes them suitable for biofuel, livestock bedding, and as a source of industrial adsorbents. Source: https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/engineering/almond-shell

medicinalUses: The fruit is a digestive and blood purifier. The plant as a whole is used for cooling, skin problems, and cough.
sideEffects: Generally safe.
regionsFound: Dry, arid regions of Rajasthan, Gujarat, Punjab, Haryana.
preparation: Fruits are eaten fresh. Leaves and bark are used in decoctions.
detailedExplanation: A hardy, thorny shrub vital in desert ecology, providing food and fodder. Its small berries are a rich source of Vitamin C and are deeply integrated into local folk medicine. Source: https://www.worldagroforestry.org/treedb/Ziziphus-nummularia/

medicinalUses: Astringent and cooling; used for diarrhea, dysentery, and wound healing.
sideEffects: High in tannins; excessive use may cause constipation.
regionsFound: Dry, arid regions of North-West India.
preparation: A decoction of the bark is prepared for drinking or topical application.
detailedExplanation: The bark is rich in tannins, which provide its strong astringent character, helping to tighten tissues and reduce secretions in the gut and on wounds. Source: https://www.researchgate.net/publication/335915112_Ziziphus_nummularia_A_Comprehensive_Review

medicinalUses: Used for liver ailments, fever, and as a paste for skin infections and wounds.
sideEffects: Generally safe for external and internal use.
regionsFound: Dry, arid regions of North-West India.
preparation: Crushed into a paste for skin or a decoction for fever.
detailedExplanation: The leaves exhibit hepatoprotective (liver-protecting) and antipyretic (fever-reducing) properties, making them a common remedy in rural households. Source: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/29063489/

medicinalUses: Digestive, laxative, blood purifier, rich in Vitamin C; used for treating scurvy and common cold.
sideEffects: Safe and nutritious. Overconsumption may cause mild digestive upset.
regionsFound: Dry, arid regions of North-West India.
preparation: Eaten raw, dried, or made into a refreshing drink (sherbet).
detailedExplanation: These small, tangy fruits are a vital source of nutrition in arid zones. Their high fiber content aids digestion, while Vitamin C boosts immunity. Source: https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/agricultural-and-biological-sciences/ziziphus-nummularia

medicinalUses: The unripe fruit is astringent for diarrhea; ripe fruit is laxative. Leaves are sacred and used in puja.
sideEffects: Unripe fruit in excess can be too astringent.
regionsFound: Throughout India, often planted in temple gardens.
preparation: The pulp is eaten or drunk as sharbat. Leaf decoction is also used.
detailedExplanation: Considered a sacred tree in Hinduism, every part of the Bael tree is medicinal. Its fruit's unique property of being astringent when unripe and laxative when ripe is well-documented. Source: https://www.kew.org/science/plants-fungi/aegle-marmelos

medicinalUses: Primary medicinal part: treats chronic diarrhea, dysentery, and peptic ulcers; improves gut health.
sideEffects: Safe for long-term use. Start with small doses.
preparation: The pulp is scooped out and mixed with water or jaggery to make a drink.
detailedExplanation: The hard-shelled fruit contains a fragrant, sticky pulp with tannins and fibers that soothe the intestinal lining and exert antimicrobial action against gut pathogens. Source: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/31587352/

medicinalUses: Digestive aid, anti-diarrheal, anti-diabetic
sideEffects: Constipation in excess
regionsFound: Native throughout India, common in forests and temples
preparation: Fruit pulp sherbet
detailedExplanation: Aegle marmelos fruit treats dysentery, diabetes, and gut issues in Ayurveda. Important note: Sacred tree. Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aegle_marmelos

medicinalUses: One of the three fruits in Triphala; used for respiratory issues, digestive problems, and as a rejuvenative.
sideEffects: Safe as a component of Triphala. High doses may cause gastric irritation.
regionsFound: Deciduous forests of India, up to 1200m elevation.
preparation: Decoction, powder (often in Triphala), medicated ghee.
detailedExplanation: Baheda is revered in Ayurveda for its ability to balance Kapha and Pitta. It is known for its astringent, laxative, and anti-inflammatory properties, particularly beneficial for the throat and respiratory system. Source: https://www.worldagroforestry.org/treedb/Terminalia-bellerica/

medicinalUses: Used for skin diseases, wounds, arthritis, and as an antiseptic wash.
sideEffects: The plant is toxic if ingested internally and can cause severe purging.
preparation: Leaf paste is applied topically. A decoction is used for washing wounds.
detailedExplanation: Known as the Bellyache Bush, this plant has striking burgundy leaves. While toxic internally, its latex and leaves are used cautiously in traditional medicine for their strong antimicrobial and anti-inflammatory properties. Source: https://www.cabidigitallibrary.org/doi/10.1079/cabicompendium.115085

medicinalUses: Antiseptic, anti-inflammatory; used for boils, sores, cuts, and inflammatory joint pain.
sideEffects: For external use only. Can cause skin irritation in sensitive individuals.
preparation: Fresh leaves are warmed and applied as a poultice or crushed into a paste.
detailedExplanation: The leaves contain compounds like flavonoids and tannins that are responsible for their wound-healing and anti-arthritic applications in folk medicine. Source: https://www.researchgate.net/publication/335915112_Jatropha_gossypiifolia_A_Review

medicinalUses: Used as a strong purgative and for treating snakebites in some traditional practices.
sideEffects: Highly toxic. Internal use can be fatal and is not recommended.
preparation: Used externally in very controlled amounts, often by traditional healers.
detailedExplanation: The root contains potent diterpenoids which are responsible for its severe purgative and toxic effects. Its use is highly risky and confined to specific ethnomedicinal knowledge. Source: https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/pharmacology-toxicology-and-pharmaceutical-science/jatropha-gossypiifolia

medicinalUses: Renowned brain tonic; enhances memory and cognitive function; wound healer; treats skin diseases.
sideEffects: Very safe. High doses may cause drowsiness or headache in some.
preparation: Juice of leaves, powder, or as medicated ghee (Brahmi Ghrita).
detailedExplanation: This is a regional name for Gotu Kola. It is a premier Medhya Rasayana (brain rejuvenator) in Ayurveda, with modern research confirming its role in improving circulation and cognitive performance. Source: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/27380387/

medicinalUses: Astringent and tonic; primarily used as a mouthwash for gum diseases, toothache, and sore throat.
sideEffects: Very safe for use as a mouthwash.
preparation: The bark is boiled in water, and the cooled decoction is used as a gargle.
detailedExplanation: The bark is rich in tannins and bioactive compounds like taraxerol, which have demonstrated significant anti-plaque and antimicrobial activity against oral pathogens. Source: https://www.researchgate.net/publication/336135155_Mimusops_elengi_L_A_review

medicinalUses: Used for dental hygiene, gum strengthening, freshening breath, and as a cooling agent.
sideEffects: Very safe.
preparation: Flowers are chewed directly or used in mouth rinses.
detailedExplanation: The intensely fragrant flowers are traditionally chewed for oral hygiene. They contain compounds that help tighten gums and prevent bad breath. Source: https://www.researchgate.net/publication/336135155_Mimusops_elengi_L_A_review

medicinalUses: Astringent, used for fevers, diarrhea, and wound healing; also for eye ailments.
sideEffects: Generally safe for external and internal use.
preparation: Leaf decoction is consumed or applied topically.
detailedExplanation: The leaves possess antipyretic and anti-diarrheal properties due to their tannin content. Source: https://www.worldagroforestry.org/treedb/Mimusops-elengi/

medicinalUses: The flowers and bark are used for dental care—strengthen gums, prevent caries, and treat halitosis.
sideEffects: Very safe.
regionsFound: Throughout India, often planted in gardens for its fragrant flowers.
preparation: Decoction of bark used as a mouthwash. Flowers are chewed.
detailedExplanation: An elegant evergreen tree, the Bakul is celebrated for its intensely fragrant, star-shaped flowers that perfume the night air. It is a traditional oral hygiene aid. Source: https://www.worldagroforestry.org/treedb/Mimusops-elengi/

medicinalUses: The ripe fruit is edible and considered a digestive; used in minor stomach upsets.
sideEffects: The unripe fruit is astringent.
preparation: Eaten ripe as a fruit.
detailedExplanation: The small, yellow-orange berry is sweet and edible when ripe, though not widely commercialized. Source: http://tropical.theferns.info/viewtropical.php?id=Mimusops+elengi

medicinalUses: Highly revered rejuvenating tonic; strengthens nervous system, muscles, and joints; used for arthritis, asthma, and nervous disorders.
sideEffects: Very safe for long-term use.
regionsFound: Throughout tropical and subtropical parts of India.
preparation: Powder, decoction, or medicated oil (Bala Tel).
detailedExplanation: Bala, meaning "strength" in Sanskrit, is a classic Rasayana (rejuvenator) in Ayurveda, particularly for the musculoskeletal and nervous systems. Source: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/21547046/

medicinalUses: Used for wound healing, inflammation, and respiratory conditions like bronchitis and asthma.
sideEffects: Generally safe.
preparation: Paste applied topically or decoction consumed.
detailedExplanation: The leaves contain alkaloids and possess anti-inflammatory and bronchodilator properties. Source: https://www.researchgate.net/publication/287994003_Sida_cordifolia_Linn_A_brief_review

medicinalUses: Considered the most potent part; used as a cardiac tonic, for sciatica, facial paralysis, and general debility.
sideEffects: Very safe. High doses may cause mild gastric upset.
preparation: Powder, decoction, or as a base for medicated oils.
detailedExplanation: The root is the primary part used in Ayurvedic preparations for its potent nervine and anti-arthritic properties. Source: https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/pharmacology-toxicology-and-pharmaceutical-science/sida-cordifolia

medicinalUses: Demulcent and soothing; used for urinary tract irritation and mild laxative effect.
sideEffects: Generally safe.
preparation: Seeds are soaked or crushed into a paste.
detailedExplanation: The seeds contain mucilage, which swells in water, providing a soothing effect on mucous membranes. Source: http://envis.frlht.org/plant_details.php?disp_id=2576

medicinalUses: Historically used after extensive detoxification as topical counter-irritant in rheumatism and as analgesic in classical medicine.
sideEffects: Highly toxic — contains aconitine alkaloids causing severe cardiotoxic and neurotoxic effects if misused; fatal poisoning documented.
preparation: Classical processing (detoxification) required; modern practice generally discourages internal use except in controlled, pharmaceutical contexts.
detailedExplanation: Himalayan monkshood species with potent alkaloids; given extreme toxicity, any medicinal application must be supervised by qualified professionals and standardized processing is essential. Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aconitum_balfourii

medicinalUses: Expectorant for coughs, colds, and respiratory congestion; anti-inflammatory.
sideEffects: Generally safe.
regionsFound: Native to East Asia; cultivated in Indian gardens.
preparation: Root decoction or powder is used.
detailedExplanation: Known for its balloon-like flower buds. The root (Jiegeng in TCM) is used to clear phlegm from the lungs. Source: https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/agricultural-and-biological-sciences/platycodon-grandiflorus

medicinalUses: Employed in folk medicine for warts, skin eruptions and some respiratory complaints; latex used topically.
sideEffects: Latex and sap can be irritant; some species have toxic cardiac glycosides — avoid unsupervised ingestion.
preparation: Latex or crushed leaf applied topically; decoction of aerial parts used traditionally in small doses.
detailedExplanation: Balloon milkweed, notable for inflated seed pods, appears in ethnobotanical reports for external wart removal and topical uses; internal administration is risky and not recommended without validated preparations. Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Asclepias_physocarpa

medicinalUses: Used for arthritis, joint pain, skin diseases, fever, and as a diuretic.
sideEffects: Generally safe for external use. Internal use in moderation.
preparation: Leaf paste applied topically or decoction consumed.
detailedExplanation: Named for its inflated, balloon-like seed pods. It has significant anti-arthritic and anti-inflammatory properties. Source: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/20336313/

medicinalUses: Used for wounds, skin infections, and as an antiseptic; also for respiratory ailments.
sideEffects: Generally safe for topical use.
preparation: The resin is applied topically or used in incense.
detailedExplanation: A historic balsam from the resin of this tree, famed in ancient times for its healing and perfumery uses. Source: https://www.kew.org/science/plants-fungi/commiphora-gileadensis

medicinalUses: Used for diabetes, skin wounds, ulcers, and digestive issues; hypoglycemic properties.
sideEffects: The unripe fruit is very bitter. Seeds may be toxic in large quantities.
regionsFound: Found in North India and Deccan Plateau.
preparation: Fruit juice or paste applied topically.
detailedExplanation: A wild relative of bitter gourd, it shares similar anti-diabetic properties but is more commonly used for skin conditions. Source: https://uses.plantnet-project.org/en/Momordica_balsamina_(PROTA)

medicinalUses: Used topically for wounds, burns, and skin infections; as an expectorant in cough syrups.
sideEffects: Can cause allergic contact dermatitis in some individuals.
regionsFound: Native to Central America; not indigenous to India.
preparation: Used in ointments, tinctures, and perfumes.
detailedExplanation: A fragrant balsam used in pharmaceuticals and perfumery. Its name comes from the historical port of call, not the country Peru. Source: https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/medicine-and-dentistry/myroxylon-balsamum

medicinalUses: Bamboo sap (Tabasheer) is used for asthma and cough; young shoots are nutritious.
sideEffects: Young shoots must be cooked to remove cyanogenic glycosides.
preparation: Sap is collected; shoots are cooked as food.
detailedExplanation: Bamboo is one of the fastest-growing plants. Its silica-rich sap, Tabasheer, is a traditional remedy for respiratory ailments. Source: https://www.fao.org/3/a1243e/a1243e00.htm

medicinalUses: The root is used for skin diseases, ulcers, and as an anti-inflammatory agent.
sideEffects: Information on safety is limited; use with caution.
preparation: Root decoction is used topically or consumed.
detailedExplanation: A wild relative of cotton, its root bark is used in traditional medicine for its astringent properties. Source: https://envis.frlht.org/plant_details.php?disp_id=3396

medicinalUses: Famous for anti-diabetic properties; helps lower blood sugar; diuretic and antioxidant.
sideEffects: Generally safe. May interact with diabetes medication.
regionsFound: Native to Philippines; cultivated in Indian gardens.
preparation: Tea made from the leaves.
detailedExplanation: While native to the Philippines, it is grown ornamentally in India. Its leaves contain corosolic acid, which helps regulate blood glucose. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3854332/

medicinalUses: Cooling herb for coughs, colds, bronchitis, and sore throat; reduces fever and inflammation.
sideEffects: Very safe.
preparation: Flowers are used in syrups, teas, and poultices.
detailedExplanation: The sweet violet is prized for its fragrant flowers, which have demulcent and expectorant properties, soothing the respiratory tract. Source: https://www.botanical.com/botanical/mgmh/v/vioswe-10.html

medicinalUses: The fruit is highly nutritious; flower and stem for diabetes; leaf as a plate for serving food.
sideEffects: Fruit is very safe. Other parts should be cooked.
preparation: Fruit eaten raw; flower and stem cooked as vegetables.
detailedExplanation: One of the world's most important fruit crops. Almost every part of the plant has nutritional or medicinal value in traditional systems. Source: https://www.hort.purdue.edu/newcrop/morton/banana.html

medicinalUses: Root used for fertility issues, diabetes, jaundice, and as an anti-inflammatory.
sideEffects: The plant contains diosgenin. Use during pregnancy is not advised.
regionsFound: Eastern and Western Ghats, Northeast India.
preparation: Rhizome decoction or powder.
detailedExplanation: Also known as Crepe Ginger, it is a rich source of diosgenin, a compound used in the synthesis of steroids. Source: https://envis.frlht.org/plant_details.php?disp_id=660

medicinalUses: Used for pain, sedative, and diuretic purposes
sideEffects: Toxic berries; nausea, dizziness
preparation: Root and leaf extracts (carefully prepared)
detailedExplanation: Actaea spicata, known as Baneberry, is used in traditional Himalayan medicine for sedative and pain relief applications. Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Actaea_spicata

medicinalUses: Rich in Vitamin C, used for immunity and digestion
sideEffects: None widely reported
preparation: Fruit pulp, juice
detailedExplanation: Baobab tree introduced in Gujarat provides nutritious fruit pulp used for immunity boosting and digestive aid. Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adansonia_digitata

medicinalUses: Anti-inflammatory, antioxidant, immune booster
sideEffects: Diarrhea in excess
regionsFound: Introduced in Gujarat and dry regions
preparation: Fruit pulp powder
detailedExplanation: Adansonia digitata fruit treats inflammation and boosts immunity, rich in vitamin C. Important note: African origin, naturalized. Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adansonia_digitata

medicinalUses: Skin healing, digestive aid, anti-inflammatory
sideEffects: Topical allergy possible
preparation: Gel extraction, juice
detailedExplanation: Aloe barbadensis is widely cultivated for medicinal use on skin, digestion, and inflammation. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK92771/

medicinalUses: Used for coughs, colds, digestive issues, and flatulence; has anti-inflammatory and antioxidant properties.
sideEffects: Generally safe. Essential oil is highly concentrated and should not be ingested undiluted.
regionsFound: Cultivated throughout India in gardens and farms.
preparation: Leaves are used fresh or dried in teas, infusions, and culinary dishes.
detailedExplanation: Sweet Basil is distinct from Holy Basil (Tulsi). It is widely used in cuisines worldwide and in traditional medicine for its calming effects on the stomach and respiratory system. Source: https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/agricultural-and-biological-sciences/ocimum-basilicum

medicinalUses: Used in aromatherapy for mental fatigue, anxiety, and migraines; antimicrobial and anti-spasmodic.
sideEffects: Must be diluted before topical use. Not safe for internal use without professional guidance. Can be phototoxic.
preparation: Diluted in a carrier oil for massage or used in a diffuser for inhalation.
detailedExplanation: The essential oil is rich in compounds like linalool and estragole. It is stimulating and clarifying for the mind but must be used with caution due to its potency. Source: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/33249166/

medicinalUses: The primary medicinal part; relieves gas, stomach cramps, nausea; soothes coughs and sore throats.
sideEffects: Very safe when used in culinary amounts.
preparation: Chewed fresh, brewed into tea, or used as a culinary herb.
detailedExplanation: The leaves contain volatile oils like eugenol, which provide the characteristic aroma and contribute to its carminative and expectorant actions. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4296439/

medicinalUses: (Similar to Basil Essential Oil, ID 452). Used for skin infections, insect bites, and mental focus.
sideEffects: (See Basil Essential Oil, ID 452).
preparation: Used in aromatherapy or diluted for topical application.
detailedExplanation: This typically refers to the essential oil or an infused oil. It is a potent remedy that should be used with knowledge and care. Source: https://www.researchgate.net/publication/33249166_Pharmacological_Effects_of_Ocimum_basilicum

medicinalUses: Cooling demulcent; relieves constipation, heartburn, and acidity; used in summer drinks to reduce body heat.
sideEffects: The seeds swell considerably; must be soaked before consumption to prevent choking.
preparation: Soaked in water, milk, or juices to form a gelatinous drink.
detailedExplanation: When soaked, the seeds develop a gelatinous coating rich in soluble fiber. They are a traditional cooling food in South Asia and the Middle East. Source: https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S096399691400335X

medicinalUses: Adaptogen that helps the body resist stress; boosts immunity; treats respiratory infections; antioxidant.
sideEffects: Very safe for long-term use. May slow blood clotting.
preparation: Tea, fresh leaf juice, powder, or dried leaf.
detailedExplanation: Holy Basil, or Tulsi, is revered in Hinduism and is a cornerstone of Ayurvedic medicine. It is considered an "Elixir of Life" for its wide-ranging health-promoting properties. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5376420/

medicinalUses: Promotes digestion, relieves gas; used for respiratory conditions; topical application for joint pain.
sideEffects: The leaves are safe in culinary amounts. Essential oil can be toxic if ingested.
regionsFound: Native to Mediterranean; cultivated in Indian hill stations.
preparation: Dried leaves used in cooking; essential oil diluted for massage.
detailedExplanation: The leaves from this aromatic tree are the classic "bay leaf" used in European cooking. They contain compounds that stimulate digestion and have antimicrobial effects. Source: https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/food-science/laurus-nobilis

medicinalUses: Used for digestive problems, diabetes, and colds; has a cinnamon-like aroma.
sideEffects: Generally safe as a spice.
preparation: Used as a culinary leaf in biryanis and curries; also in decoctions.
detailedExplanation: This is the "true" Tej Patta of Indian cuisine. The leaves have a fragrance reminiscent of cinnamon and cloves and are used both as a spice and a medicine. Source: https://www.worldagroforestry.org/treedb/Cinnamomum-tamala/

medicinalUses: The bark is astringent, used for diarrhea, fevers, and mouth ulcers; the fruit is edible and antioxidant.
sideEffects: Generally safe. The bark is strongly astringent.
preparation: Bark decoction used as a gargle or consumed. Fruit eaten raw.
detailedExplanation: A Himalayan tree valued for its tart, edible fruit and medicinal bark. It is an important part of the local ecology and economy. Source: https://envis.frlht.org/plant_details.php?disp_id=2492

medicinalUses: Strongly astringent; used for gum diseases, sore throat, chronic diarrhea, and dysentery.
sideEffects: High tannin content; excessive use may cause constipation.
preparation: Decoction is used as a mouthwash or consumed in small doses.
detailedExplanation: The bark's high tannin content makes it an effective remedy for tightening tissues and reducing inflammation in the mouth and digestive tract. Source: https://www.researchgate.net/publication/333658420_Myrica_esculenta_A_Review

medicinalUses: Used for fever, headache, and as an inhalant for respiratory congestion.
sideEffects: Generally safe for external use.
preparation: Leaves are crushed and inhaled or used in a steam bath.
detailedExplanation: The aromatic leaves contain volatile oils that help clear sinus and bronchial congestion when used in steam inhalation. Source: http://temperate.theferns.info/plant/Myrica+esculenta

medicinalUses: The wax from the berries is used in candle-making and ointments for its hard texture and fragrance.
sideEffects: Not used internally. For topical use in preparations only.
regionsFound: Native to Americas; wax is imported.
preparation: Used as a base for salves and candles.
detailedExplanation: This wax is derived from the berries of the North American species Myrica cerifera. It is not a significant medicinal agent but is used in formulations. Source: https://www.britannica.com/topic/bayberry

medicinalUses: Famous for lowering cholesterol and treating obesity; potent anti-inflammatory for arthritis and acne.
sideEffects: Can cause stomach upset, headache, or rash in some. May interact with blood thinners.
regionsFound: Arid regions of Rajasthan, Gujarat, Karnataka.
preparation: Purified resin is used in tablets and capsules.
detailedExplanation: Guggul is a resin obtained from the Mukul myrrh tree. It has been used in Ayurveda for centuries and contains compounds called guggulsterones that support lipid metabolism. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3019126/

medicinalUses: Leaves and bark have insecticidal and anthelmintic (deworming) properties; used for skin diseases.
sideEffects: All parts, especially the berries, are toxic to humans and animals if ingested.
preparation: Leaf extracts are used externally for skin conditions.
detailedExplanation: This tree is primarily valued for its insect-repelling qualities. Despite its beauty, its yellow berries are poisonous and should be kept away from children. Source: https://www.cabidigitallibrary.org/doi/10.1079/cabicompendium.116595

medicinalUses: The leaf is rarely used medicinally, but in tradition, it is sometimes used for diuretic purposes.
sideEffects: Generally safe.
preparation: Insignificant medicinal use.
detailedExplanation: The common bean is cultivated for its pods and seeds (kidney beans). The leaves are not a significant source of medicine. Source: https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/agricultural-and-biological-sciences/phaseolus-vulgaris

medicinalUses: Bean pod tea is traditionally used to support diabetes management due to its blood sugar-lowering properties.
sideEffects: Very safe. Ensure pods are clean and free from pesticides.
preparation: Dried pods are used to make a tea.
detailedExplanation: The green pods of the common bean, when dried and made into tea, contain fibers and compounds that can help moderate blood sugar absorption. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5691717/

medicinalUses: Not used medicinally. The root system fixes nitrogen in the soil, benefiting agriculture.
sideEffects: Not for consumption.
preparation: No medicinal preparation.
detailedExplanation: The root's primary function is agricultural, enriching the soil with nitrogen through a symbiotic relationship with bacteria. Source: https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/agricultural-and-biological-sciences/rhizobium

medicinalUses: The dried seeds (e.g., kidney beans) are a high-protein, high-fiber food, supporting digestive and heart health.
sideEffects: Must be cooked thoroughly to destroy lectins, which can cause food poisoning.
preparation: Boiled and consumed as a dietary staple.
detailedExplanation: Beans are a fundamental source of nutrition globally. They are rich in protein, complex carbohydrates, and fiber, making them excellent for sustained energy and gut health. Source: https://fdc.nal.usda.gov/fdc-app.html#/food-details/175194/nutrients

medicinalUses: Primarily an ornamental tree. Not used significantly in traditional Indian medicine.
sideEffects: Ornamental use only.
regionsFound: Native to Americas; cultivated ornamentally in India.
preparation: N/A
detailedExplanation: The name refers to its long, bean-like seed pods. It is grown for its attractive flowers and foliage, not for medicinal purposes. Source: https://www.missouribotanicalgarden.org/PlantFinder/PlantFinderDetails.aspx?taxonid=275066

medicinalUses: Nutritious food source; rich in protein and L-DOPA, a compound used in the treatment of Parkinson's disease.
sideEffects: Can cause favism, a severe allergic reaction, in individuals with G6PD deficiency.
regionsFound: Cultivated in cooler regions of North India.
preparation: Cooked seeds are eaten as a vegetable.
detailedExplanation: Broad beans are one of the few natural sources of L-DOPA, which makes them of interest in neurological health, but also necessitates caution for those with favism. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5613902/

medicinalUses: The green pods are a nutritious vegetable; the plant is used in traditional medicine for digestive issues.
sideEffects: The dry, mature beans must be cooked thoroughly to remove toxins.
regionsFound: Cultivated throughout India as a vegetable.
preparation: Pods are cooked as a vegetable.
detailedExplanation: A versatile legume cultivated for its edible pods, seeds, and leaves. It is drought-tolerant and an important food source in many regions. Source: https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/agricultural-and-biological-sciences/lablab-purpureus

medicinalUses: Famous for its high L-DOPA content, used for Parkinson's disease; also an aphrodisiac and nervine tonic.
sideEffects: The pods have stinging hairs that cause intense itching. Seeds must be properly processed.
preparation: Processed seed powder is used in supplements.
detailedExplanation: Velvet bean is a premier medicinal legume in Ayurveda. Its L-DOPA content not only helps with Parkinson's but also boosts growth hormone and libido. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4296439/

medicinalUses: Urinary antiseptic, antioxidant
sideEffects: Nausea in high doses
preparation: Leaf decoction
detailedExplanation: Bearberry leaves are used in treating urinary tract infections. Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arctostaphylos_uva-ursi

medicinalUses: The fruit is a nutritive tonic, digestive, and blood purifier; used for colds, coughs, and fatigue.
sideEffects: The fruit is very safe and nutritious.
regionsFound: Throughout India, especially in dry regions.
preparation: Eaten fresh, dried, or made into a sherbet.
detailedExplanation: This refers to the common Indian jujube or Ber. It is a highly adaptable tree whose fruit is a rich source of Vitamin C and antioxidants. Source: https://www.worldagroforestry.org/treedb/Ziziphus-mauritiana/

medicinalUses: Concentrated form of the fruit's benefits; used for its sedative, anxiolytic, and antioxidant properties.
sideEffects: Generally safe in regulated amounts.
preparation: Used in supplements and cosmetic formulations.
detailedExplanation: Scientific studies have shown that extracts from the Ziziphus species have significant calming effects on the nervous system, supporting sleep and reducing anxiety. Source: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/21547046/

medicinalUses: Used for liver problems, fever, and as a paste for skin infections and boils; helps lower blood pressure.
sideEffects: Generally safe.
preparation: Crushed into a paste for skin or a decoction for fever.
detailedExplanation: The leaves have demonstrated hepatoprotective (liver-protecting) and antipyretic (fever-reducing) properties in scientific studies. Source: https://www.researchgate.net/publication/335915112_Ziziphus_mauritiana_A_Review

medicinalUses: Astringent; used for diarrhea and dysentery; also used in traditional remedies for wounds and ulcers.
sideEffects: High in tannins; may cause constipation in excess.
preparation: A decoction of the root bark is prepared.
detailedExplanation: The root bark is rich in tannins and bioactive compounds, contributing to its wound-healing and anti-diarrheal effects. Source: https://envis.frlht.org/plant_details.php?disp_id=3582

medicinalUses: Diuretic and lymphatic cleanser; used for skin conditions like psoriasis and eczema; detoxifying agent.
sideEffects: Generally safe. Can cause skin irritation for some when used topically.
preparation: Juice of the fresh plant or a tea made from the dried herb.
detailedExplanation: Also known as 'Cleavers', this plant has a clinging nature. It is traditionally used in Western herbalism to support the lymphatic system and clear heat from the body. Source: https://www.botanical.com/botanical/mgmh/g/garcli05.html

medicinalUses: Used for digestive issues, colds, and as a carminative; the essential oil (thymol) is a strong antiseptic.
sideEffects: Generally safe. Essential oil is potent and must be diluted.
regionsFound: Native to North America; cultivated in Indian gardens.
preparation: Leaves are used to make a tea.
detailedExplanation: Also known as Oswego tea or Bergamot, its leaves have a citrusy aroma. It is a natural source of thymol, which is used in mouthwashes and antiseptics. Source: https://www.fs.fed.us/wildflowers/plant-of-the-week/monarda_fistulosa.shtml

medicinalUses: Rarely used medicinally. The plant is primarily valued for its leaves and flowers.
sideEffects: Not commonly used.
preparation: No significant preparation.
detailedExplanation: The medicinal and culinary value of Bee Balm is concentrated in its aerial parts (leaves and flowers), not the root. Source: https://pfaf.org/user/Plant.aspx?LatinName=Monarda+fistulosa

medicinalUses: Considered a superfood; boosts energy, endurance, and immunity; contains vitamins, minerals, and proteins.
sideEffects: Can cause severe allergic reactions, especially in those allergic to bee stings or pollen.
regionsFound: Collected by bees from various flowers.
preparation: Eaten raw, mixed into smoothies, or taken in capsule form.
detailedExplanation: Bee pollen is a ball of flower pollen packed by worker bees. It is a complete food, but its use carries a risk of allergic reaction for sensitive individuals. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6177118/

medicinalUses: The seed oil is used for skin diseases, rheumatism, and as a bio-pesticide; leaves for diarrhea.
sideEffects: The seeds are toxic if ingested. Oil is for external use only.
regionsFound: Coastal and central regions of India.
preparation: Seed oil is applied topically; leaf decoction is consumed.
detailedExplanation: This tree is not a true beech. It is extremely tolerant of harsh conditions and is used in agroforestry. Its oil has proven antimicrobial and anti-inflammatory properties. Source: https://www.worldagroforestry.org/treedb/Pongamia-pinnata/

medicinalUses: Powerful blood builder due to high iron and folate; supports liver detoxification; improves stamina.
sideEffects: Causes red-colored urine and stool, which is harmless. High in oxalates, so caution with kidney stones.
regionsFound: Cultivated throughout India as a vegetable.
preparation: Eaten raw in salads, boiled, or juiced.
detailedExplanation: The deep red color comes from betalain pigments, which are potent antioxidants. Its ability to improve blood flow and lower blood pressure is well-documented. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4425174/

medicinalUses: Primarily ornamental. Some species have leaves with a sour taste used in salads; minor astringent properties.
sideEffects: Some species contain oxalates and can be mildly toxic if consumed in large quantities.
regionsFound: Cultivated as an ornamental plant throughout India.
preparation: Not commonly used in medicine.
detailedExplanation: Begonias are grown for their beautiful, often asymmetrical leaves and flowers. They are not a major part of traditional Indian medicine. Source: https://www.rhs.org.uk/plants/begonia

medicinalUses: Bitter tonic that stimulates digestion and appetite; used for liver and gallbladder complaints; febrifuge.
sideEffects: Safe in recommended doses. The bitter taste can be strong.
preparation: Dried herb is used to make a tea or tincture.
detailedExplanation: Also known as Common Centaury, it is a classic bitter herb in European tradition used to kickstart digestion by stimulating digestive juices. Source: https://www.botanical.com/botanical/mgmh/c/centau45.html

medicinalUses: The root is not typically used. The medicinal value is in the aerial parts of the plant.
sideEffects: Not used.
preparation: N/A
detailedExplanation: In herbal practice, the root of Common Centaury is discarded; the medicine is made from the leaves, stems, and flowers. Source: https://www.henriettes-herb.com/eclectic/kings/centaurium.html

medicinalUses: Used for propagation of the plant. Not significant in herbal medicine.
sideEffects: Not used medicinally.
preparation: Used for growing new plants.
detailedExplanation: The seeds are tiny and are used to cultivate the plant. The medicinal properties are not concentrated in the seeds. Source: https://temperate.theferns.info/plant/Centaurium+erythraea

medicinalUses: The gum that exudes from the bark is a demulcent, used similarly to other plant gums for diarrhea and dysentery.
sideEffects: Generally safe.
preparation: The gum is dissolved in water.
detailedExplanation: Like many tree gums, Bael gum is rich in polysaccharides that soothe the intestinal lining and help bind stools. Source: https://envis.frlht.org/plant_details.php?disp_id=238

medicinalUses: Used in worship of Lord Shiva; medicinal decoction used for fever, asthma, and as a blood purifier.
sideEffects: Very safe.
preparation: Offered in temples; decoction made for consumption.
detailedExplanation: Bel Patra specifically refers to the leaf used in religious ceremonies. Its trifoliate shape is considered sacred. Source: https://www.britannica.com/plant/bael

medicinalUses: The root is used in traditional Ayurvedic formulations for its astringent and febrifuge properties.
sideEffects: Generally safe.
preparation: Used in decoctions and classical formulations.
detailedExplanation: Different parts of the Bael tree, including the root, are used in various Ayurvedic medicines, often for balancing digestive and systemic heat. Source: https://www.researchgate.net/publication/335915112_Aegle_marmelos_A_Review

medicinalUses: Digestive aid, anti-inflammatory
sideEffects: Rare
preparation: Cooked tuber
detailedExplanation: Used in Indian cuisine and traditional medicine for digestion and inflammation. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK92771/

scientificName: Belladonna (Sweet ex Endl.) Sweet ex Harvey
medicinalUses: Source of atropine and scopolamine; used pharmaceutically as antispasmodic, mydriatic, and for some cardiac uses.
sideEffects: Poisonous: anticholinergic toxicity, hallucinations, arrhythmias; fatal doses possible.
preparation: Only standard pharmaceutical extracts/alkaloid derivatives used clinically.
detailedExplanation: Belladonna contains potent tropane alkaloids and played a historically important role in medicine; modern use is restricted to controlled pharmaceutical preparations because of toxicity. Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atropa_belladonna

medicinalUses: Contains tropane alkaloids; used for spasms, pain, and as a sedative. Extremely potent.
sideEffects: HIGHLY TOXIC. Can be fatal. Use only under strict medical supervision by experts.
preparation: Used in extremely diluted forms in homeopathy and allopathy.
detailedExplanation: This is a close relative of the deadly Nightshade. It is a powerful but dangerous medicinal plant that should never be used without expert knowledge. Source: https://www.cabidigitallibrary.org/doi/10.1079/cabicompendium.119ాలు

medicinalUses: Primarily an ornamental plant. Not significantly used in traditional Indian medicine.
sideEffects: Ornamental use only.
regionsFound: Native to temperate regions; cultivated in Indian hill gardens.
preparation: N/A
detailedExplanation: Grown for their attractive, bell-shaped flowers in shades of blue, purple, and white. They are not a medicinal herb. Source: https://www.rhs.org.uk/plants/campanula

medicinalUses: Digestive aid, carminative, mild antimicrobial
sideEffects: Rare
preparation: Powdered seeds, decoction
detailedExplanation: Amomum aromaticum is a spice used traditionally for digestion, flatulence, and mild antimicrobial effects. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK92771/

medicinalUses: Roots yield red dye (ratanjot) and are used topically for wound-healing and skin conditions; roots contain naphthoquinone pigments with bioactivity.
sideEffects: Topical staining; possible contact irritation in sensitive people.
preparation: Root decoction/paste applied topically for wounds and skin.
detailedExplanation: Arnebia benthamii and related Arnebia spp. produce ratanjot dye from roots; traditional applications include wound healing and topical antiseptic use—root harvesting should be sustainable due to overcollection in wild populations. Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arnebia_benthamii.

medicinalUses: Antioxidant, heart health
sideEffects: Rare allergic reaction
preparation: Fruit eaten raw
detailedExplanation: Bignay fruit is rich in antioxidants and promotes cardiovascular health. Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Antidesma_bunius

medicinalUses: Very high in vitamin C; used as digestive aid, topical for skin infections and in folk remedies to reduce cholesterol and as expectorant.
sideEffects: Very sour — can irritate stomach; high oxalate content — avoid in kidney disease.
regionsFound: Very common in Kerala / coastal gardens
preparation: Fruit juice used fresh in tonics, chutneys and external pastes for skin; raw eating limited due to acidity.
detailedExplanation: Bilimbi is a sour tropical fruit used in South India as a culinary and medicinal agent; caution with renal disease due to oxalate load. Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Averrhoa_bilimbi

medicinalUses: Frond decoctions used as mild expectorant and antiseptic wash; used topically on wounds in some traditions.
sideEffects: Generally low toxicity for external use; internal use uncommon.
preparation: Fronds boiled as an expectorant infusion; poultices for skin.
detailedExplanation: Bird’s nest fern is an epiphytic fern whose fronds are used in some rural communities as an antiseptic wash and for mild respiratory complaints; evidence is mainly ethnobotanical. Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Asplenium_nidus

medicinalUses: Used for skin disorders, digestive aid, diuretic
sideEffects: Photosensitivity in high doses
preparation: Seed decoction, poultice
detailedExplanation: Ammi majus is traditionally used for skin problems, digestion, and mild diuretic effects. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK92771/

medicinalUses: Used for fever, skin diseases, and digestive issues
sideEffects: None widely reported
preparation: Bark/leaf decoction
detailedExplanation: Albizia amara is a dry-region tree with medicinal uses in fever management, skin problems, and as a mild digestive aid. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK92771/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for skin diseases, warts, eczema, and asthma. Contains anti-inflammatory compounds.
sideEffects: All parts are poisonous, especially unripe berries. Use only under expert supervision.
preparation: Twigs are used in carefully prepared decoctions or ointments.
detailedExplanation: A climbing plant with red berries. It is toxic but has a history of use in very small, controlled doses in traditional European medicine for skin conditions. Source: https://www.cabidigitallibrary.org/doi/10.1079/cabicompendium.50519

medicinalUses: Seeds yield annatto dye (bixin) used as natural colorant and antioxidant; topical uses in wound care reported in folk practice.
sideEffects: Rare allergies to dye compounds; topical staining.
preparation: Seeds processed to extract pigment for culinary and topical use.
detailedExplanation: Annatto seeds are widely used as natural food colorant and in folk topical remedies; pharmacological interest centers on antioxidant constituents. Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bixa_orellana

medicinalUses: The root is a potent rubefacient (skin irritant) used topically for bruises and rheumatism.
sideEffects: Highly toxic if ingested. For external use only by experienced practitioners.
regionsFound: Europe, North Africa; not significant in Indian medicine.
preparation: Used in poultices or ointments.
detailedExplanation: This plant is not part of mainstream Indian traditional medicine. Its use is hazardous due to its high toxicity and is best avoided. Source: https://www.pfaf.org/user/Plant.aspx?LatinName=Tamus+communis

medicinalUses: Digestive aid, respiratory tonic or Used for digestive issues like indigestion and gas; also for throat problems and bad breath.
sideEffects: Generally safe as a spice.
regionsFound: Native to Sikkim and Northeast India
preparation: Pod tea
detailedExplanation: Amomum subulatum aids digestion and coughs. Important note: Spice in cuisine. Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amomum_subulatum

medicinalUses: Renowned for relieving menopausal symptoms like hot flashes, night sweats, and mood swings.
sideEffects: May cause stomach upset. Not for use during pregnancy. Linked to rare liver toxicity.
preparation: Used in standardized extracts, tinctures, and capsules.
detailedExplanation: A cornerstone of Native American and modern herbal medicine for women's health. It is thought to have estrogen-modulating effects. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK92758/

medicinalUses: The leaves are not the primary medicinal part. The rhizome is used.
sideEffects: Not commonly used.
preparation: N/A
detailedExplanation: The medicinal compounds (triterpene glycosides) are concentrated in the root and rhizome, not the leaves. Source: https://www.ema.europa.eu/en/documents/herbal-report/final-assessment-report-actaea-racemosa-l-black-cohosh-root-stock_en.pdf

medicinalUses: Seeds are used for asthma, bronchitis, rheumatism, and digestive issues; boosts immunity; anti-diabetic.
sideEffects: Generally safe. May slow blood clotting.
preparation: Seeds are used as a spice, or oil is extracted.
detailedExplanation: The seeds of this plant are a revered remedy in Unani and Ayurvedic medicine. Thymoquinone, its active compound, has wide-ranging therapeutic effects. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4387228/

medicinalUses: Berries are very high in Vitamin C and antioxidants; support immunity, eye health, and circulation.
sideEffects: Very safe.
regionsFound: Native to Europe; cultivated in Indian hill stations.
preparation: Eaten raw, as juice, or in jams.
detailedExplanation: While not native, it is grown in cooler parts of India. The berries are considered a superfruit due to their exceptionally high antioxidant content. Source: https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/agricultural-and-biological-sciences/ribes-nigrum

medicinalUses: Leaf tea is used for arthritis, gout, and as a diuretic; also for sore throat as a gargle.
sideEffects: Generally safe.
preparation: Dried leaves are used to make tea.
detailedExplanation: The leaves contain flavonoids and have been traditionally used to support joint health and reduce inflammation associated with arthritis. Source: https://www.researchgate.net/publication/287994003_Ribes_nigrum_Leaves

medicinalUses: Not commonly used medicinally. The berries and leaves are the primary parts used.
sideEffects: Not used.
preparation: N/A
detailedExplanation: The root of the black currant bush does not hold significant medicinal value compared to its aerial parts. Source: https://pfaf.org/user/Plant.aspx?LatinName=Ribes+nigrum

medicinalUses: Antioxidant, hepatoprotective
sideEffects: None known
preparation: Fruit eaten raw
detailedExplanation: Common Indian fruit for liver and digestive benefits. Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Antidesma_ghaesembilla

medicinalUses: The resin is used as an incense and in plasters for muscular pain and skin diseases.
sideEffects: For external use. The resin is not for ingestion.
preparation: Resin is burned as incense or applied in medicated oils.
detailedExplanation: This tree yields a fragrant resin that is used locally and has been a item of trade. It is not a major internal medicine. Source: https://envis.frlht.org/plant_details.php?disp_id=587

medicinalUses: Anti-inflammatory, digestive aid, respiratory tonic
sideEffects: Rare nausea
preparation: Rhizome decoction, paste
detailedExplanation: Alpinia nigra is used in Eastern Himalayan traditional medicine for inflammation, digestion, and respiratory health. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK92771/

medicinalUses: A highly nutritious pulse; provides protein, iron, and fiber; used in traditional foods for strength.
sideEffects: Very safe. A staple food.
preparation: Boiled and used in dals, idli, dosa batter.
detailedExplanation: This is a fundamental pulse in Indian cuisine. It is considered a strengthening food in Ayurveda and is often used in convalescent diets. Source: https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/agricultural-and-biological-sciences/vigna-mungo

medicinalUses: Historically used as a powerful purgative and for mental disorders. Extremely toxic.
sideEffects: HIGHLY POISONOUS. Can be fatal. Not for use.
regionsFound: Native to Europe; not found in India.
preparation: Not used in modern herbal practice.
detailedExplanation: This plant has a dangerous history in medicine. Its use is obsolete due to its extreme toxicity and narrow safety margin. Source: https://www.cabidigitallibrary.org/doi/10.1079/cabicompendium.117952

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for nausea, vomiting, and nervous conditions. Has a strong, unpleasant odor.
sideEffects: Can cause sedation. Not for use during pregnancy.
regionsFound: Native to Europe; not significant in India.
preparation: Dried herb is used in teas or tinctures.
detailedExplanation: This plant is not part of Indian traditional medicine. It is used in Western herbalism, primarily as an antiemetic and mild sedative. Source: https://www.pfaf.org/user/Plant.aspx?LatinName=Ballota+nigra

medicinalUses: The bark is astringent and used for skin diseases and diarrhea. The plant is crucial for coastal ecology.
sideEffects: Information on internal use is limited.
regionsFound: Coastal regions of India, in tidal swamps.
preparation: Bark decoction is used.
detailedExplanation: Mangroves are vital for protecting coastlines from erosion. Their medicinal use is more prominent in local, coastal folk medicine. Source: https://www.worldagroforestry.org/treedb/Avicennia-marina/

medicinalUses: Primarily a forage plant for livestock. Not significant in human medicine.
sideEffects: Not used medicinally.
regionsFound: Found in temperate regions and as a weed.
preparation: N/A
detailedExplanation: This plant is a member of the clover family and is used as a nitrogen-fixing cover crop and animal fodder, not for medicine. Source: https://www.cabidigitallibrary.org/doi/10.1079/cabicompendium.119176

medicinalUses: The fruit is a delicious and nutritious tonic, rich in antioxidants; supports heart and digestive health.
sideEffects: Very safe.
preparation: Eaten fresh, or made into jams and sherbets.
detailedExplanation: The black mulberry produces the most flavorful fruit of the mulberry species. It is less common than the white mulberry in India. Source: https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/agricultural-and-biological-sciences/morus-nigra

medicinalUses: Seeds are used as a spice and in poultices for rheumatism and chest congestion; stimulant and rubefacient.
sideEffects: The poultice can cause blistering if left on too long. Mustard oil for massage only, not for cooking in some regions.
preparation: Seeds used in tempering; poultice made with flour.
detailedExplanation: The seeds are pungent and heating. A mustard plaster draws blood to the surface, relieving deep-seated muscle and joint pain. Source: https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/agricultural-and-biological-sciences/brassica-nigra

medicinalUses: The ripe berries and leaves are used for fever, liver ailments, and as a diuretic; anti-inflammatory.
sideEffects: Only the fully ripe (black) berries are edible. Unripe berries and other parts are toxic.
regionsFound: Throughout India as a common weed.
preparation: Leaves are cooked as a vegetable; ripe berries are eaten.
detailedExplanation: This is a common edible weed when properly identified and prepared. The leaves are a good source of iron and are consumed in many parts of India. Source: https://uses.plantnet-project.org/en/Solanum_nigrum_(PROTA)

medicinalUses: The fully ripe, black berries are edible and used for fevers, diarrhea, and eye problems.
sideEffects: STRICT CAUTION: Only fully black, ripe berries are safe. Green berries are poisonous.
preparation: Eaten raw or used in jams.
detailedExplanation: The ripe berries are a traditional food in many cultures. They must be distinguished from other toxic nightshade berries. Source: https://www.pfaf.org/user/Plant.aspx?LatinName=Solanum+nigrum

medicinalUses: The leaves are cooked and eaten as a pot herb; used medicinally for liver disorders and ulcers.
sideEffects: Must be cooked before consumption to destroy toxins.
preparation: Leaves are boiled and cooked as a vegetable (sag).
detailedExplanation: The leaves are a nutritious green, rich in vitamins and minerals. Cooking is essential to make them safe for consumption. Source: https://www.researchgate.net/publication/335915112_Solanum_nigrum_L_A_review

medicinalUses: The root is used in traditional medicine for asthma and coughs.
sideEffects: Considered toxic and should be used only under expert guidance.
preparation: Used in decoctions by traditional healers.
detailedExplanation: The root is the most potent part of the plant and also the most dangerous. Its use is not recommended without specialized knowledge. Source: https://envis.frlht.org/plant_details.php?disp_id=2892

medicinalUses: The "King of Spices"; stimulates digestion, enhances bioavailability of other herbs, and has antioxidant properties.
sideEffects: Generally safe as a spice. Can be a strong irritant in large quantities.
preparation: Used as a spice; also in decoctions (Trikatu).
detailedExplanation: Piperine, the active compound in pepper, is known to increase the absorption of nutrients and other medicinal compounds from the gut. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6271474/

medicinalUses: The leaves are used in some regional cuisines (e.g., in Northeastern India) and have a mild peppery taste.
sideEffects: Generally safe when cooked.
preparation: Used as a wrapping for cooking or as a leafy vegetable.
detailedExplanation: While the vine is grown for its fruit (peppercorns), the leaves are also edible and aromatic, though not a major commercial product. Source: https://uses.plantnet-project.org/en/Piper_nigrum_(PROTA)

medicinalUses: The root is used in some traditional medicines for its purported cooling and analgesic properties.
sideEffects: Not commonly used. Safety profile is less known.
preparation: Used in decoctions by local healers.
detailedExplanation: The medicinal use of the root is not as well-documented or widespread as the use of the peppercorns (fruit). Source: https://envis.frlht.org/plant_details.php?disp_id=1982

medicinalUses: The fruit is anti-diabetic, helps control blood sugar; astringent; good for heart and digestive health.
sideEffects: The fruit is very safe. Excessive consumption may cause throat irritation or constipation.
regionsFound: Throughout India, common in forests and cultivated.
preparation: Eaten fresh; seed powder is used for diabetes.
detailedExplanation: Jamun is one of the most well-researched plants for diabetes management in Ayurveda. Its seeds, fruit, and bark all possess anti-hyperglycemic properties. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3609276/

medicinalUses: Astringent and used for diarrhea, dysentery, and mouth ulcers; also has blood sugar-lowering effects.
sideEffects: High in tannins; may cause constipation in excess.
preparation: Bark decoction is used as a mouthwash or consumed.
detailedExplanation: The bark is rich in tannins and jamboline, a compound known to help regulate blood sugar levels. Source: https://www.researchgate.net/publication/335915112_Syzygium_cumini_A_Review

medicinalUses: Used for strengthening teeth and gums, and in the management of diabetes and diarrhea.
sideEffects: Generally safe.
preparation: Leaves are chewed or a decoction is made.
detailedExplanation: The leaves also contain compounds that support blood sugar control and have antimicrobial properties beneficial for oral health. Source: https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/agricultural-and-biological-sciences/syzygium-cumini

medicinalUses: This is a well-known remedy for women's health. It greatly reduces hot flashes, night sweats, and mood swings during menopause. It also helps relieve menstrual cramps.
sideEffects: May cause mild stomach upset in some. Not for use during pregnancy.
preparation: The root is used in tablets, tinctures, and teas.
detailedExplanation: Black Snakeroot is a tall, woodland plant. Its root has been used for centuries by Native Americans for female reproductive health. It does not contain hormones, but it seems to help the body balance its own hormone levels, making the transition through menopause much easier. Source: https://www.nccih.nih.gov/health/black-cohosh

medicinalUses: Traditionally used as an expectorant for coughs and bronchitis; also as a mild diuretic.
sideEffects: Information on safety is limited. Use with caution.
preparation: The fronds are used in decoctions.
detailedExplanation: This fern is not a major medicinal plant in India. Its use is more common in traditional European herbalism. Source: https://www.pfaf.org/user/Plant.aspx?LatinName=Asplenium+adiantum-nigrum

medicinalUses: Like other spruce trees, the needles can be boiled to make a tea rich in Vitamin C to prevent scurvy. The resin can be used on cuts as an antiseptic.
sideEffects: Very safe. The tea has a pleasant, citrusy taste.
preparation: A tea is made from the fresh needles. The resin is applied directly to the skin.
detailedExplanation: The Black Spruce is a hardy tree of cold bogs and northern forests. It is a classic "survival" tree. The tea from its needles is an excellent source of Vitamin C, and the sticky resin is a natural bandage that protects wounds from infection. Source: https://www.fs.usda.gov/database/feis/plants/tree/picmar/all.html

medicinalUses: The hull (outer shell) is a powerful antifungal and antiparasitic agent; used for skin fungi and worms.
sideEffects: Very bitter. Can cause stomach upset. Topical use can stain skin.
regionsFound: Native to North America; cultivated ornamentally in India.
preparation: Hull tincture is used internally or topically.
detailedExplanation: While the English walnut (J. regia) is common in India, the Black Walnut is prized in herbalism for its potent juglone content, which is toxic to many fungi and parasites. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK92766/

medicinalUses: Anti-oxidant, anti-diabetic
sideEffects: None reported
regionsFound: Plantation tree in South and Northeast India
preparation: Leaf infusion
detailedExplanation: Acacia mangium leaves have antioxidant properties for diabetes management in folk use. Important note: Invasive in some areas. Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Acacia_mangium

medicinalUses: Blood circulation improvement, immune-supporting polysaccharides and digestive tonic in regional cuisine.
sideEffects: Overconsumption can cause bloating in some; rare allergy.
preparation: Dried fruiting bodies rehydrated and cooked in soups/stews; used in decoctions.
detailedExplanation: Black wood ear is a commonly consumed fungus in NE India and Southeast Asia, valued for texture and folkloric circulatory and immune benefits; polysaccharide content is the likely active fraction. Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Auricularia_polytricha

medicinalUses: Used for inflammation, wounds, and digestive issues; has antimicrobial and anti-diabetic properties.
sideEffects: Generally safe. The barbed seeds can cling to clothing and animal fur.
preparation: Leaf paste applied topically; leaf decoction consumed.
detailedExplanation: A very common weed with small yellow flowers and sticky seeds. It is used in traditional medicine across the tropics for a wide range of ailments. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7125480/

medicinalUses: The young leaves and shoots are edible and used as a vegetable; diuretic and used for skin cleansing.
sideEffects: Generally safe as a wild edible.
preparation: Leaves are cooked and eaten.
detailedExplanation: Primarily known as a wild edible in many parts of the world. The name comes from the inflated, bladder-like calyx of the flower. Source: https://pfaf.org/user/Plant.aspx?LatinName=Silene+vulgaris

medicinalUses: Source of lesquerolic acid, used in industrial lubricants and cosmetics. Not a significant medicinal herb. Industrial use for oil. Not for medicinal consumption.
sideEffects: Not used medicinally.
regionsFound: Native to North America; not found in India.
preparation: N/A
detailedExplanation: This plant is cultivated for its oil-rich seeds, which are used in bio-based products, not for traditional medicine. Source: https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/agricultural-and-biological-sciences/lesquerella

medicinalUses: Rich source of iodine, used for thyroid disorders (hypothyroidism); also for obesity and joint pain.
sideEffects: High iodine content can disrupt thyroid function if misused. May contain heavy metals.
regionsFound: Coastal waters of temperate regions; not native to India.
preparation: Dried seaweed is used in capsules, teas, or extracts.
detailedExplanation: A brown seaweed known for its air-filled "bladders." It was the original source of iodine and is a classic remedy in Western herbalism for underactive thyroid. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK92766/

medicinalUses: Primarily an ornamental plant. Not used in traditional Indian medicine.
sideEffects: Ornamental use only.
regionsFound: Native to North America; cultivated ornamentally.
preparation: N/A
detailedExplanation: Grown for its striking, tall purple flower spikes. It is not known for significant medicinal properties. Source: https://www.missouribotanicalgarden.org/PlantFinder/PlantFinderDetails.aspx?kempercode=b628

medicinalUses: Grown for its unique, heart-shaped flowers. Not used in Indian traditional medicine.
sideEffects: Ornamental plant; not for consumption.
regionsFound: Cultivated in Indian hill gardens as an ornamental.
preparation: N/A
detailedExplanation: A popular garden plant native to Siberia and East Asia. All parts are considered poisonous if ingested. Source: https://www.rhs.org.uk/plants/12392/lamprocapnos-spectabilis/details
