preparation: Fruit: Eaten fresh or used in cooking.
detailedExplanation: Known as the "king of fruits," its health benefits are primarily nutritional. It is a good source of potassium, copper, and folate. Source: https://fdc.nal.usda.gov/fdc-app.html#/food-details/167765/nutrients

medicinalUses: Diuretic & Purgative: A powerful herb used to induce urination and bowel movements. Anti-inflammatory & Anti-rheumatic.
sideEffects: ALL PARTS ARE TOXIC, ESPECIALLY THE ROOTS. Causes severe vomiting, diarrhea, and dizziness. Use is dangerous.
preparation: Not recommended for home use.
detailedExplanation: This plant is much more toxic than its relative, the common elder (Sambucus nigra). Its use is not advised due to the high concentration of cyanogenic glycosides. Source: https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/pharmacology-toxicology-and-pharmaceutical-science/sambucus-ebulus

medicinalUses: Traditional Tonic: Used similarly to its relative American Ginseng as a mild stimulant and tonic for fatigue. Cough Suppressant.
sideEffects: Limited safety data. Should be used with caution.
preparation: Tea/Decoction: Made from the root.
detailedExplanation: This small, native plant is much less potent than true Ginseng (Panax ginseng). Its use is based on Native American tradition and folk medicine, with little modern research.

medicinalUses: Not for Medicinal Use: This plant is a destructive parasite on conifer trees. It does not have the same medicinal history as European Mistletoe (Viscum album).
sideEffects: Considered non-edible and potentially toxic.
preparation: No traditional medicinal preparation.
detailedExplanation: Unlike European Mistletoe, which is used in oncology support, Dwarf Mistletoe is an agricultural pest and is not used in herbal medicine.

medicinalUses: Brain Tonic & Nootropic: A premier Ayurvedic herb for enhancing memory, intelligence, and cognitive function. Anxiolytic: Calms the mind and promotes restful sleep.
sideEffects: Very safe.
preparation: Powder (Churna): Mixed with milk or ghee. Juice: From the fresh plant. Decoction.
detailedExplanation: In Ayurveda, it is considered a Medhya Rasayana (brain-rejuvenating herb). Research attributes its effects to scopoletin and other alkaloids that may support neurotransmitter function. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3459456/

medicinalUses: Diuretic & Cathartic: Traditionally used as a strong diuretic to promote urination and as a laxative. Vasoconstrictor: Was used to constrict blood vessels.
sideEffects: TOXIC. Contains the alkaloid sparteine, which can cause nausea, vomiting, and paralysis. Not safe for use.
preparation: Not recommended due to toxicity.
detailedExplanation: While historically used, its high concentration of sparteine makes it dangerous. Sparteine can severely depress heart function and was once used to induce labor, but is now considered too risky.

medicinalUses: Ornamental & Dye Plant: Primarily cultivated for the yellow dye obtained from its flowers. Limited Medicinal Use: Sometimes used similarly to chamomile for its mild anti-inflammatory properties.
sideEffects: May cause allergic reactions in those sensitive to the Asteraceae family.
preparation: Tea: Made from the flowers.
detailedExplanation: Its medicinal value is considered inferior to that of true Chamomile (Matricaria chamomilla). Its primary historical and modern value is as a source of a permanent yellow dye.

medicinalUses: Antiviral & Anti-inflammatory: The root (Ban Lan Gen) is a key herb in Traditional Chinese Medicine used to treat viral infections like influenza, mumps, and SARS. Source of Indigo Dye.
sideEffects: Generally safe in recommended doses.
preparation: Decoction: The root is boiled. Tincture/Capsules.
detailedExplanation: The root contains compounds like indirubin and tryptanthrin, which have demonstrated potent antiviral and anti-inflammatory effects in laboratory studies. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7126104/

medicinalUses: Traditional Vermifuge: Used to expel intestinal worms. Astringent: Used topically for wounds and skin conditions.
sideEffects: CARCINOGENIC and TOXIC. Contains ptaquiloside, a potent carcinogen. Linked to stomach cancer. All parts are poisonous, especially the rhizomes.
preparation: NOT RECOMMENDED. Traditional use involves careful preparation of young fronds, but the risks far outweigh any benefits.
detailedExplanation: This plant is considered one of the most common poisonous ferns. Its toxicity is not destroyed by cooking. Consumption is strongly linked to a high incidence of esophageal and gastric cancer in populations that eat it. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK448101/

medicinalUses: Aromatherapy: The resinous wood is used in incense and perfumes for its calming, grounding scent, believed to reduce anxiety and promote meditation. Digestive Aid: In traditional medicine, used for digestive complaints.
sideEffects: Generally safe as an inhaled fragrance. Internal use should be guided by a professional.
preparation: Incense: The resin-impregnated wood is burned. Essential Oil: Used in high-end perfumery and aromatherapy.
detailedExplanation: The valuable, fragrant resin (oud) is produced by the tree as a defense mechanism to a fungal infection. It is one of the most expensive natural raw materials in the world. Source: https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/agricultural-and-biological-sciences/aquilaria

medicinalUses: Anti-bacterial, wound healing
sideEffects: Allergic reactions
regionsFound: Plantation tree in Northeast and South India
preparation: Bark decoction
detailedExplanation: Acacia auriculiformis bark treats infections and wounds, with tannins providing astringent effects. Important note: Fast-growing for timber. Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Acacia_auriculiformis

medicinalUses: Nutritious Food: The tubers (Tiger Nuts) are rich in fiber, healthy fats, and minerals. Prebiotic: The high fiber content supports healthy gut bacteria.
sideEffects: Generally very safe as a food. High fiber content may cause gas or bloating if consumed in excess.
preparation: Eaten Raw: The dried tubers are chewed. Flour: Ground into gluten-free flour. Milk: Soaked and blended to make "Horchata".
detailedExplanation: While often called a nut, it is a tuber. It is an excellent source of resistant starch, a type of prebiotic fiber that feeds beneficial gut microbiota and improves digestive health. Source: https://fdc.nal.usda.gov/fdc-app.html#/food-details/787876/nutrients

medicinalUses: Liver and Gallbladder Tonic: Traditionally used to stimulate bile flow and treat skin conditions like eczema and acne linked to liver congestion. Mild Diuretic.
sideEffects: May cause stomach irritation. Not recommended for pregnant women.
preparation: Tea/Infusion: Made from the dried aerial parts. Tincture: Liquid extract.
detailedExplanation: The plant is named for its smoky odor. It contains isoquinoline alkaloids which are thought to be responsible for its bitter and bile-stimulating properties. Source: https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/pharmacology-toxicology-and-pharmaceutical-science/fumaria

medicinalUses: Resin and oils used as expectorant and antiseptic; as aromatic for coughs and chest complaints.
sideEffects: Avoid inhalation of concentrated oils in sensitive people; skin irritation possible.
preparation: Resin used in fumigation, essential-oil extraction for inhalation therapies.
detailedExplanation: East Himalayan fir yields aromatic resins applied in traditional high-altitude medicine to aid breathing and treat respiratory complaints; often used as fumigant or in topical preparations. Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abies_spectabilis

medicinalUses: Digestive Health: The rhizome is a source of easily digestible starch, used in convalescent foods. Anti-inflammatory: Used in traditional medicine for coughs, colds, and as an anti-inflammatory agent.
sideEffects: Generally safe as a food.
preparation: Starch Powder: Used as a thickener in soups and desserts. Decoction: The rhizome is boiled for medicinal use.
detailedExplanation: This plant is a close relative of turmeric. Its starch is a demulcent, meaning it soothes irritated mucous membranes in the digestive tract. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC9394427/

medicinalUses: Liver Tonic: Used in Ayurveda for liver disorders and jaundice. Anti-anxiety: Considered a nervine tonic and used for mental health conditions. Skin Diseases: Used for treating ringworm and other skin infections.
sideEffects: Generally safe in traditional doses.
preparation: Powder/Churna: Dried flower heads are powdered. Juice: Extracted from the fresh plant. Decoction.
detailedExplanation: The flowers and aerial parts contain sesquiterpene lactones and alkaloids that have demonstrated hepatoprotective (liver-protecting) and anxiolytic effects in animal studies. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3249903/

medicinalUses: Antimicrobial: The latex and root are used for treating skin infections and toothaches. Anticancer Potential: Contains indole alkaloids (e.g., coronaridine) studied for cytotoxic activity against cancer cells.
sideEffects: The latex can be irritating. All parts of the plant may be toxic if ingested in large quantities.
preparation: Topical Application: Latex applied to warts and wounds. Root Paste: Applied to relieve toothache.
detailedExplanation: The plant is rich in iboga-type alkaloids, which have complex effects on the central nervous system. Its use requires caution and professional guidance. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3862132/

medicinalUses: Immune Support: Stimulates the activity of immune cells (macrophages) to help fight infections, particularly the common cold. Antioxidant.
sideEffects: Mild side effects include stomach upset or rash. May trigger allergies in those sensitive to the daisy family.
preparation: Tea: Dried flowers and aerial parts. Tincture: Alcohol extract. Lozenges/Capsules.
detailedExplanation: The flowers, along with the rest of the aerial parts, contain polysaccharides, alkamides, and cichoric acid which work synergistically to modulate the immune response. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4441164/

medicinalUses: Immune Modulation: Similar to the flower, the leaves contain immune-supportive compounds. Topical Use: Used in creams and salves for wound healing and skin inflammation.
sideEffects: Same as Echinacea flower.
preparation: Tea/Infusion: Often used in combination with the flowers and root. Topical Salve.
detailedExplanation: While the root is often considered the most potent part, the leaves and flowers also contain beneficial alkamides and polysaccharides that contribute to the plant's overall immune-enhancing effect. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4441164/

medicinalUses: Immune System Activation: The most potent part of the plant for stimulating macrophage activity and cytokine production to fight infections. Antiviral & Antioxidant: Shown to reduce the severity and duration of colds and flu.
sideEffects: Mild stomach upset or allergic reactions, especially in those allergic to daisies.
preparation: Tincture: Alcohol extract of the root. Decoction: Root boiled in water for 10-15 minutes. Capsules: Dried powdered root.
detailedExplanation: The root has a higher concentration of alkylamides and polysaccharides than the aerial parts, which are critical for its immune-modulating effects. It is best used at the first sign of illness. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4441164/

medicinalUses: Liver Protectant: Strong hepatoprotective properties, used for jaundice and liver disorders. Hair Tonic: Traditionally used in hair oils to prevent graying, promote growth, and strengthen hair. Wound Healing.
sideEffects: Very safe.
preparation: Hair Oil: Leaves infused in coconut or sesame oil. Juice: Fresh leaf juice for liver health. Powder/Churna.
detailedExplanation: The plant contains wedelolactone and demethylwedelolactone, which have been shown to protect the liver from toxins like carbon tetrachloride. It also promotes hair growth by increasing follicular size and number. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3931201/

medicinalUses: Skin Anti-aging: Extracts are rich in leontopodic acids which have potent antioxidant activity, protecting skin from UV-induced damage and slowing collagen breakdown. Anti-inflammatory.
sideEffects: Generally safe for topical use.
preparation: Skin Serums & Creams: Commercial cosmetic products containing edelweiss extract.
detailedExplanation: The plant survives extreme alpine UV exposure by producing unique phenolic compounds and flavonoids. These same compounds are harnessed in cosmeceuticals to protect human skin from photoaging. Source: https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/agricultural-and-biological-sciences/leontopodium

medicinalUses: Relaxant & Aphrodisiac: Traditionally used in wine to induce mild euphoria, relaxation, and enhance dream states. Antioxidant Rich.
sideEffects: Limited safety data. May cause mild sedation.
preparation: Tea/Infusion: Dried flowers steeped in hot water. Tincture.
detailedExplanation: The flowers contain nuciferine and aporphine alkaloids, which interact with dopamine and serotonin receptors, contributing to its calming and mood-enhancing effects. Source: https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/biochemistry-genetics-and-molecular-biology/nymphaea

medicinalUses: Anticholinergic: Contains tropane alkaloids (hyoscyamine, scopolamine) used in pharmaceuticals for spasms, motion sickness, and as a pre-anesthetic.
sideEffects: HIGHLY TOXIC. Can cause delirium, hallucinations, tachycardia, paralysis, and death. Not for self-use.
preparation: Pharmaceuticals: Purified alkaloids are used in controlled doses in modern medicine.
detailedExplanation: This is one of the most potent sources of hyoscyamine. Its use is strictly confined to the pharmaceutical industry due to its narrow therapeutic index and high toxicity. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK548276/

medicinalUses: Diaphoretic: Promotes sweating to break fevers during colds and flu. Decongestant: Helps relieve sinus congestion and allergies. Diuretic.
sideEffects: Very safe. The raw flowers can sometimes cause nausea.
preparation: Tea: Dried flowers steeped in hot water. Syrup: Often combined with honey. Tincture.
detailedExplanation: The flowers are rich in flavonols (like rutin) and essential oils. Their diaphoretic effect helps the body eliminate toxins through the skin during a fever. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4848651/

medicinalUses: Antiviral Powerhouse: Rich in anthocyanins which can inhibit the replication of influenza viruses by blocking the virus from entering host cells. Immune Booster.
sideEffects: Raw or unripe berries are toxic and can cause severe nausea and vomiting. Only use fully ripe, cooked berries.
preparation: Syrup: The most common preparation, made by simmering ripe berries. Lozenges/Gummies.
detailedExplanation: Clinical studies have shown that elderberry syrup can significantly reduce the duration and severity of flu symptoms. The bioactive compounds destroy the virus's ability to infect host cells. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4848651/

medicinalUses: Flu & Cold Remedy: Specifically formulated to harness the antiviral and immune-stimulating properties of the berry in a palatable, preservable form.
sideEffects: Safe when made from properly prepared, ripe berries. Contains sugar.
preparation: Prepared Syrup: Taken by the spoonful (typically 1 tbsp for adults, 1 tsp for children) daily for prevention or every 2-3 hours during illness.
detailedExplanation: This preparation concentrates the berries' antiviral anthocyanins. It is a well-researched and evidence-based natural remedy for upper respiratory infections. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4848651/

medicinalUses: Respiratory Decongestant: A potent expectorant that helps clear stubborn, deep-seated mucus in bronchitis and COPD. Antimicrobial: Active against tuberculosis and other bacteria.
sideEffects: Can cause allergic reactions in those sensitive to the Asteraceae family. May cause diarrhea or vomiting in high doses.
preparation: Decoction: Root boiled for 10-15 minutes. Tincture. Syrup.
detailedExplanation: The root contains up to 44% inulin (a prebiotic fiber) and sesquiterpene lactones like alantolactone, which are responsible for its expectorant and antimicrobial actions. Source: https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/pharmacology-toxicology-and-pharmaceutical-science/inula-helenium

medicinalUses: Traditional sedative and nervine tonic; seeds and roots used in Ayurveda for nervous system complaints and as adaptogen-like remedies. Used especially as nervine rejuvenation, anti-inflammatory and aphrodisiac in Ayurveda.
sideEffects: Seeds contain psychoactive compounds; misuse can cause hallucinations and GI upset.
preparation: Roots and seeds processed into decoctions or powders; seeds should be used only by experts.
detailedExplanation: Argyreia nervosa has historical use as nervine tonic and mild sedative in traditional systems; seeds contain ergoline alkaloids so pharmacological use should be handled carefully and under guidance. Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Argyreia_nervosa.

medicinalUses: Digestive aid, anti-inflammatory
sideEffects: Rare
preparation: Boiled or cooked tuber
detailedExplanation: Elephant foot yam is widely used as a food and for mild digestive and anti-inflammatory benefits. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK92771/

medicinalUses: Fever Reducer: A well-known antipyretic in traditional medicine. Diuretic & Kidney Tonic: Used for urinary tract infections and kidney stones. Hepatoprotective.
sideEffects: Generally safe in traditional doses.
preparation: Decoction: The whole plant is boiled. Juice: From fresh leaves. Powder.
detailedExplanation: The plant contains sesquiterpene lactones (e.g., deoxyelephantopin) which have demonstrated anti-inflammatory, anticancer, and liver-protecting activities in preclinical studies. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3862118/

medicinalUses: Adaptogen: Enhances the body's resilience to physical and mental stress, reducing fatigue and improving endurance. Immune Modulator.
sideEffects: May cause mild drowsiness. Can interact with sedatives and diabetes medications.
preparation: Tincture: Liquid extract of the root and rhizomes. Capsules/Tablets.
detailedExplanation: Unlike true Panax ginseng, Eleuthero's effects are attributed to eleutherosides, not ginsenosides. It helps regulate the HPA axis and cortisol levels, improving stress response. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK548568/

medicinalUses: Adaptogen: Helps the body resist physical and mental stress, reducing fatigue and improving cognitive function. Immune Support.
sideEffects: May cause mild drowsiness. Can interact with sedatives and diabetes medications.
preparation: Tincture: Liquid extract of the root. Capsules/Tablets.
detailedExplanation: The active compounds, eleutherosides, help regulate the body's stress response (HPA axis), unlike true ginseng which uses ginsenosides. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK548568/

medicinalUses: Digestive Soothing: The inner bark forms a mucilaginous gel that coats and soothes the mouth, throat, stomach, and intestines, relieving irritation from heartburn, GERD, ulcers, and Crohn's disease. Demulcent for Coughs.
sideEffects: Very safe. May slow the absorption of other oral medications if taken at the same time.
preparation: Powder: Mixed with water to make a soothing drink or porridge. Lozenges: For sore throats. Poultice: For wounds and skin inflammation.
detailedExplanation: The therapeutic power comes from a complex mixture of polysaccharides that form a slick gel when mixed with water. This gel physically protects irritated tissues, allowing them to heal. Source: https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/pharmacology-toxicology-and-pharmaceutical-science/ulmus-rubra

medicinalUses: Potent Antioxidant: One of the richest natural sources of Vitamin C, which is remarkably heat-stable. Supports immune function and combats oxidative stress. Hair & Skin Health: Promotes collagen production. Liver Protectant.
sideEffects: Generally very safe. High doses may cause stomach acidity in some individuals.
preparation: Raw Fruit: Eaten fresh. Powder (Churna): Mixed with water or honey. Murabba: A sweet preserve. Juice.
detailedExplanation: Amla's Vitamin C is bound to tannins, which prevent its oxidation, making it highly bioavailable. It is a cornerstone of Ayurvedic medicine, believed to rejuvenate all organ systems. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3157142/

medicinalUses: Pharmaceutical Use: The bark is the source of paclitaxel (Taxol), a critically important chemotherapy drug for ovarian, breast, and lung cancers.
sideEffects: EVERY PART EXCEPT THE RED ARIL IS FATALLY POISONOUS. Causes cardiac arrest and death within hours. No antidote.
preparation: STRICTLY PHARMACEUTICAL. The purified drug paclitaxel is administered intravenously in a hospital setting. The raw plant is not medicine.
detailedExplanation: The plant contains taxine alkaloids which are deadly cardiotoxins. The bright red, fleshy aril around the seed is the only non-poisonous part, but the seed inside it is highly toxic. It is crucial to recognize and avoid this tree. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK548164/

medicinalUses: Food Security & Fiber: The pseudostem and corm are staple foods. Traditional Medicine: Used for fractures, sprains, and as a general tonic.
sideEffects: Not typically associated with toxicity when prepared correctly as food.
preparation: Food: The corm and pseudostem are fermented and cooked. Poultice: For sprains.
detailedExplanation: A crucial food crop in Ethiopia. Its medicinal use is primarily nutritional and for physical support in traditional bone-setting practices.

medicinalUses: Anti-inflammatory, used for respiratory and digestive aid
sideEffects: Rare allergic reactions
preparation: Leaf decoction
detailedExplanation: Ajuga integrifolia is used in Himalayan medicine for respiratory, digestive, and anti-inflammatory purposes. Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ajuga_integrifolia

medicinalUses: Antiparasitic: Traditionally used to expel intestinal worms, especially roundworms and hookworms. Carminative: Reduces gas and bloating, particularly from beans.
sideEffects: Essential oil is toxic in high doses. Can cause nerve damage, dizziness, and vomiting. Use the leaf sparingly as a culinary herb.
preparation: Culinary Herb: A few leaves cooked with beans. Tea: A weak tea from leaves for deworming (use with caution).
detailedExplanation: The anthelmintic property is due to ascariole, a toxic compound also found in wormwood. While effective, the narrow safety margin means it should be used carefully. Source: https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/agricultural-and-biological-sciences/dysphania-ambrosioides

medicinalUses: Bronchodilator: The alkaloid ephedrine is a potent decongestant and bronchodilator, used for asthma and nasal congestion. Stimulant: Increases heart rate and blood pressure.
sideEffects: HIGHLY REGULATED. Can cause hypertension, arrhythmia, insomnia, stroke, and heart attack. Banned in many countries for over-the-counter use.
preparation: Pharmaceuticals: Ephedrine is a prescription drug. Traditional teas are extremely risky.
detailedExplanation: Ephedra is the plant source of the drug ephedrine. Its use is associated with significant cardiovascular risks and should only be undertaken under strict medical supervision. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK538213/

medicinalUses: Source of Ephedrine: The green stems are the primary part of the plant used to extract ephedrine alkaloids for medicinal and illicit (methamphetamine) purposes.
sideEffects: Same as Ephedra Herb. Highly dangerous without medical oversight.
preparation: Not for self-preparation. Used in regulated pharmaceutical manufacturing.
detailedExplanation: The stems contain pseudoephedrine and ephedrine, which are sympathomimetic amines. Their sale and use are heavily controlled due to the potential for misuse and severe side effects. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK538213/

medicinalUses: Air Purifying: Known to remove indoor air pollutants like formaldehyde and benzene.
sideEffects: TOXIC IF INGESTED. Can cause oral irritation, vomiting, and difficulty swallowing in pets and humans.
preparation: Not for medicinal internal use. Valued as an ornamental and air-purifying plant.
detailedExplanation: While excellent for improving air quality, all parts of the plant contain calcium oxalate crystals, which are toxic upon ingestion. Keep away from children and pets. Source: https://www.aspca.org/pet-care/animal-poison-control/toxic-and-non-toxic-plants/pothos

medicinalUses: Anti-inflammatory & Analgesic: Traditionally used to treat fevers, pain, and inflammation. Culinary Herb.
sideEffects: Generally safe when used as a food. Medicinal doses may cause stomach upset.
preparation: Leaves: Used in cooking. Tea/Decoction: For fever and pain.
detailedExplanation: The plant contains eryngial, a compound with demonstrated anti-inflammatory and antimicrobial properties. It is a common flavoring agent in many cuisines.

medicinalUses: Traditional Diuretic & Tonic: Historically used to treat kidney stones, urinary infections, and as a general tonic. Expectorant.
sideEffects: Generally considered safe.
preparation: Decoction: The root is boiled in water for a tea. Tincture.
detailedExplanation: The root has a sweet, aromatic taste and was traditionally candied. It contains saponins and essential oils, which may contribute to its diuretic and expectorant properties.

medicinalUses: Sedative & Anticonvulsant: The bark and leaves are used in traditional medicine for insomnia, anxiety, and convulsions. Antimicrobial.
sideEffects: All parts are toxic if ingested raw. Can cause paralysis and respiratory depression. Must be used only after proper detoxification.
preparation: Detoxified Decoction: Used in traditional preparations after specific purification processes.
detailedExplanation: The plant contains erythrina alkaloids, which have curare-like effects, blocking neuromuscular transmission. Its medicinal use is complex and should not be attempted without expert guidance. Source: https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/pharmacology-toxicology-and-pharmaceutical-science/erythrina

medicinalUses: Anxiolytic & Sedative: Promotes calm and restful sleep without the risk of addiction associated with opium poppies. Mild Analgesic.
sideEffects: Very safe. May cause drowsiness.
preparation: Tea/Tincture: Made from the aerial parts. Capsules.
detailedExplanation: This plant contains different alkaloids (e.g., californidine) than the opium poppy. It acts as a gentle nervous system relaxant, making it ideal for anxiety and insomnia. Source: https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/pharmacology-toxicology-and-pharmaceutical-science/eschscholzia-californica

medicinalUses: Digestive Aid: The thick peel aids digestion and relieves flatulence. Antioxidant Rich: High in vitamin C and flavonoids. Traditional Ritual Use.
sideEffects: Generally safe. The peel's essential oil may cause photosensitivity.
preparation: Candied Peel: Eaten as a digestive. Jam/Preserve. Essential Oil.
detailedExplanation: A primary citrus species used in Jewish rituals during Sukkot. Its phytochemical profile is similar to other citrus fruits, offering antimicrobial and anti-anxiety benefits. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7120914/

medicinalUses: Digestive Aid & Antioxidant: The aromatic peel is rich in essential oils (limonene, citral) that aid digestion and provide potent antioxidant and antimicrobial benefits.
sideEffects: Generally safe. The essential oil may cause photosensitivity if applied topically before sun exposure.
preparation: Candied Peel: Eaten as a digestive after meals. Infused Water or Tea. Zest: Used in cooking.
detailedExplanation: The peel contains a higher concentration of bioactive flavonoids and essential oils than the pulp, making it particularly effective for soothing the digestive tract and fighting oxidative stress. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7120914/

medicinalUses: Respiratory Decongestant: The leaves are rich in cineole, a powerful decongestant for colds, flu, and sinusitis. Antiseptic.
sideEffects: Nausea, diarrhea if ingested in large amounts. Oil is toxic if swallowed.
preparation: Steam Inhalation: Leaves in hot water. Tea: Mild infusion. Topical Oil: Diluted.
detailedExplanation: 1,8-cineole (eucalyptol) is the main active compound, proven to break down mucus and fight respiratory pathogens. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3842692/

medicinalUses: Astringent & Febrifuge: Traditionally used in decoctions to reduce fevers and as an astringent.
sideEffects: Generally safe in decoction.
preparation: Decoction: Bark boiled in water.
detailedExplanation: While the leaves are the primary medicinal part, the bark has been used in traditional medicine for its tannin content, which provides astringent properties.

medicinalUses: Decongestant & Expectorant: The primary source of cineole (eucalyptol), which thins mucus and helps clear respiratory tract congestion from colds, bronchitis, and sinusitis. Antiseptic.
sideEffects: Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea if ingested in large amounts. Essential oil is toxic if ingested undiluted.
preparation: Steam Inhalation: Handful of leaves in hot water. Tea: Mild infusion from dried leaves. Chest Rub: Diluted essential oil.
detailedExplanation: The 1,8-cineole compound is both an effective mucolytic (breaks down mucus) and a potent antimicrobial agent against respiratory pathogens. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3842692/

medicinalUses: Powerful Respiratory Aid: Used in inhalants and rubs to relieve cough and congestion. Topical Analgesic: Applied to joints and muscles to relieve pain. Antiseptic for Wounds.
sideEffects: HIGHLY TOXIC if swallowed. Can cause seizures. Always dilute for topical use. Keep away from children and pets.
preparation: Steam Inhalation: A few drops in hot water. Topical Application: Diluted in a carrier oil (e.g., 5% concentration).
detailedExplanation: This is a concentrated essential oil. Its potency requires extreme caution. It provides rapid relief for respiratory symptoms due to its high concentration of 1,8-cineole. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK557643/

medicinalUses: Tonic for Bones & Muscles: A key herb in TCM to strengthen the lower back, knees, and tendons. Lowers Blood Pressure: Contains compounds that act as vasodilators. Anti-aging.
sideEffects: Very safe.
preparation: Decoction: Bark boiled for a strong tea. Tincture. Powder in Capsules.
detailedExplanation: Known as "Du Zhong" in TCM, it is considered a Yang tonic. The bark contains aucubin and geniposidic acid, which are linked to its ability to strengthen connective tissue and lower hypertension. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3853932/

medicinalUses: Flu & Fever Remedy: A classic diaphoretic used to break fevers and relieve the deep muscle aches ("bone-pain") associated with influenza. Immune Stimulant.
sideEffects: Can cause nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea in high doses. Long-term use may be hepatotoxic.
preparation: Tea/Infusion: Dried aerial parts steeped in hot water. Tincture.
detailedExplanation: The plant's common name, "Boneset," comes from its traditional use for "breakbone fever" (dengue fever). It stimulates the immune system and induces sweating to reduce a fever. Source: https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/medicine-and-dentistry/eupatorium

medicinalUses: TOPICAL for Skin Lesions: The latex (sap) is a potent skin irritant used to treat warts, skin cancers, and keratoses. CAUTION: Highly Irritating.
sideEffects: The latex is corrosive and can cause severe skin blistering, blindness in eyes, and is poisonous if ingested.
preparation: Strictly Topical: A tiny amount of fresh latex is applied precisely to the wart or lesion by a practitioner. NOT for self-treatment.
detailedExplanation: The active compound, ingenol mebutate, is derived from Euphorbia peplus and is an FDA-approved prescription drug for actinic keratosis. It works by inducing cell death in the abnormal skin cells. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK548164/

medicinalUses: Anti-inflammatory & Diuretic: The leaves are used for gout, arthritis, and rheumatism to help flush uric acid from the body and reduce joint inflammation. Laxative.
sideEffects: Generally safe.
preparation: Tea/Infusion: Made from the dried leaves. Tincture.
detailedExplanation: The leaves contain coumarins, flavonoids, and tannins. Their diuretic and mild laxative action helps in the elimination of metabolic wastes that contribute to inflammatory joint conditions.

medicinalUses: Liver and Gallbladder Tonic: Contains berberine which stimulates bile secretion and improves liver function. Antibacterial: Effective against various bacteria and fungi. Antidiabetic.
sideEffects: High doses may cause nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea. Not for use during pregnancy.
preparation: Decoction: Bark or root boiled in water. Tincture: Liquid extract. Powder.
detailedExplanation: The potent alkaloid berberine is the primary active compound, known for its antimicrobial, anti-inflammatory, and blood-sugar-lowering effects. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5871262/

medicinalUses: Potent Laxative: The berries are a strong cathartic used for severe constipation.
sideEffects: STRONG PURGATIVE. Causes severe cramping, nausea, and dehydration. Not for long-term use.
preparation: Berry Syrup/Decoction: Used in very small, controlled doses.
detailedExplanation: The anthraquinone glycosides in the berries irritate the colon lining, inducing powerful bowel movements. Its use requires extreme caution. Source: https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/pharmacology-toxicology-and-pharmaceutical-science/rhamnus-cathartica

medicinalUses: Astringent, healing
sideEffects: Toxic in high doses
preparation: Flower decoction
detailedExplanation: Common columbine with traditional healing uses. Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aquilegia_vulgaris

medicinalUses: Urinary Tract Health: A diuretic and anti-inflammatory used for kidney stones, UTIs, and bladder infections. Wound Healing.
sideEffects: Generally safe. May cause allergic reactions in those sensitive to Asteraceae.
preparation: Tea: Dried aerial parts steeped in hot water. Tincture.
detailedExplanation: The plant contains saponins and flavonoids that increase urine flow while reducing inflammation in the urinary tract, helping to flush out infections and small stones. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3528755/

medicinalUses: Integrative Cancer Care: Injected extracts are used in Europe (especially anthroposophic medicine) to improve quality of life, reduce tumor-related symptoms, and mitigate side effects of chemotherapy.
sideEffects: BERRIES ARE HIGHLY POISONOUS. Injectable extracts can cause fever, chills, and allergic reactions.
preparation: Injectable Extracts: Prepared under the brand names Iscador, Helixor, etc. NOT for oral self-medication.
detailedExplanation: Mistletoe lectins are believed to stimulate the immune system to attack cancer cells. Its use is a well-established complementary therapy in Europe but remains controversial elsewhere. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK65954/

medicinalUses: Used in regulated cancer therapy. The leaves are less toxic than berries but still contain active lectins and viscotoxins.
sideEffects: Injectable extracts can cause fever and chills. Raw leaves are unsafe to consume.
preparation: Injectable Extracts Only.
detailedExplanation: Like the berries, the leaves are used to prepare extracts for complementary cancer care, primarily in Europe, to improve quality of life and reduce side effects of chemotherapy. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK65954/

medicinalUses: Historical Use: Traditionally used to induce menstruation and abortion. Insect Repellent.
sideEffects: EXTREMELY TOXIC. HIGHLY DANGEROUS. The essential oil can cause acute liver failure, seizures, multi-organ damage, and death, even in very small doses (less than 1 teaspoon).
preparation: NO SAFE DOSAGE. The plant and especially its oil should not be used in any home preparation.
detailedExplanation: This is one of the most dangerous herbal toxins. The compound pulegone is a potent hepatotoxin and neurotoxin. There is no safe level for internal use. Its historical use for abortion has resulted in numerous fatalities. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK548164/

medicinalUses: Skin Regeneration: The berry oil is rich in omega-7 (palmitoleic acid) and antioxidants, promoting wound healing and skin repair. Nutrient Powerhouse: Berries are extremely high in Vitamin C.
sideEffects: Very safe.
preparation: Berry Oil: Applied topically for burns, wounds, and radiation-induced skin damage. Juice: From the berries.
detailedExplanation: The berries are one of the most nutrient-dense fruits. The oil is renowned for its ability to support mucosal tissue healing, both externally on the skin and internally in the digestive tract. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC8880946/

medicinalUses: Nervine Tonic: Used for anxiety, depression, and nervous exhaustion. Galactagogue: Traditionally used to promote breast milk production. Digestive Aid.
sideEffects: Generally safe. May interact with blood pressure and hormone medications.
preparation: Tea: Dried aerial parts. Tincture.
detailedExplanation: The plant contains verbenalin and other iridoid glycosides which are thought to contribute to its calming effects on the nervous system and its bitter, digestive properties.

medicinalUses: Hormonal Balance: The GLA (Gamma-Linolenic Acid) is a precursor to prostaglandins, helping to alleviate PMS and menopausal symptoms. Anti-inflammatory for Skin: Used for eczema and psoriasis.
sideEffects: Mild headache, stomach upset.
preparation: Softgel Capsules: Typically 500-1300 mg taken daily.
detailedExplanation: GLA is an Omega-6 fatty acid that the body converts into anti-inflammatory compounds. This makes the oil particularly useful for conditions driven by inflammation and hormonal fluctuation. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK557788/

medicinalUses: Eye Soother: Used in washes and compresses for conjunctivitis, styes, and tired, inflamed eyes due to its astringent properties.
sideEffects: Safe for external use on closed eyelids. Ensure sterility.
preparation: Sterile Eye Compress: A cooled, carefully strained infusion.
detailedExplanation: The flowers, along with the rest of the aerial parts, are rich in tannins and iridoid glycosides like aucubin, which help reduce inflammation and mucous discharge. Source: https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/pharmacology-toxicology-and-pharmaceutical-science/euphrasia

medicinalUses: Ophthalmic Aid: Traditionally used as an eye wash for conjunctivitis, blepharitis, and eye strain due to its astringent and anti-inflammatory properties.
sideEffects: Safe for external use. Ensure preparations are sterile.
preparation: Sterile Eye Compress: A cooled, filtered infusion is used on closed eyelids. Tea.
detailedExplanation: The name reflects its traditional use. It contains iridoid glycosides (like aucubin) and tannins that help reduce inflammation and mucous discharge in the eyes. Source: https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/pharmacology-toxicology-and-pharmaceutical-science/euphrasia

medicinalUses: Blood Purifier: Used in traditional systems (Ayurveda, Unani) to purify blood and treat skin diseases. Uterine Tonic: Used for menstrual disorders and postpartum recovery.
sideEffects: Limited safety data.
preparation: Decoction: The whole plant is used. Powder.
detailedExplanation: This species is a cornerstone of traditional medicine in South Asia for a wide range of conditions, from diabetes to viral infections, though more clinical validation is needed. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5874592/

medicinalUses: Analgesic, anti-inflammatory, used in fever management
sideEffects: Toxic; can induce cardiac arrhythmia, nausea
preparation: Root decoction (carefully diluted)
detailedExplanation: Aconitum falconeri is an endemic medicinal herb of Kashmir, used traditionally for pain and fever relief under strict supervision due to its toxicity. Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aconitum_falconeri

medicinalUses: Cooling & Digestive: The sour-sweet fruit is a summer staple, used to make sherbets that cool the body and aid digestion. Rich in Antioxidants.
sideEffects: Very safe as a food.
preparation: Fresh Fruit, Juice, Sherbet.
detailedExplanation: The fruit is rich in anthocyanins, flavonoids, and vitamin C. Its cooling property is a key reason for its traditional use in relieving sunstroke and heat exhaustion. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3550909/

medicinalUses: Hair Tonic & Liver Protectant: The most famous herb in Ayurveda for hair growth, preventing graying, and strengthening hair. Also a potent hepatoprotective.
sideEffects: Very safe.
preparation: Hair Oil: Leaves infused in coconut or sesame oil. Juice: Fresh leaf juice for the liver. Powder.
detailedExplanation: It contains wedelolactone, a compound proven to protect the liver from toxic damage. For hair, it increases follicular size and number. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3931201/

medicinalUses: Historical Use: Was used externally for pain and internally in minute doses for high blood pressure.
sideEffects: HIGHLY TOXIC. Causes severe vomiting, low blood pressure, slow heart rate, and can be fatal.
preparation: NO SAFE HOME USE. Its use is obsolete due to extreme danger.
detailedExplanation: The plant contains a mix of toxic steroidal alkaloids (e.g., veratridine) that affect the heart and nervous system. It should be identified and avoided. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK548164/

medicinalUses: Immune Stimulant: Used to treat infections of the upper respiratory tract, mouth, and throat. Antimicrobial.
sideEffects: Can cause nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. High doses are toxic.
preparation: Tincture: Liquid extract of the root. Lozenges.
detailedExplanation: The root contains alkaloids and polysaccharides that enhance the immune system's ability to fight infections. It should be used in moderation.

medicinalUses: Demulcent & Soothing: The root is used to soothe irritated tissues, especially for coughs and bronchial congestion. Anti-inflammatory.
sideEffects: Very safe.
preparation: Decoction: Root boiled in water for a tea. Poultice: For skin irritations.
detailedExplanation: Unlike true Solomon's Seal, the medicinal properties are milder. It is primarily valued for its mucilaginous root that soothes mucous membranes.

medicinalUses: Fertility & Women's Health: A classic uterine tonic used to prevent miscarriage, treat menstrual irregularities, and alleviate menopausal symptoms. Digestive Tonic.
sideEffects: May cause nausea, vomiting, and stomach cramps in high doses.
preparation: Tincture: Liquid extract of the root. Decoction.
detailedExplanation: The plant contains steroidal saponins which are thought to support hormonal balance and strengthen the uterine muscles. It is considered an endangered species, so sustainable sourcing is critical.

medicinalUses: Nutritive Green: Extremely rich in iron, calcium, and vitamins A and C. Used to treat anemia and constipation. Vermifuge: Seeds expel intestinal worms.
sideEffects: Very safe as a cooked green. The seeds in large doses can be toxic.
preparation: Cooked Leaves: Eaten as a vegetable (sag).
detailedExplanation: A highly nutritious wild edible. Its high fiber and mineral content makes it an excellent food for overall health and digestion. Source: https://fdc.nal.usda.gov/fdc-app.html#/food-details/169277/nutrients

medicinalUses: Nutritional Powerhouse: High in protein, fiber, and L-DOPA, a precursor to dopamine. Parkinson's Disease: Natural source of L-DOPA.
sideEffects: Favism: A serious hemolytic anemia in people with G6PD deficiency after ingestion.
preparation: Cooked Beans. L-DOPA supplements are derived from the plant.
detailedExplanation: For the general population, it's a healthy food. However, the risk of favism is serious for genetically susceptible individuals, who must avoid it entirely. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK230184/

medicinalUses: Antimalarial: A key herb in Traditional Chinese Medicine, it is the original source of febrifugine, a compound with potent antimalarial properties.
sideEffects: TOXIC. Causes nausea, vomiting, and liver damage. Not for self-treatment.
preparation: Used in TCM under strict guidance.
detailedExplanation: While highly effective, the alkaloids (febrifugine and isofebrifugine) have a narrow therapeutic index, meaning the effective dose is close to the toxic dose. Source: https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/medicine-and-dentistry/dichroa-febrifuga

medicinalUses: Nutrient-Dense Fruit: The fruit is very high in Vitamin C, fiber, and iodine, supporting immune and thyroid function. Antioxidant.
sideEffects: Very safe as a food.
preparation: Fresh Fruit, Juice, Jam.
detailedExplanation: The entire flower is also edible and sweet. Its unique nutrient profile, including a high iodine content, makes it a valuable functional food. Source: https://fdc.nal.usda.gov/fdc-app.html#/food-details/174673/nutrients

medicinalUses: Anthelmintic: Used to expel intestinal worms, particularly roundworms and threadworms. Antimicrobial.
sideEffects: Essential oil is toxic in high doses. Use should be moderate and short-term.
preparation: Powder/Decoction: Of the flowering tops.
detailedExplanation: This species is part of the Santonica group of wormwoods, known for their high concentration of the anthelmintic compound santonin. Source: https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/pharmacology-toxicology-and-pharmaceutical-science/artemisia

medicinalUses: Digestive Aid: Relieves gas, bloating, and stomach cramps. Galactagogue: Increases breast milk production. Antioxidant.
sideEffects: Generally very safe. May cause allergic reactions in some.
preparation: Seeds: Chewed raw after meals. Tea: Seeds steeped in hot water.
detailedExplanation: The seeds contain anethole, a compound that relaxes smooth muscles in the digestive tract, providing relief from spasms and gas. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4137549/

medicinalUses: Blood Sugar Control: Soluble fiber galactomannan helps regulate insulin activity. Galactagogue: Significantly increases milk supply. Cholesterol Management.
sideEffects: Maple-like odor in sweat and urine. May cause hypoglycemia; caution for diabetics on medication.
preparation: Seeds: Soaked, sprouted, or powdered. Tea. Leaf: Cooked as a vegetable.
detailedExplanation: The seeds are rich in diosgenin, a compound with estrogen-like effects, which contributes to its use for milk production and menopausal symptoms. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4894452/

medicinalUses: Potent Vermifuge: The root extract is a traditional treatment for tapeworm infestation.
sideEffects: HIGHLY TOXIC. Can cause permanent blindness, liver damage, and death. Use is obsolete and dangerous.
preparation: STRICTLY UNDER MEDICAL SUPERVISION. Not for home use.
detailedExplanation: The active compounds (filicin and filmarone) paralyze tapeworms, but they are also highly toxic to the human liver and optic nerve. Modern, safer drugs have replaced it. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK548164/

medicinalUses: Anti-inflammatory, antiseptic, used for wound care and digestive cramps; aromatic flowering tops used in washes.
sideEffects: Skin photosensitivity or allergic reaction for Asteraceae-sensitive individuals.
preparation: Flowering tops dried for infusion; topical compresses prepared from decoctions.
detailedExplanation: Yellow yarrow is used for wound healing and digestive complaints in Himalayan and temperate garden medicine; its essential oils and flavonoids contribute to activity. Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Achillea_filipendulina

medicinalUses: Ornamental & Toxic: Grown for its beautiful, pendulous flower clusters and colorful new growth. ALL PARTS ARE HIGHLY POISONOUS.
sideEffects: TOXIC. Contains grayanotoxins which can cause vomiting, slow heart rate, hypotension, and death.
preparation: NO MEDICINAL USE. Strictly an ornamental plant to be admired, not consumed.
detailedExplanation: This plant is related to Rhododendrons and shares their toxicity. Ingestion of any part can lead to severe poisoning, making it critical for identification and avoidance. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK548164/

medicinalUses: Migraine Prevention: Reduces the frequency and severity of migraine headaches. Anti-inflammatory.
sideEffects: Mouth ulcers and gastrointestinal upset if leaves are chewed raw.
preparation: Capsules/Tablets: Freeze-dried leaf extract. Tincture.
detailedExplanation: The active compound, parthenolide, is believed to inhibit the release of serotonin and prostaglandins, which are involved in triggering migraines. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK538500/

medicinalUses: Bone & Connective Tissue Health: Very high in silica, which is essential for bone formation and collagen synthesis. Diuretic.
sideEffects: May cause thiamine (Vitamin B1) deficiency with long-term use.
preparation: Tea: Made from the sterile green stems. Tincture.
detailedExplanation: The silica content is in a bioavailable form, helping to improve bone density and strengthen hair, skin, and nails. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK548164/

medicinalUses: Digestive Relief: Relieves gas, bloating, and indigestion. Decongestant: Provides relief from colds and sinus congestion.
sideEffects: Generally very safe.
preparation: Tea: Fresh or dried leaves. Inhalation: Steam with leaves.
detailedExplanation: The leaves contain menthol, which has antispasmodic effects on the digestive tract and a cooling, decongestant effect on the respiratory system. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4054084/

medicinalUses: Mild Sedative & Expectorant: The petals are used in syrups to soothe coughs, relieve mild pain, and promote sleep. Unlike the Opium Poppy, it is non-addictive.
sideEffects: Very safe in normal doses.
preparation: Syrup: Made from the red petals. Tea.
detailedExplanation: The petals contain rhoeadine alkaloids, which have a mild sedative effect but lack the potent narcotic properties of morphine found in Papaver somniferum.

medicinalUses: Laxative: High fiber content promotes healthy bowel movements. Rich in Nutrients: Good source of potassium, calcium, and antioxidants.
sideEffects: Very safe. Excessive consumption of dried figs may cause diarrhea.
preparation: Fresh or Dried Fruit. Syrup: Used as a sweet laxative.
detailedExplanation: The fruit contains proteolytic enzymes (ficin) and soluble fiber, which aid digestion and relieve constipation. Source: https://fdc.nal.usda.gov/fdc-app.html#/food-details/168162/nutrients

medicinalUses: Detoxifying & Anti-inflammatory: Traditionally used to treat skin conditions like eczema, psoriasis, and hemorrhoids. Lymphatic Tonic.
sideEffects: May cause contact dermatitis in sensitive individuals.
preparation: Ointment/Salve: For topical application on skin conditions. Tincture.
detailedExplanation: The name "Figwort" comes from its historical use for treating hemorrhoids (formerly known as "figs"). It is considered a "scrofula" remedy, meaning it treats swollen lymph nodes.

medicinalUses: Anti-inflammatory & Pain Relief: A natural source of salicylic acid precursors, providing aspirin-like effects for pain and fever. Digestive Soothing.
sideEffects: Safe for most. Avoid if allergic to aspirin/salicylates.
preparation: Tea: Made from the flowers and leaves. Tincture.
detailedExplanation: This plant is the original source of salicin, which led to the development of aspirin. It is gentler on the stomach than synthetic aspirin. Source: https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/agricultural-and-biological-sciences/filipendula-ulmaria

medicinalUses: Aromatic & Digestive: The peel is used in Traditional Chinese Medicine to regulate Qi (energy), relieve stomach pain, and as an expectorant.
sideEffects: Generally safe.
preparation: Candied Peel, Tea, Culinary Zest.
detailedExplanation: The fruit is valued for its strong, aromatic zest which contains high levels of limonene, known for its antioxidant and mood-lifting properties.

medicinalUses: Nutritious Grain: Gluten-free and rich in calcium, iron, and amino acids. Blood Sugar Control: High fiber content results in a low glycemic index.
sideEffects: Very safe. A staple food.
preparation: Flour: Used to make flatbreads (roti) and porridge. Fermented Drinks.
detailedExplanation: It is one of the richest plant sources of calcium, making it excellent for bone health, and its high fiber content is beneficial for diabetics. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4943871/

medicinalUses: Traditional Expectorant: Historically used in folk medicine for respiratory conditions like bronchitis and coughs to loosen phlegm. Astringent.
sideEffects: Limited safety data. Use caution as some ferns contain toxic compounds.
preparation: Infusion/Tea: Made from the fronds.
detailedExplanation: This fern, like others in its genus, has a history of use in European folk medicine for spleen and respiratory issues, though modern scientific validation is limited.

medicinalUses: Respiratory Relief: The resin is a powerful antiseptic applied to wounds and used in inhalants for colds. Antiseptic for Wounds.
sideEffects: Resin can cause skin irritation in some. Not for internal use without professional guidance.
preparation: Salve/Ointment: Resin is melted into a base oil and beeswax for topical application. Steam Inhalation: A small piece of resin or needles in hot water.
detailedExplanation: The resin, known as "Canada Balsam," contains terpenes like pinene and limonene that provide its antimicrobial and expectorant properties. It was traditionally used as a glue and a microscope lens cement. Source: https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/agricultural-and-biological-sciences/abies-balsamea

medicinalUses: Ayurvedic Respiratory Tonic: The leaves (needles) are used for asthma, bronchitis, and cough. Anti-inflammatory.
sideEffects: Generally safe in medicinal doses.
preparation: Powder/Churna: Dried leaf powder taken with honey. Decoction.
detailedExplanation: Known as "Talispatra" in Ayurveda, it is a key ingredient in many formulations for respiratory health. Its volatile oils help clear congestion and reduce inflammation in the airways. Source: https://www.researchgate.net/publication/333638420_Traditional_uses_medicinal_importance_and_pharmacology_of_Abies_spectabilis_A_review

medicinalUses: Wound Healing & Anti-inflammatory: The leaves and bark are used to make poultices and washes for skin rashes, burns, and wounds. Febrifuge.
sideEffects: Generally safe for topical use.
preparation: Poultice: Crushed leaves applied directly to the skin. Decoction: For washing wounds or as a tea for fever.
detailedExplanation: This plant is a popular ornamental and medicinal shrub. Studies show it contains tannins and flavonoids that contribute to its wound-healing and anti-inflammatory effects. Source: https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/agricultural-and-biological-sciences/hamelia-patens

medicinalUses: Ornamental Use: Primarily valued as a native wildflower. Limited Medicinal History.
sideEffects: No well-documented medicinal use or safety profile.
preparation: Not commonly used in modern herbal medicine.
detailedExplanation: While some related Silene species have traditional uses, Fire Pink is not a major medicinal plant and is best appreciated for its ecological and aesthetic value.

medicinalUses: Ornamental & Wildlife Plant: The berries are a food source for birds. Mildly Toxic to Humans.
sideEffects: Berries may cause mild stomach upset if eaten in large quantities. The thorns can cause physical injury.
preparation: Not used medicinally.
detailedExplanation: This plant is grown for its decorative berries and as a security hedge. Its medicinal value is negligible, and caution is advised due to its thorns and the potential for gastrointestinal discomfort from the berries.

medicinalUses: Ayurvedic Hair Tonic: The leaves are used in hair care preparations to strengthen hair and promote growth. Anti-inflammatory.
sideEffects: Generally safe for topical use.
preparation: Hair Oil: Leaves are infused in coconut oil. Paste: For scalp conditions.
detailedExplanation: A popular garden plant in South India, its sticky leaf juice is traditionally applied to the scalp to improve hair health and reduce dandruff.

medicinalUses: Digestive Soothing: The leaves are a soothing demulcent for stomach ulcers and inflammation. Prostate Health: Used for benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH).
sideEffects: Very safe.
preparation: Tea: Made from the dried leaves. Tincture.
detailedExplanation: This is one of the first plants to colonize after forest fires, hence the name. It is rich in mucilage and tannins, which soothe irritated tissues. Source: https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/agricultural-and-biological-species/epilobium-angustifolium

medicinalUses: Ornamental & Fiber Source: Primarily grown for its decorative value and for making paper. Limited Medicinal Use.
sideEffects: Limited safety data.
preparation: Not commonly used in modern herbal practice.
detailedExplanation: The root and bark have been used in Traditional Chinese Medicine, but it is not a major medicinal species. Its primary value is as a striking ornamental tree.

medicinalUses: Traditional Poison & Pesticide: The berries are highly toxic and were historically used to stun fish for easy capture and as a pesticide for lice and scabies.
sideEffects: HIGHLY TOXIC. Contains picrotoxin, a powerful neurotoxin that causes vomiting, seizures, respiratory failure, and death.
preparation: NO SAFE MEDICINAL USE. Its use is restricted and dangerous.
detailedExplanation: The primary compound, picrotoxin, is a central nervous system stimulant that is violently toxic. It is an example of a plant whose danger must be recognized to avoid poisoning. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK548164/

medicinalUses: Detoxifying & Diuretic: In Traditional Chinese Medicine and Vietnamese medicine, it is known as "Fish Mint" or "Lizard Tail" and is used to clear heat and toxins from the body.
sideEffects: May cause allergic reactions in sensitive individuals.
preparation: Tea, Soup, Fresh Herb in Salads.
detailedExplanation: This is the same plant as the previous entry, highlighting its use across different cultures. It is a common ingredient in folk medicine for its purifying and anti-infective properties. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4629407/

medicinalUses: Source of Sugar & Fiber: The sap is tapped to make a sweet syrup (jaggery) and fermented into toddy. The fiber is used for ropes.
sideEffects: The fruit contains oxalate crystals causing severe skin and mouth irritation.
preparation: Syrup (Jaggery) from sap. The fruit is not edible.
detailedExplanation: While not a primary medicinal plant, its economic importance is high. The sap is a natural sweetener, and the plant's parts are used in various local industries.

medicinalUses: Folk uses include topical wound applications and mild febrifuge decoctions; studies limited.
sideEffects: Little toxicity data—standard caution applies.
preparation: Leaf/fruit decoction; poultice for topical injuries.
detailedExplanation: Ardisia quinquegona is regionally used in NE India for topical and mild febrifuge applications; scientific studies are sparse, so follow traditional dosing and caution. Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ardisia_quinquegona.

medicinalUses: Traditional Cough Remedy: Used by Native American tribes as a syrup or tea for coughs and respiratory congestion. Demulcent.
sideEffects: Generally safe.
preparation: Syrup, Tea.
detailedExplanation: This delicate fern has a history of use in folk medicine similar to other maidenhair ferns, valued for its soothing effect on the respiratory tract.

medicinalUses: Adaptogen & Tonic: Known as the "berry of five flavors," it helps the body cope with stress, boosts mental performance, and increases endurance. Liver Protectant.
sideEffects: May cause heartburn or stomach upset in some.
preparation: Tincture, Powdered Berry, Tea.
detailedExplanation: Schisandra is a premier adaptogen. Its lignans protect the liver from toxins and help balance the stress response system. It is known to have sour, sweet, salty, pungent, and bitter tastes. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5378736/

medicinalUses: Diuretic & Anti-inflammatory: The stem is used in Traditional Chinese Medicine to promote urination and relieve painful urination. Emmenagogue.
sideEffects: Limited safety data. Not for use during pregnancy.
preparation: Decoction of the stem.
detailedExplanation: Known as "Mu Tong" in TCM, it is used to clear "damp-heat" from the body, particularly from the bladder and urinary tract.

medicinalUses: Anti-inflammatory & Analgesic: The leaves are famous for relieving rheumatic pain, joint swelling, and headaches. Respiratory Relief.
sideEffects: Very safe for topical use.
preparation: Leaf Paste/Poultice: Applied to swollen joints. Steam Inhalation: For colds and headache. Medicated Oil.
detailedExplanation: A cornerstone of Ayurvedic medicine for pain and inflammation. The leaves contain flavonoids and essential oils with proven anti-inflammatory and analgesic properties. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3210004/

medicinalUses: Astringent & Tonic: The galls (abnormal growths) formed on the plant are highly astringent and used for diarrhea and dysentery. Liver Support.
sideEffects: Generally safe in medicinal doses.
preparation: Decoction: Galls or bark boiled in water. Powder.
detailedExplanation: In traditional systems like Unani medicine, the galls are the primary medicinal part, valued for their high tannin content which helps bind stools and reduce intestinal inflammation.

medicinalUses: The "Immortality Herb": A powerful adaptogen that helps regulate cholesterol, blood pressure, and blood sugar. Antioxidant.
sideEffects: Very safe. May cause mild nausea initially.
preparation: Tea from the leaves, Tincture, Capsules.
detailedExplanation: Often called "Southern Ginseng," it contains gypenosides, which are similar to ginsenosides in Panax ginseng. It helps protect the body from physical and mental stress. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5758350/

medicinalUses: Antidiabetic & Antioxidant: The fruit and leaves are used to manage diabetes and as an antioxidant. Antimicrobial.
sideEffects: The unripe fruit is very astringent.
preparation: Fruit: Eaten ripe. Leaf Decoction: For diabetes.
detailedExplanation: The plant is rich in phenolic compounds and flavonoids. Studies confirm its antidiabetic potential by demonstrating blood glucose-lowering effects in animal models. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4027315/

medicinalUses: Ornamental & Limited Medicinal Use: The bark is astringent and used in traditional medicine for fevers and constipation.
sideEffects: Limited safety data.
preparation: Bark Decoction.
detailedExplanation: Primarily one of the world's most beautiful ornamental trees. Its medicinal use is not well-documented in modern pharmacology and is based on folk traditions.

medicinalUses: Traditional Use for Gout & Arthritis: The tuber was used in small, controlled doses. HIGHLY TOXIC.
sideEffects: FATALLY POISONOUS. Contains colchicine, which causes severe vomiting, organ failure, and death.
preparation: NO SAFE HOME USE. Colchicine is used pharmaceutically under strict control.
detailedExplanation: Every part of this plant, especially the tuber, is deadly. While colchicine is a valuable pharmaceutical for gout, self-medication with the plant is extremely dangerous. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK548164/

medicinalUses: Ayurvedic Powerhouse: The flowers are used for liver disorders and as a diuretic. The gum is astringent for diarrhea. The seeds are anthelmintic.
sideEffects: Very safe in traditional preparations.
preparation: Flower Juice/Infusion, Gum (Kamarkas), Seed Powder.
detailedExplanation: Known as the "Flame of the Forest" for its stunning orange-red flowers. It is a versatile medicinal tree in Ayurveda. The flowers are also used to make natural color for the Holi festival. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4094692/

medicinalUses: Ornamental Use: Primarily grown for its spectacular orange flowers. Limited Medicinal Use.
sideEffects: Limited safety data.
preparation: Not commonly used in modern herbal medicine.
detailedExplanation: While some traditional uses for cough and skin conditions are reported, its primary value is as a beautiful, fast-growing ornamental vine.

medicinalUses: Ornamental Houseplant: Valued for its long-lasting, colorful flowers. Toxic to Pets.
sideEffects: Mildly toxic to cats and dogs, causing vomiting and diarrhea.
preparation: Not for medicinal use.
detailedExplanation: A very popular decorative pot plant. It is not used medicinally and should be kept out of reach of pets due to its potential toxicity.

medicinalUses: Respiratory Soother: A premier herb for dry, hacking coughs, bronchitis, and asthma. The mucilage coats and soothes the throat. Antiviral.
sideEffects: The small hairs on fresh leaves can irritate the throat; always use dried leaves or strain tea thoroughly.
preparation: Tea: From dried flowers and leaves. Syrup, Tincture.
detailedExplanation: The leaves and flowers are rich in mucilage, which forms a protective film over irritated mucous membranes. Saponins in the plant help loosen phlegm. Source: https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/pharmacology-toxicology-and-pharmaceutical-science/verbascum

medicinalUses: Anti-inflammatory & Analgesic: Used for rheumatic pain, joint inflammation, and fever. Demulcent for Respiratory Issues.
sideEffects: Generally safe.
preparation: Decoction of the root or whole plant. Poultice.
detailedExplanation: The plant contains ephedrine and other alkaloids, which may contribute to its traditional use for asthma and as a stimulant, though in much lower concentrations than in Ephedra species.

medicinalUses: Traditional Tonic: Used in folk medicine for digestive issues and as a general health tonic.
sideEffects: Limited safety data available.
preparation: Decoction of the root or whole plant.
detailedExplanation: This plant is part of the Cyperus genus, which includes species like Nagarmotha (Cyperus rotundus), but this specific species has less documented medicinal use.

medicinalUses: Culinary Flavoring: The source of natural vanilla flavor. Aphrodisiac: Traditionally believed to have mild aphrodisiac properties.
sideEffects: Generally recognized as safe (GRAS) as a food flavoring. Can cause allergic reactions in rare cases.
preparation: Vanilla Extract, Flavoring in foods and perfumes.
detailedExplanation: The vanilla bean is the only orchid that produces an agriculturally valuable fruit. The complex flavor comes from the compound vanillin, developed during a careful curing process.

medicinalUses: Astringent & Antimicrobial: The bark and gum are used for diarrhea, dysentery, and skin infections.
sideEffects: Generally safe.
preparation: Bark Decoction, Gum.
detailedExplanation: Like many Acacia species, it is rich in tannins, which provide an astringent effect, and the gum has soothing and antimicrobial properties.

medicinalUses: Heart & Digestive Health: The seeds are one of the richest sources of Omega-3 (ALA) and soluble fiber, helping lower cholesterol and relieve constipation.
sideEffects: Must be taken with plenty of water. Whole seeds may pass undigested; ground seeds are better for nutrient absorption.
preparation: Ground Seeds, Flaxseed Oil, Whole Seeds for bulk.
detailedExplanation: Flaxseed is a nutritional powerhouse. The soluble fiber forms a gel that improves gut health and regularity, while the lignans have phytoestrogen and antioxidant properties. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6567199/

medicinalUses: Topical for Skin: The bark and leaves have been used in poultices for skin diseases and wounds.
sideEffects: ALL PARTS ARE HIGHLY POISONOUS IF INGESTED. Can cause severe burning, vomiting, and kidney damage.
preparation: NOT RECOMMENDED FOR USE. Historical topical use is extremely risky.
detailedExplanation: This plant belongs to a genus known for its toxicity. The presence of daphnetoxin and other irritant compounds makes it dangerous for any form of self-medication. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK548164/

medicinalUses: Astringent & Diuretic: Traditionally used to stop bleeding (styptic), for diarrhea, and as a mild diuretic.
sideEffects: May cause allergic reactions in those sensitive to the Asteraceae family.
preparation: Tea/Infusion of the leaves and flowers.
detailedExplanation: The common name "Fleabane" comes from the historical belief that the plant could repel fleas. Its astringent properties are due to its tannin content.

medicinalUses: Traditional Wound Healing & Fever Reduction: Used in traditional medicine as a poultice for wounds and internally to reduce fever. Anti-inflammatory.
sideEffects: Limited safety data.
preparation: Poultice from leaves and flowers, Decoction.
detailedExplanation: This high-altitude plant is part of a genus traditionally used for its astringent and anti-inflammatory properties. Its common name, "Fleabane," suggests a historical use to repel insects.

medicinalUses: Bulk-Forming Laxative: The seeds are a rich source of mucilaginous fiber that absorbs water, softening stool and relieving constipation.
sideEffects: Must be taken with a full glass of water to prevent choking or intestinal blockage.
preparation: Seed Husks mixed with water or juice.
detailedExplanation: This is the original source of psyllium husk. The soluble fiber forms a gel that not only aids digestion but can also help lower LDL cholesterol levels. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK551721/

medicinalUses: Cardiovascular Tonic: Like other Hawthorns, it is used to strengthen heart muscle, improve blood flow, and treat mild heart failure.
sideEffects: Very safe. May interact with heart medications like digoxin.
preparation: Berry Tincture, Tea, Capsules.
detailedExplanation: Hawthorn berries are rich in flavonoids (e.g., vitexin) and oligomeric procyanidins which improve coronary blood flow and protect blood vessels. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK537036/

medicinalUses: Febrifuge & Diuretic: Traditionally used to reduce fevers and promote urination.
sideEffects: Limited safety data.
preparation: Decoction of the whole plant.
detailedExplanation: An aquatic plant often mistaken for a small water lily. Its use is rooted in traditional folk medicine, particularly in East Asia, for its cooling and diuretic properties.

medicinalUses: Source of Starch: The root was historically processed to make a starch similar to arrowroot, used as a easily digestible food for convalescents.
sideEffects: RAW PLANT IS TOXIC. Contains cycasin, a carcinogenic and neurotoxic compound. Must be extensively processed to be safe.
preparation: Detoxified Starch. NOT for home preparation.
detailedExplanation: This plant is a "living fossil." While it was a vital food source for indigenous peoples, the elaborate processing required to remove toxins makes it unsafe for casual use. Source: https://plants.ifas.ufl.edu/plant-directory/zamia-integrifolia/

medicinalUses: Blood Pressure & Heart Health: The calyces are rich in antioxidants (anthocyanins) that help lower blood pressure and cholesterol. Diuretic.
sideEffects: Very safe. May cause mild stomach upset in large amounts.
preparation: Tea: Made from the dried red calyces. Juice, Jam.
detailedExplanation: The tart, red calyces are used to make a refreshing tea. Studies confirm that regular consumption of hibiscus tea can significantly reduce systolic and diastolic blood pressure. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3593772/

medicinalUses: Used for anti-inflammatory and wound healing
sideEffects: Rare allergic reactions
preparation: Leaf paste, decoction
detailedExplanation: Ageratum houstonianum is a decorative herb with minor traditional medicinal uses in hill regions. Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ageratum_houstonianum

medicinalUses: Ornamental Use: Primarily grown as a garden flower for its fluffy blue blooms. Wound Healing (Traditional).
sideEffects: TOXIC. Contains pyrrolizidine alkaloids that can cause liver damage if ingested.
preparation: Not recommended for medicinal use.
detailedExplanation: Despite its attractive appearance, this common garden plant is hepatotoxic. It should not be used in any herbal preparation and should be handled with care. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK548164/

medicinalUses: Febrifuge & Tonic: The bark was a traditional substitute for quinine to reduce fevers, especially from malaria. Astringent.
sideEffects: Generally safe in medicinal doses.
preparation: Bark Decoction.
detailedExplanation: A beloved ornamental tree, its bitter bark was a key medicine for Native Americans and early settlers for treating "intermittent fevers."

medicinalUses: Traditional TCM for Joints: Used in Traditional Chinese Medicine to relax tendons and activate blood circulation for rheumatic pain. Antioxidant.
sideEffects: The raw fruit is very hard and astringent.
preparation: Fruit Paste, Tincture, Wine.
detailedExplanation: The fruit is extremely high in Vitamin C and is often cooked with sugar to make a jelly. In TCM, it is known as "Zhou Pi" and is used in formulas for arthritis.

medicinalUses: Astringent & Tonic: The root and leaves are used as an astringent for diarrhea and as a general tonic.
sideEffects: Very safe.
preparation: Leaf or Root Tea/Decoction.
detailedExplanation: This thornless raspberry is valued more for its large, showy flowers and edible (though bland) fruit. Its medicinal properties are similar to other astringent Rubus species.

medicinalUses: Traditional Tonic & Antidiabetic: The root and leaves are used for diabetes, jaundice, and as a general health tonic. Antimicrobial.
sideEffects: Limited safety data.
preparation: Root/Leaf Decoction.
detailedExplanation: The plant contains securinine, a alkaloid that acts as a central nervous system stimulant, but its medicinal use is primarily based on long-standing traditional practices.

medicinalUses: Nutritive & Blood Tonic: The leaves are a highly nutritious vegetable, rich in iron and used to treat anemia. Antioxidant.
sideEffects: Very safe as a food.
preparation: Cooked Leaves (as a soup vegetable).
detailedExplanation: A staple in West African cuisine, this plant is a classic example of "food as medicine," providing essential vitamins and minerals that combat malnutrition and anemia.

medicinalUses: Shamanic & Ritual Use: Traditionally used in Siberian and other cultures for its psychoactive and hallucinogenic properties.
sideEffects: HIGHLY TOXIC. Causes nausea, confusion, hallucinations, seizures, and can be fatal.
preparation: NO SAFE RECREATIONAL OR MEDICINAL USE.
detailedExplanation: This iconic mushroom contains muscimol and ibotenic acid, potent neurotoxins. Its historical use was tightly controlled by shamans and is extremely dangerous today. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK548164/

medicinalUses: Tonic for Aging & Vitality: In TCM, it is revered for darkening hair, strengthening bones, and promoting longevity. Liver & Kidney Tonic.
sideEffects: Raw root is hepatotoxic. The properly processed (cured) root is safe. May cause diarrhea.
preparation: Processed Root Decoction: The root is cured with black bean juice to reduce toxicity. Tincture/Capsules.
detailedExplanation: The root contains stilbene glycosides and lecithin. Improper processing can lead to liver damage, so it is essential to use products from reputable sources that use the cured root. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3834722/

medicinalUses: Traditional Diuretic & Tonic: Used by Native American tribes as a tea for digestive and kidney problems.
sideEffects: Limited safety data.
preparation: Leaf Tea.
detailedExplanation: A delicate, shade-loving woodland wildflower. Its common name comes from the foamy, delicate appearance of its flower spikes.

medicinalUses: TOXIC PLANT - NO MEDICINAL USE: This plant is a dangerous look-alike of edible parsley and is highly poisonous.
sideEffects: FATALLY POISONOUS. Contains polyynes that cause severe vomiting, convulsions, and respiratory failure.
preparation: NOT FOR CONSUMPTION. Identification and avoidance are critical.
detailedExplanation: This plant is a classic example of a toxic umbellifer that can be mistaken for edible herbs like parsley or chervil. It must be identified and avoided to prevent fatal poisoning. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK548164/

medicinalUses: Edible Wild Green: The leaves are sometimes used as a wild salad green. Diuretic (mild).
sideEffects: Generally safe, but can be confused with toxic water plants.
preparation: Raw in salads, cooked as a green.
detailedExplanation: This aquatic plant is a relative of celery. Caution is advised when foraging to correctly distinguish it from highly toxic water hemlock (Cicuta species).

medicinalUses: Carbohydrate-rich food, mild digestive aid
sideEffects: Rare
preparation: Boiled tuber
detailedExplanation: Wild suran found in Western Ghats, used as food and for mild digestive purposes. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK92771/

medicinalUses: Traditional Tonic & Febrifuge: Used in traditional medicine for tonic purposes and to reduce fevers.
sideEffects: Limited safety data available.
preparation: Decoction of the whole plant.
detailedExplanation: This is a parasitic plant that lacks chlorophyll and gets its nutrients from the roots of host plants. Its use is based on regional folk medicine traditions.

medicinalUses: Antimicrobial & Anti-inflammatory: The bark and leaves are used for wound healing, skin infections, and gastrointestinal issues.
sideEffects: The unripe fruit is very astringent.
preparation: Bark Decoction (for washing wounds), Leaf Poultice.
detailedExplanation: The fruit is edible when ripe. Research supports its traditional use, showing antimicrobial activity against various bacteria and fungi. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5871212/

medicinalUses: Eye Health & Anti-diabetic: In Ayurveda, the flowers are used for eye treatments. The leaves and bark are used for diabetes and inflammation.
sideEffects: Limited safety data.
preparation: Flower Eye Wash, Leaf/Bark Decoction.
detailedExplanation: The blue flowers are particularly valued in traditional medicine. Preclinical studies have shown the plant possesses significant antioxidant and antidiabetic properties. Source: https://www.researchgate.net/publication/286457224_Memecylon_umbellatum_A_review_on_traditional_uses_phytochemistry_and_pharmacology
