preparation: Not for self-use. Colchicine is extracted and used in precisely controlled pharmaceutical doses.
detailedExplanation: This plant, often called Meadow Saffron, is not a true crocus. It is the original source of colchicine, a potent mitotic poison that binds to tubulin and inhibits microtubule formation. While it is a life-saving medicine for specific conditions, all parts of the plant are extremely poisonous, and ingestion of even small amounts can be fatal. Source: https://www.poison.org/articles/autumn-crocus

medicinalUses: A rare plant with limited traditional use. Research has identified alkaloids with potential neurological activity.
sideEffects: Toxicity profile is not well-known due to its rarity.
preparation: Not used in common herbal practice.
detailedExplanation: This plant is a rare and endemic species found only in specific forest habitats in Japan. It is of significant botanical interest due to its unique morphology and its production of alkaloids from the Croomia group. These alkaloids are of research interest for their potential effects on the nervous system, but the plant is not part of any mainstream medicinal tradition. Source: https://www.jstage.jst.go.jp/article/cpb1958/31/10/31_10_3678/_article

medicinalUses: The wood is highly valued for timber. Limited traditional use for anti-inflammatory and antimicrobial purposes.
sideEffects: Information Missing.
preparation: Not commonly used in modern herbal preparation.
detailedExplanation: Known as Keyaki in Japan, this tree is renowned for its beautiful, durable wood used in fine furniture, flooring, and the construction of traditional buildings. It is a relative of the elm but is resistant to Dutch elm disease. While some related species have medicinal uses, the Japanese Elm itself is not a prominent medicinal plant. Source: General botanical knowledge.

medicinalUses: Primarily Ornamental. TOXIC.
sideEffects: TOXIC. Ingestion causes severe gastroenteritis, chills, and weakness.
preparation: Not for medicinal use.
detailedExplanation: This is a very common ornamental shrub, widely used in landscaping for its glossy, evergreen leaves and tolerance of pruning. All parts of the plant, especially the seeds, are poisonous. It contains cardenolides and alkaloids which are toxic to humans and animals if ingested. It has no safe medicinal applications. Source: https://plants.ces.ncsu.edu/plants/euonymus-japonicus/

medicinalUses: Ornamental cultivar. The bark of willows contains salicin, a precursor to aspirin, with analgesic and anti-inflammatory properties.
sideEffects: Salicin can cause stomach upset and allergic reactions in those sensitive to aspirin.
preparation: The bark of the species, not necessarily the cultivar, is used to make teas or tinctures.
detailedExplanation: This particular plant is a cultivated variety (cultivar) prized for its unique, flattened, and contorted stems (fasciation) which are used in floral arrangements. While the wild species contains salicin, this ornamental form is grown for its striking appearance, not for medicine. The use of willow bark for pain and fever dates back to ancient times. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK927574/

medicinalUses: Used in traditional medicine as a diuretic and for treating urinary tract infections and coughs.
sideEffects: Generally considered safe.
preparation: The fronds are dried and decocted into a tea.
detailedExplanation: This fern is characterized by its thick, leathery, tongue-shaped fronds that have a felt-like underside. In Traditional Chinese Medicine, it is known as Shi Wei and is used to clear "damp-heat" from the bladder, making it a common remedy for painful urination and stones. It is also used as an expectorant for coughs with thick phlegm. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5871205/

medicinalUses: Primarily ornamental and cultural. The pickled leaves and flowers are used in traditional confections.
sideEffects: The seeds, like all stone fruits, contain cyanogenic glycosides and are toxic if crushed and ingested.
preparation: The salted leaves and flowers are used to make "sakura mochi," a traditional sweet.
detailedExplanation: The Japanese Flowering Cherry, or Sakura, is the iconic symbol of Japan, celebrated for its breathtaking spring blossoms. Its medicinal use is minimal compared to its immense cultural significance, representing the beauty and transience of life (mono no aware). The pickled leaves and flowers are edible and used in ceremonial foods and tea. Source: General cultural knowledge.

medicinalUses: The hard, acidic fruit is used to make jams, jellies, and liqueurs. Rich in vitamin C and antioxidants.
sideEffects: The raw fruit is extremely sour and astringent.
preparation: The fruit is cooked with sugar to make preserves or soaked in alcohol to make a liqueur.
detailedExplanation: This low-growing shrub is prized for its bright red-orange flowers in early spring. The fruit, while not palatable raw, is exceptionally high in pectin, making it ideal for jams and jellies. It is also a rich source of vitamin C and polyphenols, contributing to its antioxidant capacity. It is more of a culinary and ornamental plant than a medicinal one. Source: https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0308814610007245

medicinalUses: Used for its antimicrobial and antiemetic (anti-nausea) properties; treats digestive issues and colds.
sideEffects: Generally safe in culinary amounts.
preparation: The rhizome is used fresh or dried in decoctions and culinary dishes.
detailedExplanation: This plant is a close relative of the greater galangal (Alpinia galanga) used in Southeast Asian cuisine. Its rhizome has a pungent, aromatic quality and is used in traditional medicine to warm the digestive system, relieve nausea and vomiting, and treat colds and coughs by reducing phlegm. It contains essential oils and diarylheptanoids. Source: https://www.jstage.jst.go.jp/article/cpb/50/2/50_2_187/_article

medicinalUses: The root is a classic bitter tonic; stimulates digestion, improves appetite, and treats liver ailments.
sideEffects: The extreme bitterness can cause nausea. Contraindicated in cases of hyperacidity or ulcers.
preparation: The dried root is used in tinctures or decoctions, taken before meals.
detailedExplanation: This plant produces stunning deep blue, trumpet-shaped flowers. Its root, known as Long Dan Cao in TCM, is one of the strongest bitter herbs used to clear "damp-heat" from the liver and gallbladder. It is used for conditions like jaundice, genital herpes, and conjunctivitis. Its intense bitterness triggers digestive secretions. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5871212/

medicinalUses: The flower buds and young shoots are a culinary delicacy. Has antioxidant and potential anti-inflammatory properties.
sideEffects: Generally safe as a food.
preparation: The flower buds are pickled or used fresh as a garnish in Japanese cuisine.
detailedExplanation: Unlike common ginger, the rhizome of Myoga is not the primary edible part. Instead, the unique and aromatic flower buds and young shoots are prized in Japanese cuisine for their delicate, gingery-citrus flavor. While it contains some of the same active compounds as common ginger (like gingerols), it is primarily valued for its culinary, not medicinal, applications. Source: https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0963996912002688

medicinalUses: TOXIC. Not for medicinal use. Has been used in traditional medicine for infections with extreme caution.
sideEffects: HIGHLY TOXIC. Contains protoanemonin, causing severe blistering externally and violent gastroenteritis if ingested.
preparation: Not for self-use.
detailedExplanation: This plant is a close relative of buttercups and shares their toxicity. It produces beautiful, spherical, orange or yellow flowers. The compound protoanemonin is a potent irritant that causes blistering on the skin and severe damage to the digestive tract. It has no safe medicinal application in modern practice. Source: https://www.poison.org/articles/buttercup

medicinalUses: The young leaves are cooked and eaten. Limited traditional use for coughs and as a diuretic.
sideEffects: May cause contact dermatitis in sensitive individuals.
preparation: Young leaves are boiled and consumed as a vegetable.
detailedExplanation: This plant is grown ornamentally for its large, rounded leaves and tall spikes of yellow, daisy-like flowers. While it has some history as a wild edible (sansai) in Japan after proper preparation to remove bitterness, it is not a prominent medicinal herb. Its primary value is in the garden, where it adds a bold, tropical texture to shady, moist areas. Source: General botanical knowledge.

medicinalUses: Primarily Ornamental. TOXIC.
sideEffects: TOXIC. Berries cause vomiting and diarrhea if ingested.
preparation: Not for medicinal use.
detailedExplanation: This shrub is a popular boxwood substitute in landscaping, often used for hedges and topiary due to its small, glossy, crenate (scalloped) leaves. While less toxic than its relative English Holly (Ilex aquifolium), the black berries are still considered poisonous and can cause gastrointestinal upset. It has no medicinal uses. Source: https://plants.ces.ncsu.edu/plants/ilex-crenata/

medicinalUses: Primarily ornamental. Used in traditional medicine for wounds and as an anti-inflammatory.
sideEffects: Generally non-toxic.
regionsFound: East Asia, naturalized in other regions
preparation: The rhizome is used in decoctions or poultices.
detailedExplanation: This hardy fern is a popular houseplant and landscape plant for shady areas, valued for its glossy, dark green, holly-like fronds. In traditional Chinese medicine, it is known as Guan Zhong and has been used to treat wounds, parasites, and as a detoxifying agent. However, its modern use is overwhelmingly ornamental. Source: https://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=2&taxon_id=200004531

medicinalUses: The flowers (Jin Yin Hua) are used in TCM for fevers, colds, and infections; have antibacterial and anti-inflammatory properties.
sideEffects: The berries are toxic. The vine is highly invasive, smothering native plants.
regionsFound: East Asia, highly invasive in North America
preparation: The flower buds are dried and used in teas, syrups, and tinctures.
detailedExplanation: This aggressively invasive vine is a major ecological threat in many regions. Despite this, its flowers are a fundamental herb in Traditional Chinese Medicine for dispelling "wind-heat," the pathogenic factor associated with the early stages of colds and flu. Research confirms its broad-spectrum antimicrobial and anti-inflammatory activities. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4003722/

medicinalUses: Limited traditional use as a sedative and for treating leprosy. Primarily used in brewing as a bittering agent in some traditional beers.
sideEffects: The bristles on the stems and leaves can cause skin irritation and dermatitis.
regionsFound: East Asia, invasive in North America
preparation: The cones (female flowers) are used similarly to common hops in brewing.
detailedExplanation: This plant is a close relative of the common hop (Humulus lupulus) used in beer production. However, it is considered an inferior substitute for brewing and a noxious invasive weed outside its native range. It lacks the complex aromatic profile of common hops and its medicinal properties are not well-developed or trusted. Source: https://plants.ces.ncsu.edu/plants/humulus-japonicus/

medicinalUses: The grated rhizome is a pungent condiment. Has antimicrobial properties that may help prevent food poisoning.
sideEffects: The intense vapor can irritate the eyes and nasal passages.
regionsFound: Japan, cultivated in cool mountain streams
preparation: The rhizome is grated fresh just before consumption as a condiment for sushi and sashimi.
detailedExplanation: True wasabi is a difficult-to-cultivate plant that grows in cool, flowing water. Its characteristic pungent heat and aroma come from isothiocyanates released when the rhizome is grated. These compounds have demonstrated antibacterial and anti-inflammatory effects. Most "wasabi" served outside Japan is a substitute made from horseradish, mustard, and green food coloring. Source: https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0963996912002688

medicinalUses: Used as a diuretic and for wound healing (topically); rich in silica which may support bone and connective tissue health.
sideEffects: Contains thiaminase, which can break down vitamin B1 (thiamine). Not for long-term use.
preparation: The sterile stems are dried and used to make tea or tinctures.
detailedExplanation: This ancient, non-flowering plant is a "living fossil," related to plants from the time of the dinosaurs. Its high silica content gives it a rough, abrasive texture, which led to its historical use for scouring pots (hence the name "Scouring Rush"). The silica is also thought to contribute to its traditional use for strengthening bones and nails. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK927574/

medicinalUses: The leaves are used in a sweet tea (Amacha) and in traditional medicine for allergy and autoimmune conditions.
sideEffects: CAUTION: Other hydrangea species can be toxic, causing cyanide poisoning.
preparation: Leaves are fermented and dried to make Amacha tea, or used in decoctions.
detailedExplanation: This subspecies is the source of Amacha, a traditional Japanese tea consumed during the Buddha's birthday festival (Hanamatsuri). The leaves contain phyllodulcin, a compound hundreds of times sweeter than sugar. In traditional medicine, it is used to treat conditions like rheumatoid arthritis and lupus, with modern research investigating its immunomodulatory effects. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6273941/

medicinalUses: Primarily Ornamental. The rhizome has limited traditional use but is not a major medicinal source.
sideEffects: CAUTION: Many iris rhizomes are toxic and can cause severe gastric upset.
preparation: Not commonly prepared.
detailedExplanation: This plant is celebrated for its enormous, intricate, and flat-faced flowers, which are the result of centuries of cultivation in Japan. While some Iris species have medicinal rhizomes (e.g., I. germanica for Orris Root), the Japanese Iris is primarily grown for its unparalleled ornamental value in water gardens and is not a standard medicinal herb. Source: General botanical knowledge.

medicinalUses: Primarily ornamental. Has traditional use for detoxification and improving blood circulation.
sideEffects: Berries are mildly toxic if ingested, causing stomach upset.
preparation: Information on medicinal preparation is not well-documented.
detailedExplanation: More commonly known as Boston Ivy, this fast-growing vine is famous for covering walls of prestigious universities. It attaches with adhesive pads, not aerial roots. While it has some historical medicinal use, it is overwhelmingly valued for its spectacular fall foliage and shade-giving capabilities. Source: https://plants.ces.ncsu.edu/plants/parthenocissus-tricuspidata/

medicinalUses: The root is a rich source of resveratrol; used in TCM for Lyme disease, cardiovascular health, and as an antioxidant.
sideEffects: Can cause mild digestive upset. The plant is extremely invasive and damaging to ecosystems.
preparation: The root is dried and decocted or used to make tinctures and extracts.
detailedExplanation: This plant is one of the world's most invasive species, capable of breaking through concrete. However, its root is a major source of trans-resveratrol, the same compound famous in red wine. In Traditional Chinese Medicine (as Hu Zhang), it is used to clear heat, dampness, and toxins, and is a leading herbal therapy for Lyme disease. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6273941/

medicinalUses: The wood is used for timber. The bark contains tannins and arabinogalactan, a fiber with potential immune-boosting properties.
sideEffects: Generally safe. The sawdust can be an irritant.
preparation: Arabinogalactan is extracted from the heartwood for use as a dietary fiber supplement.
detailedExplanation: This is one of the few conifers that loses its needles in the winter. It is a commercially important timber tree. Its heartwood is a source of arabinogalactan, a soluble fiber studied for its prebiotic effects, which can support gut health and potentially modulate the immune system by stimulating natural killer cells. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6273941/

medicinalUses: Primarily Ornamental. TOXIC.
sideEffects: TOXIC. All parts, especially the berries, can cause severe stomach upset if ingested.
preparation: Not for medicinal use.
detailedExplanation: This shrub is a common landscaping plant, valued for its shade tolerance and attractive, often variegated, glossy leaves. The female plants produce bright red berries which are poisonous. It has no safe medicinal applications and should be handled with care, keeping it away from children and pets. Source: https://plants.ces.ncsu.edu/plants/aucuba-japonica/

medicinalUses: Used in traditional medicine for detoxification, reducing inflammation, and as a diuretic.
sideEffects: Generally considered safe.
preparation: The whole plant is decocted into a tea or used topically as a poultice.
detailedExplanation: This small, low-growing plant is a common lawn weed in its native range. In traditional medicine, it is used to treat conditions like hepatitis, appendicitis, and snakebites, reflecting its use as a "detoxifying" agent. It contains iridoid glycosides which are known for their anti-inflammatory and hepatoprotective properties. Source: https://www.jstage.jst.go.jp/article/cpb/50/2/50_2_187/_article

medicinalUses: The leaves are used for respiratory conditions (cough, phlegm); the fruit is nutritious and antioxidant.
sideEffects: The seeds contain cyanogenic glycosides and are toxic if ingested.
preparation: A tea is made from the dried leaves; the fruit is eaten raw or cooked.
detailedExplanation: Known as the Loquat tree, it is prized for its sweet, tangy fruit. Medicinally, the fuzzy leaves are more important. They are a key ingredient in traditional cough syrups and are rich in triterpenic acids (like ursolic and oleanolic acid) which have demonstrated anti-inflammatory and antitussive (cough-suppressing) effects. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6273941/

medicinalUses: Used as an expectorant for bronchitis and coughs; also used as a tonic and for treating insomnia.
sideEffects: Generally safe in medicinal doses.
preparation: The whole plant is dried and decocted.
detailedExplanation: This plant is a member of the milkwort genus, which is known for its use in supporting respiratory and nervous system health. The roots of some species (like P. tenuifolia) are a major TCM herb (Yuan Zhi), but the whole P. japonica plant is used similarly for its expectorant and calming properties. Source: https://www.jstage.jst.go.jp/article/cpb/50/2/50_2_187/_article

medicinalUses: Source of menthol; used for its cooling, analgesic (topical), and carminative (digestive) properties.
sideEffects: Can cause skin irritation in sensitive individuals. May cause heartburn if taken in large amounts.
preparation: The essential oil is extracted and used in liniments, balms, and aromatherapy.
detailedExplanation: This mint is the primary commercial source of natural menthol in Asia. It is cultivated extensively for its high menthol content, which is used in a vast array of products from cough drops and pain-relieving balms to toothpaste and candies. Its cooling sensation is a physiological response to the activation of TRPM8 cold receptors. Source: https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0944711313001738

medicinalUses: Primarily Ornamental. Not used in mainstream herbal medicine.
sideEffects: The seeds are considered toxic if ingested.
preparation: Not used for medicinal preparation.
detailedExplanation: This popular landscaping shrub is grown for its attractive, leathery leaves and highly fragrant, orange-blossom-scented flowers in spring. It is exceptionally tolerant of coastal conditions, salt spray, and drought. While not a medicinal plant, its resilience and scent make it a staple in warm-climate gardens. Source: https://plants.ces.ncsu.edu/plants/pittosporum-tobira/

medicinalUses: Used for menstrual and childbirth-related issues; regulates menses, eases cramps, and is a traditional postpartum tonic.
sideEffects: Generally safe. May cause stomach upset or diarrhea in high doses.
preparation: The aerial parts are dried and used in teas, tinctures, or decoctions.
detailedExplanation: Known as Yi Mu Cao in TCM, meaning "benefit mother herb," this plant is a cornerstone of women's health. It is used to invigorate blood circulation, regulate the menstrual cycle, and alleviate postpartum abdominal pain. Modern research has identified alkaloids (leonurine) that may stimulate the uterus and have cardioprotective effects. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6273941/

medicinalUses: Used in moxibustion; also as a digestive tonic, for regulating menstruation, and in traditional foods.
sideEffects: Can cause contact dermatitis in sensitive individuals.
preparation: The dried leaves are rolled into moxa sticks for burning; young leaves are used in mochi.
detailedExplanation: This species is the primary mugwort used in Japanese Kampo medicine and for the traditional practice of moxibustion, where the burned herb (moxa) stimulates acupuncture points. It is also a culinary herb, used to flavor and color rice cakes (kusa mochi). It contains thujone and other volatile oils which contribute to its therapeutic effects. Source: https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0944711313001738

medicinalUses: The flower buds and fruit are a major source of rutin, used to strengthen capillaries and as an anti-inflammatory.
sideEffects: Generally safe. The seeds and pods are toxic if ingested.
regionsFound: China, Korea, introduced to Japan & elsewhere
preparation: The flower buds (Huai Hua Mi) are dried for tea; rutin is extracted for supplements.
detailedExplanation: Also known as the Chinese Scholar Tree, this is a different species from the toxic Pagoda Tree (Sophora japonica is an outdated synonym). Its buds are one of the richest known sources of the flavonoid rutin, a powerful antioxidant and vasoprotective agent used to treat chronic venous insufficiency and hemorrhoids. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5630298/

medicinalUses: Primarily a culinary herb and vegetable, rich in antioxidants and nutrients.
sideEffects: Generally safe as a food.
preparation: The leaves and stems are eaten fresh in salads, cooked in soups, or used as a garnish.
detailedExplanation: Known as Seri in Japan, this plant is one of the traditional "seven herbs of spring" (Nanakusa). It is a wetland plant often used in soups and salads, with a flavor similar to celery or parsley. While nutritious, it is not a significant medicinal herb and is primarily valued for its fresh, clean taste in cuisine. Source: General culinary knowledge.

medicinalUses: The berries and leaves are used as a pungent spice; aids digestion and has mild analgesic properties.
sideEffects: The numbing sensation is temporary.
preparation: The dried and cracked berry husks are used as a spice; young leaves (kinome) are used as a garnish.
detailedExplanation: Sansho is a fundamental Japanese spice, related to Szechuan pepper. It creates a unique tingling, numbing sensation (due to sanshools) on the tongue. It is traditionally used to cut the richness of fatty foods like eel and to stimulate digestion. The compound hydroxy-alpha-sanshool is responsible for its characteristic effect. Source: https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0963996912002688

medicinalUses: A primary source of natural menthol; used for its cooling sensation and to relieve headaches and digestive issues.
sideEffects: Can cause skin irritation. May interact with acid reflux medications.
preparation: The essential oil is extracted for use in medicines, candies, and cosmetics.
detailedExplanation: This is another name for the Japanese Mint (Mentha canadensis), highlighting its status as the main cultivar used for commercial menthol production in Japan. The term "Hakka" refers to the dried plant. Its cultivation and processing are a significant industry, providing the raw material for countless menthol-based products worldwide. Source: https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0944711313001738

medicinalUses: The fruit is a rich source of vitamins and antioxidants. The calyx (persimmon stem) is used in TCM for hiccups.
sideEffects: Unripe fruit is very astringent due to high tannin content.
regionsFound: China, widely cultivated in Japan and globally
preparation: The fruit is eaten ripe; the dried calyx is decocted for tea to stop hiccups.
detailedExplanation: The Japanese Persimmon, or Kaki, produces sweet, orange fruits that are a good source of vitamins A and C, and dietary fiber. The astringency of unripe fruit comes from soluble tannins that coagulate proteins in the saliva. In TCM, the calyx is considered specific for treating stubborn hiccups, likely due to its antispasmodic action on the diaphragm. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6273941/

medicinalUses: Primarily Ornamental. HIGHLY TOXIC.
sideEffects: HIGHLY TOXIC. All parts contain grayanotoxins; ingestion causes vomiting, seizures, and can be fatal.
preparation: Not for medicinal use.
detailedExplanation: This popular ornamental shrub is prized for its cascading clusters of bell-shaped flowers and colorful new growth. However, it is extremely poisonous to humans and animals. It contains grayanotoxins, the same compounds found in Rhododendrons, which disrupt sodium channels in cell membranes. Source: https://www.poison.org/articles/japanese-pieris-

medicinalUses: The wood is used for timber and turpentine. The pollen is used as a tonic and for skin health.
sideEffects: Pine pollen may cause allergic reactions in sensitive individuals.
preparation: Pine pollen is collected and consumed as a powder or in tinctures.
detailedExplanation: Known as the Japanese Red Pine, it is a classic feature of the Japanese landscape. Its pollen is rich in nutrients, including amino acids, vitamins, and trace minerals, and is used as a general health tonic and adaptogen. It also contains small amounts of plant-based hormones like testosterone precursors. Source: https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0963996912002688

medicinalUses: The fruit is a nutritious food, rich in antioxidants and fiber. The bark has limited traditional use.
sideEffects: The seeds, like all stone fruits, contain cyanogenic glycosides and are toxic.
preparation: The fruit is eaten fresh, dried (as a prune), or made into umeboshi when unripe.
detailedExplanation: This species is the primary parent of most commercial plum cultivars. The fruit itself is the main benefit, providing vitamins, minerals, and sorbitol, which has a natural laxative effect. While the unripe fruit of its relative (P. mume) is more medicinally significant, this species is primarily an important fruit crop. Source: General agricultural knowledge.

medicinalUses: The bark and leaves contain alkaloids (homoharringtonine) with anti-leukemic properties.
sideEffects: TOXIC. All parts are poisonous if ingested. Can cause bone marrow suppression.
preparation: Not for self-use. Alkaloids are extracted for pharmaceutical cancer drugs.
detailedExplanation: This coniferous shrub is an ornamental alternative to true yews (Taxus). It is the original source of homoharringtonine, a compound used in the production of the chemotherapy drug omacetaxine mepesuccinate for treating chronic myeloid leukemia. All parts of the plant are poisonous and should not be consumed. Source: https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/drugs/omacetaxine

medicinalUses: Ornamental. Not a significant source of opiate alkaloids like the Opium Poppy.
sideEffects: Not well-documented, but all poppies should be treated with caution.
preparation: Not used in herbal medicine.
detailedExplanation: This poppy is grown for its large, showy, nodding flowers in shades of red and orange. Unlike the Opium Poppy (Papaver somniferum), it does not produce significant quantities of medicinal or narcotic latex. Its value is purely aesthetic in the garden. Source: General botanical knowledge.

medicinalUses: Primarily Ornamental. The fruit is considered toxic.
sideEffects: Berries are poisonous to humans and animals, causing stomach upset.
preparation: Not for medicinal use.
detailedExplanation: A very common landscaping shrub used for hedges and screens due to its dense, glossy foliage and tolerance for pruning. The black berries are mildly toxic and can cause gastrointestinal distress if ingested. It is a popular but invasive plant in some regions. Source: https://plants.ces.ncsu.edu/plants/ligustrum-japonicum/

medicinalUses: The hard, acidic fruit is rich in vitamin C and pectin; used for jams and to support immune health.
sideEffects: The raw fruit is extremely sour and astringent.
preparation: The fruit is cooked with sugar to make preserves, jellies, or liqueurs.
detailedExplanation: This low-growing shrub is valued for its bright red-orange flowers in early spring. The fruit, while inedible raw, is an excellent source of vitamin C and natural pectin, making it ideal for jams and jellies. Its high antioxidant content comes from various polyphenols and flavonoids. Source: https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0308814610007245

medicinalUses: The fleshy fruit stalk is eaten and used to treat hangovers and protect the liver from alcohol damage.
sideEffects: Generally safe. The seeds are not consumed.
preparation: The sweet, twisted fruit stalks are eaten raw, dried, or made into a tea.
detailedExplanation: This tree produces an unusual fruit: the seed itself is small and hard, but the attached stalk becomes thick, fleshy, and sweet, resembling a raisin in taste and texture when dried. In traditional medicine, it is renowned for its anti-hangover and hepatoprotective effects, with studies showing it can accelerate the metabolism of alcohol. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6273941/

medicinalUses: The hips are rich in Vitamin C. The root is used in TCM for promoting urination and reducing swelling.
sideEffects: Highly invasive in North America, forming impenetrable thickets.
preparation: Rose hips are used in teas and jams; the root is decocted.
detailedExplanation: This wild rose is prized for its abundant, small, white flowers. However, it is one of the most invasive plants in North America. While the rose hips are nutritious, its primary traditional medicinal use is the root, which is used in TCM to treat kidney and urinary conditions by promoting diuresis. Source: https://plants.ces.ncsu.edu/plants/rosa-multiflora/

medicinalUses: The pith is used in traditional Japanese medicine as a diuretic and fever reducer.
sideEffects: Generally considered safe.
preparation: The pith is dried and used in decoctions.
detailedExplanation: Known as "Igusa," this plant is culturally and economically significant in Japan, where its stems are harvested to weave the tatami mats that cover traditional flooring. In Kampo medicine, the pith (Denko-so) is used to clear "heat" and promote urination, treating conditions like painful urination and edema. Source: https://www.jstage.jst.go.jp/article/jphs/131/2/131_16245/_pdf

medicinalUses: Used in traditional medicine for its anti-inflammatory, antibacterial, and detoxifying properties.
sideEffects: Generally safe.
preparation: The aerial parts are used in decoctions.
detailedExplanation: This is one of many sage species used in East Asian traditional medicine. It is not as well-known as Chinese Sage (Salvia miltiorrhiza), but it is used similarly for clearing heat and toxins from the body, reducing inflammation, and treating infections. It contains diterpenoids and phenolic acids common to the Salvia genus. Source: https://www.jstage.jst.go.jp/article/cpb/50/2/50_2_187/_article

medicinalUses: The fruit is edible, rich in vitamins and lycopene. The flowers are used for asthma and cough.
sideEffects: Highly invasive, displacing native vegetation.
regionsFound: East Asia, invasive in North America
preparation: The fruit is eaten raw or cooked; a tea is made from the flowers.
detailedExplanation: Also known as Autumn Olive, this shrub is both valued for its nutritious, tart red berries and reviled as a highly invasive species. The berries are exceptionally high in the antioxidant lycopene. The fragrant flowers are used in traditional medicine as an astringent and for respiratory ailments. Source: https://plants.ces.ncsu.edu/plants/elaeagnus-umbellata/

medicinalUses: The root (Tian Hua Fen) and fruit (Gua Lou) are used in TCM for respiratory phlegm, cough, and diabetes.
sideEffects: The raw root is considered toxic.
preparation: The root and fruit are prepared in decoctions by trained practitioners.
detailedExplanation: This plant is a major herb in Traditional Chinese Medicine. The fruit is used as an expectorant to clear thick, stubborn phlegm from the lungs, while the root is used to reduce fevers and thirst associated with diabetes. The compound trichosanthin, from the root, has been studied for its ability to inhibit HIV replication. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5871212/

medicinalUses: Primarily Ornamental. Not known for significant medicinal use.
sideEffects: No major toxicity reported.
preparation: Not used in herbal medicine.
detailedExplanation: This small, elegant tree is cultivated for its beautiful, graceful form and stunning display of hanging, bell-shaped white flowers in late spring. It is a purely ornamental specimen tree, prized for its aesthetic contribution to gardens and landscapes, with no prominent history in traditional medicine. Source: General botanical knowledge.

medicinalUses: Primarily Ornamental. Valued for its fragrant, hanging white flowers.
sideEffects: No major toxicity reported.
preparation: Not used in herbal medicine.
detailedExplanation: This tree is closely related to the Japanese Snowbell but is known for its larger leaves and longer, more fragrant flower clusters. Like its cousin, it is grown solely for its exceptional ornamental value in gardens, providing a stunning visual and olfactory display in late spring. Source: General botanical knowledge.

medicinalUses: The young shoots are a popular spring vegetable. The root is used as a tonic and for pain relief.
sideEffects: Contact with the plant can cause skin irritation in some people.
preparation: Shoots are boiled and eaten; the root is decocted.
detailedExplanation: Known as Udo, this plant produces tall, edible shoots that are a prized wild vegetable (sansai) in Japan, with a flavor similar to angelica. The root, known as Du Huo in TCM, is used to treat "wind-damp" painful conditions like rheumatoid arthritis, acting as an anti-inflammatory and analgesic. Source: https://www.jstage.jst.go.jp/article/jphs/131/2/131_16245/_pdf

medicinalUses: Primarily Ornamental. TOXIC.
sideEffects: TOXIC. Ingestion causes severe gastroenteritis, chills, and weakness.
preparation: Not for medicinal use.
detailedExplanation: This is a very common ornamental shrub, widely used in landscaping for its glossy, evergreen leaves and tolerance of pruning. All parts of the plant, especially the seeds, are poisonous. It contains cardenolides and alkaloids which are toxic to humans and animals if ingested. Source: https://plants.ces.ncsu.edu/plants/euonymus-japonicus/

medicinalUses: Primarily Ornamental. Not used in herbal medicine.
sideEffects: All parts of the plant are toxic if ingested.
preparation: Not for medicinal use.
detailedExplanation: This plant is an extremely popular groundcover for deep shade, forming a dense, weed-suppressing mat of glossy green leaves. While effective in the landscape, all parts of the plant are considered poisonous and can cause vomiting and diarrhea if ingested. It has no medicinal applications. Source: https://plants.ces.ncsu.edu/plants/pachysandra-terminalis/

medicinalUses: HIGHLY TOXIC. NOT FOR MEDICINAL USE.
sideEffects: EXTREMELY TOXIC. Causes severe seizures, vomiting, kidney failure, and is often fatal.
preparation: AVOID ALL CONTACT AND INGESTION.
detailedExplanation: This plant is dangerously confused with the edible Chinese Star Anise (Illicium verum). While they look similar, Japanese Star Anise contains potent neurotoxins, primarily anisatin, which is a non-competitive antagonist of GABA-A receptors, leading to uncontrollable seizures. It has no safe medicinal application and must be strictly avoided. Source: https://www.poison.org/articles/2007-dec/star-anise

medicinalUses: The root is used in traditional medicine as a hemostatic (stops bleeding) and for treating wounds and bruises.
sideEffects: No major toxicity reported.
preparation: The root is dried and decocted or applied topically as a poultice.
detailedExplanation: This thistle is a common wildflower in East Asia. In traditional medicine, it is known as Da Ji and is used to cool the blood and stop bleeding, making it applicable for nosebleeds, hematuria, and traumatic bleeding. It is also considered a diuretic and hypotensive agent. The root contains flavonoids and polyacetylenes. Source: https://www.jstage.jst.go.jp/article/jphs/131/2/131_16245/_pdf

medicinalUses: The root bark (Mu Dan Pi) is used in TCM to cool the blood, reduce inflammation, and promote circulation.
sideEffects: Generally safe in medicinal doses. High doses may cause stomach upset.
regionsFound: China, cultivated in Japan for centuries
preparation: The root bark is dried and decocted in herbal formulas.
detailedExplanation: While native to China, tree peonies have been highly developed in Japan as ornamental plants. The root bark is a fundamental TCM herb for conditions of "heat in the blood," such as rashes, fever, and nosebleeds. It contains paeonol, a compound with demonstrated anti-inflammatory and analgesic properties. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6273671/

medicinalUses: Used as an anti-inflammatory and detoxifying agent, particularly for appendicitis, abscesses, and infections.
sideEffects: Generally safe.
preparation: The whole plant or root is decocted.
detailedExplanation: This plant is not a true valerian but is used in a similar context for its calming properties in Japanese and Chinese medicine. It is known as Bai Jiang Cao and is specifically used to treat appendicitis, intestinal abscesses, and gynecological infections by clearing "damp-heat and toxins." Source: https://www.jstage.jst.go.jp/article/jphs/131/2/131_16245/_pdf

medicinalUses: Primarily Ornamental. The rhizome has limited traditional use but is not a major medicinal source.
sideEffects: CAUTION: Many iris rhizomes are toxic and can cause severe gastric upset.
preparation: Not commonly prepared.
detailedExplanation: This plant is celebrated for its enormous, intricate, and flat-faced flowers, which are the result of centuries of cultivation in Japan. While some Iris species have medicinal rhizomes (e.g., I. germanica for Orris Root), the Japanese Water Iris is primarily grown for its unparalleled ornamental value in water gardens and is not a standard medicinal herb. Source: General botanical knowledge.

medicinalUses: Used topically as a stimulant and to treat swellings; internally as a diuretic and for stomach ailments.
sideEffects: The plant is very pungent and can cause intense irritation to the skin and mucous membranes.
regionsFound: Temperate regions of Asia, Europe, North America
preparation: The fresh plant is crushed and applied as a poultice; a weak tea is made for internal use.
detailedExplanation: Also known as Smartweed, this plant has a long history in European and Asian folk medicine. It contains polygodial, a compound responsible for its intense, peppery, and blistering taste. It is used as a counter-irritant for arthritic pain and has demonstrated insecticidal and anthelmintic properties. Source: https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0944711313001738

medicinalUses: The sap is used to produce lacquer and wax. HIGHLY TOXIC.
sideEffects: EXTREMELY TOXIC. Contains urushiol; causes severe allergic contact dermatitis identical to poison ivy.
preparation: AVOID ALL CONTACT.
detailedExplanation: This tree is commercially grown for the wax obtained from its berries, used in polishes and candles, and for its sap, which is used to make lacquer. Like poison ivy, it contains urushiol, and even brief contact can cause a severe, blistering rash in most people. It has no safe medicinal use. Source: https://www.poison.org/articles/poison-ivy-

medicinalUses: The wood is used for timber and the tree is a classic subject for bonsai. Pollen may be used as a tonic.
sideEffects: Pine pollen may cause allergic reactions.
preparation: Pine pollen is collected and consumed as a powder.
detailedExplanation: This pine is highly prized in Japan for its graceful, irregular form and is one of the most popular species for the art of bonsai. Its medicinal uses are minimal and similar to other pines, with the pollen sometimes used as a nutrient-rich health tonic. Its primary value is cultural and aesthetic. Source: General botanical knowledge.

medicinalUses: Used as an analgesic, diaphoretic (sweat-inducer), and for colds and headaches.
sideEffects: TOXIC. Contains the carcinogen aristolochic acid. Ingestion can cause kidney failure and cancer.
preparation: Not for internal use. Historically used in very small doses.
detailedExplanation: This groundcover plant has aromatic roots similar to true ginger but is unrelated. It contains aristolochic acid, a potent nephrotoxin and carcinogen linked to permanent kidney damage and urinary tract cancers. Its use is banned in many countries, and it must be strictly avoided. Source: https://www.poison.org/articles/aristolochic-acid

medicinalUses: The hips are rich in Vitamin C. The root is used in TCM for promoting urination and reducing swelling.
sideEffects: Highly invasive in North America, forming impenetrable thickets.
preparation: Rose hips are used in teas and jams; the root is decocted.
detailedExplanation: This wild rose is prized for its abundant, small, white flowers. However, it is one of the most invasive plants in North America. While the rose hips are nutritious, its primary traditional medicinal use is the root, which is used in TCM to treat kidney and urinary conditions by promoting diuresis. Source: https://plants.ces.ncsu.edu/plants/rosa-multiflora/

medicinalUses: Primarily Ornamental. TOXIC.
sideEffects: TOXIC. All parts, especially seeds and pods, cause severe stomach pain, nausea, and vomiting.
preparation: Not for medicinal use.
detailedExplanation: This vine is famous for its long, hanging clusters of fragrant purple, blue, or white flowers. It is a quintessential ornamental plant in Japanese gardens. However, all parts of the plant, particularly the seeds and seed pods, contain lectins and glycosides (wisterin) that are toxic if ingested. Source: https://www.poison.org/articles/wisteria

medicinalUses: Similar Artemisia uses: digestive tonic, anti-inflammatory, fumigant; local names vary.
sideEffects: Possible GI upset if misused.
preparation: Aerial-part decoction or inhalation as fumigant.
detailedExplanation: Artemisia japonica is used in northeast Asian and Himalayan traditional medicine as a bitter tonic and fumigant for respiratory complaints—regional ethnobotany records multiple uses. Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artemisia_japonica.

medicinalUses: The tuber is a nutritious food; contains allantoin, which promotes wound healing.
sideEffects: Generally safe as a food. The raw tuber may cause mild irritation in some.
preparation: The tuber is cooked and eaten; used topically in poultices for skin ulcers and boils.
detailedExplanation: This wild yam produces a long, slender tuber that is a traditional food in Japan. Unlike Mexican Wild Yam (D. villosa), it is not a source of diosgenin for hormone production. Its primary medicinal value lies in its high allantoin content, a compound that promotes cell proliferation and wound healing. Source: https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0944711313001738

medicinalUses: Source of the chemotherapy drug paclitaxel (Taxol), used for ovarian, breast, and lung cancers.
sideEffects: HIGHLY TOXIC. All parts except the red aril are poisonous, causing cardiac arrest.
regionsFound: Japan, Korea, China, Russian Far East
preparation: Not for self-use. Paclitaxel is extracted and purified pharmaceutically.
detailedExplanation: This ornamental conifer is the original source of paclitaxel, a diterpene that stabilizes microtubules, preventing cell division. While the red, fleshy aril around the seed is not toxic, the seed itself, along with the needles and bark, are deadly. It is a prime example of a plant that is both highly toxic and life-saving. Source: https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/drugs/paclitaxel

medicinalUses: The leaves are used for diabetes management; contain corosolic acid, which has insulin-like activity.
sideEffects: May cause hypoglycemia if taken with diabetes medication.
preparation: The leaves are dried and brewed as a tea or used in extracts.
detailedExplanation: Also known as Queen's Crape Myrtle or Banaba, this tree is celebrated for its beautiful purple flower clusters. Its leaves are a well-known traditional remedy for diabetes in the Philippines and India. Corosolic acid, a key active compound, is known as a "phyto-insulin" for its ability to enhance glucose uptake into cells. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6273941/

medicinalUses: Ornamental. TOXIC. All parts are poisonous, as with many nightshades.
sideEffects: TOXIC. Ingestion can cause gastrointestinal upset, headache, and respiratory depression.
preparation: Not for medicinal use.
detailedExplanation: This plant is a member of the nightshade family (Solanaceae) and is grown for its clusters of white, jasmine-like flowers. Despite its attractive appearance, it contains toxic solanine glycoalkaloids, similar to those found in deadly nightshade, and should not be ingested. Source: https://plants.ces.ncsu.edu/plants/solanum-jasminoides/

medicinalUses: The flowers are used to make jasmine tea; in aromatherapy for relaxation; and in traditional medicine for skin and eye health.
sideEffects: Generally recognized as safe. The essential oil is highly concentrated and should be diluted.
preparation: Flowers are used to scent tea; essential oil is distilled for perfumes and aromatherapy.
detailedExplanation: This species is one of the most culturally significant jasmines, known for its intensely fragrant white flowers which are used in religious ceremonies, garlands, and the production of jasmine tea. The flowers contain benzyl acetate and linalool, compounds known for their calming and sedative effects. Source: https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0944711313001738

medicinalUses: The fruit is used in TCM for irritability, insomnia, and inflammatory conditions; topically for wounds and sprains.
sideEffects: Generally safe in medicinal doses. May cause diarrhea in high doses.
preparation: The dried fruit (Zhi Zi) is decocted; a paste is made for topical application.
detailedExplanation: Despite its common name, this is a Gardenia, not a Jasmine. Its fruit is a major TCM herb used to clear "heat" from the heart and liver, treating restlessness, jaundice, and painful urination. It is also a source of yellow dye. The active compounds are geniposide and crocins. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6273671/

medicinalUses: Primarily Ornamental. Not known for significant medicinal use.
sideEffects: The sap may cause skin irritation in sensitive individuals.
preparation: Not used in herbal medicine.
detailedExplanation: This vine is grown for its profuse clusters of highly fragrant, white, trumpet-shaped flowers. It is a popular ornamental plant in warmer climates but lacks a substantial history of use in traditional medicine systems. Its value is purely aesthetic. Source: General botanical knowledge.

medicinalUses: The essential oil is used in aromatherapy for depression, stress, and as an aphrodisiac. The flowers are used in tea.
sideEffects: Generally safe. Essential oil must be diluted.
preparation: Flowers are used for tea and perfumes; essential oil is distilled for aromatherapy.
detailedExplanation: Known as Poet's Jasmine, this is the classic, hardy jasmine vine. Its fragrance, primarily from benzyl acetate and benzyl benzoate, is one of the most prized in perfumery. In traditional medicine, it has been used for liver pain and abdominal pain, but its modern use is dominated by aromatherapy for mood enhancement. Source: https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0944711313001738

medicinalUses: Primarily Ornamental. Not used in mainstream herbal medicine.
sideEffects: The milky sap can cause skin irritation and allergic reactions in some people.
regionsFound: East Asia, not a true jasmine
preparation: Not used for medicinal preparation.
detailedExplanation: This popular landscaping plant is beloved for its dense coverage, glossy leaves, and intensely fragrant white flowers. Despite its name, it is a different genus from true jasmine. It is almost exclusively an ornamental plant with no prominent history in traditional medicine. Source: https://plants.ces.ncsu.edu/plants/trachelospermum-jasminoides/

medicinalUses: Used in traditional medicine for treating wounds, ulcers, and skin diseases; has antimicrobial properties.
sideEffects: Generally considered safe.
preparation: The leaves are crushed and applied as a poultice to wounds.
detailedExplanation: This shrub is distinguished by its downy (hairy) stems and leaves. It produces clusters of white, slightly fragrant flowers. In Ayurvedic and other traditional systems, it is used primarily as a topical remedy for various skin ailments due to its astringent and antimicrobial properties. Source: https://www.jstage.jst.go.jp/article/jphs/131/2/131_16245/_pdf

medicinalUses: Primarily Ornamental. Not a major medicinal plant.
sideEffects: No significant side effects reported.
preparation: Not commonly used in herbal medicine.
detailedExplanation: This shrub is grown for its attractive, glossy green foliage and clusters of yellow, slightly fragrant flowers. While it is a true jasmine, it is not prominently featured in major herbal pharmacopoeias and is primarily valued for its ornamental appeal in gardens. Source: General botanical knowledge.

medicinalUses: The leaves and roots are used in traditional medicine for diarrhea, dysentery, and pain relief.
sideEffects: Generally safe.
preparation: A decoction is made from the leaves or root bark.
detailedExplanation: Also known as Orange Jessamine, this plant is not a true jasmine but is closely related to citrus. It is prized for its highly fragrant, white flowers that smell like orange blossoms. In traditional medicine, it is used as an astringent and analgesic. Source: https://www.jstage.jst.go.jp/article/jphs/131/2/131_16245/_pdf

medicinalUses: Primarily Ornamental. Limited information on medicinal use.
sideEffects: Information Missing.
preparation: Not commonly used.
detailedExplanation: This is a lesser-known jasmine species native to the South Pacific. It is not a major plant in international trade or traditional medicine systems. Its primary value is regional and ornamental. Source: General botanical knowledge.

medicinalUses: The essential oil is used in aromatherapy for depression and stress. The flowers are used in tea.
sideEffects: Generally safe. Essential oil must be diluted.
preparation: Flowers are used for tea and perfumes; essential oil is distilled for aromatherapy.
detailedExplanation: This is the same plant as Common White Jasmine (Jasminum officinale). The name "Poet's Jasmine" reflects its classic status and romantic association. Its use is dominated by its profound fragrance in perfumery and aromatherapy for alleviating anxiety and low mood. Source: https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0944711313001738

medicinalUses: Primarily Ornamental. Not a medicinal plant.
sideEffects: Information Missing.
preparation: Not used in herbal medicine.
detailedExplanation: This common name refers to plants in the genus Androsace (Rock Jasmines), which are small, mat-forming alpine plants in the primrose family. They are cultivated by rock garden enthusiasts for their delicate flowers but have no medicinal use. Source: General botanical knowledge.

medicinalUses: The essential oil is a key ingredient in high-end perfumery; used in aromatherapy similar to common jasmine.
sideEffects: Generally safe. Essential oil must be diluted.
preparation: Flowers are harvested at night for absolute production.
detailedExplanation: Also known as Royal Jasmine or Catalonian Jasmine, this species is commercially grown for its exceptionally rich and intense fragrance, which is extracted as an "absolute" for the perfume industry. Its medicinal uses overlap with common jasmine, focusing on its calming aromatic properties. Source: https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0944711313001738

medicinalUses: Primarily Ornamental. Not a major medicinal plant.
sideEffects: Information Missing.
regionsFound: Papua New Guinea, not a true jasmine
preparation: Not commonly used.
detailedExplanation: This plant, also called Angelwing Jasmine, is grown for its glossy leaves and large, pinwheel-shaped, fragrant white flowers. It is a popular ornamental in tropical and subtropical climates but does not have a significant history of medicinal use. Source: General botanical knowledge.

medicinalUses: Primarily Ornamental. Not used in herbal medicine.
sideEffects: No significant side effects reported.
preparation: Not used for medicinal preparation.
detailedExplanation: This shrub is valued for one reason: it blooms on bare stems in the middle of winter, providing a rare splash of bright yellow color. It is not fragrant and is not used in perfumery or traditional medicine. Its value is purely horticultural. Source: General botanical knowledge.

medicinalUses: Primarily Ornamental. Not a major medicinal plant.
sideEffects: No significant side effects reported.
preparation: Not commonly used.
detailedExplanation: This jasmine is grown for its semi-double, bright yellow flowers which appear in early spring. It is a vigorous, sprawling shrub used in landscaping. Unlike the fragrant white jasmines, it is not used in perfumery or as a significant medicinal herb. Source: General botanical knowledge.

medicinalUses: The seeds are a source of biodiesel. The oil and extracts have purgative and antimicrobial properties. TOXIC.
sideEffects: HIGHLY TOXIC. The seeds contain phorbol esters; ingestion causes severe vomiting, diarrhea, and can be fatal.
preparation: Not for self-use. The oil is used externally in traditional medicine with extreme caution.
detailedExplanation: This is likely a misspelling of Jatropha, a genus known for biofuel production. The seeds of Jatropha curcas (Physic Nut) are highly toxic but contain 30-40% oil that can be processed into biodiesel. Traditional uses of the plant are fraught with danger due to the presence of potent toxins. Source: https://www.poison.org/articles/jatropha

medicinalUses: Used as a tonic for energy and respiratory health; antifungal and anti-inflammatory properties.
sideEffects: Generally considered safe.
preparation: Bark is decocted into a tea; resin is also used.
detailedExplanation: Known as the "Brazilian Copal," Jatoba is a giant Amazonian tree. Its bark is widely used in Brazilian traditional medicine as a powerful tonic to combat fatigue and strengthen the respiratory system against bronchitis and asthma. The resin is used for its antimicrobial properties. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5871205/

medicinalUses: Anti-rheumatic, anti-spasmodic
sideEffects: None significant
regionsFound: Native to South India and Western Ghats
preparation: Root bark decoction
detailedExplanation: Alangium javanicum relieves muscle spasms and joint pain. Important note: Rare in wild. Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alangium_javanicum

medicinalUses: The roasted seeds are edible. The oil has potential for biofuel. Not a major medicinal plant.
sideEffects: Caution: Raw seeds are not recommended. Oil contains cyclopropene fatty acids.
preparation: Seeds must be roasted before consumption.
detailedExplanation: This large tree is known for its foul-smelling flowers and star-shaped fruit pods. The seeds, after roasting, are eaten. The oil from the seeds is of industrial interest for biodiesel. It lacks a significant history of traditional medicinal use compared to other plants. Source: https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0963996912002688

medicinalUses: Used in TCM for dysentery, malaria, and cancer; potent anti-parasitic and anti-tumor effects.
sideEffects: TOXIC. Can cause nausea, vomiting, and neurotoxicity. Professional supervision required.
preparation: The seeds are extracted for use in oil emulsions or capsules.
detailedExplanation: This plant is a powerful but toxic medicinal herb. Its seeds are the source of quassinoids like brusatol, which have demonstrated potent activity against malaria parasites and cancer cells in laboratory studies. It is a classic example of a plant with a very narrow therapeutic window. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6273941/

medicinalUses: In Ayurveda, used for bleeding disorders, wounds, and diabetes; astringent and anti-inflammatory.
sideEffects: The milky sap can cause skin irritation.
preparation: Bark powder is applied to wounds; a decoction is made for gargling or drinking.
detailedExplanation: This large fig tree is known for its aerial roots. In traditional systems, its bark is highly valued for its astringent properties, used to treat wounds, ulcers, gum disease, and internal conditions like diarrhea and diabetes. Source: https://www.jstage.jst.go.jp/article/jphs/131/2/131_16245/_pdf

medicinalUses: (See Java Almond) This is a common name for the same plant, Sterculia foetida.
sideEffects: (See Java Almond)
preparation: (See Java Almond)
detailedExplanation: (See Java Almond)

medicinalUses: Highly valued for antidiabetic properties; also used for digestive issues and as an antioxidant.
sideEffects: Generally safe. Excessive consumption may cause gas or hypoglycemia.
preparation: The fruit is eaten; seeds are dried, powdered, and taken for diabetes.
detailedExplanation: Also known as Jamun, this tree is iconic in Ayurveda, especially for managing diabetes ("Madhumeha"). The seeds, bark, and leaves contain jamboline and jambosine, compounds shown to reduce blood sugar levels by slowing the conversion of starch to sugar. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3609276/

medicinalUses: A well-known diuretic; used for kidney and bladder health, to flush out kidney gravel, and for gout.
sideEffects: Generally safe. May cause excessive fluid loss if overused.
preparation: The leaves are dried and brewed as a herbal tea.
detailedExplanation: Commonly known as Cat's Whiskers due to its long, protruding stamens. Java Tea is a recognized herbal medicine in Europe for flushing the urinary tract. It helps increase urine output and flush out small stones and crystals. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK927574/

medicinalUses: The root was used by Native Americans and early settlers as a diuretic, antispasmodic, and treatment for rheumatism.
sideEffects: TOXIC. All parts of the plant are poisonous if ingested.
preparation: Not for self-use. Historically, a root tea was used in very small amounts.
detailedExplanation: This beautiful and rare woodland wildflower is named after Thomas Jefferson. While it has a history of use, its toxicity is significant. It contains isoquinoline alkaloids similar to those in its relative, Blue Cohosh. It is now primarily valued for its ornamental and ecological value, not as a medicine. Source: https://plants.ces.ncsu.edu/plants/jeffersonia-diphylla/

medicinalUses: Used in traditional medicine for diarrhea, fever, and as an anti-inflammatory.
sideEffects: Generally considered safe.
preparation: The leaves are used to make a tea or poultice.
detailedExplanation: This plant is a common tropical weed. When chewed, the leaves become mucilaginous (slimy), giving it the name "Jelly Leaf." This mucilage is soothing to the digestive tract, making it a traditional remedy for diarrhea and stomach inflammation. Source: General ethnobotanical knowledge.

medicinalUses: The fruit is nutritious, rich in vitamins and antioxidants; used for jellies and juices.
sideEffects: Fruit is safe and nutritious.
preparation: The pulp is used to make juices, jellies, and ice cream.
detailedExplanation: Also known as the Pindo Palm, this tree is cultivated for its sweet, tangy fruits which are exceptionally high in pectin, making them ideal for jellies without added pectin. It is primarily a nutritional and ornamental plant, not a medicinal one. Source: General horticultural knowledge.

medicinalUses: HIGHLY TOXIC. The seeds contain abrin, a lethal toxin. Not for medicinal use.
sideEffects: EXTREMELY TOXIC. One seed, if chewed and swallowed, can be fatal. Causes severe vomiting, organ failure.
preparation: AVOID ALL CONTACT. Seeds are used in jewelry, which is dangerous if seeds are pierced.
detailedExplanation: Known as Rosary Pea, this plant has beautiful red and black seeds used in jewelry and percussion instruments. The seeds contain abrin, one of the most deadly plant toxins known, which inhibits protein synthesis at the cellular level. There is no safe medicinal use. Source: https://www.poison.org/articles/rosary-pea

medicinalUses: Used in traditional medicine for sore throats, diarrhea, and as a topical anti-inflammatory for wounds.
sideEffects: Generally considered safe.
preparation: The aerial parts are used to make a tea or poultice.
detailedExplanation: This small, woolly plant is a common weed in damp, disturbed ground. It has astringent properties due to its tannin content, making it useful for soothing inflamed mucous membranes in the throat and gut, and for healing minor wounds and burns. Source: https://www.henriettes-herb.com/eclectic/kings/gnaphalium.html

medicinalUses: The tubers are a nutritious food source high in inulin, a prebiotic fiber that supports gut health.
sideEffects: Can cause flatulence and bloating in some people due to inulin fermentation.
preparation: Tubers are eaten raw in salads, roasted, boiled, or pickled.
detailedExplanation: Not from Jerusalem and not an artichoke, this plant is a species of sunflower grown for its edible tubers. The inulin it contains is not digested but ferments in the colon, acting as a prebiotic that feeds beneficial gut bacteria like Bifidobacteria. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6273554/

medicinalUses: Ornamental. TOXIC. All parts, especially the berries, are poisonous.
sideEffects: TOXIC. Causes gastric upset, vomiting, headache. Can be fatal to children and pets.
preparation: Not for medicinal use.
detailedExplanation: This popular houseplant is grown for its bright orange-red berries that resemble cherries. It is a member of the nightshade family and contains solanocapsine, a toxic glycoalkaloid similar to solanine. It is dangerous if ingested. Source: https://www.poison.org/articles/jerusalem-cherry

medicinalUses: Used as an anthelmintic (expels worms) and for catarrh (mucus). The essential oil is toxic.
sideEffects: TOXIC in large doses. The essential oil (ascaridole) can cause liver and kidney damage.
preparation: Used in very small, controlled doses. Not for self-use.
detailedExplanation: This strongly aromatic plant, also called Feathered Geranium, has a history of use against intestinal worms. Its toxicity is due to ascaridole, a peroxide that is effective against parasites but also highly toxic to the host. Source: https://www.poison.org/articles/jerusalem-oak

medicinalUses: Primarily Ornamental. Not a major medicinal plant.
sideEffects: No significant toxicity reported.
preparation: Not used in herbal medicine.
detailedExplanation: This shrub is grown for its attractive, woolly grey-green leaves and whorls of yellow flowers. It is a drought-tolerant ornamental plant and is not related to true sage (Salvia) nor does it have a prominent history in traditional medicine. Source: General botanical knowledge.

medicinalUses: Primarily Ornamental. The seeds are edible in times of famine.
sideEffects: The thorns are sharp and can cause injury.
preparation: Seeds are roasted and eaten.
detailedExplanation: This tree is characterized by its green bark and long, slender thorns. It is highly drought-tolerant and is often used in arid landscaping. While not a significant medicinal plant, its seeds have been used as a food source. Source: General botanical knowledge.

medicinalUses: HIGHLY TOXIC. Historically used for neuralgic pain and as an anxiolytic in homeopathy.
sideEffects: EXTREMELY TOXIC. Ingestion causes dizziness, vision problems, respiratory failure, and death.
preparation: Not for self-use. Used in extreme dilutions in homeopathy.
detailedExplanation: Also called Yellow Jessamine, this state flower of South Carolina is dangerously poisonous. It contains alkaloids like gelsemine that are powerful neurotoxins. It has no safe use in herbal medicine and should be strictly avoided. Source: https://www.poison.org/articles/jessamine

medicinalUses: Source of quinine, the classic antimalarial drug; also used for fever and muscle cramps.
sideEffects: Quinine can cause cinchonism (tinnitus, nausea) and serious heart rhythm disturbances.
preparation: The bark is dried and powdered for extraction of quinine.
detailedExplanation: This tree's bark was the first effective treatment for malaria and revolutionized tropical medicine. The discovery of quinine from Cinchona bark is one of the most important events in the history of pharmacology. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK927574/

medicinalUses: Leaves are a nutritious vegetable, rich in vitamins and mucilage; used to soothe the digestive tract.
sideEffects: Generally safe as a food.
preparation: Young leaves and shoots are cooked as a leafy green vegetable, often in soups and stews.
detailedExplanation: Known in Egyptian cuisine as "Molokhia," this plant is a highly nutritious leafy green, rich in vitamins A, C, and E, iron, and calcium. The leaves become mucilaginous when cooked, similar to okra, which helps soothe the digestive system. It is more of a nutritional powerhouse than a targeted medicinal herb. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6273554/

medicinalUses: Anti-diabetic, liver tonic. Primarily Ornamental. Valued for its beautiful velvety leaves, not for medicinal use.
sideEffects: Rare allergic reactions
preparation: Whole plant extract
detailedExplanation: Jewel orchid is highly valued for its use in treating diabetes and liver ailments in traditional medicine. Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anoectochilus_formosanus

medicinalUses: A well-known folk remedy for poison ivy rash and stinging nettle burns; antifungal properties.
sideEffects: Generally safe for topical use.
preparation: The succulent stem is crushed and the juice is rubbed on the skin immediately after exposure.
detailedExplanation: Also called Touch-Me-Not because its seed pods explode when touched. The juice from its stems and leaves contains lawsone and other compounds that counteract the urushiol oil from poison ivy, providing rapid relief from itching and preventing the rash from spreading if applied quickly. Source: https://www.poison.org/articles/jewelweed

medicinalUses: A well-known folk remedy applied topically to soothe skin rashes from poison ivy, poison oak, and stinging nettles.
sideEffects: Generally very safe for topical use.
preparation: The succulent stem is crushed and the juice is rubbed on the skin immediately after exposure.
detailedExplanation: Also called Touch-Me-Not because its ripe seed pods explode when touched. The juice from its stems and leaves is a legendary field remedy that can provide rapid relief from itching and prevent the rash from spreading if applied quickly after contact with poison ivy. Source: https://www.poison.org/articles/jewelweed

medicinalUses: An adaptogen used to reduce stress, boost immunity, lower cholesterol, and improve cardiovascular health.
sideEffects: Generally safe. May cause mild nausea in some.
preparation: The leaves are dried and brewed as a tea, or taken in capsule/extract form.
detailedExplanation: Known as "Southern Ginseng" for its similar adaptogenic properties, Jiaogulan is renowned for its high concentration of gypenosides, which are structurally similar to the ginsenosides in Panax ginseng. It is used to help the body resist physical, chemical, and biological stress. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6340363/

medicinalUses: A potent adaptogen used to reduce stress, boost immunity, improve cardiovascular health, and lower cholesterol.
sideEffects: Generally safe. May cause mild nausea in some individuals.
preparation: The leaves are dried and brewed as a tea, or taken in capsule/extract form.
detailedExplanation: Known as "Xiancao" (Herb of Immortality) in some regions of China, Jiaogulan is renowned for its high concentration of gypenosides, which are structurally similar to the ginsenosides in Panax ginseng. It helps the body resist physical, chemical, and biological stress and has demonstrated antioxidant and cholesterol-lowering effects in studies. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6340363/

medicinalUses: The tuber is a nutritious, low-calorie food rich in prebiotic fiber (inulin), supporting gut health.
sideEffects: The seeds, leaves, and stems are toxic and contain rotenone. Only the tuber is edible.
preparation: The tuber is eaten raw in salads or cooked in stir-fries.
detailedExplanation: Jicama is a crunchy, sweet, and juicy root vegetable. Its high inulin content makes it an excellent prebiotic, feeding beneficial gut bacteria. It is a great source of vitamin C and fiber. It is important to only consume the peeled tuber, as other plant parts are poisonous. Source: https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/agricultural-and-biological-sciences/pachyrhizus

medicinalUses: HIGHLY TOXIC. Contains tropane alkaloids. Historically used for asthma and pain, but extremely dangerous.
sideEffects: EXTREMELY TOXIC. Causes delirium, hallucinations, tachycardia, hyperthermia, and can be fatal.
preparation: Not for self-use.
detailedExplanation: Also known as Thorn Apple, this plant is a classic and deadly poison. It contains scopolamine, hyoscyamine, and atropine, which cause severe anticholinergic syndrome. Despite historical use in rituals and folk medicine, its margin of safety is nonexistent. Source: https://www.poison.org/articles/jimson-weed

medicinalUses: The seeds are a nutritious grain; used in TCM to remove "dampness" (edema, diarrhea, arthritis).
sideEffects: Generally safe as a food.
preparation: The seeds are hulled and cooked as a grain or porridge; used in decoctions.
detailedExplanation: This cereal grass produces hard, tear-shaped seeds that are used as beads and as a food grain. In Traditional Chinese Medicine, it is known as Yi Yi Ren and is a primary herb for treating conditions caused by "dampness," such as joint pain, lung congestion, and digestive weakness. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6273671/

medicinalUses: Used as a diuretic for urinary tract infections, kidney stones, and gout; also traditionally used for fever and rheumatism.
sideEffects: Generally safe. May cause stomach upset in high doses.
preparation: The root and aerial parts are dried and used in teas or tinctures.
detailedExplanation: This tall, native North American wildflower is named after a Native American herbalist. It was a traditional remedy for typhoid fever. The common name "Gravel Root" points to its primary use: helping to break down and flush out gravel (small stones) from the urinary tract. It has a mild, sweet aroma. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK927574/

medicinalUses: Used as a gentle remedy for skin conditions like eczema, cradle cap, and acne; also as a mild expectorant.
sideEffects: Generally very safe.
preparation: The aerial parts are used to make infusions, syrups, or salves.
detailedExplanation: This small, cheerful wildflower is a type of wild pansy. It contains saponins and flavonoids, particularly rutin, which give it anti-inflammatory and cleansing properties. It is especially suitable for children and those with sensitive skin. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK927574/

medicinalUses: (See Jointfir) This is a common name for plants in the Ephedra genus.
sideEffects: HIGH RISK. Can cause hypertension, arrhythmia, insomnia, stroke, and heart attack.
preparation: (See Jointfir)
detailedExplanation: (See Jointfir)

medicinalUses: Primarily a weed. Young leaves are edible. Not a significant medicinal plant.
sideEffects: Can be a problematic invasive weed in crops.
preparation: Young leaves can be eaten raw or cooked.
detailedExplanation: Also known as Wild Radish, this plant is a common agricultural weed. While the young leaves can be foraged as a potherb, it is not prominent in any traditional medicinal system and is generally considered a nuisance by farmers. Source: General botanical knowledge.

medicinalUses: Source of ephedrine, a potent decongestant and bronchodilator for asthma and colds. RESTRICTED.
sideEffects: HIGH RISK. Can cause hypertension, arrhythmia, insomnia, stroke, and heart attack.
preparation: Not for self-use. Heavily regulated.
detailedExplanation: This is the plant from which the alkaloid ephedrine was first isolated. While highly effective for respiratory conditions, its stimulant properties have led to widespread abuse and serious health risks, resulting in its ban or heavy regulation in many countries. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK548202/

medicinalUses: Primarily a wildflower. Not known for significant medicinal use.
sideEffects: Information Missing.
preparation: Not used in herbal medicine.
detailedExplanation: This is a genus of small, wiry plants native to sandy soils in North America. They are not prominent in ethnobotany or modern herbalism and are primarily of interest to ecologists and native plant gardeners. Source: General botanical knowledge.

medicinalUses: The oil from the seeds is a superb moisturizer for skin and hair; closely resembles human sebum.
sideEffects: Non-toxic and non-comedogenic (doesn't clog pores).
preparation: The oil is cold-pressed from the seeds and used directly in cosmetics.
detailedExplanation: Jojoba is not an oil but a liquid wax ester. Its unique structure makes it extremely stable and an excellent emollient that mimics the skin's natural oils. It is a cornerstone of the natural cosmetics industry and is not used internally as a medicine. Source: https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0926669012005436

medicinalUses: The leaves are a highly nutritious leafy green, rich in protein, vitamins, and antioxidants.
sideEffects: Generally safe as a food. High in oxalates.
preparation: The leaves are cooked as a vegetable, similar to spinach.
detailedExplanation: This plant is cultivated for its brilliantly colored leaves (red, yellow, green). It is a type of amaranth, a group of plants known for their exceptional nutritional value, providing high-quality protein, iron, calcium, and vitamins A and C. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6273554/

medicinalUses: Protected and iconic, not medicinal. The roots of related yuccas contain saponins used as soap.
sideEffects: Not for internal use.
preparation: Not used in herbal medicine.
detailedExplanation: This iconic tree of the Mojave Desert is a symbol of the American Southwest and is protected by law. While some related yuccas have roots that can be used as a natural soap, the Joshua Tree itself is not used medicinally and its survival is threatened by climate change. Source: https://www.nps.gov/jotr/learn/nature/jtrees.htm

medicinalUses: The berries are a superfood, rich in antioxidants (zeaxanthin), supporting eye and immune health.
sideEffects: Generally safe. May interact with blood thinners.
preparation: The berries are eaten dried, raw, or in juice; also used in teas.
detailedExplanation: This is an old common name for the Goji Berry. These bright red berries are one of the most nutrient-dense fruits, exceptionally high in antioxidants like zeaxanthin, which is critical for eye health, and polysaccharides that support immune function. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341363/

medicinalUses: Primarily Ornamental. Some species are used in traditional medicine for cough, fever, and wounds.
sideEffects: Information Missing.
preparation: Information on preparation is limited.
detailedExplanation: This genus includes many popular ornamental plants with brightly colored foliage. While some species have traditional uses in various cultures for treating infections and inflammation, they are not major herbs in mainstream herbalism and are primarily grown for their decorative value. Source: General botanical knowledge.

medicinalUses: Primarily Ornamental. The flowers are sometimes pickled and used as a condiment.
sideEffects: No significant medicinal use or toxicity reported.
preparation: Flowers can be eaten raw in salads or pickled.
detailedExplanation: This tree is famous for its stunning display of deep pink flowers that emerge directly from its branches and trunk. Its common name is linked to the legend that Judas Iscariot hanged himself from this tree. It is not a significant medicinal plant. Source: General botanical knowledge.

medicinalUses: The fruit is a nutritious food; used in TCM as a sedative for insomnia and anxiety, and to tonify the spleen and digestive system.
sideEffects: Generally safe. May cause drowsiness.
preparation: The dried fruit (Da Zao) is used in decoctions; also eaten fresh or dried as a snack.
detailedExplanation: Jujube is a major fruit and medicinal herb. In TCM, it is one of the most important herbs for calming the spirit (Shen) and nourishing the blood, often combined with other herbs to moderate their harshness. The fruit is rich in vitamin C, flavonoids, and cyclic AMP, which may contribute to its biological effects. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6273671/

medicinalUses: Primarily Ornamental. Used in traditional medicine for dysentery, fever, and skin conditions.
sideEffects: No major toxicity reported.
preparation: The flowers, leaves, and root are used in decoctions.
detailedExplanation: This popular tropical shrub is grown for its dense clusters of bright red, orange, or yellow flowers. In Ayurveda, it is used for its astringent properties to treat diarrhea, wounds, and skin infections, but it is far more common as a landscaping plant. Source: General ethnobotanical knowledge.

medicinalUses: Primarily a weed. The grain is edible and can be used as a famine food.
