sideEffects: A problematic invasive weed in many crops.
preparation: The seeds are harvested and cooked like millet.
detailedExplanation: This grass is one of the world's worst weeds in irrigated and rain-fed crops. While the seeds are edible and nutritious, the plant is not used medicinally and is primarily known for the significant agricultural losses it causes. Source: General agricultural knowledge.

medicinalUses: The berries are used as a diuretic for urinary tract health, and as a digestive aid for bloating and indigestion.
sideEffects: Can irritate the kidneys with long-term use. Avoid during pregnancy.
preparation: The berries are crushed and used in teas, tinctures, or to flavor gin.
detailedExplanation: The blue-black "berries" are actually modified cones. They contain terpene compounds like alpha-pinene and myrcene, which give them their characteristic piney flavor and diuretic, antiseptic, and carminative properties. It is a key flavoring in gin. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK927574/

medicinalUses: TOXIC. Not for medicinal use.
sideEffects: TOXIC. Berries are poisonous if ingested.
preparation: Avoid all use.
detailedExplanation: This plant is a mistletoe that specifically parasitizes juniper trees. Like many mistletoes, it is considered toxic and should not be used for food or medicine. It is ecologically important for birds. Source: https://www.poison.org/articles/mistletoe

medicinalUses: TOXIC. The milky sap is a severe skin and eye irritant.
sideEffects: TOXIC. Sap causes contact dermatitis and blindness if it gets in the eyes.
preparation: Avoid all contact.
detailedExplanation: This spurge is a drought-tolerant ornamental plant. Like all Euphorbias, it contains a toxic, milky latex that is a potent irritant. It has no safe medicinal applications and should be handled with extreme care. Source: https://www.poison.org/articles/euphorbia

medicinalUses: Primarily Ornamental. The root wood (briar) is used to make high-quality pipes.
sideEffects: Not a medicinal plant.
preparation: Not used for medicine.
detailedExplanation: This plant is a type of heath, not a juniper, but its leaves resemble juniper needles. Its hard, heat-resistant root burls are the source of briarwood, prized for making smoking pipes. It has no significant medicinal use. Source: General botanical knowledge.

medicinalUses: The berries can be used similarly to Common Juniper, but are less common. The wood is used for timber.
sideEffects: Can irritate the kidneys with long-term use. Avoid during pregnancy.
preparation: Berries can be used for flavoring.
detailedExplanation: This juniper is named for its distinctive, checkered "alligator hide" bark. While its berries are technically edible and medicinal, they are not as commonly used as those from Juniperus communis. The tree is primarily valued for its durable wood. Source: General botanical knowledge.

medicinalUses: The berries were a traditional food and medicine for Native American tribes.
sideEffects: Can irritate the kidneys with long-term use. Avoid during pregnancy.
preparation: Berries were eaten and used in teas.
detailedExplanation: This drought-tolerant juniper is ecologically important in its native range. Native tribes used its berries for food and to make teas for treating colds, headaches, and other ailments. It is not a major commercial medicinal source. Source: General ethnobotanical knowledge.

medicinalUses: Primarily Ornamental. Used in bonsai and landscaping. Not a primary source of medicinal berries.
sideEffects: Ornamental use only.
preparation: Not commonly used for medicine.
detailedExplanation: This species is one of the most popular conifers used in landscaping and the art of bonsai worldwide. It has many cultivated varieties. While it produces berries, they are not the standard source for medicinal juniper. Source: General horticultural knowledge.

medicinalUses: Primarily Ornamental. Used as a groundcover. Not a source of edible berries.
sideEffects: Ornamental use only.
preparation: Not used for medicine.
detailedExplanation: This species is a low-growing, prostrate shrub widely used in landscaping for groundcover on slopes and in rock gardens. It does not produce significant berries and is not used in herbal medicine. Source: General horticultural knowledge.

medicinalUses: Primarily Ornamental. A classic species for bonsai.
sideEffects: Ornamental use only.
preparation: Not used for medicine.
detailedExplanation: This prostrate juniper is a staple in the world of bonsai and rock gardens due to its compact, cascading growth habit. It is valued purely for its aesthetic form and is not a medicinal plant. Source: General horticultural knowledge.

medicinalUses: The berries were a food source for Native Americans. The wood is used for fence posts and fuel.
sideEffects: Can irritate the kidneys with long-term use. Avoid during pregnancy.
preparation: Berries were eaten raw or ground into meal.
detailedExplanation: This juniper is an important component of piñon-juniper woodlands. Its berries, which typically contain a single seed, were a staple food for indigenous peoples. It is not a major commercial medicinal source. Source: General ethnobotanical knowledge.

medicinalUses: The berries can be used similarly to Common Juniper. The tree is widely planted as an ornamental.
sideEffects: Can irritate the kidneys with long-term use. Avoid during pregnancy.
preparation: Berries can be used for flavoring.
detailedExplanation: This species is known for its narrow, pyramidal form and silvery-blue foliage, making it a very popular ornamental tree. Its berries are sometimes used as a substitute for common juniper, but it is primarily a landscape tree. Source: General botanical knowledge.

medicinalUses: HIGHLY TOXIC. Historically used as an abortifacient, but extremely dangerous.
sideEffects: EXTREMELY TOXIC. Causes kidney failure, convulsions, and death.
preparation: Not for medicinal use.
detailedExplanation: This juniper is one of the most poisonous conifers. Its essential oil contains sabinyl acetate, which is a powerful abortifacient and severe kidney toxin. It has no safe medicinal application and must be strictly avoided. Source: https://www.poison.org/articles/savin-juniper

medicinalUses: The large, fleshy cones are edible and can be used to make a syrup or eaten raw.
sideEffects: Generally safe as a food.
preparation: The fruit is eaten or processed into syrup.
detailedExplanation: This juniper produces the largest "berries" of any species, which are sweet and fleshy. They are consumed locally as a food and are not a standard medicinal source. The tree is also valued for its durable wood. Source: General botanical knowledge.

medicinalUses: The berries were a food source for Native Americans. The tree is a dominant species in its ecosystem.
sideEffects: Can irritate the kidneys with long-term use. Avoid during pregnancy.
preparation: Berries were ground into a flour or eaten raw.
detailedExplanation: This is the most common juniper in the Great Basin region. Its berries were a crucial winter food source for indigenous tribes. Like other New World junipers, its medicinal use is secondary to its role as a food and ecological cornerstone. Source: General ethnobotanical knowledge.

medicinalUses: Primarily Ornamental. The young leaves are edible in salads.
sideEffects: Generally safe as a food.
preparation: Young leaves can be eaten raw.
detailedExplanation: This plant is a popular, drought-tolerant garden perennial known for its dense clusters of pink, red, or white flowers. It is not a significant medicinal herb but is sometimes foraged as a mild, edible green. Source: General horticultural knowledge.

medicinalUses: Used in Brazilian traditional medicine as a digestive tonic, for liver and stomach disorders, and anemia.
sideEffects: The unripe fruit is toxic. Only the ripe fruit and leaves are used.
preparation: A decoction or tincture is made from the leaves and ripe fruit.
detailedExplanation: This plant is a cornerstone of Brazilian folk medicine. Its name means "bitter herb," and it is considered a powerful digestive and liver tonic, used to stimulate appetite and treat hangovers and hepatitis. It contains steroidal alkaloids. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5871205/

medicinalUses: The leaves are a premier remedy for respiratory ailments; used as a bronchodilator and expectorant for asthma, bronchitis, and cough.
sideEffects: Generally safe in medicinal doses. High doses may cause nausea.
preparation: The leaves are dried and used in decoctions, syrups, or powders.
detailedExplanation: Also known as Malabar Nut, this is one of the most important herbs in Ayurveda for the respiratory system. The key alkaloid, vasicine, is a potent bronchodilator and expectorant, and is a precursor for the semi-synthetic drug bromhexine. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6273671/

medicinalUses: Used in Ayurveda for respiratory issues, rheumatism, and as a treatment for fever and headaches; also used topically for bruises and swelling.
sideEffects: Generally safe in medicinal doses.
preparation: The leaves are crushed and applied as a poultice or juiced for internal use.
detailedExplanation: This shrub is a close relative of the more famous Vasaka (Justicia adhatoda). It is used in various Asian traditional medicines for its anti-inflammatory and analgesic properties. Research has shown that extracts of the plant can have significant pain-relieving and fever-reducing effects. Source: https://www.jstage.jst.go.jp/article/jphs/131/2/131_16245/_pdf

medicinalUses: The leaves are a nutritious vegetable (see Jew's Mallow). The fiber is used to make burlap, hessian, and twine.
sideEffects: Generally safe as a food.
preparation: Leaves are cooked as a vegetable; stems are retted to extract fiber.
detailedExplanation: Jute is one of the most important natural fibers in the world, second only to cotton. While the leaves are edible and nutritious, the plant's primary global significance is economic, as the source of a strong, coarse fiber used for sacking and cordage. Source: General agricultural knowledge.

medicinalUses: The leaves are a nutritious vegetable, rich in vitamins and mucilage; used to soothe the digestive tract. The fiber is used to make burlap and twine.
sideEffects: Generally safe as a food.
preparation: Leaves are cooked as a vegetable; stems are retted to extract fiber.
detailedExplanation: Jute is one of the most important natural fibers in the world. While the leaves are edible and nutritious (becoming mucilaginous like okra when cooked), the plant's primary global significance is economic. It is a key crop for Bangladesh and India. Source: General agricultural knowledge.

medicinalUses: Leaves are a nutritious vegetable, rich in vitamins and mucilage; used to soothe the digestive tract.
sideEffects: Generally safe as a food.
preparation: Young leaves and shoots are cooked as a leafy green vegetable, often in soups and stews.
detailedExplanation: Known in Egyptian cuisine as "Molokhia," this plant is a highly nutritious leafy green, rich in vitamins A, C, and E, iron, and calcium. The leaves become mucilaginous when cooked, similar to okra, which helps soothe the digestive system. It is more of a nutritional powerhouse than a targeted medicinal herb. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6273554/

medicinalUses: * The bark is used as a febrifuge (reduces fever) and tonic. * Traditionally used for uterine complaints, skin diseases, and as a diuretic. * Has significant cultural importance, associated with Lord Krishna.
sideEffects: Safety is not well-established in modern studies. Use with caution.
regionsFound: South and Southeast Asia, including India.
preparation: Bark decoction.
detailedExplanation: The Kadamba tree is deeply embedded in Indian culture and folklore. In traditional medicine, particularly folk traditions, its bark has been used for a variety of ailments, most notably for reducing fever and as a general tonic. (Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3249903/)

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for medicinal purposes.
sideEffects: Information Missing
preparation: Information Missing
detailedExplanation: This East Asian pepper vine has a history of past medicinal use, though specific details are scarce. It only grows in warmer climates.

medicinalUses: The starchy pith of the trunk was traditionally used as a famine food after processing.
sideEffects: HIGHLY TOXIC if raw and improperly processed. Can cause liver and neurological damage.
preparation: Requires extensive traditional knowledge to process and detoxify.
detailedExplanation: This cycad is not a true bread tree. Its pith is a source of starch but contains potent toxins (cycasin). Traditional processing methods are crucial to make it safe for consumption, but it is generally not recommended due to high risk.

medicinalUses: Information Missing
sideEffects: Information Missing
preparation: Information Missing
detailedExplanation: This common name is not well-defined and may refer to several plants. Reliable information on its medicinal use is unavailable.

medicinalUses: Primarily Ornamental.
sideEffects: TOXIC. All parts, especially the bulbs, are poisonous. Causes vomiting, diarrhea, and salivation.
preparation: Not for medicinal use.
detailedExplanation: This popular houseplant is grown for its beautiful orange or yellow flowers. It contains lycorine and other alkaloids that are toxic to humans and animals if ingested.

medicinalUses: The leaves, rind, and juice are used in cooking and traditional medicine for digestion, skin health, and as an insect repellent.
sideEffects: Generally safe in culinary amounts. Can cause skin photosensitivity in some.
preparation: Leaves are used whole in curries; juice and zest are used in sauces and traditional remedies.
detailedExplanation: The distinctive double-lobed leaf is a staple in Southeast Asian cuisine. The rind is intensely aromatic and is used to add a sharp, citrus flavor to soups, curries, and pastes.

medicinalUses: The fruit is nutritious, rich in Vitamin C, antioxidants, and fiber; supports immune function and digestive health.
sideEffects: The fruit is tart; the seeds are not consumed.
preparation: The ripe fruit is eaten raw, made into jams, jellies, chutney, or smoothies.
detailedExplanation: This tree produces small, tart, red-to-purple fruit. It is a nutritional powerhouse, rich in vitamin C and antioxidants like anthocyanins. The name "Kaffir" is considered derogatory in some contexts, and it is increasingly called Sour Plum or Wild Plum.

medicinalUses: Primarily Ornamental. Research shows cytotoxic properties against certain cancer cells, but it is not for self-medication.
sideEffects: NOT EDIBLE. Can cause stomach upset if ingested.
regionsFound: Native to the Himalayas, invasive in Hawaii
preparation: Not used in herbal medicine. Its roots are not a substitute for culinary ginger.
detailedExplanation: This plant is known for its spectacular, fragrant yellow flower spikes. It is a major invasive species in many tropical areas, including Hawaii, where it disrupts native ecosystems. It is grown for its beauty, not for consumption.

medicinalUses: A nutritious vegetable; like broccoli, contains vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants for general health.
sideEffects: Generally safe as a food.
preparation: The stems, leaves, and flower heads are commonly stir-fried or steamed.
detailedExplanation: This vegetable is closely related to broccoli but has thinner stalks, larger leaves, and smaller florets. It is a common ingredient in Asian cuisines, valued for its slightly bitter and earthy flavor.

medicinalUses: Highly nutritious; rich in vitamins A, C, K; supports bone health, vision; contains sulforaphane with anti-cancer properties; aids cholesterol reduction.
sideEffects: High in vitamin K; may interact with blood thinners like warfarin. High in oxalates.
preparation: Eaten raw in salads, steamed, sautéed, or blended into smoothies.
detailedExplanation: Kail, more commonly known as Kale, is one of the most nutrient-dense leafy greens available. It is a cruciferous vegetable, packed with vitamins, minerals, and powerful antioxidants like quercetin and kaempferol.

medicinalUses: The world's richest known natural source of Vitamin C; extremely high in antioxidants (ellagic acid); supports immune function, skin health; has antimicrobial and anti-inflammatory properties.
sideEffects: Generally safe. Due to high acidity, excessive consumption may upset the stomach.
preparation: The fruit is traditionally eaten raw, but is now commonly dried and powdered for use in supplements, skincare products, and functional foods.
detailedExplanation: This plum is an endemic Australian bush food with a long history of use by Indigenous Australians. It holds the record for the highest natural vitamin C content of any food, measuring up to 14% of its dry weight.

medicinalUses: The seeds are used as a strong purgative, similar to Jalap.
sideEffects: TOXIC. A potent purgative; can cause severe cramping, nausea, and dehydration. Overdose is dangerous.
preparation: Used in very small, controlled doses in traditional medicine. Not for self-use.
detailedExplanation: This plant is a species of morning glory. Its seeds have powerful purgative properties and have been used in traditional medicine systems, but their strength and potential toxicity mean they should only be used by experienced practitioners.

medicinalUses: Powerful anthelmintic (expels worms), treats skin diseases, detoxifies blood, reduces blood sugar and blood pressure, diuretic, helps with asthma and cough-8.
sideEffects: Intensely bitter taste.
preparation: The fruits and seeds are used in powders, churnas, and rasayanas-8.
detailedExplanation: Known as "Jangli Jeera," it is not a true cumin. It is a highly valued herb in Ayurveda, primarily for its potent ability to kill intestinal worms and purify the blood, which is believed to be the root of many skin conditions-8.

medicinalUses: Powerful immunostimulant for colds and flu; hepatoprotective (liver-protecting); anti-inflammatory; antipyretic (fever-reducing).
sideEffects: Very bitter; can cause gastric upset, nausea, and loss of appetite in high doses.
preparation: The whole plant is used in decoctions, teas, tinctures, and capsules.
detailedExplanation: Known as the "King of Bitters," Kalmegh is a cornerstone of Ayurvedic and traditional Chinese medicine. It is renowned for its ability to boost the immune system at the onset of colds and for its strong protective and healing effects on the liver.

medicinalUses: * The red powder (Kamala) from the fruit is a powerful anthelmintic for expelling tapeworms. * It is a strong purgative (laxative). * Used topically for parasitic skin infections like scabies and ringworm.
sideEffects: TOXIC. Can cause severe nausea, vomiting, and abdominal cramping. Overdose is dangerous. Its use as a purgative is harsh and unpredictable.
preparation: The red glandular powder from the fruit capsules, used in professionally prescribed doses.
detailedExplanation: The key product of this tree is the brick-red powder covering its fruit, known as Kamala. It was a standard and effective, though harsh, traditional remedy for tapeworms before the advent of modern, safer drugs. It is also a source of a natural dye. (Source: https://www.henriettes-herbal.com/eclectic/usdisp/mallotus.html)

medicinalUses: The red powder from the fruit is a potent anthelmintic (expels worms); also used for skin wounds and as a natural dye.
sideEffects: The dye is for short-term use only. Can cause stomach discomfort.
preparation: The fruit covering is collected, dried, and powdered for use in decoctions or topical pastes.
detailedExplanation: This tree is known for the bright red, powdery coating on its fruits, which is used as both a medicine and a natural dye for silk and wool (giving a characteristic orange-red color).

medicinalUses: The oil from the seeds is used topically for skin ailments (psoriasis, eczema), wounds, and inflammation; known as Tamanu Oil.
sideEffects: Generally safe for topical use. May cause allergic reactions in some.
regionsFound: Coasts of India, Southeast Asia, Pacific
preparation: The nut is cold-pressed to extract the oil, which is applied directly to the skin.
detailedExplanation: This coastal tree produces a remarkable green oil that is a prized ingredient in cosmetics and traditional medicine. The oil is known for its skin-regenerating, anti-inflammatory, and antimicrobial properties.

medicinalUses: The wood is valuable for timber. Not known for significant medicinal use.
sideEffects: Information Missing
preparation: Not used in herbal medicine.
detailedExplanation: This tree is native to South Africa and is prized for its hard, yellow wood, which is used for making furniture and musical instruments. It is not a prominent feature in traditional medicine.

medicinalUses: The bulbs are edible and were a traditional food source for Indigenous peoples.
sideEffects: TOXIC if raw. Bulbs must be cooked or processed to remove bitterness and toxins.
preparation: Bulbs were traditionally steamed, pit-cooked, or dried for preservation.
detailedExplanation: This striking lily with dark, chocolate-colored flowers is found in coastal meadows. While its bulbs are a starchy food, it is not primarily known as a medicinal plant but rather as a survival food.

medicinalUses: Not a typical medicinal plant. The bark is used for tannins, and the wood for construction and fuel.
sideEffects: No known hazards.
preparation: Not used for medicinal preparation.
detailedExplanation: This plant is a type of mangrove tree that plays a crucial role in coastal ecosystems. It is not known for uses in mainstream herbal medicine but is utilized locally for practical purposes like tanning leather and as a source of timber and fuelwood.

medicinalUses: Unripe fruit is toxic. Ripe fruit is edible. Traditionally, unripe fruit was processed for contraceptive use; leaves and unripe fruit used in poultices for swollen joints-2.
sideEffects: TOXIC when unripe. Contains solasodine. Can cause nausea, vomiting, and other serious symptoms if ingested before fully ripe-2.
preparation: Ripe fruit only can be eaten fresh or made into jam. Unripe fruit requires complex processing not for self-use-2.
detailedExplanation: This shrub produces fruits that are only safe to eat when fully ripe and have split their skin. It contains steroid alkaloids, which have been researched for the production of contraceptive steroids-2.

medicinalUses: Highly nutritious seeds were a traditional food source ground into flour-6. Used in treating horse metabolic disorders; researched for human food due to high protein and mineral content-6.
sideEffects: Generally safe as a food.
preparation: Seeds can be harvested and ground into flour for making bread or porridge-6.
detailedExplanation: This is a native Australian grass with a 30,000-year history as a staple food for Aboriginal Australians-6. Modern research is investigating its potential as a sustainable, perennial grain crop due to its drought resistance and high nutritional value (40% more protein than wheat)-6.

medicinalUses: Primarily Ornamental. Research is investigating potential skin-firming properties via collagen stimulation.
sideEffects: Not an edible or medicinal plant.
preparation: Not used in herbal medicine.
detailedExplanation: This plant is famous for its unique, velvety flowers that resemble a kangaroo's paw-5-7. It is the state emblem of Western Australia and is cultivated worldwide as an ornamental garden plant and cut flower-5-7.

medicinalUses:
• Elevates mood and decreases anxiety.
• Reduces stress and tension.
• Can act as an appetite suppressant.
sideEffects: Headache, mild nausea, drowsiness at higher doses.
preparation: Fermented dried leaves are traditionally chewed. Modern use: capsules, extracts, tinctures, or tea.
detailedExplanation: A psychoactive plant used for centuries by San and Khoikhoi people of Southern Africa. It is not hallucinogenic but is known for producing a state of relaxed alertness and euphoria. It's gaining global attention as a natural mood enhancer. (Source: https://examine.com/supplements/sceletium-tortuosum/)

medicinalUses: Local traditional uses include aromatic tonic and digestive support; floral extracts used in perfumery and community remedies.
sideEffects: Minimal toxicity in mild use; contact sensitivity rare.
preparation: Flower infusion, oil extracts.
detailedExplanation: Artabotrys uncinatus is used locally for aromatic and mild tonic effects; ethnobotanical detail varies regionally. Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artabotrys_uncinatus.

medicinalUses:
• Potent anti-inflammatory.
• Strong antifungal and antibacterial properties.
• Used topically for skin infections, acne, and muscle aches.
sideEffects: Generally safe for topical use. Skin irritation is possible in sensitive individuals. Internal use is not well-studied.
preparation: Essential oil for topical application; Creams and balms; Traditional decoctions of leaves and bark.
detailedExplanation: Often confused with its famous cousin, Manuka, Kanuka is a powerful medicinal plant in its own right, traditionally used by the Māori people. Its essential oil has a different chemical profile and is highly regarded for its anti-inflammatory effects. (Source: https://www.nzpcn.org.nz/flora/species/kunzea-ericoides-var-ericoides/)

medicinalUses:
• Bark is astringent, used for diarrhea and dysentery.
• Flowers and roots used as a tonic and diuretic.
• Gum used for bowel complaints.
sideEffects: The seed floss (kapok fiber) can be an irritant to the eyes and respiratory tract.
preparation: Bark decoction; Powdered gum; Flower infusions.
detailedExplanation: Known globally as the Silk-Cotton Tree, its primary economic value is the fluffy, water-resistant fiber from its seed pods. In traditional medicine (including Ayurveda), the bark is highly valued for its astringent properties to treat gastrointestinal issues. (Source: https://www.worldagroforestry.org/treedb/AFDbases.php?Treedb=Ceiba+pentandra)

medicinalUses:
• Used as a stimulant and tonic.
• Promotes hair growth and scalp health.
• Used for respiratory issues like asthma and bronchitis.
• Pain relief (analgesic).
sideEffects: Generally safe when used externally or in prescribed doses. Overuse could cause stomach upset.
regionsFound: Himalayan regions of India and Nepal.
preparation: Powdered rhizome (for hair masks); Decoction; Essential oil for aromatherapy.
detailedExplanation: Also known as Spiked Ginger Lily, this is an aromatic herb highly prized in Ayurveda and perfumery. Its powdered root is a key ingredient in traditional hair care powders for strengthening roots and adding fragrance. (Source: https://pfaf.org/user/Plant.aspx?LatinName=Hedychium+spicatum)

medicinalUses:
• Used traditionally as a kidney tonic and diuretic.
• Bark and leaves used to treat bladder and urinary tract issues.
• Berries used to make a yellow dye.
sideEffects: The plant itself is not known to be toxic, but medicinal use requires knowledge of proper preparation.
preparation: Decoction of the leaves and bark.
detailedExplanation: A very important plant in Māori traditional medicine (Rongoā Māori). It is known as a cleansing herb, particularly for the kidneys and bladder. Its vibrant berries were also a key source of dye. (Source: https://www.landcareresearch.co.nz/resources/teaching/maori-plant-use-database/plant-list/karamu-coprosma-robusta)

medicinalUses:
• Unripe fruit is astringent, used for digestive issues.
• Ripe fruit is rich in Vitamin C and iron, used to treat anemia.
• Root used as a stomachic and for pain.
sideEffects: Overconsumption of unripe fruit may cause stomach discomfort.
preparation: Eaten as a fruit; Made into pickles and jams; Root decoction or powder.
detailedExplanation: A hardy, spiny shrub famous for its berry-sized fruits that are extremely sour when unripe and pleasantly tart when ripe. It's a very common sight in Indian markets, used more as a culinary and nutritional item than a purely medicinal one. (Source: https://hort.purdue.edu/newcrop/morton/karanda.html)

medicinalUses:
• Acts as a bulk-forming laxative to treat constipation.
• Promotes a feeling of fullness, aiding weight management.
• Used as a binder and stabilizer in pharmaceuticals.
sideEffects: Can cause bloating, gas, or esophageal blockage if not taken with sufficient water.
preparation: Powdered gum mixed with a full glass of water or juice.
detailedExplanation: This gum is a natural exudate from the Karaya tree. Medicinally, it functions almost identically to Psyllium (Isabgol), absorbing large amounts of water in the gut to form a soft, bulky gel that aids bowel movements. It's also used in the food industry (E416). (Source: https://www.drugs.com/npp/karaya-gum.html)

medicinalUses: Wound healing, anti-ulcer
sideEffects: None known
preparation: Bark decoction
detailedExplanation: Kardhai is an Aravalli tree used for healing wounds and stomach ulcers. Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anogeissus_pendula

medicinalUses:
• Traditionally used as a poultice for wounds, sores, and swellings.
• Used to treat hemorrhoids.
• A root infusion is used for internal ailments and pain.
sideEffects: Unknown. Should be used with caution as it is not a widely studied plant.
preparation: Poultice of crushed leaves; Root infusion or decoction.
detailedExplanation: A low-growing, drought-resistant plant from the Karoo region of South Africa, known for its velvety leaves and violet flowers. Its use is confined to traditional African medicine, where it is valued for its wound-healing properties. (Source: http://pza.sanbi.org/aptosimum-procumbens)

medicinalUses:
• Not a primary medicinal plant.
• Like other Eucalyptus, leaves contain aromatic oils, but it is not commercially harvested for this purpose.
sideEffects: Inhalation of any smoke is harmful. Essential oils from Eucalyptus can be toxic if ingested.
preparation: (Not applicable for standard preparation).
detailedExplanation: One of the tallest hardwood trees in the world, the Karri is prized for its strong, high-quality timber. While it belongs to the Eucalyptus genus, its medicinal use is virtually non-existent compared to species like Eucalyptus globulus (Blue Gum). (Source: https://www.anbg.gov.au/gnp/gnp9/eucalyptus-diversicolor.html)

medicinalUses: Anti-inflammatory, tonic, digestive aid
sideEffects: Rare
preparation: Leaf decoction, root extract
detailedExplanation: Used in Kashmir for tonic and digestive purposes, with anti-inflammatory properties. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK92771/

medicinalUses:
• Primary use is ornamental for its intense fragrance.
• Traditionally, the bark is used to make high-quality paper.
sideEffects: All parts of the plant are HIGHLY TOXIC if ingested. Can cause severe stomach pain, vomiting, internal bleeding, and can be fatal. Skin contact can cause dermatitis.
preparation: Not used for medicinal preparation due to toxicity.
detailedExplanation: This is a cultivar of the Nepalese Paper Plant, selected for its powerful and beautiful winter fragrance. It is a popular ornamental garden shrub. It should NOT be considered a medicinal plant for internal or casual topical use. (Source: https://www.rhs.org.uk/plants/98801/daphne-bholua-kashmir-bouquet/details)

medicinalUses: Primarily Ornamental. The wood is used for timber and the essential oil may have aromatic properties.
sideEffects: Not a medicinal plant.
preparation: Not used in herbal medicine.
detailedExplanation: This tree is famous for its stunning, weeping, silvery-blue foliage and is considered one of the most beautiful conifers in the world. It is primarily grown as an ornamental specimen and for its valuable timber, not for medicinal purposes. Source: General botanical knowledge.

medicinalUses: The sour fruit is edible and rich in Vitamin C; used to make jams and sauces. The bark and leaves are used in traditional medicine for coughs and stomach aches.
sideEffects: The fruit is very acidic.
preparation: The fruit is cooked into jams or used as a souring agent. A decoction is made from the bark and leaves.
detailedExplanation: This is the national tree of the Philippines. Its flower buds are also edible. Beyond its nutritional value, various parts of the tree are used in Filipino folk medicine for their astringent and anti-inflammatory properties. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6273554/

medicinalUses: Primarily Ornamental. Not used in herbal medicine.
sideEffects: No known medicinal use or toxicity.
preparation: Not used in herbal medicine.
detailedExplanation: This tree is cultivated for its beautiful heart-shaped leaves and spectacular fall color, which emits a sweet, caramel-like fragrance. It is a prized ornamental tree in gardens and parks, with no significant history of medicinal use. Source: General botanical knowledge.

medicinalUses: Used to reduce anxiety and stress, promote relaxation and sleep, and as a social beverage.
sideEffects: Drowsiness, stomach upset. Heavy, long-term use can cause a scaly skin rash and liver toxicity.
preparation: The root is traditionally ground and prepared as a cold-water beverage. Also available in capsules and tinctures.
detailedExplanation: Kava is a cornerstone of Pacific Islander culture, used in ceremonies and social gatherings. Its active compounds, kavalactones, act as central nervous system depressants, producing a state of calm relaxation without impairing cognitive function. However, its potential for liver damage has led to restrictions in some countries. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK927574/

medicinalUses: The leaves are used topically for skin boils, wounds, and eczema; internally for digestive issues, toothache, and bladder problems.
sideEffects: Generally safe.
preparation: Leaves are brewed into a tea or applied directly as a poultice to wounds.
detailedExplanation: This plant is one of the most important traditional Maori medicinal plants. The heart-shaped leaves, often marked with holes from insect feeding, are chewed to relieve toothache or prepared in various ways to treat a wide range of ailments from skin infections to internal pain. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5871205/

medicinalUses: Rare plant. Not known for medicinal use.
sideEffects: Information Missing.
preparation: Not used in herbal medicine.
detailedExplanation: This plant is a rare, endemic species found only in specific habitats in California. It is of interest primarily to botanists and conservationists and has no documented history of medicinal use. Source: General botanical knowledge.

medicinalUses: Primarily Ornamental. Not known for significant medicinal use.
sideEffects: Information Missing.
preparation: Not used in herbal medicine.
detailedExplanation: This genus of shrubs is native to California and is valued for its attractive, tubular flowers that are an important food source for hummingbirds. It is not a feature of any major herbal tradition. Source: General botanical knowledge.

medicinalUses: The dried bark is a strong stimulant laxative used for chronic constipation.
sideEffects: STRONG LAXATIVE. Can cause severe cramping, diarrhea, and electrolyte imbalance. Habitual use leads to dependency.
preparation: The aged bark is used in decoctions or tinctures. Not for long-term use.
detailedExplanation: The name "Keek" is a less common name for Cascara Sagrada, which means "sacred bark." It was a primary ingredient in many over-the-counter laxatives for decades. However, due to safety concerns about its potential to cause severe cramping and dependency, its use has declined and it is now regulated in many countries. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK548202/

medicinalUses: * Excellent natural source of iodine, crucial for thyroid function. * Rich in vitamins (K, A, Folate) and minerals (Iron, Calcium, Magnesium). * Contains antioxidants like fucoxanthin and fucoidan.
sideEffects: Risk of iodine-induced hyperthyroidism or hypothyroidism if taken in excess. Potential contamination with heavy metals (e.g., arsenic) depending on the source water.
preparation: Eaten as a sea vegetable; Dried and ground into powder for supplements (capsules) or as a salt substitute.
detailedExplanation: Kelp is not a single plant but a large brown seaweed that grows in underwater "forests." It is a foundational food in many coastal cuisines. Its primary medicinal value comes from its exceptionally high concentration of iodine, which is essential for healthy thyroid function. (Source: https://ods.od.nih.gov/factsheets/Iodine-HealthProfessional/)

medicinalUses: * Excellent source of iodine. * Contains vitamins and minerals. * Contains mannitol, which gives it a sweet taste and has diuretic properties. * Source of fucoidan, an anti-inflammatory and antiviral compound.
sideEffects: Same as other kelps: potential for iodine overload and heavy metal contamination.
preparation: Eaten raw, cooked as a sea vegetable, or dried. Used to flavor broths and stews.
detailedExplanation: A specific species of kelp, also known as Sugar Wrack, notable for its sweet taste which comes from a sugar alcohol called mannitol. It is both a nutritious sea vegetable and a subject of research for its bioactive compounds like fucoidan. (Source: https://www.marlin.ac.uk/species/detail/1333)

medicinalUses: * Very high in Calcium, Iodine, Iron, and Magnesium. * Rich in Vitamin B group. * Contains Fucoxanthin, a carotenoid antioxidant studied for anti-obesity effects.
sideEffects: Same as other kelps: potential for iodine overload and heavy metal contamination.
regionsFound: Cold waters of the North Atlantic Ocean.
preparation: Traditionally eaten in soups, stews, and salads. Can be dried and used as flakes or powder.
detailedExplanation: Also known as Dabberlocks or Atlantic Wakame, this seaweed is recognized by the prominent midrib running through its frond. It is a highly nutritious food source, and its notable compound, fucoxanthin, is being actively researched for its potential to target fat cells. (Source: https://www.seaweed.ie/descriptions/Alaria_esculenta.php)

medicinalUses: * Primarily an industrial plant, not medicinal. * Leaves (Ambadi Bhaji) are eaten as a vegetable and have mild laxative properties. * Seed oil is a source of Omega-6 fatty acids. * Some folk use of flowers for pain relief.
sideEffects: Generally safe when leaves are consumed as a food. No significant side effects are widely reported.
regionsFound: Old World tropics (Asia, Africa), cultivated widely.
preparation: Leaves are cooked as a vegetable (bhaji). Stems are processed for fiber. Seeds are pressed for oil.
detailedExplanation: Kenaf is a plant in the same family as okra and cotton, grown mainly for its fiber, which is used to make paper, rope, and textiles. While its leaves are a nutritious food in some cultures, it has no significant or validated role in modern or traditional medicine. (Source: https://hort.purdue.edu/newcrop/afcm/kenaf.html)

medicinalUses: * No recognized medicinal benefits. * Historically, it was sometimes used as a folk remedy for scurvy (due to Vitamin C) or as a mild astringent, but this is obsolete and not recommended.
sideEffects: Unknown. Not considered edible or safe for consumption.
regionsFound: Native to Southern Europe, now a worldwide weed.
preparation: Not applicable. Preparation is not recommended.
detailedExplanation: This is a common trailing plant found on old walls and in pavement cracks, often considered a pretty weed. Despite its name, it is not a true ivy. It has no established medicinal uses, and historical folk applications are not supported by any scientific evidence. (Source: https://www.missouribotanicalgarden.org/PlantFinder/PlantFinderDetails.aspx?taxonid=286926)

medicinalUses: * No medicinal benefits. * Its primary use is for creating lawns and for animal pasture.
sideEffects: Pollen is a major cause of seasonal allergies (hay fever).
regionsFound: Native to Europe/Asia, common in temperate lawns.
preparation: Not applicable.
detailedExplanation: This is one of the most common turf and pasture grasses in the world, prized for its dense, durable sod. It has no medicinal value. Its primary relevance to human health is negative, as its wind-borne pollen is a significant trigger for seasonal allergic rhinitis. (Source: https://www.fs.usda.gov/database/feis/plants/graminoid/poapra/all.html)

medicinalUses: * No modern medicinal use due to toxicity. * Historically, Native Americans used a pulp from the pods for nervous system ailments and laxative purposes, requiring expert preparation.
sideEffects: Highly Toxic. Raw seeds, pods, and leaves contain the alkaloid cytisine, which can cause vomiting, stomach pain, confusion, and respiratory distress if ingested.
preparation: Expert preparation required. Seeds must be roasted thoroughly to neutralize toxins before they can be ground as a coffee substitute. Not for medicinal preparation.
detailedExplanation: The common name is misleading as it's not related to coffee. This is a tough ornamental tree whose most important characteristic is the toxicity of its raw parts. The seeds were historically roasted by settlers to create a caffeine-free coffee substitute. (Source: https://www.fs.usda.gov/database/feis/plants/tree/gymdio/all.html)

medicinalUses: * No recognized medicinal benefits. * The heartwood contains compounds that produce a clear yellow dye.
sideEffects: The bark, seeds, and leaves are reported to be mildly toxic if ingested. Not for consumption.
preparation: Not applicable. Bark was historically boiled to extract dye.
detailedExplanation: A beautiful, medium-sized ornamental tree prized for its long, fragrant, wisteria-like flower clusters and smooth, gray bark. Its name comes from the yellow color of its heartwood, which was a source for dye, but it has no validated medicinal applications. (Source: https://www.missouribotanicalgarden.org/PlantFinder/PlantFinderDetails.aspx?taxonid=280457)

medicinalUses: Source of catechu (kattha) — astringent, haemostatic, used for diarrhoea, oral health, and wound contracts.
sideEffects: Excessive tannin intake may cause constipation or reduce mineral absorption.
preparation: Heartwood processed into extract (catechu) for use in lozenges, mouth rinses and decoctions.
detailedExplanation: Khair yields powerful astringent extracts used in traditional remedies and dental care; catechu preparation is an important botanical product. Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Acacia_catechu

medicinalUses: Diuretic, anti-inflammatory
sideEffects: Rare
preparation: Leaf decoction
detailedExplanation: Alternanthera pungens is used in traditional medicine for anti-inflammatory and diuretic purposes. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK92771/

medicinalUses: * Excellent source of plant-based protein and dietary fiber. * Low glycemic index helps stabilize blood sugar. * High fiber content supports digestive health and lowers cholesterol. * Rich in folate, iron, and magnesium.
sideEffects: Can cause gas and bloating due to high fiber content. Raw or undercooked beans are highly toxic.
preparation: Must be thoroughly cooked (boiled) before consumption. Canned beans are pre-cooked.
detailedExplanation: A variety of the common bean, named for its shape and color. It is a nutritional powerhouse and a staple food globally. Its medicinal value lies in its nutritional profile, which can help manage conditions like type 2 diabetes and high cholesterol when part of a balanced diet. (Source: https://www.hsph.harvard.edu/nutritionsource/food-features/kidney-beans/)

medicinalUses: * Primarily grown for fiber. * Root bark was used in traditional/folk medicine as a uterine stimulant to induce labor or menstruation, but this is a dangerous and obsolete use.
sideEffects: Use of root bark is highly risky and can cause uterine complications. No side effects from commercial cotton fiber.
preparation: Not for medicinal preparation. Fiber is processed for textiles.
detailedExplanation: This is a specific variety of upland cotton, the most widely planted species of cotton in the world. Its main value is the production of cotton fiber. While its roots contain compounds with physiological activity, its use in medicine is not safe or recommended. (Source: https://www.worldfloraonline.org/taxon/wfo-0000454641)

medicinalUses: * Traditionally used as a diuretic and for kidney and bladder ailments (Doctrine of Signatures). * The name "vulneraria" means "wound healer"; it was used topically as a poultice for wounds, sores, and rashes.
sideEffects: Generally considered safe for topical use. Internal use is not well-studied and not recommended without guidance.
preparation: Poultice of fresh flowers and leaves; Dried flowers for infusions (teas).
detailedExplanation: A low-growing plant with distinctive yellow (sometimes red) flower heads. Its common name and scientific name point to its two main uses in European folk medicine: for kidney support and for wound healing. Modern scientific evidence for these claims is lacking. (Source: https://pfaf.org/user/Plant.aspx?LatinName=Anthyllis+vulneraria)

medicinalUses: * Traditionally used topically for skin ailments. * The fresh leaves were applied as a cooling poultice to soothe minor burns, scrapes, and inflammation. * Juice was used for chilblains and warts.
sideEffects: Not generally consumed. Unknown toxicity if ingested in quantity. Safe for minor topical use.
preparation: Fresh leaves are crushed to make a poultice or the juice is applied directly.
detailedExplanation: This succulent plant grows on stone walls and rocks, and its round leaves have a central depression resembling a navel. Its traditional use is almost entirely external, valued for the cooling, soothing, jelly-like pulp inside its leaves. (Source: https://pfaf.org/user/Plant.aspx?LatinName=Umbilicus+rupestris)

medicinalUses: * Widely used in African traditional medicine for skin conditions like eczema, psoriasis, and fungal infections. * Fruit extract is used in cosmetics for its purported skin-firming and anti-aging effects. * Bark used for treating sores and rheumatism.
sideEffects: The raw, fresh fruit is reported to be poisonous if ingested. Only properly prepared extracts are used. Skin irritation is possible with topical products.
preparation: Topical creams, ointments, and lotions made from fruit extracts. Traditional preparations use dried fruit powder or bark decoctions.
detailedExplanation: A tree easily identified by its large, sausage-shaped fruits that hang from long stalks. It is one of the most important medicinal plants in Africa. Its fruit contains potent anti-inflammatory, antimicrobial, and antioxidant compounds, making it a focus for both traditional use and modern cosmetic science. (Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3731872/)

medicinalUses: * No medicinal benefits for humans. * Valued as a durable, fast-growing lawn and pasture grass for livestock.
sideEffects: Pollen is a significant allergen for some people. Can accumulate high levels of nitrates, potentially causing nitrate poisoning in grazing livestock, especially after drought and rain.
preparation: Not applicable.
detailedExplanation: A highly vigorous grass named after the Kikuyu people of Kenya. It spreads aggressively and is valued for forage and turf in warm climates, but is also considered a noxious, invasive weed in many other regions. It has no medicinal value. (Source: https://www.cabi.org/isc/datasheet/43039)

medicinalUses: Hepatoprotective, anti-inflammatory, antipyretic
sideEffects: Rare; may cause GI upset
preparation: Leaf decoction, extract
detailedExplanation: Kalmegh is a well-known Indian medicinal herb used for liver support, fever reduction, and anti-inflammatory purposes. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK92771/

medicinalUses: * Primarily ornamental. * In traditional South African medicine, a syrup or infusion made from the nectar of the flower head was used as a remedy for coughs and chest congestion.
sideEffects: No significant side effects are reported from its limited traditional use. The plant itself is not consumed.
preparation: A sweet syrup is made by boiling the nectar-rich flower heads.
detailedExplanation: The national flower of South Africa, this plant is famous for having the largest flower head in the Protea genus. It is a globally popular ornamental cut flower. Its medicinal use is minor, confined to a traditional cough syrup made from its abundant nectar. (Source: http://pza.sanbi.org/protea-cynaroides)

medicinalUses: * Minor folk remedy. * Historically used by some Native American tribes in a manner similar to other members of the genus, as a tonic or for certain urinary or respiratory ailments.
sideEffects: Safety is not well-documented. Generally not recommended for use due to lack of information.
preparation: Root/corm infusions or decoctions.
detailedExplanation: A small, grass-like plant with yellow, star-shaped flowers. It is the North American cousin of the well-known African Potato (Hypoxis hemerocallidea), a famous medicinal plant. However, this American species is not well-researched and its medicinal use is obscure and not validated. (Source: https://www.illinoiswildflowers.info/prairie/plantx/yl_stgrassx.htm)

medicinalUses: Digestive aid, carminative
sideEffects: Rare
preparation: Powdered seeds
detailedExplanation: Amomum kingii is a rare northeastern Indian spice used for digestion and as a culinary flavoring. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK92771/

medicinalUses: * No established medicinal use. * Some Native American groups reportedly used the plant as a food source (cooked greens) and as a minor folk remedy for stomach issues, similar to other clovers.
sideEffects: Generally safe when consumed as a minor food item. Eating large amounts of raw clover is not recommended.
preparation: Leaves and flowers eaten as a cooked green or used to make a tea.
detailedExplanation: A species of clover native to mountainous regions of the western U.S. It is an important plant for local ecosystems and a food source for wildlife. Its use by humans is very limited and not well documented, falling into the category of a minor wild edible or obscure folk remedy. (Source: https://www.fs.usda.gov/wildflowers/plant-of-the-week/trifolium_kingii.shtml)

medicinalUses: * A premier adaptogen: helps the body resist physical, chemical, and environmental stress. * Fights fatigue and improves mental and physical performance. * May help alleviate symptoms of mild depression and anxiety.
sideEffects: Mild side effects can include dizziness, dry mouth, or headache. Can be over-stimulating for some, causing insomnia if taken late in the day.
regionsFound: Cold, high-altitude regions of North America/Eurasia.
preparation: Root and rhizome extract in the form of capsules, tablets, or tinctures.
detailedExplanation: A powerful adaptogenic herb that grows in harsh, cold environments. King's Crown is a North American species, while Rhodiola rosea is the more studied Eurasian species. They are used interchangeably for their ability to enhance energy, mood, and focus, and to build resilience to stress. (Source: https://www.nccih.nih.gov/health/rhodiola)

medicinalUses: Source of Gamma-linolenic acid (GLA); used for eczema, rheumatoid arthritis, premenstrual syndrome (PMS), and menopausal symptoms.
sideEffects: Mild stomach upset, headache.
preparation: The oil is cold-pressed from the seeds and taken in capsules.
detailedExplanation: This plant gets its grand name from its historical use as a versatile folk remedy. Modern use is centered on its seed oil, which is rich in GLA, a rare omega-6 fatty acid that the body converts into anti-inflammatory compounds. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK927574/

medicinalUses: The root is a traditional vermifuge (expels worms) and used for treating jaundice and rheumatism.
sideEffects: Generally safe in medicinal doses.
preparation: A decoction is made from the root.
detailedExplanation: This large and stately fern has a history of use in European folk medicine. The root contains tannins and mucilage, which contribute to its astringent and soothing properties. It is also a popular ornamental plant for damp gardens. Source: https://www.henriettes-herb.com/eclectic/kings/osmunda.html

medicinalUses: Critically Endangered. Not used in medicine. It is a "paleoendemic," known for being one of the oldest and rarest plants on Earth.
sideEffects: Not applicable.
preparation: Not used.
detailedExplanation: This plant is of immense botanical interest, not medicinal. It is a clone that has been genetically identical for over 43,000 years, reproducing solely vegetatively. There is only one population left in the wild, and it is a top conservation priority. Source: https://www.tas.gov.au/tasmanian-herbarium/tasmanian-flora/king039s-holly-lomatia-tasmanica

medicinalUses: Primarily Ornamental. Not known for significant medicinal use.
sideEffects: Not a medicinal plant.
preparation: Not used in herbal medicine.
detailedExplanation: This shrub is popular in tropical and subtropical landscaping for its attractive, trumpet-shaped purple or white flowers that bloom throughout the year. Its value is purely aesthetic. Source: General horticultural knowledge.

medicinalUses: The root is used to soothe inflamed tissues, tendons, and ligaments; as a demulcent for dry coughs; and to topically treat bruises.
sideEffects: Generally safe.
preparation: The root is dried and used in decoctions, tinctures, or salves.
detailedExplanation: The name comes from the seal-like scars on the rootstock. It is a premier herb in Western herbalism for musculoskeletal injuries, particularly for its ability to "knit" tissues and reduce pain and inflammation in joints and tendons. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK927574/

medicinalUses: Primarily Ornamental. The roots and young shoots are reportedly edible.
sideEffects: Not a medicinal plant.
preparation: Not used in herbal medicine.
detailedExplanation: This plant is grown for its tall, striking spikes of bright yellow flowers. While it has been used as a food source in some Mediterranean cultures, it is not a feature of modern herbal medicine. Source: General botanical knowledge.

medicinalUses: * No safe medicinal use. * Historically used in folk medicine for warts, cramps, and other ailments, but this is extremely risky due to its toxicity.
sideEffects: Highly Toxic. All parts of the fresh plant are poisonous. Ingestion can cause severe irritation of the mouth and digestive tract, vomiting, diarrhea, and dizziness. Skin contact can cause blisters.
regionsFound: Temperate regions of the Northern Hemisphere.
preparation: Not for preparation. The plant must be thoroughly cooked to break down toxins before it is considered edible (as potherbs), but this is only for experts.
detailedExplanation: A beautiful, cheerful-looking wetland plant with bright yellow flowers, often one of the first to bloom in spring. Despite its harmless appearance, the raw plant is toxic and should not be used for medicine or eaten raw under any circumstances. (Source: https://www.poison.org/articles/marsh-marigold-203)

medicinalUses: * No established medicinal use. * Prized as a highly sought-after ornamental garden plant for its sky-blue flowers. * Like other poppies, it contains alkaloids, but not morphine.
sideEffects: Potentially toxic. The alkaloid content and safety for consumption are unknown.
preparation: Not applicable.
detailedExplanation: A species of Himalayan blue poppy named after the plant explorer Frank Kingdon-Ward. These plants are legendary among horticulturalists for their stunning beauty and difficulty in cultivation. They have no history of medicinal use and should be considered purely ornamental. (Source: https://www.rhs.org.uk/plants/10986/meconopsis-kingdon-wardii/details)

medicinalUses: The leaves are a powerful astringent and diuretic; used specifically for urinary tract infections (UTIs) and cystitis.
sideEffects: Can cause nausea. High doses or long-term use can be hard on the liver. Not for use during pregnancy.
preparation: The leaves are dried and brewed into a tea.
detailedExplanation: This low-growing, trailing shrub is a classic remedy for UTIs. Its effectiveness is due to arbutin, which converts in the body to hydroquinone, a potent antimicrobial. It requires alkaline urine to be most effective. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK927574/

medicinalUses: The resin and heartwood are used in Ayurveda for diabetes, diarrhea, and skin diseases. The wood is used to make vessels for drinking water to help manage blood sugar.
sideEffects: Generally safe.
preparation: The resin is used in powders; water is stored in wooden cups made from the heartwood overnight and drunk in the morning.
detailedExplanation: This tree is highly valued in Ayurveda. Its heartwood contains active compounds like pterostilbene and marsupin, which have demonstrated significant anti-diabetic and lipid-lowering effects in scientific studies. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3609276/

medicinalUses: The roots and leaves are used for a wide range of ailments: jaundice, fever, wounds, and as a painkiller.
sideEffects: Information Missing.
preparation: A decoction is made from the roots or leaves; leaves are crushed for poultices.
detailedExplanation: This widespread tropical shrub is a common ingredient in traditional medicine across its native range. It contains alkaloids like securinine, which has shown stimulant effects on the central nervous system in laboratory studies. Source: https://www.jstage.jst.go.jp/article/jphs/131/2/131_16245/_pdf

medicinalUses: Primarily Ornamental. Not used in herbal medicine.
sideEffects: Not a medicinal plant.
preparation: Not used in herbal medicine.
detailedExplanation: This plant is a popular, drought-tolerant annual known for its vibrant, jewel-colored flowers that open in full sun. It is grown exclusively for its ornamental value in gardens, containers, and rockeries. Source: General horticultural knowledge.

medicinalUses: The leaves are a classic respiratory remedy; used as an expectorant for bronchitis, asthma, and colds; also used topically for sprains.
sideEffects: Generally safe.
preparation: The leaves are dried and brewed into a tea or used to make a tincture or syrup.
detailedExplanation: The name "Yerba Santa" means "holy herb" in Spanish, reflecting its high regard as a medicine. It is a stimulating expectorant, helping to thin and expel mucus from the lungs. It has a distinctive, sticky, and bitter taste. Source: https://www.henriettes-herb.com/eclectic/kings/eriodictyon.html

medicinalUses: The fruit is a nutritional powerhouse; extremely high in Vitamin C, antioxidants, and fiber; supports immune function and digestive health.
sideEffects: Generally safe. Can cause allergic reactions in some individuals.
preparation: The fruit is eaten raw, juiced, or used in smoothies.
detailedExplanation: The kiwi fruit is one of the most nutrient-dense fruits available. It contains an enzyme called actinidin that aids in the digestion of proteins. Its high vitamin C content is crucial for immune function and collagen synthesis. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6273554/

medicinalUses: Primarily Timber. The wood is highly valued for construction and veneer. Not a medicinal plant.
sideEffects: Not applicable.
preparation: Not used in herbal medicine.
detailedExplanation: This massive tree is one of the tallest tropical trees in the world. It is a key species for the timber industry in New Guinea, prized for its light, strong, and easily worked wood. It has no significant history of medicinal use. Source: General botanical knowledge.

medicinalUses: Used in traditional medicine for fevers, coughs, skin infections, and as a vermifuge. Mild relaxing and euphoriant effects have been reported.
sideEffects: Generally considered safe in moderation.
preparation: The leaves and flowers are smoked, brewed into a tea, or used in a tincture.
detailedExplanation: This plant is a close relative of Wild Dagga (L. leonurus). It produces striking, bright orange, tubular flowers in tiered whorls around the stem. It has a long history of use in African traditional medicine and is sometimes used as a legal, mild psychoactive substitute for cannabis. Source: https://www.jstage.jst.go.jp/article/jphs/131/2/131_16245/_pdf

medicinalUses: Traditionally used as a diuretic, tonic, and for wound healing.
sideEffects: Information Missing.
preparation: A tea is made from the flowers and leaves.
detailedExplanation: This common wildflower of European grasslands is one of the few non-invasive knapweeds. It is a valuable nectar source for butterflies and bees. Its traditional medicinal uses are similar to other members of the genus but are not well-documented. Source: General ethnobotanical knowledge.

medicinalUses: Similar to other knapweeds; used as a digestive tonic and diuretic.
sideEffects: Information Missing.
preparation: A tea is made from the flowers.
detailedExplanation: This knapweed is characterized by its pale brown, papery bracts under the flower head. Like its relatives, it has a history of folk use for digestive ailments, but it is not a major medicinal herb. Source: General ethnobotanical knowledge.

medicinalUses: (See Knapweed, Black) This is another common name for the same plant, Centaurea nigra.
sideEffects: (See Knapweed, Black)
preparation: (See Knapweed, Black)
detailedExplanation: (See Knapweed, Black)

medicinalUses: The flowers are used as an eye wash for conjunctivitis and irritation; also as a mild diuretic and tonic.
sideEffects: Generally safe.
preparation: An infusion is made from the blue petals for an eye compress or tea.
detailedExplanation: The vibrant blue Cornflower is the national flower of Estonia. Its use as an eye remedy is classic in European folk medicine, valued for its anti-inflammatory and astringent properties. It is also a popular ornamental plant and a symbol of the "Field of Remembrance." Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK927574/

medicinalUses: Invasive Weed. Not used in medicine. It is a problematic plant that degades rangeland.
sideEffects: Not a medicinal plant.
preparation: Not used.
detailedExplanation: This plant is a highly invasive species in North America, forming monocultures that outcompete native vegetation. It is considered a noxious weed, and its control is a major land management concern. It has no medicinal value. Source: General ecological knowledge.

medicinalUses: Used similarly to Common Knapweed as a digestive tonic and for wound healing.
sideEffects: Information Missing.
preparation: A tea is made from the flowers and leaves.
detailedExplanation: This is the largest and most striking of the native European knapweeds, with large, thistle-like pink-purple flower heads. It is a valuable plant for pollinators. Its medicinal uses are part of general European folk tradition. Source: General ethnobotanical knowledge.

medicinalUses: Invasive and Allelopathic. It releases toxins into the soil to inhibit other plants. Not used in medicine.
sideEffects: Not a medicinal plant.
preparation: Not used.
detailedExplanation: This is one of the most difficult-to-control invasive weeds. It is deeply rooted and produces chemicals that prevent other plants from growing around it (allelopathy). It is a serious agricultural pest. Source: General ecological knowledge.

medicinalUses: Invasive Weed. Not used in medicine. It is a major problem in rangelands and natural areas.
sideEffects: Not a medicinal plant.
preparation: Not used.
detailedExplanation: This plant is a highly invasive species that dominates landscapes and reduces biodiversity. Like Diffuse Knapweed, it is a target for eradication programs and has no known beneficial medicinal uses. Source: General ecological knowledge.

medicinalUses: HIGHLY TOXIC to horses. Causes "chewing disease," a fatal neurological condition. Not for medicinal use.
sideEffects: TOXIC.
preparation: AVOID ALL USE.
detailedExplanation: This is one of the most problematic invasive weeds in the western United States. It is notorious for being toxic to horses, causing irreversible damage to the brain. It has no safe medicinal applications. Source: https://www.poison.org/articles/yellow-starthistle

medicinalUses: * Obsolete folk use. * Historically used as a diuretic to increase urine flow. * A decoction was used for bladder inflammation, coughs, and as a gargle.
sideEffects: Unknown. Safety is not established. Not recommended for modern use.
regionsFound: Europe, Western Asia; now a widespread weed.
preparation: Dried herb decoction. Preparation is not recommended.
detailedExplanation: A small, inconspicuous annual weed. Its name is derived from German "Knäuel," meaning "ball," referring to its tangled growth. It was used in European folk medicine, particularly German, for bladder ailments, but this practice is now obsolete and not supported by science. (Source: https://pfaf.org/user/Plant.aspx?LatinName=Scleranthus+annuus)

medicinalUses: * Topical use only. * Powerfully promotes the healing of broken bones, sprains, and wounds (vulnerary). * Reduces inflammation and pain from arthritis and injuries when applied topically.
sideEffects: INTERNAL USE IS HIGHLY TOXIC TO THE LIVER. Contains hepatotoxic pyrrolizidine alkaloids (PAs). Topical use can cause skin irritation in some.
preparation: Poultice of fresh leaves; oil infusions and ointments made from dried root and leaf.
detailedExplanation: The name "Knitted Herb" refers to its astonishing traditional ability to "knit" broken bones and heal tissue. It is one of the most famous healing herbs, but its internal use is banned in many countries due to the presence of liver-damaging alkaloids. (Source: https://www.ema.europa.eu/en/medicines/herbal/symphyti-radix)

medicinalUses: * A primary "depurative" or "blood cleansing" herb. * Used for chronic skin conditions like eczema and psoriasis. * Traditionally used for swollen lymph nodes, especially of the neck (scrofula). * Mild diuretic and laxative.
sideEffects: Can cause mild nausea or digestive upset. Not for use during pregnancy.
regionsFound: Europe and Asia; found in damp woods.
preparation: Tincture of the fresh plant; decoction of the dried root or herb.
detailedExplanation: Named for its knobby root and its historical use in treating "fig-warts" (hemorrhoids) and scrofula, a form of tuberculosis affecting the lymph nodes. It is a classic "alterative" herb in Western herbalism, used to cleanse the lymphatic system and clear chronic skin issues. (Source: https://www.botanical.com/botanical/mgmh/f/figwor11.html)

medicinalUses: * Not specifically used, but shares properties with other oaks. * Oak bark is a powerful astringent used to treat diarrhea. * A bark decoction can be used topically as a wash for weeping skin conditions, burns, and to stop minor bleeding.
sideEffects: Internal use can cause constipation and stomach irritation. May interfere with nutrient absorption.
preparation: Decoction of the inner bark.
detailedExplanation: A low-growing, shrubby oak of the southeastern US pine barrens. While not a major medicinal plant itself, its bark contains tannins, just like the more commonly used Red or White Oaks. Oak bark's primary medicinal action is as a strong astringent. (Source: https://www.wildflower.org/plants/result.php?id_plant=QUPU)

medicinalUses: * No specific medicinal uses distinct from other pines. * Pine resin (pitch) is antiseptic and was used topically for wounds. * Pine needle tea is high in Vitamin C and was used for coughs and colds.
sideEffects: Pine pollen is an allergen. Ingesting large amounts of pine needles can be irritating.
preparation: Resin applied topically; tea (infusion) of fresh needles.
detailedExplanation: A pine tree notable for its serotinous cones that remain sealed with resin until a forest fire melts them open to release seeds. Its medicinal uses are general to most pines and are not a primary feature of this species. Its main significance is ecological. (Source: https://www.fs.usda.gov/database/feis/plants/tree/pinatt/all.html)

medicinalUses: * Widely used in African Traditional Medicine. * Bark and root decoctions are used for coughs, pneumonia, and stomach pain. * The bark is also used as an aphrodisiac and for treating snakebites.
sideEffects: Safety profile is not well-established in clinical research. Potential for toxicity with incorrect use.
preparation: Decoction of the bark or root.
detailedExplanation: A signature tree of the African bushveld, easily identified by the thorn-tipped knobs on its trunk. It is an important medicinal resource in many local cultures, used for a variety of internal and external ailments, though it is not well-known outside of Africa. (Source: http://pza.sanbi.org/senegalia-nigrescens)

medicinalUses: * In folk medicine, a leaf infusion is used to treat fever, colds, and stomach aches. * A poultice of the crushed leaves is applied to cuts, skin infections, and headaches.
sideEffects: Safety is not well-documented. Generally considered safe for minor uses but not for prolonged internal use.
regionsFound: Tropical Americas, now a pantropical weed.
preparation: Infusion (tea) of the leaves; fresh leaf poultice.
detailedExplanation: A common weed of wet, disturbed areas in the tropics, easily recognized by its globe-like flower heads. It is used in folk medicine throughout its range, from the Philippines to Latin America, as a simple household remedy for common complaints like fever and skin sores. (Source: https://www.cabi.org/isc/datasheet/27855)

medicinalUses: * Acts as a diuretic. * Astringent properties help stop nosebleeds and treat diarrhea. * Contains silica, which may help strengthen connective tissue. * Traditionally used for bronchial conditions and coughs.
sideEffects: Very safe with no major side effects reported.
regionsFound: Worldwide in temperate regions; a common weed.
preparation: Infusion (tea) of the dried herb.
detailedExplanation: A common, low-growing weed found in compacted soil, paths, and waste grounds. Despite being overlooked, it has a long history in European herbalism as a gentle remedy for the urinary and respiratory tracts, and for its ability to stop minor bleeding. (Source: https://www.ema.europa.eu/en/medicines/herbal/polygoni-avicularis-herba)

medicinalUses: * Traditionally used as a vulnerary (wound healer). * A poultice was applied to stop bleeding and prevent infection in cuts and wounds. * An infusion was used for internal bleeding, cramps, and gout.
sideEffects: Safety for internal use is not well-established. Overuse could cause digestive upset.
preparation: Fresh herb poultice; Infusion of the dried herb.
detailedExplanation: This plant is a member of the mint family and a close relative of Betony. Its name "Woundwort" points to its primary use in stopping bleeding and healing wounds. The name "Knotroot" refers to its creeping, knotty white rhizomes, which are edible. (Source: https://pfaf.org/user/Plant.aspx?LatinName=Stachys+palustris)

medicinalUses: A powerful antimicrobial; used for respiratory infections, coughs, and digestive issues. Also a culinary herb.
sideEffects: Generally safe in food amounts. Medicinal doses may cause stomach upset.
preparation: The aerial parts are used to make tea, tincture, or essential oil.
detailedExplanation: This is the wild plant that is the source of the culinary herb oregano. Its strength as a medicine comes from its high concentration of volatile oils, primarily carvacrol and thymol, which are potent antiseptics. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5871212/

medicinalUses: Primarily a small wildflower. Not known for medicinal use.
sideEffects: Not a medicinal plant.
preparation: Not used.
detailedExplanation: This is a tiny, inconspicuous plant of damp, sandy or gravelly habitats. It is of interest to botanists and ecologists but holds no place in herbal medicine. Source: General botanical knowledge.

medicinalUses: Not a significant medicinal plant.
sideEffects: Information Missing.
preparation: Not used.
detailedExplanation: This plant is found in high mountain meadows. While it may have some traditional uses, it is not prominent in any major herbal pharmacopoeia and is primarily a component of alpine flora. Source: General botanical knowledge.

medicinalUses: Highly Invasive. Sometimes used similarly to Japanese Knotweed but is less studied.
sideEffects: Can be invasive.
preparation: The root is used in decoctions.
detailedExplanation: This is the largest of the invasive knotweeds, with leaves that can be over a foot long. It shares some medicinal properties with Japanese Knotweed due to the presence of resveratrol, but it is primarily known as an ecological threat. Source: General botanical knowledge.

medicinalUses: Invasive Weed. Not used in mainstream medicine.
sideEffects: Can be invasive.
preparation: Not commonly used.
detailedExplanation: This large, shrubby knotweed is another highly invasive species outside its native range. It is not a standard medicinal plant and is more often targeted for eradication than for harvest. Source: General ecological knowledge.

medicinalUses: The root is a rich source of resveratrol; used in TCM for Lyme disease, cardiovascular health, and as an antioxidant.
sideEffects: Can be invasive. May cause mild digestive upset.
preparation: The root is dried and decocted or used to make tinctures and extracts.
detailedExplanation: This plant is one of the world's most invasive species, capable of breaking through concrete. However, its root is a major source of trans-resveratrol, the same compound famous in red wine. In TCM (as Hu Zhang), it is used to clear heat, dampness, and toxins. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6273941/

medicinalUses: Used in traditional medicine as a diuretic and for urinary problems.
sideEffects: Information Missing.
preparation: A decoction is made from the whole plant.
detailedExplanation: This is a small, prostrate knotweed found in warm regions. Its uses are similar to those of Polygonum aviculare in traditional systems, but it is less well-known in Western herbalism. Source: General ethnobotanical knowledge.

medicinalUses: A classic herbal diuretic and astringent; used for urinary tract gravel, diarrhea, and respiratory catarrh.
sideEffects: Generally safe.
preparation: The aerial parts are dried and used in teas or tinctures.
detailedExplanation: This common sidewalk weed is a powerful but gentle medicine. It is particularly known for its high silica content, which is thought to help strengthen connective tissue and repair the urinary tract lining. It is also a potent astringent. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK927574/

medicinalUses: Used as a diuretic and for treating wounds and skin infections.
sideEffects: Information Missing.
preparation: The plant is used in a poultice or as a wash.
detailedExplanation: This native North American plant is found in wetlands. It has a history of use in Native American medicine, primarily as a topical application for sores and itching, and internally as a diuretic. Source: General ethnobotanical knowledge.

medicinalUses: * In traditional medicine, used to treat dysentery, colic, and fever. * The root is considered a remedy for flatulence and intestinal spasms.
sideEffects: Safety is not well-documented. Overuse could cause digestive upset.
preparation: Decoction of the root.
detailedExplanation: A genus of herbaceous plants found in the Old World tropics. Several species, like Knoxia sumatrensis, are used in local traditional medicine systems for gastrointestinal complaints, but they are not widely known or scientifically studied. (Source: https://plants.jstor.org/stable/10.5555/al.ap.upwta.5_179)

medicinalUses: * Primarily valued for its timber. * In traditional Hawaiian medicine (Lāʻau lapaʻau), the leaves and bark were used as an astringent and antiseptic for minor wounds.
sideEffects: No significant side effects are known from its limited medicinal use.
preparation: A poultice or wash made from crushed leaves or bark.
detailedExplanation: A magnificent tree endemic to Hawaii, famous for its beautiful, valuable wood used in furniture and instruments. While its role in traditional medicine was present, it was minor compared to its cultural and economic importance as a timber source. (Source: https://www.agroforestry.net/treedb/AFDbases.php?Treedb=Acacia+koa)

medicinalUses: * Minor folk use; seeds used in Chinese medicine for some skin conditions and as a diuretic. * Primarily a problematic agricultural weed and livestock forage of last resort.
sideEffects: Can cause liver damage, photosensitivity, and kidney damage in livestock that graze on it heavily. Can accumulate toxic levels of nitrates and oxalates.
regionsFound: Native to Eurasia, now a widespread weed.
preparation: Seeds used in decoctions in TCM. Forage for livestock.
detailedExplanation: An aggressive annual weed that is also sometimes planted as a fast-growing ornamental hedge. While it has minor uses in TCM, it is more significant as a problematic invasive species and a potentially toxic forage for livestock like cattle and sheep. (Source: https://www.cabi.org/isc/datasheet/30810)

medicinalUses: * Highly nutritious, gluten-free grain. * Rich in dietary fiber, which aids digestion and helps manage blood sugar. * Good source of B vitamins, iron, and antioxidants. * In Ayurveda, it is considered nourishing and easy to digest.
sideEffects: The grain can occasionally be contaminated with a fungus that produces cyclopiazonic acid, a neurotoxin, causing "kodo poisoning" (tremors, giddiness).
regionsFound: Native to Old World tropics, cultivated in India.
preparation: Grains are cooked whole like rice or ground into flour.
detailedExplanation: An ancient drought-resistant grain that is a staple food in parts of India and other tropical countries. It is gaining recognition as a "nutri-cereal" due to its high fiber content and rich micronutrient profile, making it beneficial for diabetic diets and overall health. (Source: https://www.ayush.gov.in/docs/millets.pdf)

medicinalUses: * No medicinal benefits. * It is a valuable native grass for pasture and rangeland forage for livestock and wildlife. * Used in prairie restoration and for erosion control.
sideEffects: Pollen can be a minor allergen.
regionsFound: Widespread in temperate regions of the world.
preparation: Not applicable.
detailedExplanation: This is a genus of grasses known collectively as Junegrass. Species like Koeleria macrantha are important components of native prairie ecosystems. They have no medicinal value but are significant for ecology, rangeland health, and habitat restoration. (Source: https://www.fs.usda.gov/database/feis/plants/graminoid/koemac/all.html)

medicinalUses: * Excellent source of Vitamin C (immune support). * High in dietary fiber, promoting digestive health. * Rich in antioxidants and compounds like glucosinolates, which are studied for anti-cancer properties. * Good source of potassium, which supports blood pressure control.
sideEffects: Can cause gas and bloating in some people due to its high fiber and sulfur compounds.
preparation: Eaten raw in salads and slaws, or cooked (steamed, roasted, sautéed).
