detailedExplanation: A delicate wildflower from the carnation family. Lesser Stitchwort was once a healing herb in European communities, mostly harvested for minor skin requests or soothing red/swollen eyes. Today, it is replaced by better-known herbs like eyebright or calendula. It may serve as ground cover with folkloric ties to eye and wound remedies. (Source: https://www.first-nature.com/flowers/stellaria-graminea.php)

medicinalUses:
• Mildly diuretic and used for urinary problems
• Roots used in the past for kidney and bladder complaints
• Rare in modern herbal medicine
sideEffects: May cause contact allergy or stomach upset
regionsFound: Temperate wetlands in Europe and Asia
preparation: Root decoction or boiled in folk medicine
detailedExplanation: A wetland-dwelling member of the Apiaceae family (carrot family). Its edible roots were used by ancient herbalists for treating bladder distress and stones. Modern use is minimal and overshadowed by safer urinary herbs. Potentially confused with very toxic look-alikes like Fool’s Parsley, hence not recommended for common use. (Source: https://pfaf.org/user/Plant.aspx?LatinName=Sium+latifolium)

medicinalUses:
• Cooling, hydrating, and mildly sedative
• Digestive enhancer due to mild bitterness
• Rich in chlorophyll and fiber; good for colon health
• Traditional sleep support during summer heat
sideEffects: Very safe in normal quantities
preparation: Eaten raw or cooked
detailedExplanation: Known globally as a salad green, Garden Lettuce is not just culinary—its cooling and laxative effects have been referenced in herbal systems. Traditional HVAC-seasoned Roghan Kahu (lettuce seed oil) in Unani medicine is attributed sedative and libido-lowering properties. Raw lettuce juice is sometimes used for minor constipation. (Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4324313/)

medicinalUses:
• Highly nutritious wild edible
• High in Vitamin C, used historically to prevent scurvy
• Mild anti-inflammatory and alkalizing properties
• Supports immune and kidney health
sideEffects: So gentle it's part of baby edible greens
preparation: Eaten raw in salads or lightly steamed
detailedExplanation: Known as Miner's Lettuce from its use by 19th-century California gold miners to prevent scurvy. This juicy, succulent-leafed wild herb grows in spring and is rich in minerals and vitamins. It is known more for its nutritional value than medicinal, but its wild food status makes it important in natural health communities. (Source: https://pfaf.org/user/Plant.aspx?LatinName=Claytonia+perfoliata)

medicinalUses:
• Wild lettuce species, source of herbal sedatives
• Latex (Lactucarium) historically used as sleep aid and cough suppressant
• Mild analgesic properties
sideEffects: At high doses, may cause nausea, dizziness
preparation: Latex resin extract; dried herb infusion
detailedExplanation: Known as Wild Lettuce or Opium Lettuce, due to its sedative latex, this wild relative of garden lettuce has been used in traditional European remedies for insomnia and pain. It is not addictive like opiates but has similar calming effects. Commercial latex extract is called “lactucarium.” Modern use is gaining popularity as a gentle nervine alternative. (Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC9846783/)

medicinalUses: Historically used as a sedative and analgesic; the milky latex (lactucarium) was known as "lettuce opium" for its mild pain-relieving and sleep-inducing properties.
sideEffects: Can cause drowsiness. The fresh sap can cause skin irritation.
preparation: The dried latex was smoked or made into a tincture. The leaves can be used in a mild tea.
detailedExplanation: This wild ancestor of cultivated lettuce contains a milky sap called lactucarium. In the 19th century, it was a popular substitute for opium, though its effects are significantly milder and non-narcotic. It was used to treat insomnia, anxiety, and coughs. When the plant flowers, its sap contains the highest concentration of active compounds. It is a fascinating example of a plant that bridges the gap between food and gentle medicine. Source: https://www.henriettes-herb.com/eclectic/kings/lactuca.html

medicinalUses: The root bark is used to stimulate uterine contractions during childbirth and to induce menstruation. The seeds produce cotton fiber.
sideEffects: TOXIC in high doses. Can cause nausea, vomiting, and is a potent abortifacient. Not for use during pregnancy except under professional supervision.
preparation: A decoction is made from the root bark.
detailedExplanation: This species is one of the oldest cultivated cottons. Beyond its immense economic importance for fiber, it has a long and dangerous history in traditional medicine as an ecbolic (substance that stimulates childbirth). The compound gossypol, found throughout the plant but concentrated in the seeds and roots, is responsible for both its toxicity and its antifertility effects. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK548202/

medicinalUses: Not a medicinal plant. The wood is exceptionally hard and dense, used for tool handles and mallets.
sideEffects: Not applicable.
preparation: Not used in herbal medicine.
detailedExplanation: This understory tree is known for its incredibly tough, heavy wood, which is difficult to split and will sink in water. Its common name, "Ironwood," is shared with many other hard-wooded trees. It produces hop-like fruit clusters and provides important food and cover for wildlife. Its primary value to humans has always been for making durable tools and implements where strength is critical. Source: General botanical knowledge.

medicinalUses: The root was used by Native American tribes as a diuretic and to treat sore throats and kidney problems.
sideEffects: Information Missing.
preparation: A decoction was made from the root.
detailedExplanation: This genus of striking wildflowers is unique for its flower spikes that bloom from the top down, unlike most spikes that bloom from the bottom up. They are a magnet for butterflies, bees, and other pollinators. The Catawba tribe used a tea from the roots of L. spicata to treat pain and swelling, while the Meskwaki used it as a diuretic. Today, they are primarily valued as stunning, drought-tolerant native perennials for the garden. Source: General ethnobotanical knowledge.

medicinalUses: A potent broad-spectrum antibiotic; used for respiratory tract infections (bronchitis, pneumonia), urinary tract infections, and topically for wounds.
sideEffects: Generally safe. Can cause stomach upset in high doses.
preparation: A tincture is made from the fresh or dried lichen; used in teas or throat sprays.
detailedExplanation: Often called "Old Man's Beard," this lichen is a symbiotic organism of a fungus and an alga. It has been used globally in traditional medicine, from Europe to China to North America. Its internal use skyrocketed during World War I when it was used to treat infected wounds. It is particularly effective against Gram-positive bacteria, including Streptococcus and Staphylococcus species. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5871212/

medicinalUses: The rhizome has a sweet, licorice flavor and was chewed for sore throats and colds; also used as a flavoring.
sideEffects: Generally safe.
preparation: The rhizome is chewed raw or dried and used in teas.
detailedExplanation: This fern grows as an epiphyte on the trunks of big-leaf maple trees in the damp coastal forests. Its rhizome has a distinct, sweet flavor of licorice due to the compound osladin, which is 500 times sweeter than sugar. It was a common "candy" and medicine for many Native American tribes of the region, who would chew it to soothe coughs and sore throats during long journeys or ceremonies. Source: General ethnobotanical knowledge.

medicinalUses: A premier soothing demulcent for sore throats and coughs; an adrenal tonic for fatigue; anti-inflammatory for stomach ulcers.
sideEffects: Raises blood pressure and depletes potassium with long-term use. Can cause water retention and headaches.
preparation: The root is dried and used in decoctions, teas, lozenges, or powdered.
detailedExplanation: True Licorice is one of the most important and widely used herbs in the world, with a history spanning 3,000 years in both Eastern and Western medicine. The compound glycyrrhizin is 50 times sweeter than sugar. It is a key ingredient in traditional formulas for peptic ulcers and respiratory conditions. Its ability to mimic the action of the hormone aldosterone is the cause of its main side effects. Deglycyrrhizinated licorice (DGL) is a safer alternative for digestive issues. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK927574/

medicinalUses: The root was chewed by Native Americans for toothache and coughs; used topically for earaches.
sideEffects: Generally safe. Contains less glycyrrhizin than true licorice.
preparation: The root is chewed raw or dried for tea.
detailedExplanation: This native North American relative of true licorice has a similar sweet flavor but contains significantly lower levels of the compound glycyrrhizin. Because of this, it does not carry the same risk of raising blood pressure. It was a common chewing stick and medicine for many Plains tribes. It spreads aggressively by rhizomes and can form dense patches, making it a useful groundcover but also a potential garden thug. Source: General ethnobotanical knowledge.

medicinalUses: A "harmonizing" herb in TCM; used in almost all formulas to moderate the effects of other herbs, soothe the throat, and tonify the Qi (energy).
sideEffects: Same as G. glabra: raises blood pressure and depletes potassium with long-term use.
preparation: The root is prepared in decoctions with other herbs.
detailedExplanation: In Traditional Chinese Medicine, Gan Cao is considered a "guide" herb that directs the actions of other herbs to the correct organ systems. It is also used on its own to tonify the Spleen Qi, relieving fatigue and poor digestion, and to clear "Heat" and toxicity from the body. It is one of the most frequently used substances in the entire Chinese pharmacopoeia. While chemically similar to G. glabra, it holds a uniquely central place in TCM theory. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5871212/

medicinalUses:
• Excellent for sore throat, dry cough, gastric ulcers
• Soothes inflammation in lungs and stomach
• Supports adrenal health and acts as mild laxative
• Antiviral and expectorant
sideEffects: Long-term use can cause water retention, high BP (due to glycyrrhizin)
regionsFound: Native to Eurasia, grown across India
preparation: Root decoction, powders, tablets, syrups
detailedExplanation: Licorice root (mulethi) is a classical Ayurvedic and Unani tonic herb. Its main compound, glycyrrhizin, has powerful demulcent, anti-inflammatory, and adrenal-supportive effects. Used in respiratory conditions, peptic ulcers, chronic fatigue, and hormone imbalance support. It has a long tradition in Indian, Chinese, and modern herbal pharmacopoeias. (Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3498851/)

medicinalUses:
• Similar to common licorice but milder
• Used by Native American tribes for cough, fever, and wounds
• Contains glycyrrhizin but in lower concentrations
• Supports anti-inflammatory and expectorant functions
sideEffects: Less risk of high BP but still caution needed in large doses
preparation: Decoction of root; tincture
detailedExplanation: Native American wild licorice was used medicinally for similar purposes as Eurasian licorice. Though not cultivated as commonly, it has proven effective in coughs, colds, skin ailments, and for digestive inflammation. Its uses are primarily ethnobotanical but supported by similar chemistry to G. glabra. (Source: https://www.fs.usda.gov/database/feis/plants/forb/glylep/all.html)

medicinalUses:
• Used as anti-inflammatory and mild anxiolytic
• Traditionally used in teas for colds, asthma, and as sedative
• Anti-aging and adaptogen reputation in folk medicine
sideEffects: Very safe in small infusion quantities
preparation: Infusion (leaves and flowers); dry extracts
detailedExplanation: Life Everlasting refers to various woolly, silver-leaved Gnaphalium species. In Latin America and Appalachia, it was used in "blessed teas" for colds. In India, related species (G. polycaulon) used in undernutrition, stress, and asthma. Also investigated for antioxidant-rich skin formulations. (Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3991027/)

medicinalUses:
• Previously used as emmenagogue (stimulate menses)
• Used in female reproductive tonics by Native healers
• Anti-inflammatory in roots
sideEffects: TOXIC — contains hepatotoxic alkaloids
preparation: Low-dose tincture in historical use
detailedExplanation: Once famous in 19th-century herbalism as a uterine tonic and menstrual support herb. "Life Root" (Senecio spp.) has since fallen out of use due to the presence of pyrrolizidine alkaloids, which can damage the liver. Historically used during childbirth and to treat stagnation. No longer recommended in modern herbal practices due to safety concerns. (Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC9151623/)

medicinalUses:
• Anti-inflammatory for arthritis and joint pain
• Traditionally used in detox therapies and for venereal disease
• Resin used as lymph/glandular cleanser and stimulant
sideEffects: Can cause nausea and sweating if overdosed
preparation: Resin powder in capsules; decoction of wood shavings
detailedExplanation: The “wood of life,” or Lignum vitae, was once vaunted for treating arthritis and chronic infections like syphilis in 18th-century Europe. Its resin and heartwood were used for detoxification and lymphatic drainage. Still used in some traditional and modern herbal medicines for joint pain and chronic inflammations. (Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7104530/)

medicinalUses:
• Mild astringent for skin
• Historically used for fever (“ague”) and as bitter tonic
• Gentle aromatic water used for mood and relaxation
sideEffects: Low-toxicity; not widely used internally
preparation: Flower water distillate or decoction
detailedExplanation: Although mostly ornamental today, the common lilac was used in European folk medicine for fevers, particularly malarial-like chills. The bitter bark was occasionally included in tonics, and lilac flower water was part of perfumes to lift mental fatigue. Not a primary medicinal plant now, but still appreciated for its gentle aromatic effects. (Source: https://pfaf.org/user/Plant.aspx?LatinName=Syringa+vulgaris)

medicinalUses:
• Similar to common lilac
• Used in traditional Unani and Middle Eastern perfumery
• Mild sedative and cooling properties in early texts
sideEffects: No significant side effects reported
preparation: Decoction of flowers (mild), fragrance water
detailedExplanation: A hybrid lilac with beautifully fine flowers and strong fragrance. Historically used in Persian gardens for beauty and symbolism; modest mentions in old Unani preparations as mood relaxant and for gentle perfume blends used in traditional medicine cabinets or cooling compresses. (Source: https://www.cabi.org/isc/datasheet/52966)

medicinalUses:
• High vitamin C; used for immunity and skin
• Antibacterial in extract form
• Astringent and healing for gums
• Used in liver tonics in Aboriginal medicine
sideEffects: Very safe as fruit; extract may irritate in high concentration
preparation: Berries raw or cooked; extract in skincare
detailedExplanation: A rainforest fruit tree common to Australia, Lilly Pilly (also called Riberry) produces tart, pink berries rich in vitamin C and antioxidants. Aboriginal medicine uses them for immune boosting, skin, and gum healing. Recently incorporated into cosmetic lines for anti-aging and acne-cleansing formulas. (Source: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/31291297/)

medicinalUses: Primarily Ornamental. In traditional medicine, used for heart disease, respiratory issues, and as a protective charm during pregnancy.
sideEffects: All parts may cause skin irritation and are mildly toxic if ingested.
preparation: Not commonly used in modern herbal practice.
detailedExplanation: Despite its common name, this plant is not a true lily nor from the Nile. It is a member of the Amaryllis family. It is renowned for its stunning globes of blue or white flowers. In South African traditional medicine, it was used for a range of conditions, and the Xhosa people considered it a magical medicine for pregnant women. Its primary global value today is as a drought-tolerant ornamental plant. Source: General horticultural and ethnobotanical knowledge.

medicinalUses: Contains cardiac glycosides used in pharmaceuticals for heart failure; increases heart contraction force.
sideEffects: HIGHLY TOXIC. All parts can cause abdominal pain, vomiting, reduced heart rate, confusion, and death.
preparation: Not for self-use. Purified glycosides are used in controlled medical settings.
detailedExplanation: This delicate, fragrant spring flower is one of the most dangerously poisonous plants. It contains over 40 cardiac glycosides (e.g., convallatoxin) that have a direct and powerful effect on the heart. While it was historically used in very small doses in folk medicine, the margin for error is nonexistent. It is the birth flower for May and a symbol of humility and sweetness in the "language of flowers," belying its toxic nature. Source: https://www.poison.org/articles/lily-of-the-valley

medicinalUses: Primarily Ornamental. Not known for medicinal use.
sideEffects: Information Missing.
preparation: Not used in herbal medicine.
detailedExplanation: This elegant plant is prized for its clusters of sparkling white, narcissus-like flowers that seem to float above its broad, glossy leaves. It is a classic Victorian "stove house" plant, requiring warm, humid conditions to thrive. A popular choice for tropical gardens and as a long-lasting cut flower, its common name is a misnomer, as it is not native to the Amazon basin but to the Andean foothills. Source: General horticultural knowledge.

medicinalUses: The rhizome is used in Traditional Chinese Medicine for throat infections, coughs, asthma, and to reduce phlegm.
sideEffects: May cause digestive upset in high doses.
preparation: The rhizome is dried and decocted.
detailedExplanation: This plant was recently reclassified from the Belamcanda genus to the Iris genus. It is unique for its showy, spotted flowers that give way to seed pods that split open to reveal clusters of black seeds resembling a blackberry. In TCM, it is known as She Gan and is considered specific for treating conditions where "heat" and "phlegm" congest the lungs and throat. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5871212/

medicinalUses: Primarily Ornamental. Not used in modern herbalism.
sideEffects: The bulb may be toxic if ingested.
preparation: Not used.
detailedExplanation: This exquisite and rare wildflower is known for its unique, checkerboard-patterned, bell-shaped flowers that hang delicately from slender stems. It is a plant of damp hay meadows and is increasingly uncommon in the wild due to habitat loss. While some related Fritillaria species are important in Chinese medicine (Chuan Bei Mu), this species is valued almost exclusively for its extraordinary and captivating beauty. Source: General botanical knowledge.

medicinalUses: The flowers and young shoots are edible and nutritious. Used in TCM as a diuretic and for hemorrhages.
sideEffects: The roots can be a strong laxative. Some individuals may have allergic reactions.
preparation: Flower buds are eaten raw, cooked, or dried; roots are used with caution in decoctions.
detailedExplanation: The name "Daylily" comes from each flower lasting only a single day. These are incredibly versatile plants; the dried flower buds are the "golden needles" used in hot and sour soup. They are also powerful plants that can form dense colonies, making them excellent for erosion control. While the tubers of some species have a history of use as a laxative, the primary use of common cultivars is culinary and ornamental. Source: General horticultural and culinary knowledge.

medicinalUses: The resin from the leaves was used topically by Maori for boils and wounds. The tough fiber is used for cordage and textiles.
sideEffects: Not a medicinal plant for internal use.
preparation: The leaf resin was applied directly as a poultice.
detailedExplanation: This plant is not related to true flax (Linum usitatissimum) but is a dominant feature of the New Zealand landscape. Its sword-like leaves contain exceptionally strong fibers that were used by Maori to make ropes, baskets, clothing, and even fishing lines. The plant is so integral to Maori culture that it is featured in their creation stories. Today, it is a popular architectural plant in gardens worldwide. Source: General ethnobotanical knowledge.

medicinalUses: The rhizome is used in traditional medicine for fever, pain, and as an anti-inflammatory. The intensely fragrant flowers are used in perfumery.
sideEffects: Generally safe.
preparation: The rhizome is used in decoctions; essential oil is distilled from flowers.
detailedExplanation: This plant is the national flower of Cuba, where it is known as "Mariposa" (butterfly) because its flowers resemble white butterflies. It is highly invasive in many tropical and subtropical regions, including Hawaii and Brazil, where it forms dense stands that crowd out native vegetation. Despite its invasive nature, its intoxicating fragrance, especially in the evening, makes it a beloved garden plant. Source: General horticultural knowledge.

medicinalUses:
• Used for respiratory issues (coughs, bronchitis)
• Soothing for skin wounds and burns
• Tincture useful in female reproductive imbalance
• Constituents used in traditional ointments for inflammation
sideEffects: Bulb may cause mild stomach upset if used raw
preparation: Petal/bulb tincture, ointments, poultices
detailedExplanation: The Madonna Lily is a gleaming white flower cultivated since ancient Greek and Roman times. In herbal practice, it was considered sacred and healing. Its oil or tincture was used for skin infections, boils, and inflammation, particularly in women’s reproductive healing. Though not widely used today, it remains a respected traditional remedy. (Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC8928232/)

medicinalUses:
• Historically used by Native American tribes as a food source (bulbs)
• Minor external use for strained muscles and slow-healing skin injuries
sideEffects: Not evaluated for true medicinal safety
preparation: Cooked bulbs as food (historic), external poultice
detailedExplanation: Known for its stunning appearance, the Mariposa Lily was considered sacred and useful by tribes in California. The bulbs were eaten during food scarcity. Though mostly food-related, its poultice application for joints and skin soreness shows minor medicinal use. Now mainly ornamental and part of native plant restoration. (Source: http://naeb.brit.org/uses/species/3379/)

medicinalUses:
• Highly effective female reproductive tonic
• Used traditionally for menstrual cramps, hormonal balance, miscarriage prevention
• Supports weak pelvic muscles and menopause symptoms
sideEffects: NA: Side effects rare, but overuse can lead to nausea
preparation: Root tincture (requires trained use)
detailedExplanation: Often called False Unicorn Lily, this medicinal plant is one of the most important herbs in women’s health in Native American and Appalachian traditions. It was used to support fertility and hormonal function. Today it remains in reproductive and fertility support in Western herbal protocols. (Source: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/21733980/)

medicinalUses:
• Traditional Mediterranean bulb used for boils, ulcers
• Poultice therapy for eczema, skin inflammation
• Mildly diuretic and detoxifying in some practices
sideEffects: Bulb toxic if ingested raw
preparation: Topical bulb poultice or decoction (not oral)
detailedExplanation: “Sand Lily” refers to species like Pancratium maritimum in Europe or Leucocrinum montanum in the U.S. These are delicate plants from sandy zones. Their bulb sap historically was used to heal wounds or inflammation. Mediterranean traditions especially valued Pancratium species. Not widely used due to potential bulb toxicity. (Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6158275/)

medicinalUses:
• Bulb used in Chinese medicine for dry cough, heat in lungs, palpitations
• Mild sedative properties
• Skin beautifying and used in yin tonics
sideEffects: May cause skin irritation from sap; toxic to cats
preparation: Bulb decoction; steamed bulbs; dried slices
detailedExplanation: Widely admired for beauty, this orange-spotted lily is valued in Traditional Chinese Medicine (TCM) for soothing the lungs, heart, and mind. Tiger Lily bulbs are used in yin-tonifying remedies for chronic ailments, especially dry cough and palpitations. Evidence is largely based in TCM tradition. (Source: https://www.webmd.com/vitamins/ai/ingredientmono-2090/lily)

medicinalUses:
• Traditional decoction for childbirth support, menstrual cramping
• Leaves used in poultices and as mild emetic
• Rarely used today due to toxicity concerns
sideEffects: Risk of excessive salivation, nausea if misused
preparation: Decoction (root, leaf); poultice (fresh leaf)
detailedExplanation: Known as Dogtooth Violet or Trout Lily, this species was traditionally used by Native Americans and herbalists to facilitate labor and relieve menstrual pain. Its fish-like leaf pattern gives it the name "trout lily." Though once popular, modern herbalists rarely use it due to potential toxicity and better alternatives. (Source: http://naeb.brit.org/uses/species/3805/)

medicinalUses:
• Used by Native tribes as poultice for wounds, swelling, bites
• Decoctions for cough, fever, chest complaints
• Bulb sometimes roasted for nutrition in emergencies
sideEffects: Safe in small external uses; bulb has mild toxicity if raw
preparation: Poultice (crushed bulb or leaves); bulb roasted (emergency food)
detailedExplanation: Wood Lily is a brilliantly red wildflower whose bulb was occasionally eaten and used in First Nations' healing poultices. Traditional uses included respiratory decoctions and poultices for snake bites or infection. It has waned from herbalism but has ethnobotanical value. (Source: http://naeb.brit.org/uses/species/3301/)

medicinalUses:
• Strengthens lung yin in TCM
• Used for dry throat, ulcers, dry cough
• Heart-calming, anti-inflammatory
• Skin moisture retention (modern cosmetics)
sideEffects: Very safe herb; mild cold-natured, could aggravate cold digestion
preparation: Dried tuber decoction, powder in capsules, fresh juice
detailedExplanation: Known as Mai Men Dong in TCM, this tuberous plant is prized to nourish Lung and Stomach Yin. Its cooling properties make it essential in Chinese moisturization formulas. It is also an ingredient in modern skin-care products due to its natural mucilage. Excellent yin tonic for dry, hot patterns. (Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4528347/)

medicinalUses:
• Traditional decoction for colds, respiratory infection
• Resin (pitch) used on wounds or sore muscles
• Pine needles high in Vitamin C
sideEffects: Resin can cause allergic skin reactions
preparation: Leaf tea (pine needle), resin salve, bark decoction
detailedExplanation: Limber Pine is a high-altitude conifer with flexible branches and hardy growth. Used by North American tribes for colds, lung infection, and minor wounds. The fresh inner bark and needle infusion helped with nutrition and immunity. While not FDA-approved, conifer medicine is widely respected in traditional ethno-botany. (Source: https://www.fs.fed.us/database/feis/plants/tree/pinflu/all.html)

medicinalUses: Prevents scurvy, aids digestion, antioxidant, supports immunity.
sideEffects: Tooth enamel erosion, heartburn, skin photosensitivity from peel oils.
regionsFound: Cultivated worldwide in tropical and subtropical climates.
preparation: Juice in water/food, zest in cooking.
detailedExplanation: The lime is a powerhouse of vitamin C (ascorbic acid), historically crucial for preventing scurvy in sailors. Its acidic juice stimulates the production of salivary and gastric enzymes, aiding digestion. The flavonoids and limonoids present have demonstrated antioxidant and anti-inflammatory properties in laboratory studies. It is also a common ingredient in detox drinks for its ability to flush out toxins. Source: NCBI

medicinalUses:
• Nervine relaxant / natural tranquilizer
• Used to treat insomnia, anxiety, digestive cramps
• Helps in cold and fever (as diaphoretic)
• Used for migraine and inflammation
sideEffects:
Safe herb
May lower blood pressure or cause drowsiness
preparation: Flower infusion (tea), tincture, aromatic bath
detailedExplanation: Famous in folk herbalism, the linden or lime tree is a must-have gentle nervine herb. Widely used in teas across Europe, its flowers produce a calming, lightly sweet-scented liquor that helps in digestion, calming anxiety, and lowering fever via gentle perspiration. It’s safe for children and used for restlessness. (Source: https://www.mountsinai.org/health-library/herb/linden)

medicinalUses: Primarily a nutritious fruit; source of carbs, fiber, and Vitamin C.
sideEffects: The seed is toxic if ingested. Choking hazard.
regionsFound: Caribbean, Central and South America, parts of Florida.
preparation: Fruit eaten raw by sucking pulp off the seed.
detailedExplanation: Wild Limeberry is valued primarily as a food source rather than a medicinal plant. The sweet and tangy pulp is rich in carbohydrates, dietary fiber, and contains a notable amount of vitamin C and amino acids like tryptophan. While not pharmaceutically prominent, its nutritional profile contributes to overall health, supporting energy levels and immune function. The tree is also used for its sturdy wood. Source: USDA Forest Service

medicinalUses: Used for anxiety, restlessness, colds, coughs, and high blood pressure.
sideEffects: Rare, but cardiac irritation with chronic, excessive consumption.
preparation: Tea made from the flowers and bracts.
detailedExplanation: Linden flower tea is a classic in European folk medicine, renowned as a calming nervine to alleviate anxiety and promote restful sleep. Its diaphoretic property helps induce sweating, making it useful for breaking fevers during colds and flu. The mucilaginous components coat and soothe irritated mucous membranes in the throat, relieving coughs. Some traditions also use it to support cardiovascular health by reducing mild hypertension. Source: ScienceDirect

medicinalUses: Antioxidant, anti-inflammatory
sideEffects: None known
preparation: Bark extract
detailedExplanation: Western Ghats tree used for antioxidant therapy. Source: https://powo.science.kew.org/taxon/urn:lsid:ipni.org:names:77187744-1

medicinalUses: Urinary tract health (like cranberry), antioxidant, source of vitamins.
sideEffects: Generally safe. High doses may cause nausea or diarrhea.
regionsFound: Boreal forests and Arctic tundra in the Northern Hemisphere.
preparation: Eaten raw, as jam, juice, or supplements.
detailedExplanation: Lingonberries are a close relative of cranberries and share similar medicinal properties, particularly for urinary tract health. They are rich in proanthocyanidins (PACs), which prevent E. coli bacteria from adhering to the urinary tract walls, helping to prevent infections. The berries are also packed with polyphenols and vitamins, providing strong antioxidant benefits that protect cells from damage and may support cardiovascular health. Source: NCBI

medicinalUses: High in fiber for constipation relief, source of Omega-3 (ALA), may help lower cholesterol.
sideEffects: Bloating, gas, diarrhea. Can block absorption of other medications.
preparation: Ground seeds, flaxseed oil, whole seeds.
detailedExplanation: Flaxseed is a premier functional food for digestive health. Its high soluble fiber content, primarily mucilage, absorbs water to soften stool and add bulk, effectively relieving constipation. It is one of the richest plant sources of omega-3 fatty acid (ALA), which supports heart and brain health. The lignans in flaxseed are phytoestrogens with potent antioxidant properties, studied for their potential role in hormone-related cancers. Source: NCBI

medicinalUses: Traditional use for anxiety, headaches, fever, and as a euphoriant.
sideEffects: Dizziness, nausea, sedation, thirst. Its psychoactive effects are unpredictable.
preparation: Dried leaves and flowers are smoked or brewed into tea.
detailedExplanation: Lion's Ear, also known as Wild Dagga, has a long history in African traditional medicine. It is primarily used as a remedy for a wide range of conditions including anxiety, high blood pressure, and respiratory ailments like asthma and the common cold. The plant contains the compound leonurine, which is believed to be responsible for its mild psychoactive and purported cardiovascular effects. It is often smoked as a cannabis substitute, though its effects are generally considered much milder. Source: NCBI

medicinalUses: Traditional for digestive and respiratory ailments. Modern use in cosmetics for antioxidant properties.
sideEffects: Generally considered safe, but wild populations are protected.
preparation: Extracts used in creams, tinctures, and teas.
detailedExplanation: Edelweiss is a symbol of the Alps with a rich history in traditional medicine. It was used to treat abdominal pain, diarrhea, and respiratory conditions like bronchitis and tuberculosis. Modern scientific interest has shifted to its potent antioxidant compounds, particularly leontopodic acids, which are extracted for high-end skincare products. These compounds protect the skin from UV-induced oxidative stress and have anti-inflammatory properties, helping to soothe irritation and slow signs of aging. Source: ScienceDirect

medicinalUses: Traditional use for fever, asthma, and as a mild psychoactive.
sideEffects: Sedation, dizziness, and nausea.
regionsFound: Native to Africa; naturalized in the Americas and Asia.
preparation: Dried flowers smoked or brewed into tea.
detailedExplanation: Lion's Tail is a close relative of Lion's Ear and is used similarly in folk medicine across different cultures, including in Brazil and India. It is employed to treat fevers, coughs, and asthma, and is also used during childbirth. Like its relative, it contains leonurine and other diterpenoids, but is often regarded as having weaker psychoactive effects. Its use is deeply rooted in ritual and traditional healing practices rather than evidence-based medicine. Source: ResearchGate

medicinalUses: Diuretic, supports liver and digestive health, bitter tonic.
sideEffects: Allergic reactions, heartburn, stomach upset.
preparation: Tea (from leaves or root), tincture, fresh leaves in salad.
detailedExplanation: Every part of the dandelion is medicinal. The leaves are a potent, potassium-rich diuretic, promoting urine flow without depleting electrolytes. The root is a classic liver tonic, stimulating bile production to improve fat digestion and relieve constipation. It acts as a bitter tonic, enhancing overall digestion. The plant is also rich in vitamins A, C, and K, and minerals like iron and calcium, making it a nutritious spring tonic. Source: NCBI

medicinalUses: Culinary spice; traditionally for digestive issues, respiratory problems, and as an antiseptic.
sideEffects: Generally safe in food amounts. Essential oil can be irritating.
preparation: Dried leaves as a culinary herb, tea.
detailedExplanation: Lippia is a cornerstone of Mexican cuisine, but its traditional medicinal uses are significant. It is used to treat digestive ailments like indigestion and diarrhea, and respiratory conditions such as coughs and bronchitis. These benefits are attributed to its high concentration of thymol and carvacrol, compounds with proven antimicrobial, antifungal, and antioxidant activities. A tea made from the leaves is a common household remedy for coughs and sore throats. Source: NCBI

medicinalUses:
• Fruit pulp has antioxidant and antimicrobial actions
• Seeds used traditionally for digestion, fevers, and skin issues
• Seed extract used as natural colorant in cosmetics
• Leaf tea used in diabetes and prostate disorders
sideEffects:
Generally safe
May cause mild stomach upset or skin sensitivity in rare cases
preparation: Infusion of leaves, seed paste, cosmetic use
detailedExplanation: Known for its bright red seed pulp, this tropical plant is named "Lipstick Tree" because the dye was used for body paint and cosmetics. Traditionally used by Amazonian tribes and now cultivated in India, it has a role in regulating blood sugar, as a urinary antiseptic, and topically for skin and wounds. The annatto dye (from the seeds) is also used in food. (Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7765781/)

medicinalUses:
• Used in Ayurveda as a wound healer and blood purifier
• Good for respiratory congestion, cough, fever
• Leaves chewed traditionally to manage nicotine withdrawal
• Used in siddha system for sinusitis and menstrual issues
sideEffects:
Generally safe
Excess may cause dryness
preparation: Leaf juice, decoctions, powdered herb
detailedExplanation: Recognized in Ayurveda under “Sahadevi,” this herb is valued for its utility in treating wounds, fevers, respiratory complaints, and as a blood tonic. Recent research shows it may aid nicotine withdrawal. It is also anti-inflammatory and demulcent when used in decoctions. (Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4566462/)

medicinalUses:
• Calming sedative and mild hypnotic
• Tea used for fever, sore throat, stress headaches
• Anti-inflammatory effect on mucous membranes
• Safe for children’s colds and sleeplessness
sideEffects:
Extremely safe
Drowsiness if overused
preparation: Flower tea (infusion), compress
detailedExplanation: A close cousin of Tilia europaea (Common Lime), Littleleaf Linden is used for nearly identical purposes. It’s a trusted herbal tea for fever reduction, sore throat, and calming anxiety. Its gentle, soothing actions make it a favorite herb even for young children. Used throughout Europe as a common home remedy. (Source: https://www.mountsinai.org/health-library/herb/linden)

medicinalUses:
• Bark has strong astringent properties
• Used for bleeding, mouth sores, diarrhea, and minor burns
• Ancestrally used in poultices for inflammation and skin ulcers
sideEffects: High tannin content — may cause constipation and interfere with iron absorption
preparation: Bark decoction (as mouthwash), poultices, infusions
detailedExplanation: Live Oak is a sprawling, evergreen oak that symbolizes strength. Its bark, like other oaks, is rich in tannins and was traditionally part of Native American medicine for diarrhea, sore gums, and burns. Not commonly used now due to side effects of extreme astringency, but still relevant in emergency herbalism. (Source: https://www.fs.usda.gov/database/feis/plants/tree/quevir/all.html)

medicinalUses:
• Leaf juice used for burns, skin irritations, insect bites
• Mild anti-inflammatory
• Used in folk medicine for earache and corns
sideEffects: Safe; very rare allergy or skin discomfort when fresh sap applied
preparation: Fresh sap or juice from leaves; poultice
detailedExplanation: A hardy succulent that lives on rooftops and arid zones, Sempervivum tectorum or Houseleek is called “Live-forever” due to its resilience. Used topically for healing wounds, acne, sunburn, and inflammation. In European folk medicine, the juice was inserted into the ear for earache. It is similar in composition to Aloe vera but less researched. (Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC8808979/)

medicinalUses:
• Mild liver tonic
• Used for indigestion, bloating, and sluggish bile
• In folk medicine used for cough, migraine, and kidney stones
• Once prized as a remedy for spleen and liver inflammation
sideEffects: Obsolete for internal use — not proven safe by modern standards
preparation: Historical decoction of leaves or root
detailedExplanation: Liverleaf (Hepatica) got its name from its liver-shaped leaves and was once highly favored in the Doctrine of Signatures as a liver and gallbladder tonic — particularly in medieval Europe. It has now fallen out of use due to lack of solid evidence and risk of confusion with other toxic forest herb species. (Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC9312066/)

medicinalUses:
• Traditionally used as a liver tonic (Doctrine of Signatures basis)
• Antibacterial and anti-inflammatory according to recent compound isolation
• Important subject in lab liver regeneration studies
sideEffects:
Not commonly ingested
Risky as not part of mainstream medicine
preparation: Traditionally dried, powdered; now studied in extract form
detailedExplanation: A type of moss that grows in moist forests and rocks, Liverwort looks like liver and inspired ancient people to use it for liver disease. While its historic use is not considered safe today in herbal practice, researchers are finding novel anti-inflammatory and antimicrobial compounds in liverworts, making them promising in modern drug development. (Source: https://www.frontiersin.org/articles/10.3389/fchem.2020.582982/full)

medicinalUses:
• Roots used in traditional salep (starch-rich remedy)
• May act as demulcent and nourishing tonic for lungs and throat
• Limited medicinal use today due to rarity
sideEffects:
None if from clean source
Salep can thicken GI contents
preparation: Powdered tuber as hot beverage (Salep)
detailedExplanation: The Lizard Orchid, named after its tail-like flower appendages, is one of the orchids with starch-rich roots once used in salep (Middle Eastern hot drink and remedy). Though not a mainstream herb now, it had applications in soothing digestion and inflammation. Orchid roots were traditionally believed to boost strength and disperse chronic catarrh. Due to conservation concerns, this plant is less commonly harvested today. (Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC8004795/)

medicinalUses:
• Powerful respiratory stimulant
• Used historically for asthma, bronchitis, and spasms
• Nervine and muscle relaxant in very small doses
• Has been used in smoking cessation formulas
sideEffects:
Toxic in high doses
Nausea, dizziness, vomiting
preparation: Tincture in low dilution (must be supervised)
detailedExplanation: Known as Indian Tobacco, Lobelia inflata is a strong herb historically prescribed for shortness of breath, spasms, and asthma. In low doses it clears lung congestion and relaxes muscles. In higher doses it acts as an emetic. Still used today in homeopathy and professional Western herbalism, but requires experience for safe dosing. (Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC1079419/)

medicinalUses:
• Limited medicinal use
• Bark has historical use as an astringent and sore throat remedy
• Sometimes used for skin conditions in folk medicine
sideEffects: Not well studied for safety. May cause mild GI upset if ingested raw.
preparation: Decoction of bark or leaves (external use only)
detailedExplanation: A beautiful flowering evergreen tree from the southeastern United States, known for glossy leaves and camellia-like flowers. Closely related to tea trees (Theaceae), its bark was occasionally used in early American folk medicine as an astringent for treating sore gums or wounds. Modern clinical use is absent. (Source: https://www.fs.usda.gov/database/feis/plants/tree/gorlas/all.html)

medicinalUses:
• Used traditionally for respiratory support
• Pine needle tea as Vitamin C rich tonic
• Resin may be used as antiseptic for cuts, insect bites
• Bark contains antimicrobial phytonutrients
sideEffects:
Resin may cause skin irritation
Excessive ingestion of needles may irritate stomach
preparation: Pine needle infusion, resin poultice
detailedExplanation: One of the most commercially important pines in the US. Native tribes used its inner bark, resin, and needles for treating colds, wounds, and congestion. Its essential oils contain monoterpenes that promote clearer breathing. Like other pines, it helps reduce inflammation and mucus. (Source: https://www.fs.usda.gov/database/feis/plants/tree/pintae/all.html)

medicinalUses:
• Used in traditional Native American and Appalachian medicine
• Bark historically used as laxative or emetic
• Modern use includes treatment for toothache (flowers)
• Antioxidant and antimicrobial properties in flowers
sideEffects: TOXIC: Raw bark, seeds, and young pods are poisonous
preparation: Floral infusions only (external or mild teas)
detailedExplanation: Despite its use as firewood and shade, Black Locust is potentially toxic. Only the fragrant flowers are safe for therapeutic use. Flowers are mildly sedative and analgesic, while seeds and bark contain toxic alkaloids. Historically used with caution. Not for internal bark use today. (Source: https://www.fs.usda.gov/database/feis/plants/tree/robpse/all.html)

medicinalUses:
• Pods sweet and used traditionally for diarrhea and fever
• Bark decoction for skin sores and ulcers
• Seeds contain a mild laxative and warming stimulant effect
sideEffects:
Raw seeds can be mildly toxic
Pods in excess cause purging
preparation:
Syrup from roasted pod paste
Bark decoction
detailedExplanation: Distinct from Black Locust, the Honey Locust is named for its sweet pods. Native peoples used it to treat fever and aid digestion. Its thorny bark and pods contain alkaloids and sugars that can act as diuretics or soothing agents depending on form. Pods must be cooked correctly. (Source: https://pfaf.org/user/Plant.aspx?LatinName=Gleditsia+triacanthos)

medicinalUses:
• Traditional wound healing and respiratory remedy
• Resin applied to sores and infections
• Bark used in bronchial steams and decoctions
• Pine needle tea for Vitamin C and respiratory stimulation
sideEffects:
Resin can irritate skin if raw
Essential oil ingestion not advised
preparation: Pine pitch salves, bark decoction, leaf inhalation
detailedExplanation: This mountain pine species grows in extreme habitats. The Native American tribes used every part of the Lodgepole Pine from shelter to salve. The resin was highly valued for its healing power and the twigs and bark were used to treat bronchitis and lung infections. (Source: https://www.fs.usda.gov/database/feis/plants/tree/pincon/all.html)

medicinalUses:
• High antioxidant and polyphenol content for immunity
• Aids digestion and reduces inflammation
• Used for cardiovascular support and blood pressure regulation
• Good source of Vitamin C and fiber
sideEffects: Safe in moderate dietary quantity
preparation: Eaten raw, jam, juice, powder concentrate
detailedExplanation: Loganberry is a nutritious hybrid berry developed in California by Judge Logan. Though not extensively used in herbalism, its health benefits align with blackberries and raspberries. Packed with anthocyanins and antioxidants, it is a food-based remedy to improve vascular health and inflammation. (Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6701092/)

medicinalUses:
• Leaf bud resin is anti-inflammatory
• Used externally for pain, joint inflammation, wounds
• Traditional salicylate (aspirin-like) effect
• Bark decoction sometimes applied for swelling
sideEffects: Avoid internal use due to potency; may cause skin allergy
preparation: Bud resin ointments, external salve
detailedExplanation: This graceful columnar tree has a history of resin and bud use much like its cousin, the balsam poplar. The sticky secretions from leaves were used historically in balms for muscle aches and wounds. It is rich in salicylates, suggesting a natural aspirin effect. Rarely used internally today due to toxicity. (Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4740406/)

medicinalUses:
• Bark and leaves historically used for fevers and wounds
• May treat rheumatism externally
• Some Unani reference for use in inflammation and ulcers
sideEffects: Pollen or bark dust may cause respiratory allergies
preparation: Bark decoction, leaf poultice (not common today)
detailedExplanation: A popular landscaping tree in cities (like Delhi), London Plane is a hybrid of American and Oriental plane trees. Its mild astringent bark was previously used externally for inflammation or ulcers. The tree’s importance today is more environmental than medicinal, though its historical use is worth noting. (Source: https://pfaf.org/User/Plant.aspx?LatinName=Platanus+x+hispanica)

medicinalUses:
• Expectorant and respiratory aid
• Used traditionally for hoarseness, sore throat
• Poultice for swollen glands and bruise swelling
• Improves sinuses and vocal performance
sideEffects:
Very safe herb when fresh or infused
Mild mustard-like taste
preparation: Infusion (leaves), poultice (crushed plant)
detailedExplanation: This mustard-family plant earned the name “London Rocket” after its prolific growth post-Great Fire of London (1666). Long used for sore throats and laryngitis remedies, especially for singers or public speakers. It is still valued in folk respiratory care and sometimes added to herbal syrups for voice strengthening. (Source: https://www.herbalriot.com/herbs/london-rocket-sisymbrium-irio/)

medicinalUses:
• Key herb in Ayurveda for respiratory issues and gastric disorders
• Rejuvenator (rasayana); used for cough, asthma, indigestion
• Stimulates digestion, circulatory health, and metabolism
sideEffects: Overuse may cause gastric irritation, heat sensation
preparation: Powdered fruit with honey or as component in formulations
detailedExplanation: Long Pepper (Pippali) is one of the most revered herbs in Ayurveda, particularly for chronic respiratory issues and digestive weakness. A principal ingredient in Trikatu and Chyawanprash, pippali increases bioavailability of compounds (like Turmeric) and supports overall vitality. Used extensively in cold formulas and liver remedies. (Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5514666/)

medicinalUses:
• TCM tonic for heart, spleen, and brain
• Treats insomnia, anxiety, memory loss, and fatigue
• Contains antioxidants and iron for blood-building
• Boosts immunity and digestion
sideEffects: May cause mild bloating or digestive heat when over-eaten
preparation: Eaten fresh; dried fruit as tea; decoction in TCM
detailedExplanation: Longan fruit, similar to lychee, is used in Traditional Chinese Medicine (TCM) as a tonic herb that nourishes blood and calms the heart. Particularly used for insomnia, anemia, and restlessness. The dried fruit is often brewed as tea or added to cleansing soups. (Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3834787/)

medicinalUses:
• Resin and bark used in respiratory complaints
• Pine needle tea high in Vitamin C for immunity
• Pitch applied for ulcers, rheumatism, and infections
• Bark extract supports joint health
sideEffects: Resin may irritate eyes/skin; Needle tea in high concentration may be harsh
preparation: Needle infusion; resin applied topically
detailedExplanation: One of North America's longest-living pines, traditionally employed for bronchial, rheumatic, and skin problems. Gum resin was used as an antiseptic, while inner bark decoction supported immune and lung health. Similar to other medicinal pines. (Source: https://www.fs.usda.gov/database/feis/plants/tree/pinpal/all.html)

medicinalUses:
• Young fruit used for digestion, liver support
• Seeds are purgative and anti-helminthic
• Juice used in Ayurveda for myalgia or jaundice
• Also used externally for skin exfoliation and stimulation
sideEffects:
Mature fruit fiber is indigestible
Unripe seed oil may cause nausea
preparation: Young tender gourd cooked, immature juice used in decoctions
detailedExplanation: Loofah gourds are more than just sponges. In Ayurveda, torai (ridge gourd) is used for liver cleansing, mild laxative properties, and myalgia. A decoction of unripe gourd or juice may improve digestion and reduce inflammation. Older dried fruit is used externally for its exfoliating properties. (Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4488421/)

medicinalUses:
• Powerful astringent for chronic diarrhea, dysentery
• Helps stop bleeding, ulcers, leucorrhea
• Topical uses for eczema and wounds
• Strong anti-bacterial tannin-rich plant
sideEffects:
Constipation when overused
Drying if overdosed
preparation: Infusion or decoction of flower and leaf
detailedExplanation: Known in Europe as one of the most astringent non-toxic herbs. Purple Loosestrife has been used in folk and professional herbalism (including German herbal compendia) to treat diarrhea, colitis, and external wounds. Used in syrups and washes for mucosal issues. (Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7795692/)

medicinalUses:
• Used for ulcers, sores, and eye inflammation
• Leaves applied as poultices on wounds
• Rarely used internally today
sideEffects:
Not well studied internally
Use externally only
preparation: Leaf poultice, decoction for rinses
detailedExplanation: This wetland plant of North America grows near swamps and slow-flowing water. Native herbalists used it to reduce inflammation from sores and boils. It has mild astringency and antiseptic traits. Not widely available or studied currently. (Source: https://plants.usda.gov/)

medicinalUses:
• Wound-healing and cooling
• Used for ulcers, bleeding gums
• Folk remedy for jaundice, urinary conditions
sideEffects:
May have diuretic effect in large doses
Generally very safe
preparation: Fresh leaf poultice, decoctions for compress
detailedExplanation: Yellow Loosestrife (Creeping Jenny) is known in historical traditions for its anti-inflammatory and styptic use. Applied to bleeding wounds and healing sores, especially in cottage herbal medicine. Occasionally used for liver and bladder complaints. Primary use now is cosmetic or ornamental. (Source: https://pfaf.org/user/Plant.aspx?LatinName=Lysimachia+nummularia)

medicinalUses:
• Fruit rich in Vitamin A, B, C—supports skin, lungs
• Loquat leaf decoction used in TCM for lung heat, cough, phlegm
• Mild sedative and digestive tonic
• Antidiabetic and antioxidant properties
sideEffects:
Leaf hairs can irritate throat if not strained
Seeds are toxic
preparation: Ripe fruit eaten raw/cooked; leaf decoction
detailedExplanation: Loquat fruit is common in India in spring. In TCM, the leaves are more valued, used for bronchial congestion, heat-induced asthma, and thirst reduction during fever. The leaves must be properly strained and processed to avoid coarse hairs irritating mucosa. Clinical studies support its usefulness against lung heat and oxidative stress. (Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5604002/)

medicinalUses:
• Sacred in Islamic tradition
• Leaves used for skin rashes, wounds, hair health
• Fruit strengthens digestion, immune system
• Traditionally taken for fever, cough, and mood upliftment
sideEffects: Very safe if properly prepared
preparation: Leaf powder in wash; decoction; fruits eaten
detailedExplanation: The Sidr tree (Lote Tree) holds spiritual and medicinal value. It’s considered sacred in Islam (mentioned in Quran) and used in Unani and folk practice to enhance immunity, treat skin infections, and support digestion. Dried leaves are used like a skin tonic or shampoo for dandruff. Modern studies show antioxidant, antimicrobial, and gastroprotective properties. (Source: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/32984365/)

medicinalUses: Similar to Sacred Lotus; astringent, used for digestive issues, diuretic.
sideEffects: Generally safe as food.
preparation: Seeds and rhizomes cooked and eaten.
detailedExplanation: The American Lotus, a close relative of the Sacred Lotus, was a vital food and medicine source for Native American tribes. The starchy rhizomes were boiled or roasted, and the seeds were ground into flour. Medicinally, it was used as a diuretic to increase urine flow and as an astringent to treat diarrhea, inflammation, and skin sores. Its use is more documented as a nutritional resource than a specific medicinal agent. Source: USDA

medicinalUses: Traditionally used as a mild psychoactive, aphrodisiac, and for anxiety. Often used in rituals.
sideEffects: Dizziness, sedation, mild hallucinations at high doses.
regionsFound: Originally Egypt, parts of Asia and East Africa.
preparation: Tea, tincture, or smoked.
detailedExplanation: The Blue Lotus was revered in ancient Egyptian iconography and rituals for its psychoactive and medicinal properties. It contains apomorphine and nuciferine, alkaloids that can produce mild euphoria, relaxation, and heightened sensory perception. It was used to reduce anxiety, promote sleep, and as an aphrodisiac. Its modern use is often recreational or in spiritual practices. Source: PubMed

medicinalUses: Astringent, antioxidant, used for diarrhea, bleeding, and skin health. All parts (seeds, rhizome, leaves) are used.
sideEffects: Generally safe as food. High doses of extracts may cause mild digestive upset.
preparation: Seeds eaten raw or cooked, rhizome (lotus root) cooked, leaf extracts, teas.
detailedExplanation: The Sacred Lotus is a cornerstone of traditional medicine, particularly in Ayurveda and TCM. The rhizome is rich in dietary fiber and vitamins, supporting digestive health. The seeds are used to treat digestive disorders and palpitations. Leaf extracts possess antioxidant and anti-obesity properties. The plant has symbolic spiritual significance, representing purity and enlightenment. Source: NCBI

medicinalUses: Traditional sedative, muscle relaxant, and treatment for anxiety and insomnia.
sideEffects: Generally considered safe in moderation, but potency varies by species.
regionsFound: Northern Hemisphere (Arctic, alpine, and temperate regions).
preparation: Tea or tincture made from the aerial parts.
detailedExplanation: Lousewort, particularly species like Pedicularis groenlandica, is known in herbal medicine for its potent sedative and anxiolytic properties. It has been traditionally used by various indigenous cultures to promote relaxation, relieve muscle tension, and induce restful sleep. Its effects are often described as similar to Skullcap or Valerian, but with a stronger muscle-relaxing component. It is sometimes called "Elephant Head" due to the shape of its flowers. Source: Native American Ethnobotany DB

medicinalUses: Diuretic, digestive aid (carminative), anti-flatulent, expectorant.
sideEffects: Photosensitivity (skin reaction to sun) from furanocoumarins.
preparation: Tea from leaves/roots, seeds as spice, root tincture.
detailedExplanation: Lovage is a robust herb whose seeds, leaves, and roots are all used medicinally. It acts as a powerful digestive tonic, relieving gas, bloating, and indigestion much like its relatives celery and angelica. As a diuretic, it is used to flush the kidneys and reduce water retention. The root is also used as an expectorant to clear congestion in respiratory tract infections. Its strong, savory flavor also makes it a popular culinary herb. Source: ScienceDirect

medicinalUses: Source of Lycopene (antioxidant), supports prostate and heart health, rich in Vitamins A & C.
sideEffects: Acidic, can cause heartburn or exacerbate GERD. Green parts are toxic (solanine).
preparation: Eaten raw, cooked, as juice, or in sauces.
detailedExplanation: The tomato, known historically as the "Love Apple," is a nutritional powerhouse. Its most famed compound is lycopene, a potent antioxidant linked to a reduced risk of prostate cancer and cardiovascular diseases. Cooking tomatoes increases the bioavailability of lycopene. They are also an excellent source of vitamin C, potassium, and folate, contributing to overall immune function and health. Source: NCBI

medicinalUses: Traditional use for liver health, jaundice, and as a tonic. Potent antioxidant.
sideEffects: May cause mild digestive upset in some.
preparation: Tea or tincture made from the stems.
detailedExplanation: Love Vine, more commonly known as Dodder or Amar Bel in India, is a unique parasitic plant with a strong history in Traditional Chinese Medicine and Ayurveda. It is considered a primary herb for liver and kidney vitality, used to treat jaundice, lower blood pressure, and improve bone health. Despite being a parasite, it concentrates powerful flavonoids and other antioxidants from its host plants, which contribute to its therapeutic effects. Source: NCBI

medicinalUses: Seeds are diuretic, emmenagogue (stimulates menstruation), and vermifuge (expels worms).
sideEffects: In large doses, can be toxic due to alkaloids.
preparation: Seeds used sparingly as a spice.
detailedExplanation: While its relative Nigella sativa (Black Seed) is famous medicinally, Love-in-a-mist has a more limited and cautious traditional use. Its seeds have been used in folk medicine as a diuretic to promote urination, as an emmenagogue to stimulate menstrual flow, and as a vermifuge to expel intestinal worms. However, it contains potentially toxic alkaloids (e.g., damascenine), so it is not recommended for internal medicinal use and is primarily valued as a beautiful ornamental plant. Source: Plants for a Future

medicinalUses: Highly nutritious; gluten-free grain is rich in protein, iron, and calcium. Leaves are eaten as a vegetable.
sideEffects: Contains oxalates; cooking reduces them. Those with kidney stones may need to moderate intake.
preparation: Seeds cooked as a grain, young leaves eaten as spinach.
detailedExplanation: Love-lies-bleeding is an ancient grain valued for its exceptional nutritional profile. The seeds are a complete protein, containing all essential amino acids, and are rich in magnesium, iron, and fiber. The leaves are also edible and nutritious, similar to spinach. It is not a potent medicinal herb but is a powerful functional food that supports overall health, bone strength (due to high calcium), and is excellent for those with gluten intolerance. Source: NCBI

medicinalUses: Traditional topical uses for wounds and mild skin complaints; leaf extracts show antimicrobial activity in preliminary reports.
sideEffects: Minimal reported systemic toxicity; topical irritation in sensitive skin possible.
preparation: Leaves mashed for poultice; leaf decoction for external washing.
detailedExplanation: Ardisia humilis is a lesser-known Ardisia species from Western Ghats used locally as topical antiseptic and wound-care plant in folk practice; pharmacology is limited and regional. Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ardisia_humilis.

medicinalUses: Demulcent (soothes irritation), used for coughs, digestive inflammation, and skin sores.
sideEffects: Generally very safe.
preparation: Tea from leaves, poultice for skin.
detailedExplanation: Low Mallow is a common weed with valuable soothing properties, shared with its relative Marshmallow. The leaves are rich in mucilage, a sticky substance that swells in water. When consumed as a tea, it coats and soothes irritated mucous membranes in the throat and digestive tract, providing relief from coughs, sore throats, gastritis, and heartburn. A poultice of the leaves can be applied topically to soothe boils, insect bites, and inflammation. Source: Plants for a Future

medicinalUses:
• Rich in vitamins A, C, E, K and minerals
• Used for improving digestion and anemia
• Reduces cholesterol and supports heart health
• Mild phytoestrogenic, used in menopausal formulas
sideEffects:
May cause GI upset or gas in some people
High doses may thin blood
preparation: Sprouted or dried leaf powder; capsules or decoction (leaves)
detailedExplanation: Known in Ayurveda and Western herbology as a nutritive tonic, Lucerne (Alfalfa) is high in protein and deeply nourishing. It is widely used for strengthening hair, bones, and overall vitality. Its sprouts are common in diets, and its leaves are used to make teas that support digestion and hormonal balance. (Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2673798/)

medicinalUses:
• Bark used traditionally for pain, inflammation, malaria
• Leaves & stem bark used for asthma and fever
• Flowers used against intestinal worms
sideEffects:
TOXIC in excess
May cause vomiting, paralysis if raw seeds consumed
preparation:
Bark decoction under expertise
Topical paste
detailedExplanation: Known for its bright red seeds and ornamental uses, this African tree has medicinal relevance in traditional African systems. The bark and roots are used for treating malaria, parasites, and inflammation. Sedative and spasmolytic qualities are observed at controlled doses. Due to its toxicity, it is only used carefully by trained practitioners. (Source: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/26437268/)

medicinalUses:
• No medicinal use due to high toxicity
• In past, used for inducing vomiting or punishment poisons (wrongly)
• Now considered solely toxic
sideEffects: Highly poisonous plant; ingestion causes cardiac arrest
preparation: NOT RECOMMENDED – All parts toxic
detailedExplanation: This beautifully blooming shrub/tree is now considered dangerous and avoided in serious herbalism. The seeds and sap contain cardiac glycosides that severely affect heart function. Traditionally used in extreme measures for vomiting or even poisoning. Should not be part of any healing system today. (Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5110809/)

medicinalUses:
• Traditionally used for respiratory diseases and tuberculosis
• Antibacterial and anti-inflammatory
• Used externally for wounds and frostbite
• Source of lichen acids with potential antibiotic use
sideEffects:
Raw lichen may upset stomach
Liver metabolism issues from long-term use
preparation: Dried powdered form; slow decoction of lichen
detailedExplanation: Lungmoss is a tree-dwelling lichen known for its lung-like form and historical use for pulmonary problems. Considered sacred in some indigenous cultures, it has antimicrobial compounds (lobaric acids) being studied for novel antibiotic properties. (Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC1121134/)

medicinalUses:
• Used for dry coughs, hoarseness, bronchitis
• Soothes lining of lungs, throat, and mouth
• Mildly diuretic and anti-inflammatory
sideEffects: Very safe herb – may cause mild allergy in sensitive individuals
preparation: Dried leaf infusion or extract; syrup formulas
detailedExplanation: A cornerstone in European herbal respiratory care, Lungwort is named from the Doctrine of Signatures – its spotted leaves resemble lung tissue. Widely used in treating coughs, gentle expectoration, and sore throats. Also used externally for insect bites and ulcers. (Source: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/22164760/)

medicinalUses:
• Protein-rich pulses used to support nutrition
• Some varieties used in diabetes and cholesterol management
• Seeds used in traditional medicine for helminths
• Flour used to control inflammation topically
sideEffects:
Bitter lupin varieties are toxic
May cause nausea or nervous signs
preparation: Fermented seed flour; topical or cooked pulp
detailedExplanation: Lupins are nitrogen-fixing legumes. Sweet lupin varieties are safe and protein-rich for food, while bitter types contain neurotoxic alkaloids. Traditionally, lupins were soaked and fermented for removing bitterness and used for blood sugar and parasite control. (Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4076392/)

medicinalUses:
• Mild traditional use for digestive upset and parasitic infection
• Topical soother for swellings
• Ornamental but not widely used medicinally
sideEffects: May be toxic raw – contains lupinine alkaloid (neurotoxic)
preparation: Only seeds or leaves cleansed and boiled
detailedExplanation: Native blue lupine was sometimes used externally for inflammation and stings, and internally (with caution) for parasitic infections. Today it is more appreciated for its ecological role in nitrogen cycling and pollinator support. (Source: https://plants.usda.gov/)

medicinalUses:
• Limited traditional documentation – edible bulb
• Bulb traditionally roasted and eaten by tribes
• Some mild nutritive value and seasonal use during scarcity
sideEffects: None if bulb is roasted
preparation: raw may be indigestible
detailedExplanation: Roasted bulb only

medicinalUses:
• Rich in Vitamin C and antioxidants
• Fresh pulp supports immune and skin health
• Leaves used in diabetes and inflammation
• Seed extract under study for antiviral, anti-hyperglycemia
sideEffects: Unripe fruits (especially on empty stomach) may cause hypoglycemia in children
preparation: Pulp eaten raw; leaf decoction; seed not used home
detailedExplanation: Litchi is a delicious fruit native to Asia with several therapeutic perks. The pulp nourishes skin and immunity, while leaves have been investigated for their antidiabetic effects. Recent studies have explored lychee polyphenols in managing insulin resistance. However, consuming unripe fruit in excess, especially by undernourished children, can cause sudden blood glycemic crash. (Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6631096/)

medicinalUses:
• High in monounsaturated fats — supports heart health
• Antioxidant-rich
• Source of selenium, magnesium for nerve & muscle health
• Emollient in cosmetics
sideEffects:
Nut allergy possible
High calorie content if overconsumed
preparation: Roasted, raw nuts; oil used in skin care
detailedExplanation: Macadamia nuts are nutritionally rich nuts used mainly in gourmet and health foods. While not extensively medicinal, the nut oil is valued for skincare due to its hydrating and antioxidant qualities. Safe snacks for heart disease patients when eaten in moderation. (Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC9028487/)

medicinalUses:
• Aids digestion and relieves nausea
• Tonic to nervous system
• Used in Ayurveda for flatulence and insomnia
• Anti-inflammatory, carminative
sideEffects: Toxic in large doses; hallucinogenic in excess
preparation: Ground spice used in culinary, teas, herbal oils
detailedExplanation: Mace is the aromatic red aril surrounding the nutmeg seed. Known in Ayurveda and Unani medicine as “javitri,” it is used to improve appetite, treat indigestion, and calm nerves. Its warm essence makes it suitable for pain relief oils and tonics. (Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4003790/)

medicinalUses:
• Source of powerful anticancer drugs (vincristine, vinblastine)
• Historically used for diabetes, fevers
• Modern oncology uses isolated alkaloids for leukemia and lymphoma
sideEffects:
Highly toxic raw plant
Do Not self-medicate
preparation: Pharmaceutical extract only (Rx drugs), historical leaf decoction (now obsolete)
detailedExplanation: An ornamental with pink or white flowers, Catharanthus roseus is one of the few plants from which real chemotherapy drug alkaloids are derived. While historically a diabetes remedy, its leaf juice is now considered dangerous and replaced by purified alkaloids. (Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5585735/)

medicinalUses:
• Premier blood purifier in Ayurveda
• Helpful in skin conditions like acne, eczema
• Used for lymphatic support, detox
• Antioxidant and menstrual regulator
sideEffects:
Can cause mild nausea
Blood-thinner effects possible
preparation: Root decoction, capsules, churnas
detailedExplanation: Root of this traditional herb has red color due to alizarin content. In Ayurveda, Manjistha is a pivotal herb for purifying blood, enhancing complexion, treating hyperpigmentation, and lymph stagnation. Often paired with neem and turmeric.

medicinalUses: The sweet-and-sour fruit pulp is a nutritious snack. The bark and pods are astringent and used to treat diarrhea, mouth sores, and gum problems.
sideEffects: The fruit is very safe. The seeds are not for consumption.
regionsFound: Throughout India, commonly planted as a roadside tree.
preparation: Eat the ripe fruit pulp raw. Boil the bark to make a tea for diarrhea or a mouthwash/gargle for mouth ulcers and sore throat.
detailedExplanation: This fast-growing tree is easily recognized by its curved pink and white pods. The fruit is a popular, refreshing treat. The bark, rich in tannins, is a reliable traditional remedy for gastrointestinal and oral inflammation. Source: FRLHT

medicinalUses: The flowers are a nutritious food and tonic. The seed oil is applied to skin diseases and used for rheumatism. The bark helps reduce fever.
sideEffects: The fermented flower drink can cause intoxication. The seeds are not for eating.
preparation: Flowers are eaten raw, cooked, or fermented. Seed oil is applied topically. A decoction is made from the bark for fever.
detailedExplanation: Mahua is a life-sustaining tree for many tribal communities. Its flowers are rich in sugar and nutrients. The seed oil is a traditional remedy for skin problems and joint pain. The bark has antipyretic (fever-reducing) properties. Source: FRLHT

medicinalUses: No significant medicinal benefits documented. Primarily valued as an ornamental groundcover.
sideEffects: Non-toxic but not used for consumption.
regionsFound: Native to Europe and Asia; naturalized in parts of North America.
preparation: Not used for medicine or food. Grown for its attractive, low-growing mat of foliage and bright pink flowers.
detailedExplanation: Maiden Pink is a hardy, mat-forming perennial prized in rock gardens and as a groundcover for its profusion of small, vivid pink flowers with a light scent. It is drought-tolerant and easy to grow, spreading to form a dense carpet that suppresses weeds. While it belongs to the same genus as the Clove Pink, it does not share the same strong scent or historical medicinal use and is cultivated almost exclusively for its aesthetic appeal in landscaping. Source: https://www.rhs.org.uk/plants/5733/dianthus-deltoides/details

medicinalUses: Respiratory tonic, mild diuretic, Expectorant, and hair tonic.
sideEffects: Rare skin irritation
preparation: Leaf decoction
detailedExplanation: Maidenhair fern used traditionally for respiratory conditions and mild diuretic purposes. Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adiantum_capillus-veneris

medicinalUses: Used in folk remedies for coughs, kidney complaints and menstrual irregularities; astringent and demulcent actions attributed.
sideEffects: Overconsumption uncommon; check for local adulterants.
preparation: Decoction of fronds taken as mild tonic; topical poultice for wounds.
detailedExplanation: Maidenhair spleenwort grows on rocks in temperate zones; local herbalists use frond decoctions for urinary and respiratory complaints, though research is limited. Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Asplenium_trichomanes

medicinalUses: The best Ayurvedic herb for all respiratory problems. It relieves cough, asthma, and bronchitis by loosening and expelling mucus.
sideEffects: Very safe. May cause nausea or vomiting in extremely high doses.
regionsFound: Found throughout India, up to 1300 meters.
preparation: The juice of fresh leaves is taken with honey. A decoction is made from leaves and roots. It is also available as a syrup or tablet.
detailedExplanation: Vasaka is a premier bronchodilator and expectorant. It is used for a wide range of respiratory conditions, from common colds to chronic asthma. It works by soothing the bronchial tubes and making it easier to cough up phlegm. Source: NCBI

medicinalUses: Expectorant, respiratory aid, anti-inflammatory
sideEffects: May cause nausea in high doses
preparation: Leaf decoction, juice
detailedExplanation: Adhatoda vasica is a widely used medicinal shrub in India for respiratory issues like asthma and bronchitis. Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adhatoda_vasica

medicinalUses: Laxative (mild), demulcent (soothing), rich in vitamins A & C, iron, and calcium.
sideEffects: The oxalate content may be a concern for individuals prone to kidney stones if consumed in very large quantities.
regionsFound: Tropical Asia and Africa; cultivated worldwide.
preparation: Leaves and stems are cooked as a vegetable, used in soups and curries.
detailedExplanation: Malabar Spinach is not a true spinach but a highly nutritious leafy green. Its succulent leaves and stems are rich in mucilage, which gives it a slightly slippery texture when cooked. This mucilage acts as a gentle bulk laxative and soothes the digestive tract. It is an excellent source of vitamins, particularly A and C, and minerals like iron and calcium, making it a valuable dietary supplement for overall health and vitality, especially in tropical regions where it thrives. Source: NCBI

medicinalUses: Anti-inflammatory, digestive aid, antioxidant
sideEffects: Rare
preparation: Rhizome decoction
detailedExplanation: Alpinia malaccensis is cultivated in Northeast India and used as both spice and medicine for digestive and inflammatory disorders. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK92771/

medicinalUses: Primarily consumed as a nutritious fruit; the astringent bark is used for thrush and mouth sores.
sideEffects: Generally safe when consuming the fruit.
regionsFound: Southeast Asia, widely cultivated in tropics.
preparation: Fruit eaten raw; a decoction of the bark is used as a mouthwash.
detailedExplanation: The Malay Apple is prized for its crisp, juicy, and mildly sweet fruit, which is a good source of hydration and vitamins. In traditional medicine, the astringent bark is the primary part used. A decoction is prepared and used as a gargle to treat candidiasis (thrush), canker sores, and other inflammatory conditions of the mouth and throat due to its antimicrobial and tissue-tightening properties. Source: Useful Tropical Plants

medicinalUses: Traditional and historical treatment for intestinal tapeworm infestation.
sideEffects: HIGHLY TOXIC. Can cause severe poisoning, blindness, liver damage, and death.
preparation: Oil extract from the rhizomes was used, ONLY under strict professional supervision.
detailedExplanation: Male Fern was once the treatment of choice for expelling tapeworms before the development of modern, safer anthelmintic drugs. The active compounds are potent paralysing agents for worms. However, due to its narrow therapeutic index (the difference between a therapeutic and toxic dose is very small), it is extremely dangerous for self-administration and is now obsolete in mainstream medicine. Source: PubMed

medicinalUses: Demulcent, emollient, used for coughs and skin irritation, identical to Common Mallow.
sideEffects: Generally very safe.
preparation: Tea from leaves and flowers; poultice for skin.
detailedExplanation: Blue Mallow typically refers to a variety or a common name for Malva sylvestris, which is known for its striking blue-purple flowers. Its properties and uses are identical to those of Common Mallow. It is a superb soothing herb, rich in mucilage, used to make teas that calm respiratory and digestive inflammation and poultices for external skin complaints. The vibrant flowers are also edible.

medicinalUses: Demulcent, diuretic, galactagogue (promotes breast milk), used in TCM for "damp-heat" conditions.
sideEffects: Generally safe.
preparation: Seeds, leaves, and roots are used in decoctions; young leaves eaten.
detailedExplanation: Known as "Dong Kui Zi" in Traditional Chinese Medicine, Cluster Mallow is used to clear heat and promote urination. It is specifically used for conditions like painful urination and edema. The seeds are considered a galactagogue to promote milk flow in nursing mothers. The plant is also cultivated as a vegetable in parts of Asia, and its high mucilage content provides the typical soothing actions of the mallow family. Source: ScienceDirect
