medicinalUses: Demulcent (soothing), emollient, used for coughs, sore throats, and skin irritation.
sideEffects: Generally very safe.
regionsFound: Europe, North Africa, Asia; naturalized elsewhere.
preparation: Tea from leaves and flowers; poultice for skin.
detailedExplanation: Common Mallow is a classic demulcent herb, rich in mucilage. It has been used for centuries to soothe inflammation and irritation, both internally and externally. A tea made from the leaves and flowers is effective for calming dry, irritating coughs, laryngitis, and sore throats by coating the mucous membranes. Externally, a poultice or wash can be applied to soothe eczema, insect bites, and wounds. Source: ScienceDirect

medicinalUses: Demulcent, used for coughs, digestive inflammation, and skin sores.
sideEffects: Generally very safe.
preparation: Tea from leaves, poultice for skin.
detailedExplanation: Dwarf Mallow is a common and widespread weed with significant soothing properties. Like its larger relatives, it is rich in mucilage. A tea made from the leaves is an excellent, readily available remedy for soothing sore throats, coughs, and digestive irritation like heartburn or gastritis. A poultice made from the crushed leaves can be applied topically to draw out infection from boils and to soothe insect bites and minor burns. Source: PFAF

medicinalUses: Primarily ornamental. Not widely known for significant medicinal use.
sideEffects: No known side effects.
preparation: Not typically used for medicinal preparation.
detailedExplanation: Malope is an annual plant grown primarily for its large, showy, trumpet-shaped flowers that resemble those of the mallow family. While it belongs to the Malvaceae family, it does not share the prominent medicinal history or high mucilage content of genera like Malva or Althaea. Its value is almost exclusively horticultural, adding vibrant color to garden borders and flower arrangements.

medicinalUses: Demulcent, used for respiratory and digestive irritations, similar to Common Mallow.
sideEffects: Generally very safe.
preparation: Tea from leaves and flowers.
detailedExplanation: Musk Mallow is closely related to Common Mallow and shares its high mucilage content and soothing demulcent properties. It is used in folk medicine to prepare a soothing tea for respiratory ailments like bronchitis and coughs, as well as for mild digestive upsets like gastritis. The leaves are also edible. It is distinguished by its musky-scented leaves and beautiful pink flowers. Source: PFAF

medicinalUses: The flowers are diuretic, ophthalmic, and stomachic. The leaves are used for skin irritations.
sideEffects: Generally safe.
regionsFound: Asia, widely cultivated as an ornamental.
preparation: A decoction of the flowers or leaves is used.
detailedExplanation: While primarily an ornamental plant, Rose of Sharon has applications in traditional medicine, particularly in East Asia. A decoction of the flowers is used as a diuretic and to support digestive function. The leaves are demulcent and can be crushed and applied as a poultice to soothe skin irritations such as insect bites and minor rashes. Its showy flowers make it a popular garden shrub. Source: PFAF

medicinalUses: Demulcent, used for coughs and respiratory congestion; poultices for wounds and inflammation.
sideEffects: Generally very safe.
regionsFound: Coastal regions of the Mediterranean and Western Europe.
preparation: Tea from leaves and flowers; poultice from crushed leaves.
detailedExplanation: Tree Mallow is a large, shrubby member of the mallow family. Like its smaller relatives, it is rich in mucilage, which gives it strong soothing properties. Traditionally, a tea made from its leaves and flowers has been used to relieve coughs, bronchitis, and sore throats. Externally, a poultice made from the crushed leaves can be applied to wounds, boils, and inflamed skin to reduce swelling and draw out impurities. Source: PFAF

medicinalUses: Extremely rich in vitamin C — used as immune-supportive tonic, antioxidant and nutritive fruit.
sideEffects: High vitamin C may irritate sensitive stomachs; seeds not eaten.
preparation: Fruit eaten fresh; processed into syrups, juices and tonics.
detailedExplanation: Acerola is valued for its exceptionally high vitamin C content and used in nutritional and immune-support products; limited cultivation in India. Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Malpighia_emarginata

medicinalUses: The seed is used for parasitic skin infestations (e.g., scabies, head lice). The fruit is edible and nutritious.
sideEffects: Seed is toxic if ingested. Fruit pulp is safe.
regionsFound: Caribbean, Central and Northern South America.
preparation: Crushed seeds are made into a paste or infusion for topical application only.
detailedExplanation: The Mammee Apple is valued for its large, edible fruit. However, the seeds possess potent insecticidal and antiparasitic properties. In traditional medicine, a paste or infusion made from the crushed seeds is applied topically to treat skin conditions caused by parasites, such as scabies mites and head lice. The fruit itself is rich in vitamins and fiber. Source: USDA

medicinalUses: Extremely poisonous. No safe medicinal use. Historically, the sap was used on arrowheads.
sideEffects: Severe phytodermatitis (skin blistering and inflammation) from sap, blindness from smoke or sap, and fatal poisoning if ingested.
regionsFound: Coastal regions of the Caribbean, Florida, and Central & South America.
preparation: NO INTERNAL OR TOPICAL USE.
detailedExplanation: Known as the "little apple of death," the Manchineel is one of the most poisonous trees in the world. Every part of it is toxic. The milky sap contains powerful irritants like phorbol esters. Contact with the skin causes severe blistering and burns. Ingesting the small, apple-like fruit can be fatal. Even standing under the tree during rain can cause skin blistering from diluted sap runoff. It has no safe modern medicinal applications. Source: NCBI

medicinalUses: Historically used as a sedative, analgesic (painkiller), and psychoactive; also as an anesthetic for surgery.
sideEffects: HIGHLY TOXIC. Can cause delirium, hallucinations, tachycardia, respiratory depression, and death.
preparation: Historically used in minute, controlled doses in potions and poultices.
detailedExplanation: Mandrake is steeped in European folklore and magic, often associated with rituals due to its human-shaped root. It contains potent tropane alkaloids (scopolamine, hyoscyamine) similar to those in Deadly Nightshade. These compounds have anticholinergic effects, which in toxic doses cause delirium, but in carefully controlled modern medicine, derivatives are used for anesthesia and motion sickness. Self-administration is extremely dangerous. Source: PubMed

medicinalUses: The fruit is rich in vitamins (A, C), fiber, and antioxidants. The leaf is used in traditional medicine for diabetes and as an astringent.
sideEffects: Skin contact with sap can cause dermatitis (similar to poison ivy) in sensitive individuals. Unripe fruit can cause stomach upset.
regionsFound: Native to South Asia; cultivated in tropics worldwide.
preparation: Fruit eaten ripe or unripe; leaf decoction is drunk.
detailedExplanation: The "king of fruits" is a nutritional powerhouse. The ripe fruit is an excellent source of Vitamin C and beta-carotene. In Ayurveda, mango leaves are particularly valued; a decoction is used to help manage blood sugar levels and treat hiccups and throat problems. The bark and kernel also have astringent properties. Source: NCBI

medicinalUses: Potent antioxidant, anti-inflammatory; the pericarp (rind) is traditionally used for skin infections and diarrhea.
sideEffects: Generally safe when consuming the fruit pulp. The rind is very astringent and can cause constipation in high doses.
regionsFound: Southeast Asia; cultivated in tropical climates.
preparation: Fruit pulp eaten fresh; a decoction is made from the dried rind.
detailedExplanation: Known as the "queen of fruits," the mangosteen's deep purple rind is its most medicinally active part. It is exceptionally rich in a class of antioxidants called xanthones (e.g., alpha-mangostin). Traditionally, a tea from the rind is used to treat dysentery, diarrhea, and skin conditions like eczema and acne due to its powerful anti-inflammatory and antimicrobial properties. Source: NCBI

medicinalUses: Astringent; the bark is used for treating diarrhea, fever, and to reduce inflammation; also used for tanning leather.
sideEffects: High tannin content can cause constipation or stomach upset if overused.
regionsFound: Tropical and subtropical coastlines in the Americas and West Africa.
preparation: Decoction or tincture of the bark.
detailedExplanation: Red Mangrove is a vital coastal ecosystem engineer. Its bark is exceptionally rich in tannins, which give it strong astringent properties. In traditional medicine, a decoction of the bark is used to treat diarrhea, dysentery, fever, and to reduce inflammation. It has also been used as a folk remedy for diabetes and to stop hemorrhages. Source: USDA

medicinalUses: The pulp is a source of vitamins; the bark is astringent and used for diarrhea and gum diseases.
sideEffects: Generally safe in food amounts. The seeds are not edible.
regionsFound: Native to Mexico; naturalized in South and Southeast Asia.
preparation: Pulp eaten raw; a decoction is made from the bark.
detailedExplanation: Manila Tamarind is a fast-growing tree known for its sweet-and-sour pink and white pulp that surrounds the seeds. This pulp is rich in vitamin C. The bark and pods are rich in tannins, and a decoction is used as a gargle for sore throats and gum inflammation and is taken internally to treat chronic diarrhea and dysentery. Source: PFAF

medicinalUses: Source of "Manna," a sweet, mild laxative suitable for children and the elderly.
sideEffects: Can cause bloating or cramping in sensitive individuals.
preparation: The dried sap (Manna) is eaten directly or dissolved in water.
detailedExplanation: The Manna Ash is the primary source of the substance "Manna," a sweet, gummy sap obtained by making cuts in the bark. This sap contains mannitol, a sugar alcohol, which acts as an osmotic laxative. It is known for being a very gentle and effective laxative that does not cause griping or cramping, making it ideal for delicate constitutions. Source: PubMed

medicinalUses: Manuka honey is renowned for its potent, non-peroxide antibacterial activity, used for wound healing and sore throats.
sideEffects: Generally safe. Allergic reactions are rare.
preparation: Honey is applied topically to wounds or taken orally for throat infections.
detailedExplanation: Manuka is famous for the honey produced by bees that pollinate its flowers. This honey contains a unique compound, Methylglyoxal (MGO), which gives it powerful and stable antibacterial properties, even when diluted. It is clinically used in wound dressings to treat burns, ulcers, and infections, including those resistant to antibiotics. It is also effective for soothing sore throats and supporting digestive health. Source: NCBI

medicinalUses: Digestive aid, anti-inflammatory, mild diuretic
sideEffects: Rare
preparation: Leaf decoction
detailedExplanation: Ammannia multiflora grows in wet rice fields and is used traditionally for digestive and anti-inflammatory purposes. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK92771/

medicinalUses: Traditional tonic and expectorant; used in regional remedies for cough and mild infections.
sideEffects: No widespread toxicity reports; topical irritation possible.
preparation: Leaf decoction; fruit preparations regionally used as tonics.
detailedExplanation: Ardisia polycephala occurs in montane zones and is used locally as an expectorant and tonic; ethnobotanical documentation is region-specific. Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ardisia_polycephala.

medicinalUses: The berries are a traditional food; leaves are astringent and used for urinary tract infections.
sideEffects: Generally safe when consumed as food. High tannin content in leaves can cause stomach upset if overconsumed.
preparation: Berries eaten raw or made into cider; leaf tea.
detailedExplanation: Manzanita is a genus of evergreen shrubs known for their smooth, red bark and small, apple-like berries. Native American tribes extensively used the berries as a nutritious food source, often grinding them into a meal or making a refreshing cider. The leaves, similar to its relative Uva Ursi, contain arbutin and are highly astringent. A tea made from the leaves was traditionally used as a diuretic and to treat urinary tract infections and kidney ailments. Source: USDA Forest Service

medicinalUses: The inner bark was used by indigenous peoples as a laxative and for coughs. The sap can be boiled into syrup.
sideEffects: No common side effects reported for traditional uses.
preparation: Decoction of inner bark; syrup from sap.
detailedExplanation: The Bigleaf Maple, as its name implies, has the largest leaves of any maple species. While not as famous for syrup as the Sugar Maple, its sap can be concentrated into a sweet syrup. More medicinally, various Native American tribes prepared a decoction from the inner bark to be used as a gentle laxative and to treat tuberculosis and coughs. The bark was also used to make ropes and baskets. Source: Native American Ethnobotany DB

medicinalUses: The sap can be used for syrup; limited historical medicinal use for skin warts.
sideEffects: No common side effects.
regionsFound: Europe and Western Asia (invasive in North America)
preparation: Sap is boiled into syrup; the milky sap from leaf stalks was applied to warts.
detailedExplanation: The Norway Maple is widely planted as an ornamental and street tree. Like other maples, its sap contains sugar and can be converted into syrup, though the sugar content is lower than in Sugar Maple. In traditional European folk medicine, the milky fluid from the leaf stalks was applied directly to skin warts in an attempt to remove them, likely due to its mild irritant and enzymatic properties. Source: PFAF

medicinalUses: The inner bark was used as a wash for inflamed eyes and for muscle aches. Sap is used for syrup.
sideEffects: No common side effects.
preparation: Decoction of inner bark as a wash; syrup from sap.
detailedExplanation: The Red Maple is a major source of maple syrup, second only to the Sugar Maple. In terms of traditional medicine, Native American tribes had several uses for it. A decoction of the inner bark was used as a wash for sore, inflamed eyes. It was also used internally for hives, cramps, and as a general remedy for muscle aches and pain. The bark was also considered to have astringent properties. Source: Native American Ethnobotany DB

medicinalUses: The sap is used for syrup; inner bark was used in cough remedies.
sideEffects: No common side effects.
preparation: Syrup from sap; decoction of inner bark.
detailedExplanation: The Silver Maple is a fast-growing tree often found in wet soils. Its sap can be boiled down into syrup, though it is paler and milder than that from the Sugar Maple. In traditional Appalachian and Native American medicine, a compound infusion of the inner bark was used specifically as a remedy for coughs. The bark was also used to make a wash for treating sore eyes, similar to the Red Maple. Source: Native American Ethnobotany DB

medicinalUses: The inner bark was used as a cough remedy and a "blood purifier" in folk traditions.
sideEffects: No common side effects.
preparation: Decoction of inner bark.
detailedExplanation: The Striped Maple, also known as Moosewood, is a small understory tree easily identified by its distinctive green-and-white striped bark. Native American tribes, such as the Iroquois, prepared a decoction from the inner bark and used it as a remedy for colds and coughs. It was also considered a "blood purifier," a traditional concept for treating skin diseases and systemic inflammation. Source: Native American Ethnobotany DB

medicinalUses: The primary source of maple syrup; the inner bark was historically used as a cough suppressant and diuretic.
sideEffects: No common side effects from traditional medicinal use.
preparation: Syrup from sap; decoction of inner bark.
detailedExplanation: The Sugar Maple is the quintessential source of maple syrup and sugar. Beyond its culinary fame, it had minor uses in folk medicine. A decoction of the inner bark was used to treat coughs and as a diuretic. The syrup itself, beyond being a sweetener, was sometimes used to mask the taste of bitter herbal medicines and to soothe sore throats. Source: Native American Ethnobotany DB

medicinalUses: The berries are one of the richest known sources of antioxidants, supporting overall wellness, anti-aging, and blood sugar control.
sideEffects: Generally safe. Due to high antioxidant content, very high doses may theoretically act as pro-oxidants.
preparation: Berries eaten fresh, dried, or as powder/juice.
detailedExplanation: The Maqui berry is a potent "superfruit" from the Patagonia region. It has an exceptionally high ORAC (Oxygen Radical Absorbance Capacity) value, largely due to its high concentration of anthocyanins, particularly delphinidins. These compounds are studied for their ability to combat oxidative stress, reduce inflammation, support cardiovascular health, and help modulate blood glucose levels by influencing carbohydrate metabolism. Source: NCBI

medicinalUses: The fruit is rich in antioxidants and fiber. The leaves are used for anxiety, insomnia, and as a mild sedative.
sideEffects: Fruit is safe. Leaf extracts may cause drowsiness. Do not use with sedative medications without consultation.
regionsFound: Native to South Brazil; cultivated in tropical/subtropical areas worldwide.
preparation: Fruit eaten raw; tea or tincture made from the leaves.
detailedExplanation: Maracuja, more commonly known as Passion Fruit, is prized for its aromatic and juicy fruit. Beyond its nutritional value, the leaves contain harmala alkaloids and flavonoids, including chrysin, which are known for their calming effects. Traditionally, a tea made from the leaves is used to alleviate anxiety, nervousness, and promote restful sleep, sharing these properties with other Passiflora species. Source: NCBI

medicinalUses: Skin Health & Wound Healing: Flowers are rich in lutein and antioxidant carotenoids. Used in salves for minor burns, wounds, and skin irritations for their antiseptic and anti-inflammatory properties. Eye Health.
sideEffects: Very safe for topical use. May cause skin irritation in sensitive individuals.
preparation: Poultice of crushed flowers, Infused oil, Tea from petals.
detailedExplanation: Marigold petals are a rich source of carotenoids like lutein and zeaxanthin, which are crucial for filtering harmful blue light and protecting eye health, potentially reducing the risk of macular degeneration. Topically, its flavonoids and essential oils help soothe inflamed skin, promote wound healing, and fight infection. It is also a sacred flower in many cultural and religious ceremonies. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3841999/

medicinalUses: Used for digestive issues, as a diuretic, and topically for skin fungi and wounds. The flowers are a source of lutein for eye health.
sideEffects: Skin contact may cause dermatitis in sensitive individuals.
preparation: Tea from leaves and flowers; poultice for skin; flower petals as food color.
detailedExplanation: African Marigold is widely grown for ornamental and cultural purposes. In traditional medicine, it is used to treat stomach aches, indigestion, and as a diuretic. Topically, a poultice of the leaves is applied to sores, wounds, and fungal infections. The vibrant flowers are a rich source of lutein and zeaxanthin, carotenoids essential for filtering blue light and protecting eye health. Source: ResearchGate

medicinalUses: Similar to Pot Marigold; used for its anti-inflammatory and wound-healing properties, though considered less potent.
sideEffects: Generally safe. Potential for allergic reactions in those sensitive to the Asteraceae family.
regionsFound: Mediterranean region; naturalized in parts of America and Asia.
preparation: Infused oil, salve, or tea from the flowers.
detailedExplanation: Corn Marigold is a close relative of the more famous Pot Marigold (Calendula officinalis). It shares similar medicinal properties but is less commonly used. Its bright yellow flowers contain flavonoids and triterpenoids that promote wound healing and reduce inflammation. It is used in folk medicine to make salves for minor cuts, burns, and skin irritations, and as a tea for internal inflammation. Source: ScienceDirect

medicinalUses: Used by Native Americans to treat coughs, colds, and gastrointestinal issues; also as a fish poison.
sideEffects: Can be toxic to livestock and humans if ingested in large quantities.
preparation: Used with caution in traditional preparations.
detailedExplanation: Desert Marigold is a drought-tolerant plant with silvery-green foliage and bright yellow flowers. It was used by indigenous peoples for medicinal purposes, but it must be used with caution as it contains toxic compounds. It was traditionally used in small, controlled amounts to treat coughs, colds, and stomach problems. Its use as a fish poison highlights its inherent toxicity. Source: SEINet

medicinalUses: Used similarly to African Marigold for digestive issues and skin conditions. Also planted as a natural nematode pesticide in gardens.
sideEffects: Skin contact may cause dermatitis.
preparation: Tea from leaves; poultice for skin.
detailedExplanation: French Marigold is a popular compact ornamental plant. It shares medicinal uses with its relative, African Marigold, being used in teas for digestive complaints and in poultices for boils, sores, and earaches. Its most significant modern use is in companion planting; the roots release thiophenes into the soil which are toxic to nematodes, protecting nearby crops. Source: PFAF

medicinalUses: Historically used for fits, anemia, and as a wart remedy.
sideEffects: RAW PLANT IS TOXIC and can cause severe irritation. Toxicity is reduced by thorough drying or boiling.
regionsFound: Temperate regions of the Northern Hemisphere in wetlands.
preparation: Used historically only after careful preparation (drying/boiling).
detailedExplanation: Marsh Marigold is a beautiful plant of wet meadows and stream banks. It is a member of the Buttercup family and contains the toxic irritant protoanemonin, which is released when the plant is bruised. This toxin causes severe blistering of the skin and mucous membranes. Traditional uses are historical and risky; it was sometimes used after extensive processing to treat convulsions and warts. Source: PFAF

medicinalUses: Potent wound healer, anti-inflammatory, antiseptic. Used for skin lesions, cuts, burns, rashes, and internally for digestive inflammation.
sideEffects: Allergic reactions possible, especially in those sensitive to Asteraceae plants (ragweed, chrysanthemums).
regionsFound: Native to Southern Europe; cultivated worldwide.
preparation: Infused oil, salve, cream, tea, or tincture.
detailedExplanation: Pot Marigold, or Calendula, is one of the most revered herbs in skin care. Its vibrant orange flowers are rich in triterpenoids, flavonoids, and carotenoids. Clinical studies support its use to significantly speed up wound healing, reduce inflammation in skin conditions like dermatitis, and soothe radiation-induced skin damage. It is also used in gargles for mouth inflammation and teas for gastritis. Source: NCBI

medicinalUses: Pain relief, anti-nausea, appetite stimulation, muscle relaxant, reduces anxiety, treats seizures.
sideEffects: Impaired memory, coordination; anxiety, paranoia; dry mouth, red eyes; long-term use risk of dependence.
regionsFound: Cultivated worldwide, both legally and illegally.
preparation: Smoked, vaporized, ingested as edibles/oils, applied topically.
detailedExplanation: Cannabis contains over 100 cannabinoids, primarily THC (psychoactive) and CBD (non-psychoactive). It is used medicinally for chronic pain, chemotherapy-induced nausea, multiple sclerosis spasticity, and epilepsy (e.g., Epidiolex for Dravet syndrome). Effects vary drastically based on THC:CBD ratio, dosage, and individual physiology. Source: National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine

medicinalUses: Digestive aid (carminative), mild sedative, antioxidant, used for colds and coughs.
sideEffects: Generally safe in culinary amounts. Essential oil is potent and should be diluted.
preparation: Tea from dried leaves, culinary herb, infused oil.
detailedExplanation: Sweet Marjoram is a delicate culinary herb with a sweet, piney flavor. Its therapeutic properties are primarily as a carminative, helping to relieve flatulence and indigestion. It also has mild nervine properties, used in tea to calm nerves and promote sleep. Its antioxidant compounds, such as rosmarinic acid, contribute to its anti-inflammatory and antimicrobial effects. Source: ScienceDirect

medicinalUses: Potent antioxidant, antimicrobial, antifungal, expectorant, digestive aid.
sideEffects: Generally safe in food amounts. Can cause stomach upset in large doses.
preparation: Tea, tincture, culinary spice, essential oil (diluted).
detailedExplanation: Wild Marjoram is the plant known as Oregano. It is far more potent medicinally than Sweet Marjoram. Its high concentration of carvacrol and thymol gives it powerful antibacterial and antifungal properties. It is used to treat respiratory infections, digestive issues, and as a general immune booster. Its antioxidant capacity is one of the highest among herbs. Source: NCBI

medicinalUses: In purified Ayurvedic form, it is used as a rejuvenating tonic for the brain and nervous system, and to treat rheumatoid arthritis.
sideEffects: THE RAW NUT IS HIGHLY TOXIC AND CAUSTIC, causing severe skin blisters and poisoning.
regionsFound: Sub-Himalayan tract and warmer parts of India.
preparation: STRICT WARNING: Only used in Ayurveda after a complex multi-step purification (shodhana) process. Never use raw nuts.
detailedExplanation: The Marking Nut is a powerful but dangerous medicine. Its common name comes from the black, corrosive juice of the nut, which was used to mark linen. In Ayurveda, after detoxification, it is a highly valued rasayana (rejuvenator). Source: AYUSH

medicinalUses: Primarily ornamental. No significant documented traditional medicinal uses.
sideEffects: No known side effects.
regionsFound: Native to Andes; cultivated in frost-free gardens.
preparation: Not typically used for medicine.
detailedExplanation: The Marmalade Bush is a vibrant evergreen shrub known for its clusters of brilliant orange flowers that change from yellow to red as they mature. It is grown exclusively for its ornamental value in gardens and greenhouses. While it belongs to the Solanaceae (nightshade) family, it is not known to be toxic nor does it have a history of use in folk medicine.

medicinalUses: The Aboriginal people used the resin (kino) as an antiseptic for wounds and sores, and as a digestive aid.
sideEffects: No common side effects from traditional external use.
preparation: Resin applied directly to wounds or dissolved in water.
detailedExplanation: Marri is a prominent eucalyptus tree in Western Australia. Its most notable medicinal product is the dark red resin that exudes from its bark. This resin is rich in tannins. Noongar Aboriginal people traditionally used it as a powerful antiseptic, applying it directly to cuts, burns, and sores to prevent infection. It was also dissolved in water to make a solution for treating diarrhea and stomach upsets. Source: CSIRO

medicinalUses: Nutritious, low-calorie food; high in fiber, vitamins A and C; seeds are anti-parasitic (vermifuge).
sideEffects: Generally very safe.
preparation: Fruit cooked; seeds eaten raw or dried.
detailedExplanation: A marrow is a type of summer squash, valued as a nutritious vegetable. The flesh is low in calories and high in water and fiber, aiding digestion. Like pumpkins, the seeds of all Cucurbita species contain the compound cucurbitin, which has anthelmintic (anti-worm) properties and is used in traditional medicine to expel intestinal parasites like tapeworms and roundworms. Source: NCBI

medicinalUses: Astringent, used for diarrhea, mouth and throat inflammation, and to stop bleeding.
sideEffects: Generally safe due to astringency, but high tannin content can cause stomach upset.
regionsFound: Northern temperate and Arctic regions in bogs and fens.
preparation: Gargle or mouthwash from root/leaf decoction; tea for diarrhea.
detailedExplanation: Marsh Cinquefoil is a plant of wetlands, recognized by its distinctive dark red flowers. It is a powerful astringent due to its high tannin content. Traditionally, a decoction of the roots and leaves has been used as a gargle for sore throats, mouth ulcers, and gum disease. Internally, it was used to treat diarrhea, dysentery, and internal bleeding. Source: PFAF

medicinalUses: Used historically as a vermifuge (expels intestinal worms) and for rheumatism.
sideEffects: Potential for toxicity; use is not well-documented and is considered risky.
regionsFound: Temperate Northern Hemisphere in wet habitats.
preparation: Historical use of root decoction.
detailedExplanation: The Marsh Fern has a limited history of medicinal use. It was reportedly used by Native American tribes and in European folk medicine as a vermifuge to expel intestinal worms. It was also used in poultices for rheumatism and muscle aches. However, like many ferns, it may contain thiaminase (which breaks down vitamin B1) or other potentially toxic compounds, so its use is not recommended. Source: PFAF

medicinalUses: Reduces thyroid hormone activity, used for hyperthyroidism (Graves' disease); also astringent and sedative.
sideEffects: Can significantly lower thyroid function. Contraindicated in hypothyroidism.
regionsFound: Europe, Asia, North America in damp habitats.
preparation: Tea, tincture from aerial parts.
detailedExplanation: Marsh Horehound, or Gypsywort, is a key herb in Western herbalism for managing mild to moderate hyperthyroidism. Its lithospermic acid and other phenolic compounds interfere with the thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH), reducing the production of thyroid hormones T4 and T3. It also has astringent properties useful for reducing heavy menstruation. Source: PubMed

medicinalUses: Demulcent, emollient; soothes irritated mucous membranes in coughs, sore throats, and digestive issues like gastritis.
sideEffects: Generally very safe.
regionsFound: Europe, Western Asia, North Africa; naturalized in North America.
preparation: Tea, syrup, or tincture from the root; poultice from leaves.
detailedExplanation: The Marsh Mallow plant is the original source of the marshmallow confection. Its root is exceptionally rich in mucilage—a thick, slippery substance that coats and soothes inflammation. It is a premier herb for dry, hacking coughs, bronchitis, and sore throats. This demulcent action also extends to the digestive tract, relieving heartburn, gastritis, and IBS. Topically, it soothes skin inflammation. Source: NCBI

medicinalUses: Historically used for fits, anemia, and as a wart remedy.
sideEffects: RAW PLANT IS TOXIC and can cause severe irritation. Toxicity is reduced by thorough drying or boiling.
regionsFound: Temperate regions of the Northern Hemisphere in wetlands.
preparation: Used historically only after careful preparation (drying/boiling).
detailedExplanation: Marsh Marigold is a beautiful plant of wet meadows and stream banks. It is a member of the Buttercup family and contains the toxic irritant protoanemonin, which is released when the plant is bruised. This toxin causes severe blistering of the skin and mucous membranes. Traditional uses are historical and risky; it was sometimes used after extensive processing to treat convulsions and warts. Source: PFAF

medicinalUses: Digestive aid, diuretic
sideEffects: None known
preparation: Seed decoction
detailedExplanation: Marsh parsley helps with digestion and water retention. Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apium_leptophyllum

medicinalUses: Cognitive enhancer, wound healer, reduces anxiety, improves circulation, treats venous insufficiency.
sideEffects: Generally safe. Can cause skin sensitivity or headache in high doses. Drowsiness.
regionsFound: Wetlands in Asia, Africa, North America, and Oceania.
preparation: Tea, tincture, capsule, or poultice from leaves.
detailedExplanation: Marsh Pennywort, widely known as Gotu Kola, is a cornerstone of Ayurvedic medicine. It is renowned as a "brain tonic" for improving memory and cognitive function. It significantly accelerates wound healing and is used for skin conditions like psoriasis. It also strengthens blood vessels, making it effective for chronic venous insufficiency and reducing varicose veins. Source: NCBI

medicinalUses: Traditional antiseptic, used for coughs, bronchitis, and arthritis; insect repellent.
sideEffects: TOXIC if ingested. Can cause vomiting, dizziness, and organ damage. Essential oil is a neurotoxin.
regionsFound: Bogs and wetlands in northern North America, Europe, and Asia.
preparation: Not recommended for internal use. Historically used in dilute infusions or as an insect repellent.
detailedExplanation: Marsh Rosemary is a strongly aromatic bog plant. It contains ledol and palustrol, compounds that are toxic to humans but have traditional use as a potent antiseptic and insecticide. It was historically used in very small, controlled doses for respiratory ailments and rheumatic pain, but due to its high toxicity, it is considered unsafe for modern internal use. Source: PubMed

medicinalUses: Astringent, diuretic; used for kidney and urinary ailments, diarrhea.
sideEffects: Generally safe, but may cause photosensitivity like other Hypericum species.
regionsFound: Wet meadows and shores in Eastern North America.
preparation: Tea or tincture from aerial parts.
detailedExplanation: This specific species of St. John's Wort found in wetlands shares some properties with the more common H. perforatum. It is primarily known for its astringent (tissue-tightening) and diuretic properties. It has been used in traditional medicine, particularly by Native American tribes, to treat kidney problems, bladder infections, and diarrhea. Source: Native American Ethnobotany DB

medicinalUses: The root has been used as a tonic and diuretic. Young stems are edible after peeling.
sideEffects: No common side effects from traditional use. The plant is very spiny.
regionsFound: Europe, naturalized in parts of North America, in damp fields and marshes.
preparation: Decoction of the root; peeled young stems eaten raw or cooked.
detailedExplanation: The Marsh Thistle is a tall, spiny biennial. Like many thistles, it has a history of use as a survival food and mild medicine. The root has been used as a weak tonic and diuretic, believed to help support overall vitality and kidney function. The most reliable use is as a food source; the young stems, after the spiny outer layer is removed, can be consumed similarly to asparagus. Source: PFAF

medicinalUses: Demulcent, soothes respiratory tract, anti-inflammatory
sideEffects: May cause mild diarrhea
preparation: Root decoction, syrup
detailedExplanation: Althaea officinalis (Marshmallow) is used for throat irritation, cough, and inflammation. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK92771/

medicinalUses: The root is a purgative and diuretic. Leaves used for skin abscesses and wounds.
sideEffects: The seeds and root are toxic if ingested in quantity, causing digestive upset.
regionsFound: Native to tropical Americas; cultivated worldwide.
preparation: Poultice from crushed leaves; root used with extreme caution in traditional preparations.
detailedExplanation: Marvel of Peru is named for its fragrant flowers that open in the late afternoon. While ornamental, its root has a strong purgative effect and was used traditionally for its laxative and diuretic properties. The crushed leaves are commonly used as a topical poultice to treat boils, abscesses, and skin inflammations due to their anti-inflammatory and antimicrobial properties. Source: PFAF

medicinalUses: Digestive aid, carminative; used for indigestion, bloating, and as a mild sedative.
sideEffects: Skin contact may cause photosensitivity in some individuals.
regionsFound: Mountainous regions of Central and Southern Europe.
preparation: Tea, tincture, or extract from the rhizome.
detailedExplanation: Masterwort is a bitter, aromatic herb traditionally used in European folk medicine. It acts as a digestive stimulant, helping to relieve flatulence, bloating, and sluggish digestion. It was also considered a remedy for mild anxiety and insomnia. The root has a spicy, warming quality and was sometimes used to flavor liqueurs. Source: PFAF

medicinalUses: The resin (Mastic) is used for digestive issues (ulcers, Crohn's), oral health, and as an antimicrobial.
sideEffects: Generally safe. Rare allergic reactions.
preparation: Resin chewed directly, powder in capsules, essential oil.
detailedExplanation: The Mastic Tree produces a unique aromatic resin that has been used since antiquity. Clinical studies show it is effective against H. pylori bacteria and for healing peptic ulcers. It is also a traditional chewing gum for oral hygiene, freshening breath, and preventing cavities. Its anti-inflammatory properties are beneficial for inflammatory bowel diseases. Source: NCBI

medicinalUses: Stimulant (similar to coffee), rich in antioxidants, aids weight management, improves mental focus.
sideEffects: Insomnia, nervousness, upset stomach, increased heart rate and blood pressure (due to caffeine).
regionsFound: Native to South America (Argentina, Paraguay, Brazil, Uruguay).
preparation: Dried leaves brewed as a tea (traditional in a gourd).
detailedExplanation: Maté is a caffeinated herbal tea deeply embedded in South American culture. It provides a clean, focused energy boost due to its caffeine and theobromine content. It is also incredibly rich in antioxidants and nutrients, supporting cardiovascular health and aiding in weight management by slightly increasing metabolism and promoting satiety. Source: NCBI

medicinalUses: Calming sedative, anti-inflammatory, antispasmodic; treats anxiety, insomnia, digestive cramps, skin irritation.
sideEffects: Rare allergic reactions in individuals sensitive to the Asteraceae family.
preparation: Tea, tincture, essential oil, cream.
detailedExplanation: German Chamomile is one of the most popular herbs worldwide. Its blue essential oil, containing chamazulene and apigenin, is responsible for its powerful anti-inflammatory and mild sedative effects. It is a safe and gentle remedy for promoting sleep, calming nervous stomachs, relieving colic in infants, and soothing skin conditions like eczema. Source: NCBI

medicinalUses: Antipyretic, diuretic
sideEffects: None known
preparation: Grass decoction
detailedExplanation: Used in rural areas for fever and urinary health. Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apluda_mutica

medicinalUses: Source of podophyllotoxin, a compound used in prescription drugs to treat genital warts and some cancers.
sideEffects: HIGHLY TOXIC. All parts, especially the root, are poisonous and can be fatal if ingested.
preparation: Used only in purified, pharmaceutical-grade derivatives by doctors.
detailedExplanation: The May Apple is a forest plant whose fruit is only edible when fully ripe. The root, however, is extremely toxic. Despite this, it is a crucial medicinal plant because it is the source of podophyllotoxin, which is chemically modified to create powerful prescription drugs like etoposide for cancer chemotherapy and topical solutions for genital warts. Source: American Cancer Society

medicinalUses: Historically used as a diuretic and astringent for urinary tract disorders.
sideEffects: No common side effects, but the plant is rare and protected in many areas.
preparation: Tea from leaves.
detailedExplanation: The Mayflower is a delicate, fragrant, evergreen groundcover and the state flower of Massachusetts. It was used by Native American tribes and early colonists as a tea to treat urinary tract infections and kidney stones due to its astringent and diuretic properties. Due to its rarity and slow growth, it should not be foraged. Source: Native American Ethnobotany DB

medicinalUses: Anxiolytic, sedative; used for anxiety, insomnia, nervous restlessness, and muscle spasms.
sideEffects: Drowsiness, dizziness.
preparation: Tea, tincture from aerial parts.
detailedExplanation: Maypop is a hardy North American species of passionflower. It is a highly effective and non-addictive nervine, used to calm anxiety and promote natural sleep without the hangover effect of pharmaceutical sedatives. It also has antispasmodic properties, useful for calming nervous stomachs and muscle tension. The fruit is edible. Source: NCBI

medicinalUses: Limited traditional use as a mild digestive and anti-inflammatory, but not a primary remedy.
sideEffects: Can cause contact dermatitis in sensitive individuals.
regionsFound: Europe, Asia; naturalized in North America.
preparation: Infusion of flowers.
detailedExplanation: Mayweed is often confused with true chamomile but lacks its distinctive apple-like scent. It has very limited and weak medicinal use, occasionally employed in folk medicine as a mild digestive tea or a topical wash for minor skin irritations. It is not considered a major medicinal herb and is often regarded as a weed. Source: PFAF

medicinalUses: TOXIC. Historically used topically in poultices for joint pain, but causes skin blistering.
sideEffects: Severe skin and mucosal irritation, blistering. Internal ingestion is poisonous.
regionsFound: Europe, Asia; naturalized in North America.
preparation: Not recommended. Historical poultices used with caution.
detailedExplanation: The Meadow Buttercup, like all buttercups, contains protoanemonin, a potent irritant. When applied to the skin, it causes redness, itching, and blistering (a counter-irritant effect), which was historically used to treat arthritic and rheumatic pain. This practice, known as rubefacient, is dangerous and not recommended. Ingesting the plant causes severe pain and damage to the digestive system. Source: PFAF

medicinalUses: Stops diarrhea and bleeding. Helps to close wounds faster and reduce swelling.
sideEffects: Very safe. Too much might cause stomach upset.
preparation: Tea from the dried plant. Liquid extract.
detailedExplanation: This plant is very good for tightening and drying body tissues. It is used for problems like diarrhea, stomach bleeding, and heavy periods. You can also use it on the skin for cuts and wounds to stop bleeding and help the skin heal. It is a strong and reliable plant for these problems. Source: PFAF

medicinalUses: Helps with stomach problems and women's monthly period pain. Can make you sweat if you have a fever.
sideEffects: Can cause skin irritation for some people. Do not eat a lot of it.
preparation: Weak tea from leaves or roots.
detailedExplanation: This plant is not very strong, so it is used carefully. It can help with pain in the stomach and for women who have bad pain during their monthly period. Sometimes, people drink a little to help them sweat when they have a fever from a cold. You must use only a little bit. Source: PFAF

medicinalUses: Very poisonous, but used by doctors. In very small, controlled amounts, it treats gout and a disease called Familial Mediterranean Fever.
sideEffects: EXTREMELY POISONOUS. Causes vomiting, organ failure, and can kill you.
preparation: Only used in prescription medicine from a doctor.
detailedExplanation: This beautiful plant is very dangerous. You should never touch or eat it. However, doctors use a chemical from this plant to make a strong prescription medicine. This medicine is very good for treating the extreme pain and swelling of gout and for a special fever disease. It is not a home remedy. Source: NCBI

medicinalUses: Used in the past for kidney stones and eye infections. Not commonly used today.
sideEffects: Not well known. It is best to be careful.
preparation: Paste from the leaves for the skin. Tea from the plant.
detailedExplanation: This plant's name means "stone-breaker." A long time ago, people believed it could help break down and remove small stones from the kidney and bladder. It was also used as a wash for sore or infected eyes. Today, people do not use it much for medicine.

medicinalUses: Reduces pain and fever. Soothes stomach pain and acidity. The plant that aspirin was originally made from.
sideEffects: Safe for most people. Can cause stomach upset in some, like aspirin.
preparation: Tea from the flowers and leaves.
detailedExplanation: This plant is very good for pain. It can help with headaches, muscle pain, and the pain from arthritis. It also reduces fever. Unlike aspirin, it is gentle on the stomach and can even protect the stomach lining. It is excellent for heartburn and an upset stomach. It smells very sweet. Source: NCBI

medicinalUses: Not a strong medicine. Sometimes used in tea for stomach problems or as a mild tonic.
sideEffects: No common side effects.
preparation: Eaten as a vegetable or made into a weak tea.
detailedExplanation: This plant is more of a food than a medicine. You can eat the young leaves in a salad. Sometimes people make a very mild tea from it to help with a tired feeling or a mild stomach ache. It does not have strong healing powers, but it is safe and nutritious.

medicinalUses: The fruit is a good food for digestion because it has a lot of fiber. A tea from the leaves is a mild laxative.
sideEffects: The fruit is safe to eat. The seeds have a very small amount of poison, but you would have to eat many to get sick.
preparation: Eat the fruit when it is soft and brown. Make tea from the leaves.
detailedExplanation: This tree makes a strange fruit that you must eat only after it becomes very soft and almost rotten. Then it tastes sweet and is good for your digestion because it has fiber. A tea made from the leaves can help if you have constipation and need a gentle push.

medicinalUses: Reduces swelling and fluid retention (edema). Helps blood flow in veins. Used in creams for bruises and swelling.
sideEffects: Too much can cause a headache and liver damage. The plant can become poisonous if it gets moldy.
preparation: Tea from the dried flowers. Used in creams and gels.
detailedExplanation: This plant has a very nice smell. It is very good for reducing swelling when you get hurt. It is often put in creams for bruises, sprains, and swollen legs. When you drink it as a tea, it can help your body get rid of extra water and improve blood circulation in your veins. You must always use it dried, not fresh. Source: NCBI

medicinalUses: Very good for lowering blood sugar for people with diabetes. Also helps with digestion and is good for the liver.
sideEffects: Eating too much can cause stomach pain and diarrhea. Can make blood sugar too low if you take diabetes medicine.
preparation: Eat the vegetable cooked or drink the juice.
detailedExplanation: This vegetable is very, very bitter, but very healthy. It is famous for helping to control diabetes by lowering the sugar level in your blood. It is also good for your stomach and helps clean your liver. Many people in Asia and Africa use it as both a food and a medicine. Source: NCBI

medicinalUses: A very healthy food. It is full of water and vitamins A and C. It helps your eyes, skin, and immune system stay strong.
sideEffects: Eating the fruit is very safe.
preparation: The fruit is eaten fresh.
detailedExplanation: This sweet fruit is not a strong medicine, but it is a very good food for your health. It has a lot of water to keep you hydrated. The vitamins help your body fight sickness and are good for your eyesight. It is a delicious way to stay healthy. Source: USDA FoodData Central

medicinalUses: The fruit is a healthy food full of vitamin A for good eyes. The seeds are used to kill stomach worms.
sideEffects: The fruit is very safe. Eating too many seeds can cause a stomach ache.
preparation: Cook and eat the fruit. Eat the raw or roasted seeds.
detailedExplanation: Winter Melon is a type of squash or pumpkin. The orange flesh is very good for you because it has vitamin A for strong eyes. The seeds are famous in many countries for getting rid of worms in the stomach and intestines, especially in children. Source: NCBI

medicinalUses: This plant is poisonous. It was used in the past to make people vomit or have a bowel movement, but it is not safe.
sideEffects: POISONOUS. Causes vomiting, diarrhea, kidney damage, and can be fatal.
preparation: Not recommended. Do not use.
detailedExplanation: This plant is very dangerous. Even a small amount can make you very sick. It can hurt your stomach and your kidneys. It is not a medicine and you should not touch it or eat it. Source: PFAF

medicinalUses: The seeds are very poisonous. They were used in sacred rituals by Native people, but they are not a safe medicine.
sideEffects: VERY POISONOUS. Causes vomiting, convulsions, and can stop your breathing.
preparation: Not recommended. For ritual use only by experts.
detailedExplanation: The beautiful red seeds of this plant are extremely dangerous. They contain a poison similar to nicotine. Some Native American tribes used them in very careful rituals, but they are not for healing or for anyone to use at home. Swallowing even one seed can kill a person. Source: USDA Forest Service

medicinalUses: The sweet pods are a healthy food. The gum from the tree is used for sore eyes and as a glue for wounds.
sideEffects: The food is safe. The gum can cause allergies in some people.
regionsFound: Americas, Africa, and Asia, in dry areas.
preparation: Eat the pods raw or grind into flour. Use the gum as an eye wash or on wounds.
detailedExplanation: The Mesquite tree is very useful. Its long, sweet pods can be eaten or made into flour that is good for people with diabetes because it does not raise blood sugar quickly. The sticky gum from the tree can be mixed with water and used as an eye drop for sore eyes or put on a cut to help seal it. Source: NCBI

medicinalUses: The seeds are poisonous. The plant was used in the past to make you vomit, but it is not safe.
sideEffects: POISONOUS. Causes vomiting, diarrhea, and weakness.
preparation: Not recommended. Do not use.
detailedExplanation: This plant has pretty pink flowers, but its seeds are dangerous. Eating them will make you very sick with stomach pain and vomiting. It is not a plant to use for medicine. You should only enjoy its beauty from a distance. Source: Lady Bird Johnson Wildflower Center

medicinalUses: The flowers are used in tea to make you sweat when you have a fever and to treat colds and flu.
sideEffects: The raw berries are poisonous. Only use the flowers.
preparation: Tea made from the dried flowers.
detailedExplanation: Like other elder trees, the Mexican Elder's flowers are very good for treating colds. Drinking the tea helps your body sweat out a fever. It also helps with a runny nose and cough. Remember, the raw berries can make you sick, so only use the flowers. Source: Native American Ethnobotany DB

medicinalUses: Used for stomach problems, to calm nerves, and as a tea for colds. It is also a bug repellent.
sideEffects: Very safe in normal amounts.
preparation: The leaves are used to make tea.
detailedExplanation: This marigold has a sweet smell like licorice. People use it to make a tea that helps with stomach pain, gas, and diarrhea. It is also a calming tea that can help you relax if you feel nervous or stressed. In the garden, it keeps bugs away. Source: PFAF

medicinalUses: The yellow sap is used on the skin for warts, skin diseases, and wounds. The seeds and sap are poisonous if eaten.
sideEffects: POISONOUS if swallowed. Skin contact can cause irritation for some people.
regionsFound: Tropical America, now found in many parts of the world.
preparation: The yellow sap is applied directly to warts or skin problems.
detailedExplanation: This plant has a bright yellow sap. This sap is put directly on warts to make them disappear. It is also used for other skin problems like scabies and to help heal wounds. You must be very careful not to get the sap in your mouth or eyes, and never eat the seeds. Source: NCBI

medicinalUses: Traditional uses include antimicrobial, analgesic, and in wound care; seeds historically used as purgative in small doses.
sideEffects: Toxic seeds/oil can cause epidemic dropsy when adulterating edible oils; ingestion can be dangerous.
preparation: External poultices, careful traditional preparations—internal use only with expert guidance.
detailedExplanation: Argemone mexicana contains toxic alkaloids (e.g., sanguinarine) and while used in folk medicine for external ailments, internal use is risky—documented poisonings (epidemic dropsy) make this plant one to treat with extreme caution. Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Argemone_mexicana.

medicinalUses: This is the same plant as the Mexican Poppy. The yellow sap is used on the skin for warts, skin diseases, and wounds. The seeds and sap are poisonous if eaten.
sideEffects: POISONOUS if swallowed. Skin contact can cause irritation for some people.
regionsFound: Tropical America, now found in many parts of the world.
preparation: The yellow sap is applied directly to warts or skin problems.
detailedExplanation: This is another name for the same plant, Mexican Poppy (Satyanashi). All the information is the same. The yellow sap is good for skin problems but dangerous if you eat it. Source: NCBI

medicinalUses: Kills stomach worms and parasites. Reduces gas and helps with stomach pain.
sideEffects: The essential oil is very strong and poisonous. Using the leaf as a spice is safe.
regionsFound: Native to Americas, now found worldwide.
preparation: Use the fresh or dried leaf in cooking beans. Make a weak tea for worms.
detailedExplanation: This strong-smelling herb is famous in cooking, especially with beans, because it stops gas. As a medicine, a tea made from the leaves is very powerful for killing and expelling roundworms and hookworms from the stomach. You must never use the pure oil from the plant, as it is dangerous. Source: NCBI

medicinalUses: All parts of this plant are very poisonous. It was used in the past on the skin to treat arthritis and blisters, but it is not safe.
sideEffects: VERY POISONOUS. Causes burning in the mouth, stomach pain, kidney damage, and can be fatal.
preparation: Not recommended. Do not use.
detailedExplanation: This plant has pretty flowers but is one of the most dangerous plants. Even a few of the bright red berries can kill a child. The sap can burn your skin. It is not a medicine and should be avoided completely. Source: PFAF

medicinalUses: Used in a steam bath to clear a stuffy nose. The leaves can be used in a poultice for headaches.
sideEffects: May cause skin rash in people allergic to daisies.
preparation: Inhale steam from boiling leaves. Crush leaves for a forehead poultice.
detailedExplanation: This pretty, late-blooming flower is mostly grown for beauty. In traditional medicine, people boil the leaves and breathe in the steam to help open a blocked nose from a cold. Sometimes, the crushed leaves are placed on the forehead to relieve a headache.

medicinalUses: Grown mostly for its very sweet smell. It is not known as an important medicine.
sideEffects: No common side effects.
preparation: Not typically used for medicine.
detailedExplanation: This plant is famous for its wonderful fragrance, which is why people grow it in gardens. It is not a plant that is used for healing sickness. Its main job is to make the air smell nice.

medicinalUses: Stops bleeding from cuts very fast. Helps to bring down a fever by making you sweat. Good for women's monthly period problems.
sideEffects: Can cause skin allergy in some people. Makes you more sensitive to the sun.
preparation: Press fresh leaves on a cut. Make tea from dried flowers for fever.
detailedExplanation: Yarrow is a powerful first-aid plant. If you get a cut, you can crush the leaves and press them on the wound to stop the bleeding quickly. Drinking yarrow tea when you have a fever helps you sweat and break the fever. It is also very good for regulating women's menstrual cycles and easing period cramps. Source: NCBI

medicinalUses: Protects and repairs the liver from damage caused by poison, alcohol, or viruses. Also helps to lower high cholesterol.
sideEffects: Very safe. May have a mild laxative effect for some people.
preparation: Capsules, tincture, or tea made from the seeds.
detailedExplanation: This is one of the best plants for liver health. If your liver is damaged by toxins, medicine, or disease like hepatitis, milk thistle can help to heal it. It acts like a shield for your liver cells. It is also good for your heart because it can help lower bad cholesterol. Source: NCBI

medicinalUses: The milky sap is a nutritious drink that looks and tastes like cow's milk. It is a food, not a strong medicine.
sideEffects: The sap is safe to drink.
preparation: The sap is tapped from the tree and drunk fresh.
detailedExplanation: This amazing tree produces a thick, sweet sap that you can drink just like milk. It is full of nutrients and is a good source of food in the jungles where it grows. It does not cure sickness, but it keeps people strong and healthy by giving them good food.

medicinalUses: Strengthens the body's immune system to help fight colds and flu. Gives you more energy and is good for heart health.
sideEffects: Very safe for long-term use.
preparation: The root is boiled in soups or made into tea and tincture.
detailedExplanation: Astragalus is a tonic herb, meaning it makes your body stronger over time. It is famous for boosting your immune system so you don't get sick as often. If you feel tired and weak, it can help increase your energy. It is also good for your heart and helps your body adapt to stress. Source: NCBI

medicinalUses: The milky sap is used on the skin to get rid of warts and ringworm. The plant is poisonous if eaten.
sideEffects: POISONOUS if swallowed. Sap can irritate skin and eyes.
preparation: The sap is applied directly to warts.
detailedExplanation: This plant has a white, milky sap. This sap is very good for putting on skin problems like warts and fungal infections (ringworm) to make them go away. You must be very careful not to get the sap in your eyes or mouth, and never, ever eat any part of the plant. Source: PFAF

medicinalUses: The root is used to make a tea that makes you sweat for fevers, and as a strong medicine to make you vomit or have a bowel movement. Use with great care.
sideEffects: Can be poisonous in large doses. Causes vomiting and diarrhea.
regionsFound: Eastern North America, in wet areas.
preparation: A weak tea is made from the dried root.
detailedExplanation: This milkweed is less toxic than others, but you must still be careful. A tea from the root is a strong medicine. It can make you sweat out a fever. It can also clean out your stomach and bowels if you have eaten something bad, but it is very powerful and can be dangerous if you use too much. Source: PFAF

medicinalUses: Used as an expectorant to help cough up phlegm from the chest. Also used to increase breast milk in nursing mothers.
sideEffects: Very safe in normal doses. High doses can cause vomiting.
regionsFound: Found in many parts of the world.
preparation: Tea or tincture from the root.
detailedExplanation: The name "Milkwort" comes from its old use to help mothers produce more breast milk. It is also very good for the lungs. If you have a cough with a lot of sticky mucus, this plant helps to loosen the phlegm so you can cough it out more easily. Source: PFAF

medicinalUses: A very healthy food that is gluten-free. It is good for digestion, helps control blood sugar, and gives you energy.
sideEffects: Eating the grain is very safe.
preparation: The grains are cooked and eaten like rice.
detailedExplanation: Millet is a nutritious seed that is a staple food in many parts of the world. It is not a strong medicine, but it is a very healthy food. It is full of fiber which is good for your stomach and helps you have regular bowel movements. It is also good for people with diabetes because it releases energy slowly. Source: USDA FoodData Central

medicinalUses: The whole plant is used for anxiety, depression, and to help with wound healing. It is also used for heavy bleeding during periods.
sideEffects: Very safe in normal amounts.
regionsFound: Tropical Americas, now found in many tropical areas.
preparation: Juice from the leaves, paste, or tea.
detailedExplanation: This amazing plant is famous for closing its leaves when you touch it. In medicine, it is used to calm the mind. It helps if you feel very sad, worried, or stressed. It is also good for stopping bleeding, especially heavy bleeding during a woman's period, and it helps cuts and wounds heal faster. Source: NCBI

medicinalUses: Used as a soothing skin wash for minor cuts and irritations. Sometimes used in a steam bath for coughs.
sideEffects: Generally safe.
preparation: Crush leaves for a skin poultice or add to steam inhalation.
detailedExplanation: This plant is mostly grown as a pretty indoor plant that forms a soft carpet of tiny leaves. It has very mild medicinal use. You can crush the leaves and put them on small cuts or skin rashes to cool and soothe them. Breathing in steam with the leaves can help a little with a cough.

medicinalUses: Soothes an upset stomach and helps with digestion. A calming tea that can help you relax.
sideEffects: Very safe.
preparation: Tea from the fresh or dried leaves.
detailedExplanation: This mint has a soft, fuzzy leaf and a sweet, apple-like smell. Like other mints, it is excellent for your stomach. Drinking tea after a meal can help with indigestion and gas. It is also a very gentle and relaxing tea to drink before bed.

medicinalUses: Soothes stomach cramps and nausea. Its calming smell helps to reduce stress and anxiety.
sideEffects: Very safe.
preparation: Tea from the leaves. Use in aromatherapy.
detailedExplanation: This mint has a wonderful citrus smell, like the bergamot orange. It makes a delicious tea that is good for a nervous stomach, cramps, and feeling sick. Just smelling its fragrance can help to lift your mood and make you feel less stressed.

medicinalUses: Used for headaches, colds, and fever. Helps with digestion and stomach pain.
sideEffects: Very safe.
regionsFound: Europe, Asia; naturalized in North America.
preparation: Tea from the leaves. Crushed leaves inhaled for headaches.
detailedExplanation: This is a wild mint that is very useful. A tea made from the leaves can help with the symptoms of a cold or flu, including fever. It is also good for headaches; you can crush the leaves and smell them for relief. Of course, it also helps with stomach aches. Source: PFAF

medicinalUses: This is the same plant as Corn Mint. It is used for headaches, colds, fever, and stomach pain.
sideEffects: Very safe.
regionsFound: Europe, Asia; naturalized in North America.
preparation: Tea from the leaves. Crushed leaves inhaled for headaches.
detailedExplanation: This is another name for Corn Mint. All the information is the same. It is a common wild mint used for colds, fevers, headaches, and digestion. Source: PFAF

medicinalUses: Used to make a tea that helps with nausea, gas, and stomach cramps. Also used to help bring up phlegm during a cold.
sideEffects: Very safe. The tea has a very strong, thyme-like taste.
preparation: Tea from the leaves and flowers.
detailedExplanation: This plant is not a true mint, but it is called Horse Mint. It has a very strong and pleasant smell. A tea made from it is very good for settling an upset stomach, relieving gas, and stopping feelings of nausea. It can also help to clear chest congestion when you have a cough. Source: PFAF

medicinalUses: Used for treating nausea, vomiting, and poor appetite. Also used for chest congestion and as a fever reducer.
sideEffects: Very safe.
preparation: Tea from the leaves and flowers.
detailedExplanation: This plant, also called Korean Mint or Patchouli Mint, is a key herb in Traditional Chinese Medicine. It is mainly used for stomach problems like feeling sick, vomiting, and not wanting to eat. It is also used for the common cold to reduce fever and relieve a stuffy chest. Source: ScienceDirect

medicinalUses: Used like other mints to soothe an upset stomach and aid digestion. Also used to make a refreshing tea.
sideEffects: Very safe.
preparation: Tea from the leaves.
detailedExplanation: This is a native American mint with a very strong minty fragrance. It is used in the same way as common garden mints. The primary use is to make a pleasant tea that helps with digestion after a meal, relieving gas and stomach discomfort.

medicinalUses: Very effective for relieving stomach pain, gas, and bloating. Also helps to clear a stuffy nose and soothe headaches.
sideEffects: Very safe. Can cause heartburn in some people if taken in large amounts.
preparation: Make a strong tea by soaking fresh or dried leaves in hot water for 5-10 minutes. For headaches, rub crushed leaves on the temples.
detailedExplanation: Peppermint is one of the best herbs for your stomach. The strong oil in it, called menthol, relaxes the muscles of your intestines, which quickly relieves gas and cramping. It is also very cooling and can open up a blocked nose when you have a cold. Source: NCBI

medicinalUses: A gentler mint that helps with digestion and freshens breath. Often used to help balance female hormones.
sideEffects: Very safe, even for children.
preparation: Make a mild tea by steeping fresh leaves in hot water. Chew on a fresh leaf to freshen breath.
detailedExplanation: Spearmint is the common mint used in cooking. It is milder than peppermint but still very good for soothing an upset stomach. Recent studies show that drinking spearmint tea regularly can help reduce excess hair growth in women by lowering male hormone levels. Source: NCBI

medicinalUses: Used for stomach cramps and to help with digestion. Also used to relieve tension headaches.
sideEffects: Very safe.
regionsFound: Europe, Africa, Asia; in wet areas.
preparation: Crush the fresh leaves and smell them for a headache. Make a tea from the dried leaves for stomach issues.
detailedExplanation: This mint grows near water and has a strong smell. Like other mints, it is very useful for stomach problems like cramps and indigestion. The strong scent of the crushed leaves is also effective for relieving a stress-related headache when you inhale it.

medicinalUses: The berry makes sour foods taste sweet. This can help people on chemotherapy or with diabetes enjoy food without sugar.
sideEffects: No known side effects.
regionsFound: Native to West Africa; cultivated in tropics.
preparation: Eat the fresh berry, allowing the pulp to coat your tongue, before eating sour foods like lemons.
detailedExplanation: This is a fascinating fruit, not a medicine for sickness. After you eat the berry, it coats your tongue and makes everything sour taste sweet for about an hour. This is very helpful for sick people who have a bad taste in their mouth from medicine, allowing them to eat healthy sour foods like lemons. Source: PubMed

medicinalUses: Used as an injectable extract by doctors in Europe to support cancer therapy. It may improve quality of life. The raw plant is poisonous.
sideEffects: RAW BERRIES ARE POISONOUS. Can cause vomiting, diarrhea, and slowed heartbeat.
preparation: Only used as a prescribed injection by trained doctors. Do not prepare at home.
detailedExplanation: Mistletoe is a famous Christmas plant, but it is also a strong medicine. In Europe, doctors give special injections of mistletoe extract to cancer patients to help boost their immune system and reduce side effects from chemotherapy. You should never eat the raw berries or leaves. Source: National Cancer Institute

medicinalUses: Grown for its very beautiful and fragrant flowers. It is not used as a medicine.
sideEffects: No known side effects.
preparation: Not used for preparation.
detailedExplanation: This shrub is planted in gardens for one reason: its stunning white flowers have an incredibly sweet, orange-like smell. It is purely an ornamental plant and does not have any known traditional medicinal uses.

medicinalUses: The leaves are sometimes used in a tea to treat skin wounds and swelling, but it is not a strong medicine. The fruit is edible but tasteless.
sideEffects: The plant is safe.
regionsFound: Asia; naturalized in many parts of the world.
preparation: Crush the leaves into a paste to apply on skin sores or make a weak tea from the leaves.
detailedExplanation: This plant looks like a strawberry but its fruit is not juicy or sweet. It is mostly a weed. The leaves have very mild antiseptic properties and can be used as a simple poultice for small cuts or to reduce swelling from insect bites, but it is not a powerful remedy.

medicinalUses: Grown for its unique and beautiful green flowers. It is not known to be used as a medicine.
sideEffects: No known side effects.
preparation: Not used for preparation.
detailedExplanation: This plant is famous in flower arrangements for its striking green bell-shaped flowers. It is grown entirely for its beauty and is not used in traditional healing practices.

medicinalUses: The fruit is a good source of Vitamin C. The bark and leaves are used to treat diarrhea, wounds, and sore throats.
sideEffects: The fruit is safe. The bark/leaf medicine can be strong.
preparation: Eat the ripe fruit fresh. Make a tea or gargle from the bark and leaves for diarrhea and sore throat.
detailedExplanation: This tree produces a tasty sour fruit that is rich in vitamins. The bark and leaves are more medicinal; a tea made from them is a strong remedy for diarrhea and dysentery. A tea from the leaves can also be used as a mouthwash for sore throats and gum problems. Source: Useful Tropical Plants

medicinalUses: Grown for its beautiful purple flowers and unique, papery seed pods. It is not used as a medicine.
sideEffects: No known side effects.
preparation: Not used for preparation.
detailedExplanation: This plant is called Money Plant because of its silvery, coin-shaped seed pods that are used in dried flower arrangements. It is a popular garden plant for its beauty, not for any healing properties.

medicinalUses: Used in a tea to help with coughs and chest problems. Applied to the skin to help heal wounds and stop minor bleeding.
sideEffects: Very safe for external use.
preparation: Make a tea from the dried leaves for a cough. Crush fresh leaves into a paste and apply directly to cuts and scrapes.
detailedExplanation: This plant grows low to the ground like a carpet. It has mild medicinal properties. A tea made from it can help soothe a persistent cough. More commonly, the crushed leaves are used as a first-aid poultice for small wounds to help stop the bleeding and protect the skin. Source: PFAF

medicinalUses: The fruit pulp is incredibly rich in Vitamin C and antioxidants. The leaves are nutritious and used to treat fevers and diarrhea.
sideEffects: The fruit and leaves are very safe and highly nutritious.
preparation: Eat the dry fruit pulp mixed into water or porridge. Cook the leaves as a vegetable or make a leaf tea.
detailedExplanation: The Baobab tree is a life-giving tree in Africa. Its fruit has one of the highest Vitamin C contents of any fruit in the world, making it great for the immune system. The leaves are a staple food and also used as medicine to reduce fever and calm an upset stomach. Source: NCBI

medicinalUses: Used in some traditions as a poultice for burns and skin sores. Not a widely known medicine.
sideEffects: Generally considered safe.
preparation: Crush the fresh leaves and flowers into a paste and apply to the affected skin area.
detailedExplanation: This plant has cheerful yellow flowers. Its use in traditional medicine is not very common, but some Native American groups used the crushed plant as a cooling poultice for burns, wounds, and skin irritations to reduce inflammation. Source: Native American Ethnobotany DB

medicinalUses: The fruit is a nutritious food. The roots and leaves are used in traditional medicine to treat stomach pains, snakebites, and malaria.
sideEffects: The unripe fruit and seeds may be toxic. Only the ripe pulp is safe to eat.
preparation: Eat the ripe fruit pulp. A decoction is made from the roots and leaves for medicinal use.
detailedExplanation: This tree produces a hard-shelled fruit with a tasty, juicy pulp inside. While the fruit is a valuable food source, the roots and leaves are used by traditional healers for serious conditions like malaria and snakebite, as well as for common issues like stomach aches. Source: Useful Tropical Plants

medicinalUses: The seeds are a traditional food. The resin from the bark is used to help heal wounds.
sideEffects: The seeds are safe to eat when cooked. The sharp leaves can cause injury.
preparation: Roast the large seeds like nuts. Apply the resin directly to wounds.
detailedExplanation: This ancient, strange-looking tree is valued for its large, nutritious seeds, which are a staple food for the indigenous Mapuche people. The sticky resin that comes from the bark is used as a natural bandage, applied directly to cuts and wounds to protect them and help them heal. Source: PFAF

medicinalUses: One of the most poisonous plants in the world. It was used in tiny amounts in historical medicine for pain, but is not safe.
sideEffects: EXTREMELY POISONOUS. Can cause numbness, vomiting, heart failure, and death from very small amounts.
preparation: Not recommended. For historical interest only.
detailedExplanation: This plant has beautiful blue flowers but is deadly. All parts, especially the roots, are extremely toxic. It was once used by ancient healers as a painkiller and poison for hunting, but it is much too dangerous for anyone to use today. Source: PubMed

medicinalUses: The seeds are used as a spice like nutmeg. In traditional medicine, they are used for headaches, stomach pains, and to treat wounds.
sideEffects: The seeds are safe as a spice in small amounts.
preparation: Grind the seeds into a powder to use as a spice. The powder can also be mixed into a paste for headaches or applied to wounds.
detailedExplanation: This tree produces seeds that smell and taste similar to nutmeg. Besides being a popular spice, the ground seeds are used in African traditional medicine. A paste is applied to the forehead for headaches, and the powder is used on wounds to prevent infection. Source: Useful Tropical Plants

medicinalUses: The roots and berries are poisonous. It was used by Native Americans for skin problems and as a laxative, but it is not safe for use.
sideEffects: POISONOUS. Causes convulsions and respiratory failure.
preparation: Not recommended. Do not use.
detailedExplanation: This climbing vine has berries that look like wild grapes, but they are very dangerous. While some tribes used a very small amount of the root for medicine, it is very easy to make a mistake with the dose. Because of its high toxicity, it should be completely avoided. Source: PFAF

medicinalUses: In historical European folklore, it was believed to have magical powers to open locks and find treasure. Its medicinal use is not significant.
This grass is not known for medicinal use. It is important for protecting wetland environments.
sideEffects: None.
preparation: Not used for medicine.
detailedExplanation: Moor Grass is a type of plant that grows in wet, boggy areas. It plays a crucial role in its ecosystem by providing habitat and preventing soil erosion. It is not used in traditional or modern medicine for treating human ailments.

medicinalUses: Used in high-altitude medicine for digestive complaints, fever and as antiparasitic in some traditions.
sideEffects: Limited toxicity data; follow traditional dosing.
preparation: Decoction of aerial parts.
detailedExplanation: Artemisia moorcroftiana is reported from cold montane regions and used in high-altitude folk medicine as a digestive and antiparasitic bitter herb. Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artemisia_moorcroftiana.

medicinalUses: The inner bark was used in a tea to treat coughs and colds. It was also considered a "blood purifier" for skin problems.
sideEffects: No common side effects from traditional use.
preparation: Make a tea by boiling the inner bark in water for 10-15 minutes.
detailedExplanation: This small maple tree has beautiful striped bark. Native American tribes would make a tea from the inner bark to relieve coughs and cold symptoms. It was also used for skin conditions, based on the old idea of purifying the blood. Source: Native American Ethnobotany DB

medicinalUses: A highly prized and delicious edible mushroom. It is a good source of vitamins and minerals, but not a known medicine.
sideEffects: Must be cooked thoroughly. Raw morels are mildly toxic and can cause stomach upset.
preparation: Clean thoroughly and cook well by sautéing, frying, or adding to sauces.
detailedExplanation: Morel mushrooms are a famous and expensive delicacy. They are packed with nutrients like Vitamin D and iron. However, they are valued as a gourmet food, not for treating specific health conditions. It is very important to cook them properly to avoid stomach problems. Source: USDA FoodData Central

medicinalUses: An extremely nutritious "superfood." The leaves are rich in vitamins, help lower blood sugar, and reduce inflammation.
sideEffects: Very safe. Large doses of the root/bark may be harmful.
regionsFound: Native to India; cultivated in tropics worldwide.
preparation: Add fresh or powdered leaves to curries, soups, or smoothies. Make a tea from the dried leaves.
detailedExplanation: Often called the "Miracle Tree," Moringa is one of the most nutritious plants on Earth. Its leaves are loaded with vitamins, protein, and calcium. It is especially useful for fighting malnutrition. It also helps control blood sugar and cholesterol levels. Source: NCBI

medicinalUses: The seeds of some species are psychoactive and toxic. They can cause hallucinations and severe stomach upset. They are not a safe medicine.
sideEffects: SEEDS ARE POISONOUS. Cause nausea, vomiting, hallucinations, and increased heart rate.
preparation: Not recommended. Do not consume the seeds.
detailedExplanation: This plant is grown for its beautiful trumpet-shaped flowers. However, the seeds of certain types contain a natural chemical similar to LSD. Ingesting them is dangerous and can lead to a "bad trip," panic, and physical illness. They are not used in safe herbal practice. Source: Poison Control

medicinalUses: The raw seeds are poisonous. After extensive processing to remove toxins, Aboriginal people used them as a food source.
sideEffects: RAW SEEDS ARE POISONOUS. Cause severe vomiting and diarrhea.
preparation: Not recommended without expert knowledge of traditional preparation.
detailedExplanation: This tree produces large seeds that look like chestnuts. They are packed with nutrients but also contain strong toxins.
