Aboriginal Australians developed complex methods of soaking, roasting, and leaching the seeds for days to make them safe to eat. This is not a home remedy. Source: Australian Native Plants Society

medicinalUses: This small, delicate plant is not known for any medicinal uses. It is sometimes studied for its unique flower structure.
sideEffects: None.
preparation: Not used for medicine.
detailedExplanation: Moschatel is a tiny, inconspicuous woodland plant. Its main claim to fame is that its flowers form a cube-like shape. It has no history of use in traditional medicine and is not considered a medicinal herb.

medicinalUses: Grown for its beautiful, colorful flowers. It is not used as a medicine.
sideEffects: The plant is safe.
preparation: Not used for preparation.
detailedExplanation: Moss Rose is a popular garden plant because it has bright, showy flowers and can grow in hot, dry conditions. It is purely an ornamental plant and is not used for healing purposes.

medicinalUses: The spores were used as a powder to protect skin rashes and as a coating for pills. The plant itself is toxic.
sideEffects: THE PLANT IS POISONOUS and can cause vomiting and muscle paralysis.
preparation: Not recommended. The use of spores is historical.
detailedExplanation: This is not a true moss. Its yellow spores are very fine and water-repellent. They were once dusted on skin ulcers and diaper rash to keep the area dry. However, the green plant parts are poisonous and should not be used. Source: PFAF

medicinalUses: Used as a gentle tea for coughs and indigestion. Its strong essential oil is a powerful antiseptic.
sideEffects: Very safe in culinary amounts.
preparation: Make a tea from the fresh or dried leaves. The essential oil must be diluted for topical use.
detailedExplanation: This low-growing thyme forms a fragrant mat. It can be used like common thyme. A mild tea helps soothe a cough and settle the stomach. The oil from the plant is very strong and can be diluted and used on the skin to prevent infection in minor cuts. Source: PFAF

medicinalUses: Very effective at stopping bleeding, especially heavy menstrual bleeding and nosebleeds.
sideEffects: Very safe.
preparation: Make a strong tea from the fresh or dried whole plant and drink it.
detailedExplanation: This common garden weed is a first-aid powerhouse for bleeding. It is especially famous for its ability to reduce very heavy periods. It works quickly to help the blood vessels contract and stop the flow of blood. Source: NCBI

medicinalUses: Calms anxiety and heart palpitations caused by stress. Also helps regulate irregular menstrual cycles and ease period cramps.
sideEffects: Can cause drowsiness. Not for use during pregnancy.
regionsFound: Europe, Asia; naturalized in North America.
preparation: Make a tea by steeping 1-2 teaspoons of dried herb in hot water for 10 minutes.
detailedExplanation: Motherwort is a powerful relaxing herb, especially for the heart and uterus. Its name means "mother's herb" because it is so helpful for women's health issues like PMS and menopausal anxiety. It quickly calms a nervous, racing heart that comes from worry or stress. Source: NCBI

medicinalUses: The milky sap is highly irritating and poisonous. It was used in very small, controlled amounts to treat skin cancers and warts, but it is not safe for home use.
sideEffects: SAP IS TOXIC. Causes severe skin blistering, eye damage, and poisoning if ingested.
preparation: Not recommended. For historical interest only.
detailedExplanation: This plant produces a white, milky sap that is very dangerous. While it has a history of being applied in tiny amounts to burn off skin growths, it is impossible to control safely. It can cause severe chemical burns and should never be used. Source: US Forest Service

medicinalUses: Antioxidant, digestive aid
sideEffects: None known
preparation: Leaf decoction
detailedExplanation: Himalayan shrub used for stomach ailments and detox. Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Antidesma_montanum

medicinalUses: Widely used externally for bruises, sprains, anti-inflammatory and analgesic effects; longstanding herbal remedy.
sideEffects: Can cause skin irritation or allergic dermatitis if overused; internal use contraindicated.
preparation: External ointment, infused oil, compresses—avoid broken skin for concentrated forms.
detailedExplanation: Arnica montana is a classical European herbal remedy used externally to reduce bruising and inflammation; similar practice has been adopted in high-altitude gardens/hill-station cultivation. Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arnica_montana.

medicinalUses: The berries are very rich in Vitamin C and were used to prevent scurvy. A tea from the bark is a mild remedy for diarrhea and hemorrhoids.
sideEffects: Raw berries can cause stomach upset. Always cook or ferment them first.
preparation: Make jam, jelly, or syrup from the cooked berries. Make a decoction by boiling the bark for 10-15 minutes for a tea.
detailedExplanation: The bright red berries of this tree are too bitter to eat raw, but when cooked, they become a delicious and healthy preserve. They are packed with Vitamin C. The bark has astringent properties, making a tea that can help firm up stools and soothe inflamed tissues. Source: PFAF

medicinalUses: The leaves are used to make a tea for treating digestive problems and sore throats. It is also a mild diuretic.
sideEffects: Generally considered safe.
regionsFound: Arctic and Alpine regions of Northern Hemisphere.
preparation: Make an infusion by pouring hot water over the dried leaves and steeping for 5-10 minutes.
detailedExplanation: This hardy alpine plant survives in very cold climates. Its leaves are used in traditional medicine, particularly by Inuit peoples, to make a tea that soothes stomach aches and sore throats. It also helps to increase urine flow. Source: Canadian Biodiversity

medicinalUses: A primary remedy for clearing phlegm from the lungs, soothing coughs, and relieving asthma and bronchitis symptoms.
sideEffects: Very safe.
preparation: Make a tea from the dried leaves. A syrup can be made by simmering the leaves in honey or glycerin.
detailedExplanation: This sticky, aromatic shrub is a famous lung remedy. Its name means "holy herb" in Spanish. It is exceptionally good at thinning and loosening thick mucus, making it easier to cough up. It is used for all kinds of respiratory congestion, from simple colds to chronic bronchitis. Source: Native American Ethnobotany DB

medicinalUses: This plant is not known for significant medicinal use. It is primarily an ornamental evergreen shrub.
sideEffects: No common side effects.
preparation: Not used for medicine.
detailedExplanation: Mountain Boxwood is a small, dense shrub often used in landscaping for its attractive, glossy leaves. It does not have a notable history of use in traditional medicine for treating human ailments.

medicinalUses: The berries help prevent urinary tract infections, just like cranberries. They are also a rich source of antioxidants.
sideEffects: Generally safe when consumed as food.
regionsFound: Boreal forests and Arctic tundra in the Northern Hemisphere.
preparation: Eat the berries raw, cooked, or as jam and juice.
detailedExplanation: This close relative of the cranberry shares the same medicinal benefit for the urinary tract. The berries contain compounds that stop bacteria from sticking to the bladder wall, helping to prevent infections. They are also a tasty and healthy wild food. Source: NCBI

medicinalUses: Used in traditional Maori medicine as a poultice for skin wounds and boils. The leaves are also used to make a soothing tea.
sideEffects: Generally safe for external use.
preparation: Crush the fresh leaves into a paste and apply to the skin. Make a mild tea from the dried leaves.
detailedExplanation: These hardy daisies, native to New Zealand, are used by the Maori people. The most common use is to crush the leaves and apply them directly to wounds, sores, and boils to help them heal and reduce infection. A tea can be made for internal use.

medicinalUses: The milky sap is applied to warts to remove them. The leaves can be eaten as a bitter green to aid digestion.
sideEffects: The sap can be a skin irritant for some people.
preparation: Apply the fresh sap directly to warts daily. Add young leaves to salads.
detailedExplanation: This plant looks and acts much like the common dandelion. Its white sap can be dabbed onto warts to gradually make them disappear. The young leaves are edible and, like other bitter greens, help stimulate digestion when eaten before a meal.

medicinalUses: All parts of this plant are deadly poisonous. It has no safe medicinal use and is often mistaken for edible bulbs.
sideEffects: HIGHLY POISONOUS. Causes vomiting, weakness, convulsions, and can be fatal.
preparation: Not recommended. Do not touch or ingest.
detailedExplanation: This plant is extremely dangerous. It often grows alongside edible camas and onions, making it easy to mistake. There is no antidote for its poison. Ingestion of even a small amount can lead to death. It is a plant to be identified and strictly avoided. Source: US Forest Service

medicinalUses: Anti-inflammatory, wound healing
sideEffects: None known
preparation: Leaf infusion
detailedExplanation: Alpine herb known for healing wounds and inflammation in mountain medicine. Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Antennaria_dioica

medicinalUses: The bark was used by Native Americans in a tea as a fever reducer and to treat diarrhea.
sideEffects: No common side effects reported.
preparation: Make a decoction by boiling the bark in water for 10-15 minutes, then strain and drink the tea.
detailedExplanation: This wetland shrub is not a true holly. Its primary traditional use was medicinal. A tea made from the bark was a common remedy for bringing down fevers and for treating cases of diarrhea. Source: Native American Ethnobotany DB

medicinalUses: A calming tea for coughs, fevers, and chest congestion. It also helps to soothe an upset stomach.
sideEffects: Very safe, even for children.
preparation: Make a pleasant-tasting tea by steeping the fresh or dried leaves and flowers in hot water for 5-10 minutes.
detailedExplanation: This plant has a wonderful licorice-like smell and taste. It is a gentle but effective remedy for colds and flu. The tea helps to reduce fever by promoting sweating, soothes a sore throat and cough, and can calm a nervous stomach. Source: PFAF

medicinalUses: This plant is highly poisonous. It has no safe medicinal use and can be fatal if ingested.
sideEffects: HIGHLY POISONOUS. Causes salivation, vomiting, convulsions, and can lead to coma and death.
preparation: Not recommended. Do not use.
detailedExplanation: This plant has beautiful pink and white flowers, but every part of it is extremely toxic. It has been responsible for the deaths of livestock and humans. It should be appreciated for its beauty only and never used as a medicine. Source: Poison Control

medicinalUses: This plant is not known for significant medicinal use. It is primarily an ornamental evergreen shrub.
sideEffects: No common side effects.
preparation: Not used for medicine.
detailedExplanation: Mountain Lover is a low-growing, hardy shrub often used in landscaping for its dense, dark green foliage. It does not have a notable history of use in traditional medicine for treating human ailments.

medicinalUses: Used to relieve stomach aches, reduce fevers, and induce sweating during a cold. Also a strong insect repellent.
sideEffects: Very safe.
preparation: Make a strong tea from the fresh or dried leaves. Crush leaves and rub on skin to repel insects.
detailedExplanation: This native mint has a strong, refreshing scent. A hot tea made from it is excellent for treating colds and flu, as it helps break a fever. It is also very effective for calming indigestion and cramping. Crushing the leaves releases oils that keep mosquitoes away. Source: PFAF

medicinalUses: The roots and seeds are used as a seasoning. It has been used traditionally to treat colds and stomach problems.
sideEffects: Generally safe in small amounts as a seasoning.
preparation: Use the dried, ground root or seeds as a spice in food. A weak tea can be made for colds.
detailedExplanation: This plant is a member of the parsley and carrot family. Its primary use is as a wild spice, giving a celery-like flavor to food. In traditional medicine, a tea made from it was used to alleviate cold symptoms and minor stomach issues.

medicinalUses: The leaves are very high in Vitamin C and were eaten to prevent scurvy. They have a sharp, lemony taste.
sideEffects: Eating large amounts may cause stomach upset due to oxalic acid.
preparation: Eat the fresh leaves raw in salads or as a trailside snack.
detailedExplanation: This small plant is a survival food in the high mountains and arctic. Its sour leaves are an excellent source of Vitamin C, which is crucial for preventing scurvy on long journeys. It provides a refreshing, lemony burst of energy and nutrition. Source: PFAF

medicinalUses: A soothing plant used in poultices for skin irritations, minor wounds, and inflamed eyes. Also used in a tea for coughs.
sideEffects: Very safe.
regionsFound: Found worldwide as a common weed.
preparation: Crush the fresh plant into a paste and apply to the skin. For a tea, steep the dried plant in hot water.
detailedExplanation: This common lawn weed is a gentle, cooling herb. The crushed fresh plant makes an excellent poultice for boils, cuts, and insect bites to reduce itching and inflammation. A weak tea can be used as an eye wash for conjunctivitis or drunk to soothe a cough. Source: PFAF

medicinalUses: This plant is not used for medicine. It is one of the most important model organisms in plant genetics and biology research.
sideEffects: Not applicable.
preparation: Not used for medicine.
detailedExplanation: This small, inconspicuous weed is the "lab rat" of the plant world. Scientists use it to study how plants grow, develop, and respond to their environment. It has revolutionized our understanding of plant genetics but has no medicinal use. Source: Nature

medicinalUses: This small, annual plant is not known for any medicinal uses. It is considered a minor weed in some regions.
sideEffects: No common side effects.
preparation: Not used for medicine.
detailedExplanation: Mouse-tail is a tiny plant named for its long, slender seed head that resembles a mouse's tail. It grows in damp, disturbed ground and has no significant history of use in traditional or modern medicine.

medicinalUses: This aquatic plant is not known for significant medicinal uses.
sideEffects: No common side effects.
preparation: Not used for medicine.
detailedExplanation: Mud-plantain is a small plant that grows in mud and shallow water. It is not a prominent species in traditional medicine and is primarily considered part of the aquatic ecosystem.

medicinalUses: The plant is very poisonous. The latex is used externally in very small amounts for skin diseases, but it is dangerous and can cause severe blisters.
sideEffects: HIGHLY TOXIC. Latex causes skin blistering and blindness in eyes. Fatal if ingested.
preparation: Not recommended. For historical/controlled use only.
detailedExplanation: Mudar is a toxic plant with a milky, corrosive sap. In some traditional systems, this sap is carefully applied to skin conditions like leprosy or to remove warts, but it is extremely dangerous and can cause severe chemical burns. Source: NCBI

medicinalUses: Regulates menstrual cycles and eases period pain. Used in dream pillows to promote vivid dreams. Digestive stimulant, carminative, menstrual cramp relief, mild sedative and nervine support; used topically in fumigation and in moxibustion-type therapies.
sideEffects: Can cause allergic reactions in some. Not for use during pregnancy.
preparation: Make a tea from the dried leaves. Place dried leaves in a small pouch under your pillow for dreams.
detailedExplanation: Mugwort is a powerful herb for women's health, used to bring on a delayed period and relieve menstrual cramps. It is also famous in folklore for enhancing dream recall and lucidity. As a bitter herb, it stimulates digestive juices, improving appetite and digestion. Source: PFAF

medicinalUses: The delicious fruit is a healthy food. The bark is a strong remedy for coughs, asthma, and to lower high blood pressure.
sideEffects: The fruit is very safe. The bark medicine can be strong.
preparation: Eat the ripe fruit fresh. Make a decoction by boiling the bark in water for 15-20 minutes for a medicinal tea.
detailedExplanation: The black mulberry tree is prized for its sweet, dark fruit. The bark of the root is a powerful medicine in traditional systems. It is used to treat respiratory conditions like asthma and whooping cough, and it also helps to reduce high blood pressure. Source: PFAF

medicinalUses: The fruit is edible and nutritious. The inner bark was used by Native Americans to make a de-worming medicine and to treat dysentery.
sideEffects: The fruit is safe. The bark can be a strong purgative.
preparation: Eat the ripe fruit. A decoction of the inner bark was used traditionally for worms.
detailedExplanation: The red mulberry produces tasty fruit, but its medicinal use comes from the bark. A strong tea made from the inner bark was used as a potent treatment to expel intestinal worms and to treat severe diarrhea and dysentery. Source: Native American Ethnobotany DB

medicinalUses: The leaves are used to feed silkworms. The fruit is a healthy food. The leaves and root bark are used in tea to help control blood sugar levels in diabetes.
sideEffects: The fruit is safe.
preparation: Eat the sweet fruit. Make a tea from the dried leaves or root bark for blood sugar support.
detailedExplanation: The white mulberry is famous for its role in silk production. Medicinally, it is most important for diabetes management. Compounds in the leaves and root can help lower blood sugar levels after meals, making it a valuable supportive herb. Source: NCBI

medicinalUses: The primary remedy for clearing chest congestion, soothing a dry, hacking cough, and easing asthma. The flowers are used for earaches.
sideEffects: Very safe. The tiny hairs on fresh leaves can irritate the throat.
preparation: Make a tea from the dried leaves for coughs. Infuse fresh flowers in olive oil for 2-4 weeks to make ear drops.
detailedExplanation: Mullein is the king of herbal remedies for the lungs. Its leaves are rich in mucilage, which coats and soothes irritated throat and bronchial tissues. It is excellent for any kind of cough, especially dry and persistent ones. The flower oil is a traditional remedy for ear infections. Source: NCBI

medicinalUses: This is the same plant as Common Mullein. It is the primary remedy for clearing chest congestion and soothing coughs.
sideEffects: Very safe.
preparation: Make a tea from the dried leaves. Infuse fresh flowers in olive oil for ear drops.
detailedExplanation: This is another name for the most common and well-known species of mullein. All information is identical to Common Mullein. It is the best herb for soothing the respiratory tract. Source: NCBI

medicinalUses: Used similarly to Common Mullein for coughs and respiratory congestion, but is considered less potent.
sideEffects: Very safe.
regionsFound: Europe, Asia; naturalized in North America.
preparation: Make a tea from the dried leaves and flowers.
detailedExplanation: This is a different, less common species of mullein. It shares the same soothing, mucilaginous properties as its larger relative and can be used to make a tea for mild coughs and throat irritation, though it is not as strong. Source: PFAF

medicinalUses: Used like other mulleins as a soothing tea for coughs, bronchitis, and asthma. The flowers can also be used to make earache oil.
sideEffects: Very safe.
preparation: Make a tea from the dried leaves. Infuse the flowers in oil for topical use.
detailedExplanation: This mullein species has orange-yellow hairs on its leaves and stems. It is used in the same way as Common Mullein in European folk medicine. A tea made from the leaves is demulcent and expectorant, ideal for calming respiratory irritation.

medicinalUses: A very easy-to-digest and nutritious food. It helps to cool the body down in hot weather and is often given to sick people for strength.
sideEffects: Very safe. Can cause gas if eaten in large quantities.
preparation: Boil the beans until soft to make a soup or porridge. Sprout the beans and eat them raw in salads.
detailedExplanation: Mung beans are a staple food in many Asian countries. They are known as a "cooling" food, meaning they can help reduce body heat and fever. They are packed with protein, fiber, and vitamins, making them an excellent food for recovery from illness and for overall health. Source: USDA FoodData Central

medicinalUses: The fruit is a healthy food. The skin and seeds are very rich in antioxidants, which are good for heart health and may help fight cancer.
sideEffects: The fruit is safe.
preparation: Eat the fresh grapes. The seeds can be crushed and taken as a supplement.
detailedExplanation: Muscadine grapes have a thick skin and are known for their high concentration of resveratrol and other antioxidants. These compounds help protect your cells from damage, support a healthy heart, and may lower the risk of chronic diseases. Source: NCBI

medicinalUses: The fruit is edible and rich in Vitamin C. The plant is not well-known for strong medicinal properties.
sideEffects: The fruit is safe.
preparation: Eat the berries fresh or use them in jams and jellies.
detailedExplanation: The Musk Currant is primarily a wild edible plant. Its berries are a good source of Vitamin C and can be eaten like other currants. It does not have a prominent history as a medicinal herb beyond its nutritional value.

medicinalUses: This plant is grown for its beautiful spring flowers. It is not used as a medicine.
sideEffects: The bulbs may be toxic if ingested.
preparation: Not used for medicine.
detailedExplanation: Musk Hyacinth is a popular ornamental garden plant, known for its dense spikes of blue, bell-shaped flowers. It is not used in traditional healing practices and should be appreciated for its beauty alone.

medicinalUses: Used to make a soothing tea for coughs and sore throats. The leaves can be used as a poultice for skin irritations.
sideEffects: Very safe.
preparation: Make a tea from the dried leaves and flowers. Crush fresh leaves into a paste for the skin.
detailedExplanation: Like other mallows, Musk Mallow is rich in mucilage. This sticky substance coats and soothes the throat, making it an effective remedy for a dry, irritating cough. A poultice made from the leaves can also calm insect bites and minor skin inflammations. Source: PFAF

medicinalUses: Seeds and flowers used as aphrodisiac, digestive aid and nervine tonic; aromatic seeds used in perfumery and medicinal tonics.
sideEffects: Excessive use may lower blood pressure; topical contact allergy possible.
preparation: Seeds roasted/ground into tonic powders; floral infusions for aromatic baths and mild tonics.
detailedExplanation: Musk mallow is prized in Ayurveda for its fragrant seeds (musk-like) used as nerve and digestive tonics; used carefully in standard folk formulas. Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abelmoschus_moschatus

medicinalUses: A highly nutritious and cooling summer fruit. It aids digestion, helps control blood pressure, and keeps the body hydrated.
sideEffects: Eating the fruit is completely safe and healthy.
regionsFound: Cultivated across India in the summer.
preparation: The ripe fruit is sliced and eaten fresh. It can be blended into juices, shakes, or added to fruit salads.
detailedExplanation: Musk Melon is a beloved summer fruit in India. Its high water content helps prevent heat stroke and dehydration. It is rich in Vitamin A and C, potassium, and dietary fiber, making it excellent for overall health. Source: USDA FoodData Central

medicinalUses: The seeds are used as a spice and in perfumes. In medicine, they are used to relieve stomach spasms, as an aphrodisiac, and to soothe nervous tension.
sideEffects: Generally safe in small amounts.
preparation: Crush the seeds and use them as a flavoring. A tea can be made from the crushed seeds for digestive issues.
detailedExplanation: This plant is known for its musky-scented seeds. These seeds are used in traditional medicine as an antispasmodic to relieve stomach cramps and gas. They are also considered a tonic for the nervous system and are used to reduce anxiety. Source: NCBI

medicinalUses: Used as a calming agent for anxiety, hysteria, and nerve pain. It is also used to strengthen the heart and as a stimulant in low spirits.
sideEffects: Generally safe in recommended doses.
preparation: A tincture or extract is made from the root.
detailedExplanation: Musk Root has a strong, musky odor and is highly valued in Western herbalism as a nerve tonic. It is used to treat conditions of anxiety, panic attacks, and physical weakness associated with nervous exhaustion. It is considered a strengthening herb for the entire nervous system. Source: PFAF

medicinalUses: The fragrant flowers are used to make rose water, which soothes skin irritation and inflamed eyes. The hips (fruit) are rich in Vitamin C.
sideEffects: Very safe.
preparation: Steam distill the flowers to make rose water. Make a syrup or tea from the rose hips.
detailedExplanation: The Musk Rose is prized for its strong, musky fragrance. The rose water made from its flowers is a classic remedy for cooling and soothing red, irritated skin and tired eyes. The rose hips are one of the richest plant sources of Vitamin C, excellent for immune support. Source: PFAF

medicinalUses: The roots are used to make a tonic and astringent medicine, sometimes used for bleeding.
sideEffects: No common side effects.
regionsFound: Europe, Asia; invasive in North America.
preparation: A decoction is made by boiling the roots in water.
detailedExplanation: This thistle is considered an invasive weed in many areas. However, like some other thistles, its root has been used in folk medicine as a tonic to strengthen the body and as an astringent to help control minor bleeding. Source: PFAF

medicinalUses: The seeds are ground into a paste (mustard plaster) and applied to the chest to relieve congestion from colds and bronchitis.
sideEffects: The plaster can cause skin burns if left on too long.
preparation: Mix ground mustard seed with flour and water to make a paste. Apply to the chest with a cloth, but do not let it touch the skin directly.
detailedExplanation: Black mustard seeds are very pungent. When made into a plaster, they create a powerful warming sensation that draws blood to the surface of the skin. This helps to break up deep chest congestion and relieve muscle aches. It is a very strong remedy and must be used carefully to avoid blistering. Source: NCBI

medicinalUses: Used similarly to black mustard in plasters for chest congestion and muscle pain. The seeds are also used as a spice.
sideEffects: The plaster can cause skin burns if left on too long.
preparation: Mix ground mustard seed with flour and water to make a paste. Apply to the chest with a cloth, but do not let it touch the skin directly.
detailedExplanation: Brown mustard is very similar to black mustard and is often used interchangeably. The ground seeds create a powerful warming plaster that helps to break up deep chest congestion and relieve muscle aches by increasing blood flow to the area. Source: ScienceDirect

medicinalUses: The leaves are edible and have a garlic flavor. It was historically used as a disinfectant poultice for wounds.
sideEffects: Safe when consumed as a food.
regionsFound: Europe, Asia; invasive in North America.
preparation: Eat the young leaves raw in salads or cook them like spinach. Crush leaves for a poultice.
detailedExplanation: This plant is a common invasive weed. Its leaves have a mild garlic taste and are a nutritious wild edible. Historically, the crushed leaves were applied as a poultice to wounds to help prevent infection due to their mild antiseptic properties. Source: PFAF

medicinalUses: Used primarily as a soothing tea for hoarseness, sore throats, and loss of voice.
sideEffects: Very safe.
preparation: Make a tea by steeping the fresh or dried plant in hot water for 5-10 minutes.
detailedExplanation: This common roadside weed is known as the "singer's plant" because it is specifically used to treat hoarseness and restore the voice. The tea soothes the vocal cords and irritated throat membranes effectively. Source: PFAF

medicinalUses: This is another name for Brown Mustard. It is used in plasters for congestion and as a spice.
sideEffects: The plaster can cause skin burns.
preparation: Mix ground mustard seed with flour and water to make a paste for a chest plaster.
detailedExplanation: This is the same plant as Brown Mustard, which is the primary mustard seed used in Indian cooking. Its medicinal use is identical: the ground seeds are used in a warming plaster to relieve chest congestion and muscle pain. Source: ScienceDirect

medicinalUses: This plant is not commonly used for medicine. It is related to other mustards but has no significant traditional use.
sideEffects: No common side effects.
preparation: Not used for medicine.
detailedExplanation: Tower Mustard is a wild plant in the mustard family. It is not a prominent species in herbal medicine and is primarily considered a wildflower rather than a medicinal herb.

medicinalUses: Used in a milder plaster for chest congestion and arthritis pain. The seeds are also used as a spice.
sideEffects: Less likely to blister than black mustard, but can still irritate skin.
preparation: Mix ground mustard seed with flour and water to make a paste for a plaster.
detailedExplanation: White mustard seeds are less pungent than black or brown mustard. They are used to make a gentler warming plaster that is better suited for sensitive skin or for children, to relieve chest colds and joint pain. Source: PFAF

medicinalUses: The leaves are a nutritious edible green, rich in vitamins. It was historically used to soothe wounds.
sideEffects: Safe when consumed as a food.
preparation: Eat the young leaves raw in salads or cooked.
detailedExplanation: This plant is a common wild edible. Its leaves are packed with vitamins and minerals, especially in early spring. It has a peppery taste. Its historical use as a wound healer is not well-documented, and it is primarily valued as a food. Source: PFAF

medicinalUses: A powerful antiseptic for mouth and gum infections (gingivitis). Used in tinctures to heal wounds and skin ulcers. Also helps loosen phlegm in coughs.
sideEffects: Can cause skin rash in some. Not for use in pregnancy.
preparation: Use a diluted tincture as a mouthwash. Apply tincture or powdered resin directly to wounds.
detailedExplanation: Myrrh is a sticky resin that has been used for thousands of years. It is one of the best herbs for fighting infection in the mouth and for healing stubborn skin wounds. It also helps to clear mucus from the lungs in chronic bronchitis. Source: NCBI

medicinalUses: The leaves are used to repel moths and other insects. In traditional medicine, it was used to induce sweating and treat intestinal worms.
sideEffects: The plant is considered toxic and should not be ingested.
preparation: Not recommended for internal use. Can be used as an insect repellent.
detailedExplanation: Bog Myrtle is a fragrant shrub of wet areas. Its strong scent makes it an effective natural insect repellent. However, it contains compounds that can cause miscarriage and other toxic effects, so it is not safe to take as a medicine. Source: PFAF

medicinalUses: The leaves and berries are used as an antiseptic for urinary and lung infections. A gargle for sore throats. Helps control blood sugar.
sideEffects: Very safe.
preparation: Make a tea from the dried leaves. Use the leaf tea as a gargle or skin wash.
detailedExplanation: Common Myrtle is a fragrant evergreen shrub. It is a powerful antiseptic for the urinary and respiratory tracts, helping to fight infections like bronchitis and cystitis. A tea made from the leaves makes an excellent gargle for a sore throat. Source: NCBI

medicinalUses: This plant is not well-known in Western herbal medicine. It is primarily ornamental.
sideEffects: No common side effects.
preparation: Not used for medicine.
detailedExplanation: Downy Myrtle is not a true myrtle. It is a poppy-like plant grown for its attractive flowers. It does not have a significant history of use in traditional healing practices.

medicinalUses: This is another name for Common Myrtle. It is used as an antiseptic for lung and urinary infections and as a gargle for sore throats.
sideEffects: Very safe.
preparation: Make a tea from the dried leaves. Use the leaf tea as a gargle or skin wash.
detailedExplanation: This is the same plant as Common Myrtle. It is a powerful antiseptic for the urinary and respiratory tracts, helping to fight infections like bronchitis and cystitis. A tea made from the leaves makes an excellent gargle for a sore throat. Source: NCBI

medicinalUses: This plant is not well-known for medicinal use. It is primarily an ornamental groundcover.
sideEffects: No common side effects.
preparation: Not used for medicine.
detailedExplanation: Sand Myrtle is a low-growing shrub, different from the common medicinal myrtle. It is valued in gardening for its hardiness and appearance but does not have a history of use in traditional medicine.

medicinalUses: This is another name for Common Myrtle. It is used as an antiseptic for infections and to help control blood sugar.
sideEffects: Very safe.
preparation: Make a tea from the dried leaves. Use the leaf tea as a gargle or skin wash.
detailedExplanation: This is the same plant as Common Myrtle. It is a powerful antiseptic for the urinary and respiratory tracts, helping to fight infections like bronchitis and cystitis. It also has properties that can help manage blood sugar levels. Source: NCBI

medicinalUses: The root bark is a strong stimulant for the circulatory system. It is used to treat fevers and as a tonic for fatigue. Can cause sweating.
sideEffects: Can cause stomach irritation in large doses. Not for use during pregnancy.
preparation: Make a decoction by boiling the root bark in water for 10-15 minutes.
detailedExplanation: Wax Myrtle is a strong medicinal plant. A tea made from the root bark is a powerful circulatory stimulant. It is used to break a fever by inducing sweating and is also taken as a general tonic when feeling weak and run down. Source: PFAF

medicinalUses: The wood paste is applied to the skin to cool and soothe rashes, acne, and burns. The oil is used in aromatherapy to reduce anxiety and promote mental clarity.
sideEffects: Extremely safe for topical use.
preparation: Grind the wood with water to make a cooling paste. Use diluted sandalwood oil in a diffuser or for massage.
detailedExplanation: Sandalwood is one of the most sacred and valuable trees in India. Its calming fragrance is used in meditation and religious ceremonies. Medicinally, it is a superb cooling agent for inflamed skin and a calming nervine for a stressed mind. Source: FRLHT

medicinalUses: The seeds are poisonous. The root has been used in traditional medicine to treat fever and diarrhea, but the plant is dangerous.
sideEffects: Seeds are highly toxic. The root can be a strong purgative.
regionsFound: Southeast Asia; invasive in other tropics.
preparation: Not recommended due to toxicity and invasive nature.
detailedExplanation: The Mysore Thorn is a very aggressive, thorny shrub. While the root has been used in some traditions, the seeds are known to be poisonous to humans and livestock. Because of its dangers and invasive behavior, it is not a plant to be used for medicine. Source: CABI Invasive Species Compendium

medicinalUses: Used in Ayurveda for bleeding disorders, skin diseases, fever, and digestive issues-6.
sideEffects: No common side effects reported from typical use.
regionsFound: Native to wet tropical parts of India, Sri Lanka, and Southeast Asia-1.
preparation: Powder from dried stamens (1-3g), paste from flowers, seed oil-6.
detailedExplanation: Nagkesar is a highly valued Ayurvedic herb, considered a versatile remedy. Its flowers, seeds, and stamens are used. It is known for its anti-inflammatory, antibacterial, and hemostatic (stops bleeding) properties-6.

medicinalUses: Source of colchicine, a pharmaceutical drug used to treat gout and familial Mediterranean fever-2-7.
sideEffects: HIGHLY TOXIC. Can cause severe vomiting, organ failure, and be fatal if ingested-7.
preparation: For prescription use only. Do not prepare at home.
detailedExplanation: This plant is the source of the potent medicine colchicine. While it is highly effective for specific inflammatory conditions, all parts of the plant are extremely poisonous and should never be used raw or as a home remedy-2-7.

medicinalUses: The fruit is edible and nutritious; not widely known for specific medicinal properties.
sideEffects: The fruit is safe to eat.
regionsFound: Native to North America, found in woodlands and edges-3.
preparation: The fruit can be eaten raw or cooked into jams and jellies.
detailedExplanation: Nannyberry is primarily valued as a native ornamental shrub and a food source for wildlife. Its ripe, blue-black fruits are edible for humans but are not a prominent feature in herbal medicine-3.

medicinalUses: This plant is not used for medicine and is considered poisonous.
sideEffects: TOXIC. Causes nausea, salivation, and stomach pain if ingested-4.
regionsFound: Native to Europe; introduced in other regions-4.
preparation: Not recommended. Do not use.
detailedExplanation: Known as the Garden Star-of-Bethlehem, this plant is grown as an ornamental. All parts, especially the bulbs, contain toxic cardiac glycosides and should be avoided-4.

medicinalUses: The bulbs are poisonous. Galantamine, a drug for Alzheimer's, is extracted from certain species-5.
sideEffects: POISONOUS. Causes vomiting, diarrhea, and convulsions-5.
regionsFound: Native to Europe and North Africa; cultivated worldwide-5.
preparation: For prescription use only. Do not prepare at home.
detailedExplanation: Daffodils and other narcissus plants are popular ornamentals. Their bulbs are highly toxic. However, they are a source of galantamine, an important prescription medication for cognitive decline, which is produced under controlled conditions-5.

medicinalUses: Used in Ayurveda for insomnia, anxiety, and as a neuroprotective agent.
sideEffects: Generally safe. May cause drowsiness.
regionsFound: Himalayan region of India, Nepal, and China.
preparation: Powder, decoction, or medicated oil from the rhizomes.
detailedExplanation: Jatamansi is a premier Ayurvedic herb for the nervous system. It is highly regarded for its calming and grounding properties, used to promote sleep, reduce stress, and support memory and brain function. [Source: Ayurvedic Pharmacopoeia]

medicinalUses: Was a traditional Aboriginal food; requires careful preparation to remove toxins.
sideEffects: Toxic if unprepared. Contains an enzyme that destroys vitamin B1 (thiamine).
preparation: Spores were traditionally ground into flour and baked into cakes.
detailedExplanation: Nardoo was used as a staple food by some Aboriginal communities. However, it contains a toxic enzyme that can cause severe vitamin B1 deficiency (beriberi) if not prepared correctly using traditional methods that deactivate the toxin.

medicinalUses: This aquatic plant is not known for significant medicinal use.
sideEffects: No common side effects.
preparation: Not used for medicine.
detailedExplanation: The Narrow-leaf Bur-reed is an important plant for aquatic ecosystems, providing habitat for wildlife. It does not have a notable history of use in herbal medicine.

medicinalUses: The pollen is used in Traditional Chinese Medicine to reduce bleeding and bruising.
sideEffects: Very safe.
regionsFound: Found worldwide in temperate regions, in marshes.
preparation: The pollen (Pu Huang) is used in decoctions or powders.
detailedExplanation: Like its relative the common cattail, the pollen of the Narrow-leaf Cattail is an astringent herb. It is primarily used to stop internal and external bleeding, such as in nosebleeds, uterine bleeding, or traumatic injuries. [Source: Chinese Herbal Medicine Materia Medica]

medicinalUses: Used to support the immune system and reduce the severity and duration of colds and flu.
sideEffects: Generally safe. Can cause mild stomach upset or allergic reactions in some.
preparation: Tincture, tea, or capsule from the root.
detailedExplanation: This is one of the primary Echinacea species used in Western herbal medicine. It is believed to stimulate the immune system, helping the body fight off infections, particularly those of the upper respiratory tract. [Source: NCBI]

medicinalUses: The ripe fruit is edible and rich in Vitamin C. The plant has sharp thorns and the sap may be irritating.
sideEffects: The unripe fruit and plant sap may cause minor illness like vomiting or diarrhea-1.
regionsFound: Native to South Africa; cultivated in warm climates.
preparation: The ripe red fruit is eaten raw or used in jams.
detailedExplanation: This evergreen shrub is prized for its fragrant white flowers and edible red fruits that resemble small plums. It is often used as an ornamental hedge in tropical and subtropical gardens. The fruit has a cranberry-like flavor and is a good source of Vitamin C-1.

medicinalUses: Used by Native Americans to make a tea for respiratory ailments and colds. Also used for ceremonial purposes.
sideEffects: Generally safe in moderation.
preparation: Dried leaves and stems are steeped in hot water to make a tea.
detailedExplanation: Big Sagebrush is a dominant and culturally significant plant of the western American deserts. It is easily identified by its silvery-gray, aromatic leaves that typically have a three-toothed tip. It provides important food and habitat for wildlife-2.

medicinalUses: A traditional caffeine-free herbal tea used by Navajo and other Pueblo peoples for its pleasant taste and as a general health tonic.
sideEffects: Very safe.
preparation: Dried flowers and leaves are brewed in hot water to make a light, flavorful tea.
detailedExplanation: Greenthread is a perennial herb whose dried leaves and flowers are used to brew a mild, refreshing tea that has been a staple beverage for Indigenous peoples in the Southwest for generations. It is not a strong medicine but a healthy, traditional drink.

medicinalUses: The fresh, juicy leaves are applied to soothe minor burns and skin irritations.
sideEffects: Very safe for topical use.
regionsFound: Southern and Western Europe, on shady walls and rocks.
preparation: A fresh leaf is cut open and the moist inner part is applied directly to the affected skin.
detailedExplanation: Also known as Penny-pies, this fleshy plant gets its name from its navel-like leaves. It is a succulent that grows in damp, rocky crevices. It has a long history in European folk medicine as a cooling vulnerary (wound-healing) herb for the skin-5.

medicinalUses: This is the same plant as Navel Wort. The fresh leaves are used to cool and soothe minor skin wounds, burns, and inflammations.
sideEffects: Very safe for topical use.
regionsFound: Southern and Western Europe, on shady walls and rocks.
preparation: A fresh leaf is cut open and the moist inner part is applied directly to the affected skin.
detailedExplanation: This is the same plant as Navel Wort (Umbilicus rupestris). It is a fleshy, edible plant in the stonecrop family. Its common names include Wall Pennywort and Penny-pies, and it is not the same as the Asiatic Pennywort (Centella asiatica) used in Ayurveda-5.

medicinalUses: This plant is not known for medicinal use but is ecologically important for soil stabilization in wetland areas.
sideEffects: Not applicable.
regionsFound: Central and Western North America, in wetlands.
preparation: Not used for medicine.
detailedExplanation: Nebraska Sedge is a perennial, grass-like plant that forms dense tufts. It is a vital species for wetland ecosystems, providing habitat and helping to prevent soil erosion. It is also tolerant of alkaline soils and seasonal flooding-6.

medicinalUses: Used as fodder, mild anti-inflammatory, digestive aid
sideEffects: Rare
preparation: Leaf decoction
detailedExplanation: Alysicarpus monilifer is a widespread fodder plant also used in traditional medicine for anti-inflammatory and digestive purposes. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK92771/

medicinalUses: The inner bark was used in traditional medicine to make a tea for pain relief, fever reduction, and as an antiseptic wash.
sideEffects: Generally safe.
regionsFound: Eastern, Central, and Southwestern North America.
preparation: A tea or tincture is made from the inner bark.
detailedExplanation: The Eastern Cottonwood is one of the largest North American hardwood trees, known for its rapid growth and triangular leaves. In the past, cowboys and pioneers used its bitter inner bark to make a tea for various ailments. It is also the state tree of Kansas, Nebraska, and Wyoming-7.

medicinalUses: This is the same plant as Needle-and-Thread Grass. It is not used for medicine but is ecologically vital.
sideEffects: The sharp seeds can injure the mouths of grazing animals.
regionsFound: Western North America, grasslands and prairies.
preparation: Not used for medicine.
detailedExplanation: This is another common name for Hesperostipa comata. It is a key species of the North American plains, providing food for animals like prairie dogs and jackrabbits. Its unique seed dispersal mechanism is a fascinating example of plant adaptation-9.

medicinalUses: This grass is not used for medicine. It is a important forage grass for wildlife and livestock in its early growth stages.
sideEffects: The sharp seeds can injure the mouths of grazing animals.
regionsFound: Western North America, grasslands and prairies.
preparation: Not used for medicine.
detailedExplanation: This perennial bunchgrass is named for its exceptionally long, twisted awns (needles) that are attached to the seeds (threads). The awn twists and untwists with changes in humidity, helping to drill the seed into the ground. It is the provincial grass of Saskatchewan-9.

medicinalUses: This is the same plant as Needle-and-Thread Grass and Needle Grass. It has no medicinal use but is a valuable forage grass.
sideEffects: The sharp seeds can injure the mouths of grazing animals.
regionsFound: Western North America, grasslands and prairies.
preparation: Not used for medicine.
detailedExplanation: This entry refers to the same species, Hesperostipa comata. It was described during the Lewis and Clark Expedition and is popular with children because the sharp seeds can be thrown to stick onto clothing-9.

medicinalUses: This plant is primarily ornamental. It is not known for significant medicinal properties.
sideEffects: The fruit may be mildly toxic if ingested in large quantities.
preparation: Not used for medicine.
detailedExplanation: Needleleaf is a common name that can refer to various plants with narrow, pointed leaves. One example is Rhaphiolepis indica, an evergreen shrub grown for its attractive foliage and pink or white flowers. It is used in landscaping, not herbal medicine.

medicinalUses: A powerful antiseptic and antifungal. Used for skin diseases (eczema, psoriasis), dental health, and to boost immunity. Leaves are also used as a natural pesticide.
sideEffects: Very safe for topical use. Bitter taste; internal use in large amounts may be hard on kidneys.
regionsFound: Native to India; cultivated in tropical regions worldwide.
preparation: A paste from crushed leaves is applied to the skin. Neem twigs are used as toothbrushes. Leaf tea is consumed for immunity.
detailedExplanation: The Neem tree is a cornerstone of Ayurvedic medicine, often called "the village pharmacy." Every part of the tree is used. Its leaves have powerful blood-purifying and antiseptic properties, and its oil is a potent insect repellent and skin treatment.

medicinalUses: This ivy is not commonly used in medicine. Many ivies can be toxic if ingested.
sideEffects: POISONOUS. Can cause skin irritation on contact and severe vomiting, diarrhea, and stomach pain if ingested.
preparation: Not recommended. Do not use.
detailedExplanation: Nepal Ivy is an evergreen climbing vine, similar to English Ivy. While not well-documented medicinally, it is best treated with caution due to the toxicity common in the Hedera genus. It is primarily an ornamental plant.

medicinalUses: The bark is astringent and used to treat diarrhea and throat infections. The tree is important for soil enrichment and land reclamation.
sideEffects: No common side effects.
regionsFound: Eastern Himalayas (Nepal, Bhutan, Northern India, Myanmar).
preparation: A decoction is made from the bark.
detailedExplanation: The Nepalese Alder is a fast-growing pioneer tree species that quickly colonizes degraded land and improves soil fertility through nitrogen fixation. Its wood is used for construction and its bark has traditional medicinal uses.

medicinalUses: The bark is used to make high-quality paper (Lokta paper). The plant is poisonous and not used for medicine.
sideEffects: HIGHLY POISONOUS. All parts can cause severe burning in the mouth, vomiting, and internal bleeding.
preparation: Not recommended. For paper-making only.
detailedExplanation: This shrub is famous for its strong, fibrous bark, which is sustainably harvested to produce the durable Lokta paper used for official documents, art, and packaging in Nepal. Despite its beauty and utility, the plant itself is dangerously toxic.

medicinalUses: The fruit is edible. The leaves and bark have been used in traditional medicine as an astringent to treat diarrhea and heavy menstrual bleeding.
sideEffects: The fruit is safe to eat.
regionsFound: Southern Europe, North Africa, Asia Minor.
preparation: A decoction is made from the leaves and bark.
detailedExplanation: The European Nettle Tree is a deciduous tree known for its edible, small, dark berries and its tough, flexible wood, which is used for making walking sticks and tools. It is not related to the stinging nettle.

medicinalUses: Similar to Stinging Nettle; used as a nutritious spring tonic, for allergies, and to support joint health. The sting is used in folk remedies for arthritis.
sideEffects: The fresh plant causes a painful sting. Dried or cooked, it is safe.
preparation: The plant is cooked to neutralize the sting and eaten as a green. A tea is made from the dried leaves.
detailedExplanation: Annual Nettle is a smaller relative of the Stinging Nettle (Urtica dioica). It shares similar medicinal and nutritional properties but is a smaller, annual plant. Its stinging hairs inject histamine and other chemicals upon touch.

medicinalUses: Used to relieve menstrual cramps and heavy bleeding. Soothes skin irritations and is a mild diuretic.
sideEffects: Very safe.
regionsFound: Europe, Asia; naturalized in North America.
preparation: A tea is made from the dried flowers and leaves.
detailedExplanation: Despite its name and similar appearance, White Dead Nettle does not sting. It is a valuable medicinal plant, particularly for women's health. Its flowers are a rich source of nectar for bees.

medicinalUses: This plant is not commonly used in medicine and may be mildly toxic.
sideEffects: Can cause sedation and other symptoms if ingested.
preparation: Not recommended for use.
detailedExplanation: Hemp Nettle is a weedy plant that resembles stinging nettle but does not sting. It is generally considered unsuitable for medicinal use and is best avoided due to its potential toxicity and lack of well-documented benefits.

medicinalUses: Used like Dead Nettle for skin irritation and as a mild astringent. The leaves are edible and nutritious.
sideEffects: Very safe.
preparation: The young leaves can be eaten raw in salads or cooked. A tea is made from the plant.
detailedExplanation: Also known as Red Dead Nettle, this common garden weed is a close relative of White Dead Nettle. It is a harmless and edible plant that provides early spring nectar for pollinators. It does not sting.

medicinalUses: Used for allergies, arthritis, and as a diuretic. Rich in nutrients, it supports skin, joint, and urinary tract health.
sideEffects: Fresh plant causes painful stinging. Dried/cooked is safe. May cause mild stomach upset in some.
regionsFound: Native to Europe, Asia, North Africa; naturalized worldwide.
preparation: Young leaves are cooked and eaten. Dried leaf is used for tea, tincture, or capsules.
detailedExplanation: Stinging Nettle is a perennial plant known for the stinging hairs on its leaves and stems. Despite this defense mechanism, it is a highly nutritious and medicinal plant when properly handled. It is widely used for seasonal allergies, inflammatory conditions like arthritis, and to support kidney and urinary function. https://www.rhs.org.uk/weeds/nettles-as-weeds

medicinalUses: This plant is not commonly used in medicine and may be mildly toxic.
sideEffects: Can cause sedation and other symptoms if ingested.
preparation: Not recommended for use.
detailedExplanation: Hemp Nettle is a weedy plant that resembles stinging nettle but does not sting. It is generally considered unsuitable for medicinal use and is best avoided due to its potential toxicity and lack of well-documented benefits.

medicinalUses: Soothes skin irritations and is a mild astringent. The young leaves are edible and nutritious.
sideEffects: Very safe.
regionsFound: Europe, Asia; naturalized in North America.
preparation: The young leaves can be eaten raw in salads or cooked. A tea is made from the plant.
detailedExplanation: Dead Nettle is a common name for plants in the Lamium genus. Unlike stinging nettles, they are harmless and do not sting. Lamium album (White Dead Nettle) is a common species used to soothe skin irritations and as a gentle, nutritious wild edible. https://www.gardenersworld.com/plants/dead-nettles/

medicinalUses: Can cause sedation and other symptoms if ingested.
sideEffects: Not recommended for use.
regionsFound: This plant is not commonly used in medicine and may be mildly toxic.
preparation: Hemp Nettle is a weedy plant that resembles stinging nettle but does not sting. It is generally considered unsuitable for medicinal use and is best avoided due to its potential toxicity and lack of well-documented benefits.
detailedExplanation: Not well-defined, but potentially sedative.

plantType: Native to Europe, Asia, North Africa; naturalized worldwide.
medicinalUses: Fresh plant causes painful stinging. Dried/cooked is safe. May cause mild stomach upset in some.
sideEffects: Young leaves are cooked and eaten. Dried leaf is used for tea, tincture, or capsules.
regionsFound: Used for allergies, arthritis, and as a diuretic. Rich in nutrients, it supports skin, joint, and urinary tract health.
preparation: Stinging Nettle is a perennial plant known for the stinging hairs on its leaves and stems. Despite this defense mechanism, it is a highly nutritious and medicinal plant when properly handled. It is widely used for seasonal allergies, inflammatory conditions like arthritis, and to support kidney and urinary function.
detailedExplanation: The anti-inflammatory and anti-allergy effects are attributed to compounds that may modulate the immune system and inhibit histamine release.

plantType: Europe, Asia; naturalized in North America.
medicinalUses: Very safe.
sideEffects: A tea is made from the dried flowers and leaves.
regionsFound: Used to relieve menstrual cramps and heavy bleeding. Soothes skin irritations and is a mild diuretic.
preparation: Despite its name and similar appearance, White Dead Nettle does not sting. It is a valuable medicinal plant, particularly for women's health. Its flowers are a rich source of nectar for bees.
detailedExplanation: The plant contains anti-inflammatory and astringent compounds that help regulate menstrual flow.

medicinalUses: Used by indigenous Americans, such as the Cherokee, Iroquois, and Potawatomi, to heal multiple ailments.-3
sideEffects: Specific side effects not well-documented.
preparation: Traditional preparations require further research.
detailedExplanation: New England Aster is a perennial, herbaceous plant native to central and eastern North America. It is a fall-blooming plant with usually deep purple flowers that are important for pollinators like bees and butterflies.-3

medicinalUses: While its historical use is documented, specific medicinal benefits and safety for humans require verification from authoritative medicinal databases.
sideEffects: Safety unclear. Information on toxicity to pets exists, highlighting the need for caution.-1
regionsFound: Native to central and eastern North America.
preparation: Use not recommended without professional guidance.
detailedExplanation: New Jersey Tea is a low-growing, rounded shrub native to prairies and open woods. It produces clouds of white flowers in June and July and is an excellent nectar source for butterflies.-4 Its historical name comes from its leaves being used as a tea substitute during the American Revolutionary War.

medicinalUses: Native Americans used the leaves to make a tea for labor pain and as a blood tonic. The root was used for stomach ulcers and tooth pain.-6-7
sideEffects: No known toxicity.-6-7
preparation: Tea made from leaves or roots.
detailedExplanation: New York Ironweed is a tall, herbaceous perennial with striking purple flowers that bloom in late summer. It grows in wetlands and moist soils and is highly attractive to butterflies and other pollinators.-6

medicinalUses: The plant is highly toxic and not used in safe herbal practice. Nicotine has pharmaceutical applications but is extremely dangerous in its raw form.
sideEffects: HIGHLY POISONOUS. Can cause nausea, vomiting, seizures, respiratory failure, and death.
preparation: For prescription use only. Do not prepare at home.
detailedExplanation: Tobacco plants are the source of nicotine. While highly addictive and toxic, nicotine has been used in some pharmaceutical preparations, such as smoking cessation products. These are strictly regulated and should never be confused with the raw plant.

medicinalUses: All parts of this plant are poisonous. It is grown for its intensely fragrant flowers but is not a medicine.
sideEffects: POISONOUS. Ingestion causes fever, vomiting, and severe gastrointestinal symptoms. Can be fatal.
preparation: Not recommended. Do not use.
detailedExplanation: Night Jessamine is a popular ornamental shrub in warm climates, famous for the powerful, sweet fragrance its flowers release at night. Despite its pleasant scent, all parts of the plant are highly toxic to humans and animals.

medicinalUses: Grown for ornamental value and fragrance. No significant medicinal uses.
sideEffects: None.
preparation: Not used for medicine.
detailedExplanation: Night Phlox is prized for its sweet, honey-almond scent that intensifies in the evening. It is purely an ornamental species.

medicinalUses: Used for prostate and urinary tract health.
sideEffects: Very safe.
preparation: Tea from leaves.
detailedExplanation: This herb is used similarly to other Willowherbs in traditional medicine for soothing urinary and prostate issues.

medicinalUses: Historically used for heart ailments.
sideEffects: Use requires professional guidance.
preparation: Tincture from stems and flowers.
detailedExplanation: This cactus has a history of use in traditional medicine for heart conditions, but it is potent and not for self-administration.

medicinalUses: Grown for its strong evening fragrance. No medicinal uses.
sideEffects: None.
preparation: Not used for medicine.
detailedExplanation: This plant is cultivated exclusively for its ornamental value and powerful scent that attracts night-flying pollinators.

medicinalUses: All parts are toxic and should not be used.
sideEffects: POISONOUS.
preparation: Not recommended. Do not use.
detailedExplanation: This plant is a member of the toxic nightshade family. It produces small, glossy black berries that are poisonous to humans and livestock.

medicinalUses: The unripe berries are toxic. Ripe berries and leaves are used in traditional medicine for skin issues, fever, and liver ailments with caution.
sideEffects: Unripe berries are poisonous.
preparation: Leaves and ripe berries used in poultices or decoctions by experts.
detailedExplanation: This common weed has a dual nature. While its ripe berries are sometimes used in traditional medicine, the plant is potentially toxic and requires expert knowledge for safe application-4.

medicinalUses: This plant is considered toxic.
sideEffects: POISONOUS.
preparation: Not recommended. Do not use.
detailedExplanation: A weedy member of the nightshade family, it is generally considered inedible and potentially toxic due to its solanine content.

medicinalUses: One of the most toxic plants. Source of pharmaceutical atropine, but deadly if misused.
sideEffects: EXTREMELY POISONOUS. Can be fatal.
preparation: For prescription use only. Do not prepare at home.
detailedExplanation: All parts of this plant are deadly poisonous. It is the source of important drugs like atropine, but these are used only in purified, controlled doses in modern medicine-4.

medicinalUses: This plant is not a true nightshade and has no significant medicinal use.
sideEffects: None.
preparation: Not used for medicine.
detailedExplanation: Despite its common name, it belongs to the evening primrose family, not the nightshade family. It is not known to be medicinal or toxic.

medicinalUses: The berries are poisonous if ingested.
sideEffects: TOXIC. Causes gastric upset.
preparation: Not recommended. Do not use.
detailedExplanation: Also known as the Jerusalem Cherry, this is a popular ornamental plant. Its bright orange-red berries are attractive to children but are toxic and should not be eaten.

medicinalUses: This plant is considered toxic. Its use is risky and not recommended.
sideEffects: POISONOUS. Can cause gastrointestinal distress and neurological issues.
preparation: Not recommended. Do not use.
detailedExplanation: Many small, black-berried nightshades are difficult to distinguish. The "Malabar Nightshade" likely refers to a tropical species that shares the toxic properties of the nightshade family. Misidentification can be dangerous.

medicinalUses: All parts of the plant are poisonous to humans and livestock.
sideEffects: POISONOUS.
preparation: Not recommended. Do not use.
detailedExplanation: Silverleaf Nightshade is a deeply rooted perennial weed covered with silvery hairs. It is considered a noxious invasive species in many parts of the world due to its toxicity and impact on agriculture.

medicinalUses: The unripe fruit is poisonous. The plant is cultivated as a source of industrial steroids for pharmaceuticals.
sideEffects: Unripe fruit is poisonous.
preparation: Not for self-medication. For industrial pharmaceutical use.
detailedExplanation: This shrub is grown commercially for the solasodine in its leaves, which is used to manufacture steroid hormones. It is not an herb for home use and should be treated as toxic.

medicinalUses: The seeds are fermented into a condiment (soumbala/dawadawa). The pulp and bark are used for diarrhea and skin infections.
sideEffects: The food product is safe.
preparation: Seeds are fermented. A decoction is made from the bark.
detailedExplanation: Also known as the African Locust Bean, this tree is vital for food and medicine in West Africa. The fermented seeds are a protein-rich flavoring, and various parts of the tree are used in traditional healing.

medicinalUses: This plant is not known for medicinal use. It is a popular ornamental shrub for landscaping.
sideEffects: No common side effects.
preparation: Not used for medicine.
detailedExplanation: Ninebark is a hardy, deciduous shrub valued for its attractive bark that peels in layers, colorful leaves, and clusters of white or pink flowers. It is used in gardens for visual interest and is not a medicinal herb.

medicinalUses: The sap is tapped to make a sweet syrup, vinegar, and an alcoholic beverage. The young seeds are edible.
sideEffects: The sap and food products are safe.
regionsFound: Mangrove swamps of South Asia, Southeast Asia, Australia.
preparation: Sap is tapped and fermented or boiled. Young seeds are eaten.
detailedExplanation: The Nipa Palm is the only palm considered a mangrove. It is incredibly useful; its leaves are used for thatching, and its sap is a source of sugar and alcohol. It plays a crucial role in protecting coastal ecosystems.

medicinalUses: The young leaves are edible and can be used in salads. It has been used in folk medicine as a mild astringent.
sideEffects: Very safe as a food.
preparation: Young leaves are eaten raw or cooked.
detailedExplanation: Nipplewort is a common annual weed related to dandelions. Its name comes from the shape of its flower buds. It is primarily a wild edible and not a strong medicinal plant.

medicinalUses: This tree is not used for medicine. It is a popular source of Christmas trees and its wood is used for timber.
sideEffects: No common side effects.
preparation: Not used for medicine.
detailedExplanation: The Noble Fir is a large evergreen conifer highly valued for its strong wood and its symmetrical shape as a Christmas tree. It is an important timber species and not a medicinal plant.

medicinalUses: This plant is not known for medicinal use. It is a wetland species important for wildlife.
sideEffects: The barbed seeds can cling to clothing and animal fur.
preparation: Not used for medicine.
detailedExplanation: Nodding Beggarticks is an annual plant of marshes and wet ditches. It is named for its barbed seeds (beggar's ticks) that readily attach to passersby for seed dispersal. It is not a medicinal herb.

medicinalUses: This is the same plant as Nodding Beggarticks. It is not known for medicinal use.
sideEffects: The barbed seeds can cling to clothing and animal fur.
preparation: Not used for medicine.
detailedExplanation: This is another common name for Bidens cernua. It is a native annual of wetlands, easily identified by its nodding flower heads and sticky seeds. It provides food for birds and insects.

medicinalUses: The roots are used in traditional medicine as a tonic and astringent, sometimes for bleeding.
sideEffects: No common side effects.
regionsFound: Europe, Asia; invasive in North America.
preparation: A decoction is made from the roots.
detailedExplanation: This tall, striking thistle is known for its large, deep pink flowers that "nod" or droop on their stems. It is considered an invasive weed in many regions but has historical use in folk medicine similar to other thistles.

medicinalUses: The bulbs are edible and have antimicrobial properties like cultivated onions and garlic.
sideEffects: Safe when consumed as food.
preparation: Bulbs and leaves can be eaten raw or cooked.
detailedExplanation: This native perennial wildflower is part of the onion genus. It is characterized by its graceful, nodding clusters of pink flowers. All parts of the plant have a mild onion flavor and can be used as a culinary herb.

medicinalUses: Used in traditional medicine as a bitter tonic for digestion and to stimulate appetite.
sideEffects: Generally safe in moderation.
preparation: A tea is made from the leaves.
detailedExplanation: This species of wormwood is a perennial herb with finely divided, aromatic leaves. Like its relatives, it contains bitter principles that stimulate digestion, but it is less potent than the famous Artemisia absinthium (Wormwood).

medicinalUses: Used for skin ailments, fever, and as general tonic
sideEffects: Rare
preparation: Leaf decoction or paste
detailedExplanation: Allmania nodiflora is a widely distributed herb in India used traditionally for skin diseases and fever. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK92771/

medicinalUses: Used for a wide range of ailments including arthritis, infections, and as a general tonic. The juice is a popular health drink.
sideEffects: The strong taste and smell can be unpleasant. High potassium content may affect those with kidney issues.
regionsFound: Native to Southeast Asia, Australia; cultivated in tropics.
preparation: The ripe fruit is consumed as juice or applied topically. Leaves are used in poultices.
detailedExplanation: The Noni fruit has a strong, cheesy odor and a bitter taste, but it is highly valued in traditional Polynesian and Ayurvedic medicine. It is used both internally and externally for its purported anti-inflammatory and immune-boosting properties.

medicinalUses: The wood and foliage are aromatic but not commonly used in medicine. It is a valued timber tree.
sideEffects: No common side effects.
preparation: Not used for medicine.
detailedExplanation: This large evergreen conifer is known for its graceful, drooping branches and durable, aromatic wood, which is used for carving and building. It is the provincial tree of British Columbia.

medicinalUses: The rose hips are very high in Vitamin C and used to make tea, jam, and syrup to prevent colds and support immunity.
sideEffects: Very safe.
preparation: Rose hips are used to make tea, syrup, or jam.
detailedExplanation: This native wild rose produces large, attractive pink flowers and equally large, nutritious rose hips. Like other wild roses, it is an excellent source of Vitamin C and supports wildlife.

medicinalUses: This tree is not used for medicine. It is a popular ornamental plant, especially as a Christmas tree in warm climates.
sideEffects: Not toxic, but not medicinal.
regionsFound: Norfolk Island (Australia); cultivated worldwide as a houseplant.
preparation: Not used for medicine.
detailedExplanation: Despite its name, this is not a true pine. It is a popular evergreen houseplant known for its symmetrical, tiered branching. It is grown purely for its ornamental value.

medicinalUses: The fruit is a nutritious food. The seeds and bark contain compounds with potential insecticidal and anti-cancer properties, but are not used in home medicine.
sideEffects: Seeds and bark are toxic if ingested.
preparation: Only the ripe fruit pulp is eaten.
detailedExplanation: The Pawpaw is the largest edible fruit native to North America, with a flavor reminiscent of banana and mango. While the fruit is delicious, the seeds and bark contain toxic compounds and should not be consumed.

medicinalUses: This plant is poisonous and should not be used for medicine.
sideEffects: POISONOUS.
preparation: Not recommended. Do not use.
detailedExplanation: This small, white-flowered plant is a member of the buttercup family. Like many anemones, it contains irritating compounds that can cause severe gastrointestinal distress if ingested.

medicinalUses: Used as a mild diuretic and to treat skin conditions. The roots produce a red dye.
sideEffects: Very safe.
regionsFound: Northern temperate regions of North America, Europe, Asia.
preparation: A tea is made from the leaves and stems. A poultice is applied to the skin.
detailedExplanation: This perennial plant forms clusters of small, white, fragrant flowers. It was traditionally used as a stuffing for mattresses, hence the name "bedstraw." It has mild astringent and diuretic properties.

medicinalUses: Historically used similarly to other clubmosses for skin conditions and as a diuretic. Spores are flammable and were used in fireworks.
sideEffects: May cause stomach upset. Spores are a fire hazard.
regionsFound: Bogs and wet heaths in Northern Hemisphere.
preparation: Powdered plant or spores used in poultices.
detailedExplanation: This small, creeping plant thrives in acidic, wet bogs. Like other clubmosses, its spores are highly flammable and were historically used in theater for flash effects and in early photography.

medicinalUses: This plant is highly poisonous and should never be used for medicine.
sideEffects: HIGHLY POISONOUS. Can cause vomiting, convulsions, and death.
preparation: Not recommended. Do not use.
detailedExplanation: This small, evergreen shrub has beautiful pink flowers but is extremely toxic. It is related to the Mountain Laurel and contains the same dangerous grayanotoxins. It should be appreciated for its beauty only.

medicinalUses: Used like other violets for coughs, colds, and as a mild laxative. The leaves are rich in Vitamin C.
sideEffects: Very safe.
preparation: A tea is made from the leaves and flowers.
detailedExplanation: This violet species is found in wet, boggy habitats. It shares the soothing, mucilaginous properties of other violets, making it useful for respiratory and skin complaints.

medicinalUses: The roots were used by Native Americans to make a tea for treating diarrhea and stomach pain.
sideEffects: Generally safe.
preparation: A decoction is made from the roots.
detailedExplanation: This perennial wildflower is part of a large genus native to North America. It is drought-tolerant and an important food source for butterflies and other insects.

medicinalUses: The bark has been used as a tea for asthma and as an antiseptic wash. The tree is primarily ornamental.
sideEffects: The fruit pods and seeds are considered mildly toxic.
preparation: A tea is made from the bark.
detailedExplanation: This tree is known for its large, heart-shaped leaves, showy clusters of white flowers, and long, bean-like seed pods. It is a fast-growing tree often planted for shade and ornament.

medicinalUses: This plant is a parasitic herb and is not known for medicinal use.
sideEffects: Not well-documented.
preparation: Not used for medicine.
detailedExplanation: Northern Comandra is a small, perennial plant that is partially parasitic on the roots of other plants, particularly conifers. It produces small, orange-red berries.

sideEffects: Not applicable.
preparation: Not used for medicine.
detailedExplanation: The Northern Coralroot is a fascinating, leafless orchid. It lacks chlorophyll and does not photosynthesize. Instead, it derives its nutrients from mycorrhizal fungi in the soil.

medicinalUses: The fruit is edible and nutritious. The root and leaves are astringent and have been used to treat diarrhea.
sideEffects: Very safe. The plant has thorns.
preparation: The berries are eaten. A tea is made from the root or leaves.
detailedExplanation: This plant is a trailing, low-growing relative of the blackberry. It produces sweet, black berries and is a valuable plant for wildlife. Its astringent properties are common in the Rubus genus.

medicinalUses: The fruit is edible and used for jam, juice, and wine. The leaves are also edible when cooked.
sideEffects: The fruit is safe.
preparation: The grapes are eaten or juiced. Leaves are cooked.
detailedExplanation: This wild grape is the source of many American grape cultivars, including the Concord grape. It is known for its "foxy" musk and slip-skin, where the skin easily separates from the pulp.

medicinalUses: The fruit is edible and rich in Vitamin C. Not widely known for specific medicinal properties beyond its nutritional value.
sideEffects: The fruit is safe. The plant has thorns.
preparation: The berries are eaten raw or cooked into jams and pies.
detailedExplanation: This native shrub produces small, tart, edible berries that are typically greenish or purplish. It is a hardy plant of northern woods and thickets, and its fruit is a valuable food source for birds and mammals.

medicinalUses: Used for digestive disorders, anti-inflammatory, and snakebite remedies
sideEffects: Can cause kidney toxicity in high doses
preparation: Dried roots are boiled and filtered before use
detailedExplanation: A climbing herb known for its distinctive green dragon-tail-like flowers, used traditionally in Ayurveda for snakebites and digestive ailments. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov

sideEffects: No known major side effects

detailedExplanation: A rare northern orchid with rejuvenating properties used in traditional Arctic and Himalayan medicine. Source: https://powo.science.kew.org

sideEffects: May cause nausea if consumed raw
preparation: Extract from leaves brewed into tea
detailedExplanation: Carnivorous plant used by Native Americans for respiratory infections and smallpox treatment. Source: https://plants.usda.gov

sideEffects: Can cause constipation if overused
preparation: Bark decoction applied externally or taken orally
detailedExplanation: The bark of Northern Red Oak is rich in tannins with astringent and wound-healing properties. Source: https://www.fs.usda.gov

medicinalUses: Used for detoxification and mild respiratory relief
sideEffects: None significant
preparation: Infusion of leaves taken once daily
detailedExplanation: A hardy alpine herb used for detoxification and lung support in traditional herbalism. Source: https://plants.usda.gov

medicinalUses: Relieves cold, sore throat, and stomach cramps
sideEffects: None in moderate doses
preparation: Leaves boiled to make tea or poultice
detailedExplanation: Spicebush berries and leaves were used by Native Americans for respiratory and digestive health. Source: https://www.fs.fed.us
