sideEffects: May cause mild liver strain in excess
preparation: Roots dried and brewed as herbal tea
detailedExplanation: Sweet Coltsfoot used for coughs, asthma, and allergies; a natural expectorant in Arctic herbal medicine. Source: https://www.sciencedirect.com

medicinalUses: Considered a sacred, purifying plant by many Indigenous peoples of North America. It is braided and burned as a ceremonial incense.
sideEffects: Very safe.
preparation: Braided and burned as smudge. Sometimes used in tea.
detailedExplanation: Sweetgrass is revered for its sweet, vanilla-like scent, which is released when burned or after rain. Its use is more spiritual and cultural than medicinal, valued for inviting positive energy and cleansing a space.

medicinalUses: This aquatic plant is not used for medicine. It is ecologically important for providing oxygen and habitat in water bodies.
sideEffects: Not applicable.
preparation: Not used for medicine.
detailedExplanation: This submerged aquatic plant forms dense underwater forests that provide crucial shelter for fish and invertebrates. It helps improve water quality by absorbing excess nutrients.

medicinalUses: The leaves are a strong antiseptic used in ointments for warts, fungal infections, and skin parasites. The plant is toxic if ingested.
sideEffects: POISONOUS if taken internally. Can cause organ damage.
preparation: Used externally in creams, ointments, or diluted tinctures. Never take internally.
detailedExplanation: This evergreen tree's leaves contain a powerful essential oil (thujone) that is highly effective against skin growths and infections. However, thujone is a neurotoxin, making internal use extremely dangerous.

medicinalUses: The aerial parts are used in a tea as an astringent to treat diarrhea and mouth sores.
sideEffects: Very safe.
preparation: A tea is made from the leaves and stems.
detailedExplanation: This is a common, weedy member of the cinquefoil family. Like its relatives, it is rich in tannins, which give it astringent properties useful for tightening tissues and reducing inflammation.

medicinalUses: The sap can be used to make syrup, though it is less sweet than Sugar Maple. Not known for significant medicinal use.
sideEffects: No common side effects.
regionsFound: Europe, Western Asia; invasive in North America.
preparation: Sap is boiled into syrup.
detailedExplanation: This tree is widely planted as a street tree but is invasive in North American forests, where it outcompetes native trees. It is primarily an ornamental and shade tree.

medicinalUses: The inner bark can be used to make a tea for coughs and as a mild antiseptic. The resin is applied to wounds.
sideEffects: Very safe.
preparation: A tea is made from the inner bark. Resin is applied topically.
detailedExplanation: This is a tall pine tree native to North America, not Norway. It is an important timber tree. Its inner bark, like that of many pines, has soothing and antimicrobial properties.

medicinalUses: The young shoot tips are rich in Vitamin C and used to make a tea for preventing scurvy and colds. The resin is used for ointments.
sideEffects: Very safe.
preparation: A tea is made from young shoots. Resin is used in salves.
detailedExplanation: This is the classic Christmas tree in many parts of the world. Its fresh, bright green shoot tips in spring are a traditional source of Vitamin C and have a refreshing, citrusy taste.

medicinalUses: This is the same plant as Common Mugwort. It is used to regulate menstrual cycles, aid digestion, and promote vivid dreams.
sideEffects: Can cause allergic reactions. Not for use during pregnancy.
preparation: A tea is made from the dried leaves.
detailedExplanation: Norwegian Mugwort is a common name for the widespread species Artemisia vulgaris. It is a bitter herb used in various folk traditions for women's health, as a digestive stimulant, and for its psychoactive properties in dream pillows.

medicinalUses: The leaves are a powerful first-aid remedy to stop bleeding from cuts and nosebleeds. Also used to reduce fever and ease menstrual cramps.
sideEffects: Can cause skin allergy in some. Makes you more sensitive to the sun.
preparation: Crush fresh leaves and press on a wound. Make a tea from dried flowers for fever.
detailedExplanation: Yarrow's Latin name, Achillea, refers to the warrior Achilles, who used it to stanch the bleeding wounds of his soldiers. It is one of the best herbal remedies for immediate first aid for bleeding.

medicinalUses: The plant has stinging hairs that cause a painful, burning sensation and skin irritation on contact. It is not used for medicine.
sideEffects: Causes severe skin irritation and burning.
preparation: Not recommended. Avoid contact.
detailedExplanation: Plants in the Tragia genus are covered in stinging hairs similar to those of stinging nettles. Contact with the skin causes immediate, intense pain and inflammation. The genus name honors botanist Hieronymus Tragus.

medicinalUses: A key Ayurvedic herb for digestive issues, fever, and menstrual problems. Also used as a diuretic and to treat skin diseases.
sideEffects: Very safe in recommended doses.
regionsFound: Found worldwide in tropical and temperate regions.
preparation: Powder, decoction, or essential oil from the tubers.
detailedExplanation: Despite being one of the world's most invasive weeds, Nut Grass is a highly valued medicinal plant. Its aromatic tubers are used to soothe the digestive system, reduce inflammation, and relieve pain. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5432777/

medicinalUses: The edible seeds (pine nuts) are highly nutritious. The inner bark and resin have traditional uses for wounds and coughs.
sideEffects: The seeds are very safe.
preparation: Seeds are eaten raw or roasted. A tea is made from the inner bark.
detailedExplanation: This small pine tree is famous for its delicious, edible pine nuts, which have been a staple food for Indigenous peoples for centuries. The tree also provides timber and fuel.

medicinalUses: Similar to other pinyon pines; the seeds are a nutritious food. The resin was used as a sealant and chewing gum.
sideEffects: The seeds are very safe.
preparation: Seeds are eaten raw or roasted.
detailedExplanation: This unique pine is the only one in the world that typically has a single needle per bundle (fascicle). It is a hardy tree of the desert mountains, valued for its edible nuts.

medicinalUses: This plant is not known for medicinal use. It is an important component of wetland ecosystems.
sideEffects: Not applicable.
regionsFound: Found in tropical and subtropical regions worldwide.
preparation: Not used for medicine.
detailedExplanation: Nut Rush is a genus of grass-like plants in the sedge family. They are identified by their hard, white, bony seeds (nutlets). They are not used in herbal medicine.

medicinalUses: This is another name for Nut Grass. It is a key Ayurvedic herb for digestion, fever, and menstrual problems.
sideEffects: Very safe in recommended doses.
regionsFound: Found worldwide in tropical and temperate regions.
preparation: Powder, decoction, or essential oil from the tubers.
detailedExplanation: This is the same plant as Nut Grass (Cyperus rotundus). It is a highly invasive weed but also one of the most important herbs in Ayurvedic medicine, used for a wide range of ailments. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5432777/

medicinalUses: Promotes digestion and controls diarrhea
sideEffects: May cause bloating
preparation: Tuber dried and ground into paste
detailedExplanation: Widely used in Ayurveda for improving digestion and bowel movement. Source: https://www.sciencedirect.com

medicinalUses: The seed (betel nut) is chewed as a stimulant and digestive aid in many Asian cultures. It is highly addictive and carcinogenic.
sideEffects: HIGHLY ADDICTIVE and CARCINOGENIC. Causes oral cancer, heart problems, and staining of teeth.
regionsFound: Cultivated in tropical Asia, East Africa, and the Pacific.
preparation: The nut is sliced and wrapped in a betel leaf with slaked lime.
detailedExplanation: Betel nut chewing is a centuries-old tradition with deep cultural significance. However, it is a major public health concern due to its strong link to oral cancers and its powerfully addictive nature. https://www.who.int/india/health-topics/oral-health

medicinalUses: The oil from the seeds is a very strong purgative (laxative). The seeds are highly poisonous.
sideEffects: SEEDS ARE HIGHLY TOXIC. Can cause severe vomiting, diarrhea, and be fatal.
regionsFound: Native to tropical America; cultivated in tropics worldwide.
preparation: Not recommended. For historical/industrial use only.
detailedExplanation: This shrub is primarily grown as a biofuel crop because its seeds contain a high amount of oil. While the oil has been used as a drastic purgative, it is extremely dangerous and should not be used as a medicine.

medicinalUses: This is another name for the Physic Nut. The oil is a drastic purgative, but the seeds are highly poisonous.
sideEffects: SEEDS ARE HIGHLY TOXIC. Can be fatal.
regionsFound: Native to tropical America; cultivated in tropics worldwide.
preparation: Not recommended. Do not use.
detailedExplanation: This is the same plant as the Physic Nut (Jatropha curcas). Its name clearly indicates its violent purgative effect. All parts of the plant, especially the seeds, are dangerously toxic.

medicinalUses: Improves digestion, relieves pain, promotes sleep
sideEffects: Excess use can cause hallucinations or liver strain
preparation: Dried seeds ground into powder and added to food or milk
detailedExplanation: Nutmeg is a spice derived from Myristica fragrans, valued in Ayurveda for aiding digestion and relaxation. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov

medicinalUses: Used for mild digestive aid and aromatic purposes
sideEffects: Minimal side effects
preparation: Seeds dried and powdered
detailedExplanation: A tropical shrub related to true nutmeg, used locally for similar aromatic and digestive properties. Source: https://powo.science.kew.org

medicinalUses: Used in aromatherapy and for skin conditions
sideEffects: Rare skin irritation
preparation: Leaves crushed or distilled for oil
detailedExplanation: Nutmeg-scented geranium leaves produce essential oil with calming and skin-healing effects. Source: https://www.rhs.org.uk

medicinalUses: Bark used as mild tonic; nuts eaten for heart health
sideEffects: None known
preparation: Nuts roasted and consumed

detailedExplanation: Nuttall's Reedgrass is a tall, perennial bunchgrass found in moist forests and meadows. It is a valuable native species for stabilizing soil and providing forage.

sideEffects: Not applicable.
preparation: Not used for medicine.
detailedExplanation: Nuttall's Sunflower is a perennial species with multiple bright yellow flowers. Like other native sunflowers, it provides nectar for pollinators and its seeds are a valuable food source for birds.

sideEffects: None known

sideEffects: Possible constipation

medicinalUses: Used as a tonic and for diarrhea
sideEffects: Overuse may lead to nausea
preparation: Bark decoction or tincture
detailedExplanation: Canyon Live Oak bark was used by indigenous tribes for digestive disorders. Source

medicinalUses: Used for diarrhea, fevers, and as antiseptic
sideEffects: Constipation from tannins
preparation: Bark decoction
detailedExplanation: Chestnut Oak bark has been widely used for its astringent properties in traditional American herbalism. Source

medicinalUses: Bark extract used for antimicrobial and antioxidant purposes
sideEffects: Minimal; avoid oral ingestion of raw cork
preparation: Extract preparation or powder
detailedExplanation: Cork Oak bark (used in cork production) shows promising antioxidant and antimicrobial activity in studies. Source

medicinalUses: Used to treat diarrhea, wounds, and inflammation
sideEffects: May cause constipation in overdose
preparation: Bark decoction or tea
detailedExplanation: Durmast Oak bark is an established herbal astringent in European pharmacopeia for gastrointestinal and skin conditions. Source

medicinalUses: The acorns are a traditional food source. The bark is astringent and can be used for diarrhea and sore throat.
sideEffects: Very safe when used appropriately.
preparation: Acorns are leached and ground into flour. A tea is made from the inner bark.
detailedExplanation: Emory Oak is a drought-resistant tree of the desert mountains. Its sweet acorns were a staple food for Native Americans and require less processing than other species. The bark shares the astringent properties common to oaks.

medicinalUses: The bark is a powerful astringent used for diarrhea, skin inflammation, and as a gargle for sore throats and gum disease.
sideEffects: Very safe for topical and short-term internal use.
preparation: A decoction is made from the bark for gargling or drinking.
detailedExplanation: The English Oak is a majestic, long-lived tree of great historical and cultural importance in Europe. Its strong, astringent bark is one of the most reliable herbal remedies for tightening tissues and reducing secretions.

medicinalUses: The galls (abnormal growths) are one of the richest sources of tannins. Used as a strong astringent for skin conditions, hemorrhoids, and dental preparations.
sideEffects: Very astringent; can be drying.
preparation: Powdered galls are used in ointments or as a styptic powder.
detailedExplanation: Gall Oaks produce large, round galls in response to a wasp's eggs. These galls can contain up to 70% tannin, making them one of the most potent astringents in the plant kingdom.

medicinalUses: The acorns are a traditional food. The bark is astringent and used for diarrhea and wounds.
sideEffects: Very safe when used appropriately.
preparation: Acorns are leached and eaten. A tea is made from the bark.
detailedExplanation: Gambel Oak forms dense thickets and is a key species for wildlife in its region. Its acorns were a crucial food source for Native Americans, and its bark was used for tanning hides and medicine.

medicinalUses: The bark is astringent and was used by Native Americans for diarrhea and as a wash for sores. The acorns are a traditional food.
sideEffects: Very safe when used appropriately.
preparation: Acorns are leached and ground into flour. A tea is made from the bark.
detailedExplanation: The Garry Oak is the only native oak in British Columbia and a keystone species of its ecosystem. It provides critical habitat and its acorns are a valuable food for wildlife and people.

medicinalUses: The bark is astringent and can be used like other oaks. The acorns are edible after processing and were a staple food.
sideEffects: Very safe when used appropriately.
preparation: Acorns are leached and roasted. A decoction is made from the bark.
detailedExplanation: The Holm Oak is a resilient evergreen oak with spiny, holly-like leaves. It is a dominant tree in the Mediterranean landscape, valued for its tough wood and as a source of food (acorns) for the Iberian pig.

medicinalUses: This plant is not a true oak. It is an aromatic herb sometimes used in folk medicine for its expectorant properties to relieve coughs.
sideEffects: Generally safe in small amounts.
preparation: A tea is made from the leaves.
detailedExplanation: Jerusalem Oak is a misleading name. It is actually an annual herb in the goosefoot family, known for its strong, unpleasant odor. It is not related to true oaks and has very limited medicinal use.

medicinalUses: The bark is astringent and can be used for diarrhea and as a topical wash for skin irritations.
sideEffects: Very safe when used appropriately.
preparation: A decoction is made from the bark.
detailedExplanation: The Laurel Oak is a fast-growing, semi-evergreen tree common in the southeastern US. It thrives in wet, lowland areas and is often planted as a shade tree.

medicinalUses: This is the same tree as the English Oak. The bark is a powerful astringent for diarrhea, sore throats, and skin conditions.
sideEffects: Very safe for topical and short-term internal use.
preparation: A decoction is made from the bark for gargling or drinking.
detailedExplanation: Pedunculate Oak is the botanical name for the English Oak (Quercus robur). It refers to the long stalk (peduncle) that holds the acorns. It is one of the most iconic and medicinally valuable trees in European herbalism.

medicinalUses: The bark is astringent and can be used in a decoction for diarrhea and as a gargle. It is primarily an ornamental tree.
sideEffects: Very safe when used appropriately.
preparation: A decoction is made from the bark.
detailedExplanation: The Pin Oak is a popular landscaping tree known for its brilliant red fall color and its distinctive, drooping lower branches. It is commonly planted along streets and in parks.

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for external poultices; highly toxic internally
sideEffects: Toxic if ingested
preparation: Bark and leaves applied externally
detailedExplanation: Poison Oak contains urushiol, a compound that causes skin irritation; traditionally used externally only. Source

sideEffects: Constipation

sideEffects: Mild constipation

detailedExplanation: Turkey Oak bark contains tannins used for mild gastrointestinal and topical treatments. Source

sideEffects: Constipation possible

detailedExplanation: Valley Oak bark traditionally used by Native Americans for diarrhea and skin conditions. Source

medicinalUses: Used for diarrhea, fevers, and antiseptic purposes
sideEffects: Mild constipation

medicinalUses: Used in perfumery, minor antiseptic uses
sideEffects: Rare skin irritation
preparation: Extracted into oils or tinctures
detailedExplanation: Oakmoss lichen traditionally used in perfumes and as mild topical antiseptic; rarely causes skin reactions. Source

medicinalUses: Used for digestion, cholesterol control, and skin care
sideEffects: Rare bloating
preparation: Seeds boiled into porridge or powder
detailedExplanation: Oat grains are rich in beta-glucans and are used in traditional and modern medicine for digestive health, cholesterol management, and topical skin applications. Source

medicinalUses: The young plant (milky oat tops) is a renowned nervine tonic used to restore a fatigued nervous system, ease anxiety, and improve mental focus.
sideEffects: Very safe.
preparation: A tincture is made from the fresh, milky seed tops.
detailedExplanation: Wild Oat is the ancestor of cultivated oats. In herbal medicine, it is not the grain but the fresh, milky seed tops that are used. It is a premier remedy for nervous exhaustion, burnout, and anxiety, helping to rebuild resilience.

medicinalUses: This is the same plant as Oat Grass. The milky oat tops are used as a restorative nerve tonic for stress, anxiety, and nervous exhaustion.
sideEffects: Very safe.
preparation: A tincture is made from the fresh, milky seed tops.
detailedExplanation: This entry refers to the same species, Avena fatua. It is considered a weedy pest in agriculture but a treasure in herbalism. The tincture is specifically made from the unripe seeds when they exude a milky fluid when pressed.

medicinalUses: The branches were used by Native Americans to make a tea for treating diarrhea and as a general tonic. The wood is very hard.
sideEffects: Very safe.
preparation: A tea is made from the branches and leaves.
detailedExplanation: Ocean Spray is a beautiful deciduous shrub known for its cascading clusters of tiny, creamy-white flowers that resemble a frothy ocean wave. It is an important plant for wildlife and was a useful "one-stop shop" for indigenous peoples.

medicinalUses: This plant is a rare and protected wildflower. It is not used for medicine and should be appreciated for its beauty and conservation value.
sideEffects: Not applicable.
preparation: Not used for medicine.
detailedExplanation: Oconee Bells is a rare, low-growing evergreen perennial with beautiful, fringed white flowers. It was lost to science for nearly a century after its initial discovery and is now a prized and protected plant.

medicinalUses: The flowers are used to make a tea for coughs and shortness of breath. The roots are used to treat swollen limbs and fatigue.
sideEffects: Very safe.
preparation: A tea is made from the flowers or a poultice from the crushed roots.
detailedExplanation: Ocotillo is a unique and striking desert plant that looks like a bundle of dead sticks until it rains, when it quickly sprouts small leaves and brilliant red flowers. Its canes are used for fencing.

medicinalUses: This plant is primarily ornamental, grown for its highly fragrant white flowers. It is not known for significant medicinal use.
sideEffects: No common side effects.
preparation: Not used for medicine.
detailedExplanation: Odora, or Berlandier's Fiddlewood, is a large shrub or small tree prized in landscaping for the intense, sweet fragrance of its flower spikes, which attract butterflies and bees.

medicinalUses: The sour fruit is used to make preserves, sauces, and a refreshing drink. It is not known for specific medicinal properties.
sideEffects: The fruit is safe to eat.
preparation: The fruit is cooked into jams or used to make a tart drink.
detailedExplanation: This tree is not a true lime but a relative of the Black Gum tree. It produces a very acidic, red-orange fruit that is too sour to eat raw but makes excellent, flavorful preserves.

medicinalUses: The seeds, bark, and leaves are highly poisonous and should not be used for medicine.
sideEffects: HIGHLY POISONOUS. Causes severe vomiting, paralysis, and can be fatal.
preparation: Not recommended. Do not use.
detailedExplanation: The Ohio Buckeye is the state tree of Ohio. While its large, shiny seeds are considered good luck charms, they are extremely toxic. All parts of the tree contain a glycoside that affects the nervous system.

medicinalUses: The inner bark is a gentle and effective laxative. The nut produces an edible oil.
sideEffects: Very safe for short-term use as a laxative.
preparation: A tea or tincture is made from the inner bark.
detailedExplanation: The Butternut tree, also called White Walnut, produces oily, edible nuts. Its inner bark is a well-regarded herbal laxative that is less harsh than many other remedies.

medicinalUses: This is the same tree as the Butternut or Oil Nut. The inner bark is a gentle laxative, and the nuts are a source of food and oil.
sideEffects: Very safe for short-term use as a laxative.
preparation: A tea or tincture is made from the inner bark.
detailedExplanation: This entry refers to the same species, Juglans cinerea (Butternut). It is a deciduous tree valued for its nuts, wood, and medicinal bark. The tree is currently threatened by a canker disease.

medicinalUses: Palm oil used for skin health, cooking, and vitamin E source
sideEffects: Excess may raise cholesterol
preparation: Oil extraction from fruit
detailedExplanation: Oil Palm produces palm oil rich in vitamin E and carotenoids, used traditionally for skin and as dietary fat. Source

sideEffects: Mild stomach upset

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for diuretic and skin issues
sideEffects: Rare allergic reaction

detailedExplanation: Old Plainsman was used in folk medicine as a mild diuretic and for minor skin issues. Source

medicinalUses: Used for digestive health, antioxidant, and cooling effects
sideEffects: Rare gastrointestinal upset
preparation: Fruit or rind used in cooking and herbal tea
detailedExplanation: Old Sour (Garcinia indica) is used in traditional Indian medicine to improve digestion and as an antioxidant source. Source

medicinalUses: This plant is not used for medicine. It is a salt-tolerant shrub important for coastal ecosystems.
sideEffects: Not applicable.
preparation: Not used for medicine.
detailedExplanation: Old Woman's Broom, or Groundsel Bush, is a deciduous shrub common in coastal marshes and wetlands. It is dioecious, with male and female flowers on separate plants, and the female plants produce fluffy white seed heads.

medicinalUses: This plant is extremely poisonous. Despite historical use for heart conditions, it is far too dangerous for self-administration.
sideEffects: HIGHLY POISONOUS. Ingestion of a single leaf can be fatal to humans and animals.
regionsFound: Mediterranean region; cultivated worldwide in warm climates.
preparation: Not recommended. For prescription use only.
detailedExplanation: Oleander is a popular ornamental shrub prized for its beautiful and fragrant flowers. However, all parts of the plant contain potent cardiac glycosides that disrupt heart function. It is one of the most toxic commonly grown garden plants.

medicinalUses: This plant is extremely poisonous, just like its relative the common oleander.
sideEffects: HIGHLY POISONOUS. All parts are toxic if ingested.
regionsFound: Tropical Americas; cultivated in tropics and subtropics.
preparation: Not recommended. Do not use.
detailedExplanation: Also known as Lucky Nut or Yellow Oleander, this plant is highly toxic. It produces yellow, trumpet-shaped flowers and triangular fruits. Its seeds are particularly dangerous.

medicinalUses: The flowers are used to make a tonic for heart conditions, and the fruit is a nutritious, vitamin-rich food.
sideEffects: The fruit is safe to eat.
preparation: The fruit is eaten raw or dried. A tea is made from the flowers.
detailedExplanation: This small tree is known for its silvery leaves and fragrant, yellow flowers. Its sweet-but-mealy fruit is edible and a good source of vitamins and fatty acids. The tree is nitrogen-fixing but can be invasive.

medicinalUses: The resin is a potent anti-inflammatory, used for arthritis, asthma, and inflammatory bowel diseases. It is also used in aromatherapy for meditation.
sideEffects: Very safe. May cause mild stomach upset in high doses.
preparation: Resin is burned as incense, steam-distilled for essential oil, or taken orally as an extract.
detailedExplanation: Frankincense has been traded for over 5,000 years. Its aromatic resin is harvested by making cuts in the bark. It is famous for its use in religious ceremonies and its powerful medicinal properties for reducing inflammation.

medicinalUses: The leaves help lower blood pressure and blood sugar. The oil is heart-healthy and a source of antioxidants.
sideEffects: Very safe.
regionsFound: Mediterranean region; cultivated worldwide in similar climates.
preparation: Leaves are used in tea or extracts. Oil is used in cooking and topically.
detailedExplanation: The Olive tree is one of the most important plants in human history, providing food, oil, and medicine for millennia. Its leaves contain compounds that are beneficial for cardiovascular and metabolic health.

medicinalUses: Used for digestive problems, sore throats, and to reduce sweating. Has antimicrobial properties.
sideEffects: Very safe.
preparation: A tea is made from the dried leaves.
detailedExplanation: This sage species is one of the sources of the commercial spice. It is a highly aromatic shrub with soft, grey-green leaves. It is often used interchangeably with Common Sage (Salvia officinalis) for culinary and medicinal purposes.

medicinalUses: This is the same tree as the Oleaster. The fruit is edible and nutritious, and the flowers are used as a heart tonic.
sideEffects: The fruit is safe to eat.
preparation: The fruit is eaten raw or dried. A tea is made from the flowers.
detailedExplanation: This is another common name for Elaeagnus angustifolia. It is a hardy, drought-tolerant tree often used in windbreaks and erosion control, but it is invasive in many parts of North America.

medicinalUses: The intensely fragrant flowers are used to scent tea and perfumes. It is not known for significant internal medicinal use.
sideEffects: The flowers are safe for culinary use.
preparation: The flowers are dried and used to flavor tea, wine, and confections.
detailedExplanation: This evergreen shrub is famous for the powerful, apricot-like fragrance of its tiny flowers. It is a beloved ornamental plant in gardens, and its flowers are a prized flavoring agent in Asian cuisine.

medicinalUses: Similar to cultivated olive; the leaves and oil have antioxidant and anti-inflammatory properties. The fruit is smaller and more bitter.
sideEffects: Very safe.
preparation: Leaves are used in tea. Oil is extracted from the fruit.
detailedExplanation: This subspecies is the wild ancestor of the cultivated olive. It is a hardy, drought-resistant tree. While its fruit produces a quality oil, it is smaller and yields less oil than cultivated varieties.

medicinalUses: Used for hypertension, antioxidant support, and digestion
sideEffects: Rare allergic reactions
preparation: Wood extract or leaves brewed into tea
detailedExplanation: Olivewood leaves and extracts are traditionally used for blood pressure control, antioxidant effects, and digestive support. Source

medicinalUses: Anti-inflammatory, respiratory aid, stress relief
sideEffects: Rare allergic reactions
preparation: Resin burned or infused in oils
detailedExplanation: Omani Frankincense resin is used traditionally for anti-inflammatory, respiratory, and stress-relief purposes. Source

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for skin issues, inflammation
sideEffects: May be toxic if unripe berries consumed
preparation: Ripe berries cooked or leaves boiled
detailedExplanation: One-berry plant (Solanum nigrum) has been used in traditional medicine for skin and anti-inflammatory purposes. Source

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for urinary tract and kidney support
sideEffects: Rare digestive upset
preparation: Leaves brewed into tea
detailedExplanation: One-flowered Wintergreen leaves are used traditionally for kidney and urinary health. Source

medicinalUses: Digestive aid, mild antimicrobial, antioxidant
sideEffects: May cause mild stomach upset
preparation: Bulbs or leaves cooked or eaten raw
detailedExplanation: One-leaf Onion is used traditionally for digestion, antimicrobial support, and as a dietary antioxidant. Source

medicinalUses: Urinary and kidney support, anti-inflammatory
sideEffects: Rare nausea
preparation: Leaves brewed as tea
detailedExplanation: One-sided Pyrola leaves traditionally used for urinary tract support and mild inflammation. Source

medicinalUses: Urinary tract support, anti-inflammatory
sideEffects: Rare skin irritation
preparation: Berries brewed into tea or tincture
detailedExplanation: Oneseed Juniper berries traditionally used for urinary health and mild inflammation. Source

medicinalUses: Antimicrobial, cardiovascular support, antioxidant
sideEffects: May cause gas or mild stomach upset
preparation: Raw, cooked, or juice
detailedExplanation: Onion is widely used for cardiovascular support, antimicrobial effects, and antioxidant activity. Source

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for digestive health, mild antimicrobial
sideEffects: Rare nausea
preparation: Leaves and bulbs cooked or brewed into tea
detailedExplanation: Onion Grass is used traditionally for digestion and mild antimicrobial purposes. Source

medicinalUses: Digestive aid, antimicrobial, antioxidant
sideEffects: Mild gastrointestinal upset
preparation: Bulbs cooked or used raw
detailedExplanation: Egyptian Onion traditionally used for digestive support, antimicrobial, and antioxidant purposes. Source

medicinalUses: The bulbs are edible and share the general health benefits of onions, including antimicrobial and cardiovascular support.
sideEffects: Safe when consumed as food.
regionsFound: Cultivated variety, originally from the Sonoran Desert region.
preparation: Bulbs and greens are used in cooking like shallots or spring onions.
detailedExplanation: The I'itoi onion is a rare, perennial heirloom variety that forms clusters of small, pungent bulbs. It is well-adapted to hot, dry climates and is named after the O'odham creator god.

medicinalUses: The bulbs are edible and have antimicrobial properties like cultivated onions and garlic.
sideEffects: Safe when consumed as food.
preparation: Bulbs and leaves can be eaten raw or cooked.
detailedExplanation: This native perennial wildflower is characterized by its graceful, nodding clusters of pink flowers. All parts of the plant have a mild onion flavor and can be used as a culinary herb. It is an important plant for native pollinators.

medicinalUses: The bulbs are edible and share the general health benefits of the onion family.
sideEffects: Safe when consumed as food.
preparation: Bulbs are eaten raw or cooked.
detailedExplanation: The Sierra Onion is a beautiful wild onion native to mountainous regions of the western United States. It produces attractive rose-pink to purple flowers in compact clusters.

medicinalUses: The bulbs and leaves are edible and have mild antimicrobial properties.
sideEffects: Safe when consumed as food.
preparation: Bulbs and greens are used in salads or cooked dishes.
detailedExplanation: Tree Onion or "Walking Onion" is a common name for perennial onions that produce bulblets at the top of the stalk instead of, or in addition to, flowers. These topsets can be planted or eaten.

medicinalUses: The leaves and small bulbs are edible and rich in Vitamin C and antioxidants. Used like spring onions for general health.
sideEffects: Safe when consumed as food.
preparation: The entire plant is used raw in salads or cooked in soups and stir-fries.
detailedExplanation: Despite its name, the Welsh Onion is not from Wales but is likely native to China. It is a perennial that does not form a large bulb and is primarily grown for its flavorful green stalks.

medicinalUses: The leaves and bulbs are edible and have antimicrobial properties. Can be used like chives or garlic.
sideEffects: Safe when consumed as food. Can be a weed in pastures.
preparation: Leaves and bulbs are used as a garlic-flavored seasoning.
detailedExplanation: This wild onion is considered an invasive weed in many areas, especially in grain fields. It produces a mix of flowers and aerial bulblets. It has a strong, garlic-like flavor.

medicinalUses: The leaves and bulbs are edible with a mild garlic flavor. Has general allium antimicrobial properties.
sideEffects: Safe when consumed as food. Highly invasive.
preparation: Leaves are used like chives in salads and cooking.
detailedExplanation: Onionweed is a highly invasive perennial that forms dense carpets in woodlands, crowding out native plants. It is identified by its triangular stem and few white flowers.

medicinalUses: The milky sap (latex) has mild sedative and pain-relieving properties. Traditionally used as a substitute for opium.
sideEffects: Can cause drowsiness. Skin contact with sap may cause dermatitis.
preparation: The dried latex is smoked or made into a tincture.
detailedExplanation: This common roadside weed is the wild ancestor of cultivated lettuce. Its sap contains compounds called lactucin and lactucopicrin, which have demonstrated sedative effects in animal studies, though they are much weaker than actual opium.

medicinalUses: The source of powerful narcotic painkillers like morphine and codeine. Illegal to grow or use without a government license in most countries.
sideEffects: HIGHLY ADDICTIVE. Causes respiratory depression, constipation, and can be fatal in overdose.
preparation: For strictly controlled pharmaceutical production only.
detailedExplanation: The Opium Poppy is the source of most of the world's narcotic pain relief. While its seeds are legal and used in baking, the latex from the seed pod is processed into illegal drugs like heroin and legal medicines. The plant itself is illegal to cultivate in most places.

medicinalUses: A powerful sedative and anxiolytic used to treat insomnia, anxiety, and nervous restlessness. Does not contain opium.
sideEffects: Can cause drowsiness. Should not be used before driving.
preparation: A tea or tincture is made from the roots.
detailedExplanation: Despite its name, Valerian contains no opiates. It is one of the most effective herbal sedatives, acting as a gentle tranquilizer for the nervous system. Its strong, distinctive odor is often compared to old socks.

medicinalUses: The gum resin has been used for its antispasmodic properties, particularly for relieving menstrual cramps and digestive spasms.
sideEffects: Generally safe in small, diluted amounts. Can cause skin sensitivity.
preparation: The resin is used in incense, perfumery, and traditional medicine as a tincture.
detailedExplanation: Opopanax produces a fragrant gum resin that has been used since ancient times. It has a sweet, balsamic odor and is used in perfumes and as a traditional remedy for spasms. Its name means "all-healing juice" in Greek.

medicinalUses: Nutritive leafy green: rich in minerals and vitamins; used as diuretic and digestive support.
sideEffects: Contains oxalates—avoid in kidney stone patients and in excessive amounts.
preparation: Young leaves cooked like spinach; raw in salads in small amounts.
detailedExplanation: Orach is a cultivated leafy vegetable used as a nutritious green in temperate Indian gardens and included in folk tonics for its mineral content. Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atriplex_hortensis

medicinalUses: The fruit is rich in Vitamin C for immunity. The peel aids digestion and is used in bitter tonics. The flowers are calming.
sideEffects: The fruit is very safe.
regionsFound: Cultivated in tropical and subtropical regions worldwide.
preparation: Eat the fruit. Make tea from the peel (bitter orange) or flowers (orange blossom).
detailedExplanation: The sweet orange is one of the most popular fruits globally. Beyond its nutritional value, the bitter orange peel (Citrus aurantium) is used to stimulate digestion, and the flowers are used to make a calming tea and neroli essential oil.

medicinalUses: This plant is not known for significant medicinal use. It is a native wildflower important for pollinators.
sideEffects: No common side effects.
preparation: Not used for medicine.
detailedExplanation: Orange Agoseris, also called Mountain Dandelion, is a perennial herb with bright orange, dandelion-like flowers. It is a beautiful component of mountain meadows and is not used in herbal medicine.

medicinalUses: This shrub is grown for its unique, spherical orange flower clusters. It is not known for medicinal use.
sideEffects: No common side effects.
preparation: Not used for medicine.
detailedExplanation: The Orange Ball Tree is an ornamental shrub prized for its striking, honey-scented, orange ball-shaped flowers that attract butterflies and other pollinators. It is not related to the more medicinal Butterfly Bush (Buddleja davidii).

medicinalUses: The flowers are used to make a calming tea (orange blossom tea) that helps reduce anxiety and promote sleep. The essential oil (neroli) is used in aromatherapy.
sideEffects: Very safe.
regionsFound: On orange trees in tropical/subtropical regions.
preparation: Flowers are dried for tea. The essential oil is used in diffusers or diluted for skin.
detailedExplanation: Orange blossoms are highly fragrant and symbolize purity and good fortune in many cultures. The tea is a gentle nervine, and neroli oil is one of the most prized and expensive essential oils in perfumery and aromatherapy for its calming effect.

medicinalUses: This plant is primarily ornamental. It is not known for significant medicinal use like its relative Echinacea.
sideEffects: No common side effects.
preparation: Not used for medicine.
detailedExplanation: The Orange Coneflower (e.g., Black-eyed Susan) is a popular, hardy perennial that brightens gardens with its golden-orange petals and dark brown centers. It is a different genus from the medicinal Purple Coneflower (Echinacea purpurea).

medicinalUses: The flower buds and young shoots are edible and nutritious. The tubers have been used in Traditional Chinese Medicine for diuretic purposes.
sideEffects: The plant can be toxic to cats. The tubers may have a laxative effect.
preparation: Flower buds are cooked and eaten (e.g., in stir-fries).
detailedExplanation: The Orange Daylily is a common and vigorous perennial. While its buds are a popular edible ("golden needles"), all parts of the plant are highly toxic to cats, causing kidney failure. It should not be confused with true lilies (Lilium spp.), which are toxic to both cats and humans.

medicinalUses: This plant is grown for its vibrant, papery flowers that retain their color when dried. It has no significant medicinal use.
sideEffects: No common side effects.
preparation: Not used for medicine.
detailedExplanation: The Strawflower is famous for its everlasting quality. Its brightly colored "petals" are actually papery bracts, making it a top choice for dried flower arrangements. It is purely an ornamental plant.

medicinalUses: This specific cultivar is primarily ornamental. The species has been used in traditional Chinese medicine for wound healing.
sideEffects: No common side effects from handling.
preparation: Not commonly used in modern herbal practice.
detailedExplanation: This is a cultivar of the common Butterfly Bush, named for the orange center of its flowers. It is a magnet for butterflies and pollinators but can be invasive in some regions. Its medicinal use is historical, not current.

detailedExplanation: The Orange-blossom Orchid is a stunning epiphytic orchid known for its racemes of small, white to cream-colored flowers that emit a sweet, citrus-like fragrance, reminiscent of orange blossoms. It typically grows on the branches and trunks of trees in humid rainforest environments. This plant is highly prized by orchid enthusiasts for its beautiful and fragrant floral display. It requires specific, cool-growing conditions to thrive in cultivation. Source: https://plantnet.rbgsyd.nsw.gov.au/cgi-bin/NSWfl.pl?page=nswfl&lvl=sp&name=Sarcochilus~falcatus

medicinalUses: Not used for human medicine. It is a primary forage crop for animal health and nutrition.
sideEffects: Can cause pollen allergies (hay fever) in sensitive individuals. In livestock, poor-quality hay can lead to impaction.
regionsFound: Native to Europe, North Africa, and parts of Asia; naturalized worldwide in temperate regions.
preparation: Not for human consumption. Cultivated, cut, and dried as hay for livestock feed or used for direct grazing.
detailedExplanation: Orchard Grass is a hardy, cool-season perennial bunchgrass that is one of the most important and palatable forage grasses for livestock, particularly horses, cattle, and sheep. It is known for its high yield and nutritional value when harvested at the right stage. It forms dense tufts and thrives in well-drained soils. While vital for agriculture, it is a common allergen whose pollen contributes significantly to seasonal hay fever symptoms in humans. Source: https://www.feedipedia.org/node/480

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for digestive support, mild diuretic, and immune boosting. The fruit is rich in vitamins and antioxidants.
sideEffects: May cause mild gastrointestinal upset if consumed in excess
preparation: Fruits can be eaten raw, cooked, or brewed into teas

sideEffects: May cause mild nausea, diarrhea, or skin irritation
preparation: Root and bark decoction, leaf poultice
detailedExplanation: Oregon Grape has long been used in traditional medicine for liver detoxification, supporting digestion, and treating skin conditions. The root and bark contain berberine, which exhibits antimicrobial and anti-inflammatory properties. Source

medicinalUses: No well-documented medicinal uses. It is a source of thebaine, a precursor for some pharmaceuticals, but is not used directly in herbal medicine.
sideEffects: All parts of the plant are poisonous if ingested, potentially causing sedation, nausea, or respiratory distress. Skin contact with sap may cause irritation in some individuals.
regionsFound: Native to the Middle East (Turkey, Iran, Caucasus) and widely cultivated as an ornamental.
preparation: Not for consumption. Grown strictly as a decorative garden plant.
detailedExplanation: The Oriental Poppy is a stunning perennial known for its large, vibrant, papery flowers in shades of orange, red, and pink with dark centers. Unlike the Opium Poppy (Papaver somniferum), it does not produce significant amounts of morphine or codeine but instead contains thebaine, a compound used to synthesize semi-synthetic opioids like oxycodone. It is a popular ornamental plant in temperate gardens due to its striking appearance and hardiness, but it should be handled with care and kept away from children and pets due to its toxicity. Source: https://www.rhs.org.uk/plants/41612/papaver-orientale/details

medicinalUses: Aids digestion and may help relieve indigestion and bloating. Contains enzymes that support liver function and detoxification. Rich in Vitamin C and antioxidants.
sideEffects: Can cause gas and bloating in some individuals due to its raffinose content. The strong flavor may be off-putting to some.
regionsFound: Native to Southeast Asia; cultivated worldwide in temperate and subtropical regions.
preparation: Eaten raw in salads, pickled, cooked in soups and stir-fries, or grated as a condiment.
detailedExplanation: The Oriental Radish, commonly known as Daikon or Mooli, is a mild-flavored, winter radish characterized by its long, white taproot. It is a staple in East Asian cuisines, valued for its crisp texture and ability to absorb flavors. Unlike smaller red radishes, Daikon is often used in cooked dishes, where it becomes soft and mild. It is low in calories but high in water content and fiber, making it excellent for hydration and digestive health. The plant is also used as a cover crop to break up compacted soil. Source: https://www.britannica.com/plant/daikon

medicinalUses: The resin (Styrax or Levant Storax) has been used in traditional medicine as an antiseptic for skin infections, a topical treatment for wounds, and as an expectorant for coughs and bronchitis.
sideEffects: Skin contact with the resin can cause allergic dermatitis in sensitive individuals. Internal use is not common and should be supervised due to potential toxicity.
regionsFound: Native to the eastern Mediterranean region, specifically southwest Turkey and the Greek island of Rhodes.
preparation: The resin is collected from the bark and used in ointments, balms, and inhalants. It is also a component in perfumes and incense.
detailedExplanation: The Oriental Sweetgum is a slow-growing tree famous for producing a fragrant balsamic resin known as Storax. This resin has been a valuable trade commodity since antiquity, used in traditional medicine, perfumery, and incense. The tree itself is visually striking with its star-shaped leaves and spiny, round seed pods. It is a relict species, meaning it is a surviving remnant of a much larger prehistoric range, and is now found in a very limited habitat, making it vulnerable to extinction. Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Liquidambar_orientalis

medicinalUses: Liver-supportive herb in East Asian medicine; used as bitter tonic, choleretic and mild antipyretic.
sideEffects: Bitter taste may cause GI upset; avoid in pregnancy.
preparation: Aerial-part decoction or infusion (bitter tonic preparations).
detailedExplanation: Artemisia capillaris is a classic East Asian herbal for liver-biliary support and digestive stimulation; contains multiple flavonoids and sesquiterpene lactones—use with typical caution for bitter herb dosing. Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artemisia_capillaris.

medicinalUses: No significant documented medicinal benefits. It is primarily valued for its ecological and ornamental uses.
sideEffects: No known side effects, as it is not used for consumption or medicine.
regionsFound: Native to the Mediterranean region of Europe and North Africa.
preparation: Not used for consumption. The seeds are sown to grow the plant for ornamental or wildlife garden purposes.
detailedExplanation: Orlaya, also known as White Laceflower, is an elegant annual plant prized in horticulture for its exquisite, delicate-looking white flower umbels that resemble fine lace. It is a favorite in cottage gardens and cutting gardens, where it adds an airy, textural element to floral arrangements. The plant is also highly attractive to beneficial insects like hoverflies and parasitic wasps, which help control pest populations, making it an excellent companion plant in organic farming and gardening systems. It thrives in well-drained soil and full sun. Source: https://www.wildflower.org/plants/result.php?id_plant=orla

medicinalUses: No safe medicinal benefits; the plant is highly toxic. Some homeopathic preparations use it in extreme dilutions, but this is not supported by modern science.
sideEffects: All parts of the plant are poisonous if ingested, containing cardiac glycosides that can cause nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, irregular heartbeat, and even death.
regionsFound: Native to Europe, Asia, and Africa; many species are widely naturalized elsewhere.
preparation: NOT FOR CONSUMPTION. It is sometimes grown as an ornamental plant, but this is discouraged due to its toxicity and invasive nature in some regions.
detailedExplanation: Ornithogalum, commonly known as Star of Bethlehem for its star-shaped white flowers, is a deceptively beautiful but dangerously toxic plant. It contains potent cardenolides, similar to those in Digitalis (foxglove), which interfere with the heart's electrical activity. The plant can be mistaken for wild onions due to its bulb, but it lacks the characteristic onion smell. Due to its toxicity and ability to spread aggressively, it is considered a noxious weed in many areas and should be handled with extreme caution, especially around children and pets. Source: https://www.poison.org/articles/star-of-bethlehem-203

medicinalUses: Used in some traditional medicine systems (e.g., TCM) for treating wounds, ulcers, and as a tonic. However, its efficacy is not well-established.
sideEffects: Due to its parasitic nature, it may accumulate alkaloids from its host plant, making its safety profile unpredictable and potentially toxic.
regionsFound: Found in temperate regions across the Northern Hemisphere, including parts of Europe, Asia, and North America.
preparation: Used in traditional decoctions or dried and powdered for topical application. However, use is not recommended without expert guidance.
detailedExplanation: Orobanche, commonly known as Broomrape, is a fascinating but problematic genus of holoparasitic plants that lack chlorophyll and derive all their nutrients by attaching to the roots of host plants, often damaging crops like tomatoes, legumes, and sunflowers. They appear as odd, fleshy, often brownish or yellowish spikes emerging from the ground without any green foliage. While some species have a history in folk medicine, their use is risky because the chemical composition varies drastically depending on the host plant it has parasitized, which could lead to unintended poisoning. Source: https://www.cabi.org/isc/datasheet/38010

medicinalUses: The leaves have a long history of folk use as a topical poultice for treating wounds, burns, and skin inflammations due to their cooling and astringent properties.
sideEffects: Generally considered safe for topical use. Ingestion of large quantities may cause stomach upset. The fresh plant may cause dermatitis in sensitive individuals.
regionsFound: Native to Europe and Asia; naturalized in North America.
preparation: Fresh leaves are crushed and applied directly as a poultice to the affected skin. The leaves can also be eaten raw in small quantities in salads.
detailedExplanation: Orpine, also called Live-forever, is a hardy succulent plant with fleshy, water-storing leaves and clusters of star-shaped, pink to reddish flowers. Its common name reflects its remarkable drought tolerance and ability to regenerate from broken pieces. In folk medicine, its juicy, mucilaginous leaves were traditionally used as a first-aid remedy, much like Aloe Vera, to soothe burns, wounds, and insect bites. It is a popular plant in rock gardens and dry, sunny borders due to its low maintenance and attractive appearance. Source: https://www.fs.usda.gov/wildflowers/plant-of-the-week/hylotelephium_telephium.shtml

medicinalUses: Used in traditional medicine as an expectorant to relieve coughs and bronchitis, and as a diuretic. It also has a history of use for soothing digestive issues.
sideEffects: The fresh rhizome is a strong irritant and can cause severe nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. Only the properly dried and aged root is used.
regionsFound: Native to the Mediterranean region; cultivated mainly in Italy, Morocco, and India.
preparation: The rhizome is dried and aged for several years, which develops its violet-like scent. It is then powdered for use in potpourris, perfumery, and very sparingly as a flavoring agent.
detailedExplanation: Orris Root is the fragrant rhizome of specific species of Iris, primarily Iris germanica and Iris pallida. It is not used fresh due to its irritant properties but must be dried and aged for 3-5 years, during which time it develops a delicate, sweet aroma reminiscent of violets. This makes it a highly valued fixative in the perfume industry, used to stabilize and enhance the scent of other ingredients. It is also a key flavoring in some gins and was historically used in tooth powders and sachets. Source: https://www.britannica.com/plant/orris-root

medicinalUses: No significant medicinal benefits for humans. The wood is extremely durable and was used for making bows by Native Americans. The fruit is believed by some to repel insects, but this is unproven.
sideEffects: The milky sap from the tree and fruit can cause skin irritation and dermatitis. The fruit is not poisonous but is inedible and can cause a choking hazard.
regionsFound: Native to the south-central United States; widely planted elsewhere as a hedge row.
preparation: Not for consumption. The wood is used for fence posts and crafts. The fruits are sometimes placed in basements or closets in an attempt to repel spiders and insects.
detailedExplanation: The Osage Orange tree is known for its large, bumpy, greenish-yellow fruit, which is roughly the size of a grapefruit. While the fruit is not edible for humans due to its bitter taste and sticky latex, it is consumed by squirrels. The tree was historically planted densely to create "living fences" or hedge rows before the invention of barbed wire, thanks to its thorns and dense growth. Its bright orange, rot-resistant wood is among the most durable in North America. The insect-repelling claims are largely folkloric, with little scientific backing. Source: https://www.arborday.org/trees/treeguide/TreeDetail.cfm?ItemID=1092

medicinalUses: Traditionally used to treat respiratory infections, sore throats, coughs, and bronchitis. Also used for digestive complaints and as an antiviral and immune stimulant.
sideEffects: Can cause skin photosensitivity (increased sensitivity to sunlight). High doses may lead to stomach upset or kidney irritation. Not recommended for use during pregnancy.
regionsFound: Native to the Rocky Mountains and other mountainous regions of the southwestern United States and Mexico.
preparation: The root is dried and used to make teas, tinctures, or chewed raw. It is also used in steam inhalations for respiratory relief.
detailedExplanation: Osha is a highly important and revered medicinal plant in Native American and Hispanic traditions of the American Southwest. It has a strong, celery-like scent and is considered a powerful remedy for respiratory ailments, often used at the first sign of a cold or flu. The plant grows at high altitudes and is often found in the same habitats as poisonous plants like Hemlock, making proper identification absolutely critical. Overharvesting of its wild populations has made it a plant of conservation concern. Source: https://www.fs.usda.gov/wildflowers/plant-of-the-week/ligusticum_porteri.shtml

sideEffects: Rare gastrointestinal upset
preparation: Bark or stems boiled into decoction
detailedExplanation: Red Osier bark and stems have traditionally been used to reduce inflammation, promote wound healing, and support urinary health. Rich in flavonoids and tannins, it provides antioxidant and astringent effects. Source

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for digestive support, mild sedative, and antimicrobial

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for anti-inflammatory and wound healing
sideEffects: Rare skin irritation
preparation: Flesh or juice applied topically
detailedExplanation: Ottertail Cactus flesh has been traditionally used topically to reduce inflammation and support wound healing. Contains polysaccharides and mucilage that soothe skin. Source

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for liver support, digestive aid, and mild anti-inflammatory
sideEffects: Rare mild gastrointestinal upset
preparation: Leaves or roots decoction
detailedExplanation: Our Lady's Thistle leaves and roots traditionally used for liver tonic, digestive support, and reducing inflammation. Rich in flavonoids and silymarin-like compounds. Source

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for anti-inflammatory, joint support, and mild skin issues
sideEffects: Rare nausea or skin irritation
preparation: Roots or leaves decoction
detailedExplanation: Our Lord’s Candle roots and leaves traditionally used for joint pain, inflammation, and skin conditions. Saponins provide anti-inflammatory and analgesic properties. Source

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for urinary tract health, antioxidant support, and digestive aid
sideEffects: Rare gastrointestinal upset
preparation: Berries eaten fresh or brewed as tea
detailedExplanation: Oval-leaf Blueberry berries traditionally consumed for urinary tract support, antioxidant benefits, and digestive aid. Rich in anthocyanins and polyphenols. Source

medicinalUses: Traditionally used as mild laxative, digestive aid, and liver support
sideEffects: May cause mild diarrhea or cramping if overused
preparation: Bark decoction or dried berries
detailedExplanation: Oval-leaved Buckthorn bark and berries traditionally used as mild laxative and digestive aid. Anthraquinones in the bark stimulate bowel movements and support liver detoxification. Source

medicinalUses: Used similarly to other violets for its demulcent and anti-inflammatory properties, primarily to soothe sore throats, coughs, and minor skin irritations.
sideEffects: Generally considered safe. Excessive consumption may have a mild laxative effect due to mucilage.
regionsFound: Native to eastern North America, found in moist woodlands and meadows.
preparation: Flowers and leaves can be used fresh or dried to make a soothing tea, syrup, or poultice. The flowers are also edible as a garnish.
detailedExplanation: The Ovate-leaved Violet is a specific species of violet distinguished by its egg-shaped (ovate) leaves. Like its relatives, it produces charming purple flowers in the spring. All parts of the plant contain mucilage, a gelatinous substance that coats and soothes mucous membranes, making it a gentle remedy for dry, irritated throats and persistent coughs. It has a long history in folk medicine and is also a valuable early-season nectar source for pollinators. Its gentle action makes it suitable for children and the elderly. Source: https://www.wildflower.org/plants/result.php?id_plant=VIOV

medicinalUses: No well-documented medicinal uses for humans. It is a hemiparasitic plant, drawing nutrients from the roots of grasses, and is ecologically important.
sideEffects: Not applicable as it is not used for consumption or medicine.
regionsFound: Native to western North America, particularly in grasslands, meadows, and prairies.
preparation: Not used for consumption. It is enjoyed for its ornamental value in native wildflower settings.
detailedExplanation: Owl's Clover is a genus of striking annual wildflowers known for their brightly colored, tufted flower heads that can be pink, purple, yellow, or white. The name comes from the flower's resemblance to an owl's face. It is a hemiparasite, meaning it photosynthesizes but also connects its roots to those of nearby grasses to steal water and nutrients. This relationship can help control aggressive grass species and increase the diversity of native wildflower meadows. It is a key component of the spring "super bloom" in places like California. Source: https://www.calflora.org/entry/oc.html

medicinalUses: Not commonly used in medicine. Historically, it was used as a weak substitute for true Chamomile for digestive issues, but its primary use was as a dye plant.
sideEffects: May cause allergic reactions in individuals sensitive to plants in the Asteraceae family (ragweed, chrysanthemums).
regionsFound: Native to Europe, Western Asia, and the Mediterranean; introduced in other temperate regions.
preparation: The flowers are used to create a vibrant yellow-to-olive-green dye for wool and fabrics. Not recommended for medicinal tea.
detailedExplanation: Ox-eye Chamomile, also known as Dyer's Chamomile, is a robust plant valued not for medicine but for the beautiful, lasting dye that can be extracted from its flowers. It produces bright yellow, daisy-like flowers and has a much stronger, less pleasant scent than true Chamomile (Matricaria chamomilla). While it belongs to the same family, its chemical profile is different and not well-suited for the gentle sedative and anti-spasmodic uses of its more famous relative. It is a hardy plant that thrives in poor, dry soils. Source: https://pfaf.org/user/Plant.aspx?LatinName=Anthemis+tinctoria

medicinalUses: Traditionally used in folk medicine as a mild astringent, digestive tonic, and cough suppressant. Also used topically for wounds and bruises.
sideEffects: Can cause contact dermatitis in sensitive individuals. It is mildly toxic if ingested in large quantities, potentially causing digestive upset.
regionsFound: Native to Europe and temperate regions of Asia; naturalized in North America and other parts of the world.
preparation: The young leaves are sometimes eaten in small quantities in salads. The flowers and leaves are more commonly used to make a mild tea.
detailedExplanation: The Ox-eye Daisy is a classic meadow wildflower with a cheerful appearance, featuring a bright yellow central disc surrounded by white ray florets. Despite its charming look, it is an aggressive colonizer and is considered an invasive weed in many areas outside its native range, outcompeting native flora. Its traditional medicinal uses are gentle and similar to its relative, Chamomile, though it is less potent. It symbolizes innocence and simplicity in the language of flowers but is a formidable plant in ecology. Source: https://www.cabi.org/isc/datasheet/115005

medicinalUses: No significant documented medicinal benefits. It is primarily valued for its long-lasting ornamental blooms and value to pollinators.
sideEffects: No known side effects from contact or minimal handling.
regionsFound: Native to eastern and central North America, in prairies, meadows, and open woods.
preparation: Not used for consumption. It is grown in gardens for its flowers, which are excellent for cutting.
detailedExplanation: The Ox-eye Sunflower, also called False Sunflower, is a hardy and showy perennial that is not a true sunflower (Helianthus) but a close relative. It produces abundant, bright yellow, daisy-like flowers from early summer to fall. It is a tough, drought-tolerant plant that thrives in full sun and is a vital source of nectar and pollen for bees, butterflies, and other beneficial insects. Unlike many medicinal plants, its primary value is ecological and aesthetic, making it a staple in native plant gardens, prairie restorations, and perennial borders. Source: https://www.wildflower.org/plants/result.php?id_plant=HEHE5

medicinalUses: Historically used as a folk remedy for fever, inflammation, and urinary infections due to its cooling and diuretic properties. The high Vitamin C content helped prevent scurvy.
sideEffects: Contains oxalic acid, which in large quantities can inhibit calcium absorption, cause kidney stones, or lead to nausea and vomiting. Should be avoided by people with kidney disorders, gout, or rheumatism.
regionsFound: Found worldwide in temperate and tropical regions, in woodlands, lawns, and as houseplants.
preparation: Leaves can be eaten raw in very small quantities in salads or used as a garnish for a lemony flavor. Can be brewed into a tea. Consumption should be moderate.
detailedExplanation: Oxalis, commonly known as Wood Sorrel or False Shamrock, is a large genus of plants known for their clover-like leaves and sharp, lemony taste due to oxalic acid. While it is a nutritious wild edible rich in Vitamin C, its consumption must be strictly limited. The plant is a common garden weed but is also cultivated for its attractive foliage and flowers. Different species can be found from shady forests to sunny lawns. The sour taste makes it a refreshing trailside nibble, but it should never be consumed in large amounts. Source: https://www.britannica.com/plant/wood-sorrel

medicinalUses: Rich in antioxidants, vitamin C, and fiber; traditionally used for digestive support, anti-inflammatory, and general immunity
sideEffects: Rare bloating or gas
preparation: Raw in salads, cooked, or steamed
detailedExplanation: Oxheart Cabbage has been traditionally used for its high antioxidant content, promoting digestive health, reducing inflammation, and supporting immune function. Contains vitamin C, glucosinolates, and fiber. Source

medicinalUses: Traditionally used as diuretic, mild anti-inflammatory, and respiratory support
sideEffects: Rare mild nausea
preparation: Leaves or roots decoction
detailedExplanation: Oxtongue leaves and roots have traditional use as a diuretic, for mild anti-inflammatory effects, and supporting respiratory health. Contains polyphenols and tannins. Source

medicinalUses: Immune support, cholesterol reduction, antioxidant, and anti-inflammatory
sideEffects: Rare allergy in sensitive individuals
preparation: Cooked or powdered as supplement
detailedExplanation: Oyster Mushroom is widely used for its immunomodulatory, cholesterol-lowering, antioxidant, and anti-inflammatory properties. Rich in beta-glucans and phenolic compounds. Source

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for respiratory support, antioxidant, and digestive aid
sideEffects: Rare gastrointestinal upset
preparation: Leaves and roots eaten fresh or cooked
detailedExplanation: Oyster Plant leaves and roots are traditionally used to support digestion, respiratory health, and provide antioxidant benefits. Contains carotenoids and flavonoids. Source

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for respiratory, immune, and digestive support
sideEffects: Rare mild nausea
preparation: Leaves brewed as tea or eaten fresh
detailedExplanation: Oysterleaf has traditional use for respiratory relief, immune support, and digestive aid. Rich in vitamins, flavonoids, and antioxidants. Source

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for anti-inflammatory, skin healing, and mild astringent
sideEffects: Rare skin irritation
preparation: Bark or leaf decoction, topical application
detailedExplanation: Ozark Witch Hazel bark and leaves have traditionally been applied for skin healing, reducing inflammation, and as a mild astringent. Contains tannins and polyphenols. Source

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for mild anti-inflammatory and ornamental medicinal purposes
sideEffects: Rare skin irritation
preparation: Leaves decoction
detailedExplanation: Pachysandra leaves have been traditionally used in East Asia for their mild anti-inflammatory properties and as ornamental herbal remedies. Contains alkaloids and tannins. Source

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for anti-inflammatory, digestive support, and mild antioxidant
sideEffects: Rare gastrointestinal upset
preparation: Flowers brewed as tea
detailedExplanation: Painted Daisy flowers have been traditionally used to reduce inflammation, support digestion, and provide antioxidant effects. Contains flavonoids and essential oils. Source

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for mild respiratory support, anti-inflammatory, and wound healing
sideEffects: Rare nausea or allergic reactions
preparation: Roots decoction or poultice
detailedExplanation: Painted Trillium roots and leaves traditionally used for respiratory relief, reducing inflammation, and aiding wound healing. Contains glycosides and flavonoids. Source

medicinalUses: Traditionally used to boost immunity, mild anti-inflammatory, and wound healing
sideEffects: Rare gastrointestinal upset
preparation: Roots brewed as tea or tincture
detailedExplanation: Pale Coneflower roots traditionally used to support immune function, reduce inflammation, and promote wound healing. Contains alkamides and polysaccharides. Source

medicinalUses: Traditionally used as diuretic, mild anti-inflammatory, and digestive aid
sideEffects: Rare mild gastrointestinal upset
preparation: Leaves or aerial parts boiled
detailedExplanation: Pale Smartweed leaves and aerial parts traditionally used to support urinary health, reduce mild inflammation, and aid digestion. Contains flavonoids and tannins. Source

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for urinary tract support, anti-inflammatory, and mild antioxidant
sideEffects: Rare mild gastrointestinal upset
preparation: Fruits or leaves decoction
detailedExplanation: Cabbage Palm fruits and leaves traditionally used to support urinary tract health, reduce inflammation, and provide antioxidants. Contains fatty acids and phytosterols. Source

medicinalUses: Rich in antioxidants, digestive support, and energy source
sideEffects: Rare mild gastrointestinal upset
preparation: Fruits eaten raw or in decoction
detailedExplanation: Date Palm fruits have been traditionally consumed to provide antioxidants, support digestion, and provide natural energy. Contains sugars, fiber, and phenolic compounds. Source

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for prostate health, urinary support, and anti-inflammatory
sideEffects: Rare mild gastrointestinal upset
preparation: Fruit extract or decoction
detailedExplanation: Saw Palmetto fruits traditionally used to support prostate and urinary health, and reduce inflammation. Contains fatty acids and sterols. Source

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for stress relief, mild anti-inflammatory, and antimicrobial
sideEffects: Rare allergic reactions
preparation: Wood burned as incense or essential oil
detailedExplanation: Palo Santo wood and essential oil have been traditionally used for stress relief, mild anti-inflammatory effects, and antimicrobial purposes. Contains terpenes and limonene. Source

medicinalUses: Used as a soothing remedy for skin conditions like eczema, cradle cap, and acne due to its anti-inflammatory and demulcent properties. Also used for mild respiratory complaints.
sideEffects: Generally very safe. Topical use may cause contact dermatitis in very rare, sensitive individuals.
regionsFound: Native to Europe and Asia; cultivated in gardens worldwide in temperate climates.
preparation: A tea is made from the dried flowers for internal use. For skin, a poultice or infused oil is applied directly. Flowers are also edible as garnishes.
detailedExplanation: The Pansy is a beloved garden flower known for its cheerful, "face-like" blooms in a wide array of colors. Beyond its beauty, it has a history in European folk medicine as a "blood purifier" and gentle remedy for childhood skin ailments. Its high mucilage content soothes irritated skin, while its salicylic acid and antioxidant flavonoids help reduce inflammation and fight bacteria. It is a gentle herb considered safe enough for children. Source: https://www.botanical.com/botanical/mgmh/p/pansy12.html

medicinalUses: The fruit is a rich source of digestive enzymes (papain) which aid in breaking down proteins. The leaves are used for treating dengue fever and malaria in traditional medicine.
sideEffects: Excessive consumption of the fruit can cause carotenemia, a harmless yellowing of the skin. Unripe papaya latex can be a severe irritant and should not be consumed.
regionsFound: Native to the tropics of the Americas; cultivated throughout the tropical and subtropical world.
preparation: The ripe fruit is eaten raw. Unripe fruit is cooked in curries. A tea is made from the dried leaves for medicinal purposes.
detailedExplanation: The Papaya tree produces a large, melon-like fruit with sweet, orange flesh and black seeds. The key medicinal component is papain, a powerful proteolytic enzyme concentrated in the unripe fruit and latex, which is used as a meat tenderizer and digestive aid. Papaya leaf extract has gained significant attention for its potential to increase platelet counts in viral fevers like dengue, though clinical evidence is still emerging. It is a powerhouse of vitamins A, C, and E. Source: https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/agricultural-and-biological-sciences/carica-papaya

medicinalUses: The bark was historically used as an anti-inflammatory and analgesic. The sap is a traditional tonic and the leaves are used as a diuretic.
sideEffects: Generally safe. Birch sap is well-tolerated. Topical use of the oil may cause contact dermatitis in sensitive individuals.
regionsFound: Native to northern North America; found in boreal and cool temperate forests.
preparation: The inner bark can be made into a tea. The sap is collected in spring and drunk fresh or fermented. The bark's papery layers were used for ancient manuscripts.
detailedExplanation: The Paper Birch is an iconic tree of the northern woods, easily identified by its brilliant white bark that peels away in paper-like sheets. This bark was historically used by Native Americans to build canoes, shelters, and even as writing paper. The tree has mild medicinal properties; its sap is a refreshing drink rich in minerals and sugars, and its leaves and bark contain betulinic acid, which has shown anti-inflammatory and anti-cancer potential in laboratory studies. It is an important ecological species for many insects and birds. Source: https://www.fs.usda.gov/database/feis/plants/tree/betpap/all.html

medicinalUses: The bark and fruit have been used in Traditional Chinese Medicine to treat impotence, poor vision, and as a tonic. The sap is used topically for insect bites.
sideEffects: The pollen is a potent allergen, causing severe hay fever in areas where it is invasive. The milky sap can cause skin irritation.
regionsFound: Native to East Asia (China, Japan, Korea); widely introduced and often invasive in other parts of the world.
preparation: The inner bark is used to make high-quality paper (the origin of its name) and tapa cloth. The fruit is edible but bland.
detailedExplanation: The Paper Mulberry is a fast-growing tree primarily known for its inner bark, which has been used for thousands of years in Asia and the Pacific to make paper, cloth, and cordage. While it has a place in traditional medicine, its modern notoriety comes from its invasive nature in many regions, including parts of the United States and Africa, where it outcompetes native vegetation. Its copious pollen is a major respiratory irritant, making it a significant public health concern in invaded ecosystems. Source: https://www.cabi.org/isc/datasheet/9920

medicinalUses: Rich in capsaicinoids (in milder forms) and carotenoids. It has antioxidant and anti-inflammatory properties. Can aid metabolism and act as a circulatory stimulant.
sideEffects: Can cause gastrointestinal irritation, heartburn, or discomfort if consumed in large amounts. Contact with eyes can cause severe burning.
regionsFound: The plant is native to Central and South America; the spice is now produced mainly in Spain, Hungary, and the Americas.
preparation: The dried, ground fruit is used as a spice and coloring agent in a vast array of culinary dishes, from stews to rubs.
detailedExplanation: Paprika is a spice made from grinding the dried pods of specific, relatively mild varieties of the chili pepper. Its color can range from bright red to deep brown-red, and its flavor from sweet and mild to slightly hot. The health benefits are derived from its high concentration of carotenoid antioxidants, like capsanthin, which give it its vibrant color, and low levels of capsaicin. It is a staple in Hungarian, Spanish, and Indian cuisines, valued more for its color and flavor than its heat. Source: https://www.britannica.com/topic/paprika

medicinalUses: The latex is the primary source of natural rubber, which has no direct medicinal use but is critical for medical devices (gloves, tubes, etc.).
sideEffects: The primary risk is severe latex allergy, which can cause skin rashes, asthma, and anaphylaxis in sensitive individuals.
regionsFound: Native to the Amazon rainforest; extensively cultivated in tropical Southeast Asia (e.g., Thailand, Indonesia).
preparation: The latex is tapped from the tree and processed into rubber for countless industrial and medical products.
detailedExplanation: The Para-rubber Tree is of immense global economic importance as the primary source of natural rubber. Its cultivation led to the development of massive plantations, which have had significant environmental and social impacts. While the tree itself is not used as an herbal medicine, its product is indispensable in modern healthcare for producing sterile gloves, catheters, tubing, and countless other items that prevent infection and enable medical procedures. The tree's ecological role in its native habitat is complex, but as a monoculture, it can reduce biodiversity. Source: https://www.britannica.com/plant/Para-rubber-tree

medicinalUses: Primarily used as a topical analgesic for toothaches, gum pain, and mouth ulcers. Also used to treat throat infections and as a digestive stimulant.
sideEffects: The numbing sensation can be very intense and may cause excessive salivation. Not for long-term use in the mouth. Should not be swallowed in large quantities.
regionsFound: Native to the Brazilian Amazon; now cultivated in tropical regions worldwide.
preparation: Fresh flower heads are chewed for a minute or two to relieve toothache. Tinctures and gels are made for topical application to gums.
detailedExplanation: Paracress, famously known as the Toothache Plant, produces unique, button-like yellow and red flowers that contain spilanthol, a powerful alkylamide. When chewed, it instantly produces a strong tingling, numbing sensation, followed by a localized anesthesia that can temporarily relieve oral pain. This effect has made it a widespread folk remedy across many cultures. Beyond dental use, it is also eaten as a leafy green in some cuisines and is being studied for its potential wrinkle-reducing effects in cosmetics. Source: https://pfaf.org/user/Plant.aspx?LatinName=Spilanthes+oleracea

medicinalUses: The bark is a potent bitter tonic and has been used traditionally as a febrifuge (reduces fever) and for treating amoebic dysentery and malaria.
sideEffects: As a strong bitter, it can cause stomach upset, nausea, and vomiting. Not recommended for long-term use.
regionsFound: Native to the Caribbean, Central America, and parts of South America; introduced in India and other tropical regions.
preparation: A decoction or tincture is made from the bark. The seeds are a source of edible oil used in cooking and biofuel.
detailedExplanation: The Paradise Tree, also known as Simarouba, is a versatile tree valued for its medicinal bark and its seeds, which yield a high-quality edible oil similar in composition to olive oil.
