Source: https://pfaf.org/user/Plant.aspx?LatinName=Satureja+montana

medicinalUses: This is the most well-known and effective natural remedy for an enlarged prostate (BPH) in men. It helps improve urine flow, reduce nighttime bathroom trips, and ease other prostate-related symptoms.
sideEffects: Very safe. May cause mild stomach upset in some individuals.
regionsFound: Native to the southeastern United States.
preparation: The ripe berries are dried and used in capsules, tinctures, and extracts.
detailedExplanation: Saw Palmetto is a small, creeping palm that forms dense thickets in its native habitat. Its fat-rich berries have been used for over a century to support men's urinary and reproductive health. It is one of the most thoroughly researched herbal medicines, with many studies confirming its benefits for prostate health without the side effects of prescription drugs. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK541037/

medicinalUses: In traditional Chinese medicine, the whole plant is used to relieve earaches, reduce inflammation, and treat coughs and hemorrhoids. It has cooling and detoxifying properties.
sideEffects: Generally safe. Mainly used externally.
regionsFound: Native to Asia; cultivated worldwide as a houseplant.
preparation: A poultice is made from the crushed fresh leaves. A decoction is made for internal use.
detailedExplanation: This type of Saxifrage is a very popular and easy-to-grow houseplant, known for its rounded, veined leaves and its ability to produce many "baby" plants on long runners. Its name means "rock-breaker," as many species in this family grow in rocky crevices. While it is beautiful to look at, it also has a history of use in Asian folk medicine for soothing various inflammatory conditions. Source: https://pfaf.org/user/Plant.aspx?LatinName=Saxifraga+stolonifera

medicinalUses: The name "scabious" comes from its traditional use to treat scabies, an itchy skin condition. It was used as a blood purifier for skin diseases like eczema and acne, and to soothe a dry, itchy scalp.
sideEffects: Generally safe.
regionsFound: Native to Europe and Asia; found in dry grasslands.
preparation: A tea is made from the leaves and flowers. A wash is made for the skin.
detailedExplanation: Scabious is a delicate and beautiful wildflower with pincushion-like flower heads that are highly attractive to bees and butterflies. Its historical use is a classic example of the "Doctrine of Signatures," where the rough, scaly appearance of the seed head was thought to indicate its use for rough, scaly skin diseases. It is a gentle cleansing herb for the skin. Source: https://www.pfaf.org/user/Plant.aspx?LatinName=Scabiosa+columbaria

medicinalUses: Historically used for treating epilepsy, mental health issues, and as a diuretic. However, it is considered toxic and its use is not recommended. Traditionally used in folk medicine for mild diuretic effects, skin ailments, and respiratory support.
sideEffects: All parts of the plant are poisonous. Ingestion can cause diarrhea, vomiting, and kidney damage. Skin contact can cause dermatitis in sensitive individuals.
regionsFound: Native to Europe and Asia; naturalized as a weed in temperate regions worldwide.
preparation: NOT RECOMMENDED FOR USE. Historically, it was used in infusions and poultices, but this is unsafe.
detailedExplanation: The Scarlet Pimpernel is a low-growing weed famous for its small, bright red-orange flowers that close in cloudy weather. Despite its charming appearance and historical place in folk medicine, modern understanding classifies it as a toxic plant due to the presence of saponins and other irritant compounds. Its use was often based on the "Doctrine of Signatures" because of its red color, suggesting it could treat blood disorders. It is not safe for consumption or self-treatment. Source: https://www.pfaf.org/user/Plant.aspx?LatinName=Anagallis+arvensis

medicinalUses: Used for skin disorders, diuretic, anti-inflammatory
sideEffects: Toxic in high doses
preparation: Leaf decoction, poultice
detailedExplanation: Anagallis arvensis is a herb used in folk medicine for skin conditions and as a mild diuretic, with caution due to potential toxicity. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK92771/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for mild stress relief, digestive aid, and skin toning in aromatherapy.
sideEffects: Rare allergic reaction
preparation: Tea, essential oil
detailedExplanation: Scented Geranium leaves and essential oils are used in teas and topical applications to soothe stress, aid digestion, and refresh skin. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6110602/

medicinalUses: Adaptogen supporting stress reduction, liver function, respiratory health, and energy.
sideEffects: Rare digestive upset
preparation: Tea, tincture, powder
detailedExplanation: Schisandra berries are traditionally used in Chinese medicine to improve mental performance, liver health, and energy while reducing stress. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4003790/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used in small doses as sedative and antispasmodic; historically for pain relief.
sideEffects: Toxic if overdosed; nausea, dizziness
preparation: Extract, tincture
detailedExplanation: Scopolia roots contain tropane alkaloids used carefully in traditional medicine for sedation, pain relief, and muscle relaxation. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Used for respiratory health, mild antiseptic, and joint pain relief; pine oils support cough and congestion.
sideEffects: Rare allergy or skin irritation
preparation: Steam inhalation, oil, tea
detailedExplanation: Scots Pine needles and resin are traditionally used to support respiratory function, reduce mild joint pain, and provide antiseptic benefits. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5474520/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for urinary support, mild diuretic, and to strengthen hair/nails externally.
sideEffects: Overuse may cause mild kidney irritation
preparation: Tea, poultice
detailedExplanation: Scouring Rush stems and shoots are brewed as tea for mild urinary support and used externally for hair and nail strengthening. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6121586/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for mild anxiety, nervous tension, sleep support, and muscle relaxation.
sideEffects: Rare digestive upset
preparation: Tea, tincture
detailedExplanation: Scullcap leaves and stems are brewed or tinctured to promote relaxation, reduce anxiety, and improve sleep quality. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4003790/

medicinalUses: Rich in vitamin C; traditionally used to prevent scurvy, support immunity, and digestive health.
sideEffects: Rare digestive upset
preparation: Fresh leaves, juice, decoction
detailedExplanation: Scurvy Grass leaves are rich in vitamin C and traditionally consumed to prevent scurvy, boost immunity, and aid digestion. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5111906/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for mild digestive issues, liver support, and antioxidant properties.
sideEffects: Rare mild digestive upset
preparation: Decoction, infusion
detailedExplanation: Sea Aster leaves and stems are brewed to support digestion, liver function, and provide antioxidant benefits. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6121586/

medicinalUses: Supports skin health, immunity, digestive system, and rich in antioxidants and omega fatty acids.
sideEffects: Rare mild stomach upset
preparation: Juice, oil, powder
detailedExplanation: Sea Buckthorn berries are rich in vitamin C, flavonoids, and omega fatty acids. Traditionally used to boost immunity, support skin, and digestive health. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5514173/

medicinalUses: The root is a strong diuretic, helping the body get rid of excess water. It was traditionally used to treat kidney stones, bladder infections, and as a tonic to improve overall health and energy levels.
sideEffects: Generally safe in moderation.
regionsFound: Native to the coastlines of Europe and North Africa.
preparation: A decoction (strong tea) is made from the cleaned and dried root.
detailedExplanation: Sea Holly is a stunning, thistle-like plant with striking metallic blue-green stems and flowers. It is a specialist of coastal sand dunes, where its deep roots help stabilize the sand. Its use in medicine is similar to its relative, Rattlesnake Master, acting as a cleansing tonic for the urinary system. However, it is not a common herb in modern practice. Source: https://www.pfaf.org/user/Plant.aspx?LatinName=Eryngium+maritimum

medicinalUses: Anti-inflammatory, used for ulcers, asthma and joint pain; roots and leaves used in decoctions and poultices.
sideEffects: GI upset possible with high internal doses; topical irritation rare.
preparation: Root/bark decoction; topical paste for ulcers and skin lesions.
detailedExplanation: Acanthus ilicifolius is a mangrove-associated medicinal shrub used in Ayurveda and coastal folk medicine for its anti-inflammatory and wound-healing properties. Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Acanthus_ilicifolius

medicinalUses: The young shoots and leaves are a highly nutritious vegetable, rich in Vitamin C, iodine, and minerals. It was historically eaten by sailors to prevent scurvy. It supports thyroid function due to its iodine content.
sideEffects: The raw plant can be tough and bitter. It is best cooked. Ensure it is harvested from clean, unpolluted shores.
regionsFound: Native to the coastlines of Europe.
preparation: The young, blanched shoots are harvested in spring and cooked like asparagus or broccoli.
detailedExplanation: Sea Kale is a robust, salt-tolerant plant that grows on shingle beaches. It was a popular Victorian vegetable, where gardeners would force the shoots to grow early in the spring. Its high Vitamin C content made it a vital anti-scurvy food for coastal communities. Today, it is a protected species in many areas, so it should only be foraged sustainably or cultivated in gardens. Source: https://www.pfaf.org/user/Plant.aspx?LatinName=Crambe+maritima

medicinalUses: This plant is primarily ornamental and is not used for medicine. It is not related to true lavender and does not have the same calming properties.
sideEffects: Not considered edible or medicinal.
regionsFound: Found in coastal salt marshes and saline environments worldwide.
preparation: Not used for medicine or food.
detailedExplanation: Sea Lavender is a common sight in salt marshes, producing clouds of small, papery flowers in shades of purple, pink, and yellow. It is famous for its use in dried flower arrangements, as the flowers retain their color and shape for a long time. While it is ecologically important in its habitat, it has no significant role in herbal medicine. Source: https://www.britannica.com/plant/sea-lavender

medicinalUses: This calcareous algae is a rich source of minerals, especially calcium and magnesium, which are important for strong bones and teeth. It also helps to balance the body's pH levels.
sideEffects: Very safe. Ensure it is harvested from clean, unpolluted waters.
regionsFound: Found in tropical and subtropical oceans worldwide.
preparation: The dried algae can be powdered and added to smoothies or used as a mineral supplement.
detailedExplanation: Sea Oak is a type of green algae that has a segmented, leaf-like appearance that resembles an oak tree, hence its name. It incorporates calcium carbonate from the seawater, making it hard and chalky. It is not as well-known as other seaweeds like kelp, but it is a valuable source of essential minerals for both human consumption and as a component of coral reef ecosystems. Source: https://www.algaebase.org/search/species/detail/?species_id=11665

medicinalUses: The young leaves and seed pods are edible and can be used as a spicy salad green. It is a hardy halophyte (salt-tolerant plant) and a source of nutrition in coastal areas.
sideEffects: Grows in sandy, salty soil; ensure it is washed thoroughly before consumption.
regionsFound: Native to coastal areas of Europe, North Africa, and Western Asia.
preparation: Young leaves and seed pods can be eaten raw in salads or cooked like spinach.
detailedExplanation: Sea Rocket is a succulent plant adapted to life on sandy beaches and dunes. Its fleshy leaves help it conserve water in its harsh, windy, and salty environment. It plays a vital ecological role in stabilizing sand dunes. While not a major medicinal plant, it is a interesting and edible halophyte, with a pungent, radish-like flavor that can foraged from clean coastal areas. Source: https://www.ediblewildfood.com/sea-rocket.aspx

medicinalUses: Historically used as anthelmintic and bitter tonic; contains thujone-like compounds in related Artemisia.
sideEffects: Some Artemisia species contain neuroactive constituents; avoid in pregnancy and high doses.
preparation: Dried aerial parts used in decoction; historically as wormwood preparations.
detailedExplanation: Artemisia maritima has an old history as wormwood used to treat helminths and as a bitter tonic—use supported by traditional texts but modern safety guidance suggests cautious dosing. Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artemisia_maritima.

medicinalUses: The young leaves are edible and can be cooked as a leafy green vegetable. They are a good source of vitamins and were traditionally eaten in coastal communities.
sideEffects: Ensure it is harvested from clean, unpolluted areas.
regionsFound: Found in salt marshes and coastal mudflats worldwide.
preparation: The young leaves and shoots are boiled or steamed and eaten as a side dish.
detailedExplanation: Sea-blite is a common, succulent plant of salt marshes. It can tolerate very high levels of salt in the soil. Like other coastal greens, it was an important source of fresh vegetables for people living near the sea. It has a mild, salty, and slightly spinach-like flavor when cooked. It is more of a survival or traditional food than a medicinal plant. Source: https://www.pfaf.org/user/Plant.aspx?LatinName=Suaeda+maritima

medicinalUses: This plant lives up to its name. It is a powerful wound healer when applied as a poultice to cuts, burns, and sores. As a tea, it is used to soothe a sore throat, reduce fever, and calm allergy symptoms.
sideEffects: Very safe.
regionsFound: Found in lawns, meadows, and woods in temperate regions worldwide.
preparation: A poultice is made from the crushed fresh leaves. A tea is made from the dried flowering tops.
detailedExplanation: Self-heal is a common lawn weed that is a fantastic first-aid plant. Its traditional use across many cultures for healing wounds is supported by its strong antiviral and antibacterial properties. It is a gentle but effective herb that can be used for both internal inflammation and external injuries, making it a true "medicine chest" in a small plant. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3923904/

medicinalUses: Traditional anti-inflammatory, antimicrobial
sideEffects: Rare
preparation: Bark/rhizome decoction
detailedExplanation: Alseodaphne semecarpifolia, a Western Ghats tree, is used in Ayurveda for its anti-inflammatory and antimicrobial properties. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK92771/

medicinalUses: The root is a strong medicine for the lungs. It helps break up thick, sticky mucus in bronchitis and asthma, making it easier to cough up and clear the airways.
sideEffects: Can cause nausea and vomiting if the dose is too high. Not for home use without guidance.
preparation: Used in very small doses in professional herbal medicine.
detailedExplanation: This plant was a famous Native American remedy for serious coughs. It is very powerful and works by irritating the stomach, which then tells the lungs to produce more fluid to thin the mucus. Because it is so strong, it is best used by experienced practitioners. Source: https://www.pfaf.org/user/Plant.aspx?LatinName=Polygala+senega

medicinalUses: The root is a strong expectorant, meaning it helps to loosen and clear mucus from the lungs. It is used for severe bronchitis, asthma, and stubborn coughs.
sideEffects: Can cause nausea and vomiting if the dose is too high. Not for long-term use.
preparation: Not for home use. Used in very small, controlled doses in herbal medicine by experienced practitioners.
detailedExplanation: Senega Snakeroot was a famous Native American remedy adopted by European settlers. Its name suggests it was also used for snakebite, but its primary use is for the respiratory system. It is a very potent herb that powerfully irritates the stomach lining, which reflexively stimulates the production of fluid in the lungs to thin thick mucus. It is not a gentle herb and is best left to professionals. Source: https://www.pfaf.org/user/Plant.aspx?LatinName=Polygala+senega

medicinalUses: This plant is a highly invasive weed and has no well-documented medicinal benefits. Its primary impact is negative, clogging waterways and harming ecosystems.
sideEffects: Not used for medicine.
regionsFound: Native to South America; invasive in waterways in the USA, Australia, and Asia.
preparation: Not used for medicine or food.
detailedExplanation: Senegal Tea is a fast-growing aquatic plant that forms dense mats on the surface of slow-moving water bodies. It outcompetes native plants, reduces oxygen in the water, and interferes with recreation and irrigation. It is considered a noxious weed in many countries, and efforts are focused on its eradication, not its use. Source: https://www.cabi.org/isc/datasheet/108315

medicinalUses: This is a very strong and fast-acting laxative used to relieve temporary constipation. It stimulates the muscles of the colon to produce a bowel movement.
sideEffects: For short-term use only. Causes strong cramping and abdominal pain. Long-term use can lead to dependency and damage to the colon.
regionsFound: Native to North Africa and the Middle East; cultivated in India and other arid regions.
preparation: The leaves and pods are used to make tea or are sold in standardized capsules.
detailedExplanation: Senna is one of the most common ingredients in over-the-counter laxative teas and products. While it is very effective, it is a harsh medicine. The pods are generally gentler than the leaves. It should only be used for a few days at a time and never as a long-term solution for constipation, as the colon can become dependent on it to function. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK547922/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for mild anxiety relief, wound healing, and anti-inflammatory purposes.
sideEffects: Rare mild digestive upset
preparation: Decoction, poultice
detailedExplanation: Sensitive Plant leaves are used in traditional medicine to soothe minor anxiety, promote wound healing, and reduce inflammation. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Used for digestive disorders, fever, and anti-inflammatory
sideEffects: Rare
preparation: Leaf decoction
detailedExplanation: Allophylus serratus is a Western Ghats shrub used for digestive and fever-related ailments. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK92771/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for digestive support, mild anti-inflammatory, and tonic purposes.
sideEffects: Rare digestive upset
preparation: Fruit decoction, tincture
detailedExplanation: Service Tree fruits are used in traditional remedies to aid digestion, reduce mild inflammation, and provide general tonic support. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for mild digestive support, antioxidant intake, and general wellness.
sideEffects: Rare mild allergy
preparation: Fresh fruit, tea
detailedExplanation: Serviceberry fruits are consumed fresh or as tea in folk medicine to aid digestion, provide antioxidants, and support overall wellness. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Supports heart health, skin and hair, mild antioxidant, and digestive aid.
sideEffects: Rare allergy, especially seed allergy
preparation: Oil, seeds, paste
detailedExplanation: Sesame seeds and oil are widely used in traditional medicine for cardiovascular health, skin and hair nourishment, and digestive support. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4003790/

medicinalUses: Blood purifier, anti-inflammatory, diuretic
sideEffects: Rare
preparation: Leaf juice, decoction
detailedExplanation: Alternanthera sessilis is a wetland herb traditionally used as a blood purifier and anti-inflammatory. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK92771/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for digestive support, mild antimicrobial, and cardiovascular support.
sideEffects: Rare mild digestive upset
preparation: Raw, cooked, decoction
detailedExplanation: Shallots are used in traditional diets and remedies to improve digestion, provide mild antimicrobial effects, and support heart health. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4003790/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used to support mild nervous tension, anti-inflammatory, and circulation support.
sideEffects: Rare mild digestive upset
preparation: Leaf decoction, poultice
detailedExplanation: Shameplant leaves are traditionally used in teas or applied externally to reduce mild nervous tension, inflammation, and improve circulation. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for mild digestive discomfort, anti-inflammatory, and skin tonic.
sideEffects: Rare mild allergy
preparation: Decoction, poultice
detailedExplanation: Shasta Daisy petals and leaves are used in teas and poultices to reduce mild digestive discomfort, soothe skin, and provide anti-inflammatory effects. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Supports female reproductive health, lactation, digestive aid, and mild adaptogen.
sideEffects: Rare digestive upset
preparation: Powder, decoction, capsule
detailedExplanation: Shatavari roots are widely used in Ayurveda to support female hormonal balance, lactation, digestive health, and act as a mild adaptogen. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4270108/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for mild detoxification, diuretic support, and digestive aid.
sideEffects: Rare mild digestive upset
preparation: Tea, decoction
detailedExplanation: Sheep Sorrel leaves are traditionally brewed as tea to support detoxification, mild diuretic effects, and digestive comfort. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Antioxidant, digestive aid, anti-inflammatory
sideEffects: Rare
preparation: Leaf decoction, rhizome paste
detailedExplanation: Alpinia zerumbet is used in Northeast India for digestive support and inflammation. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK92771/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for mild digestive discomfort, menstrual support, and anti-inflammatory purposes.
sideEffects: Rare mild allergic reaction
preparation: Decoction, infusion
detailedExplanation: Shepherd’s Club leaves are used in teas to soothe digestive discomfort, support menstrual health, and reduce mild inflammation. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: This plant is not a major medicinal herb. It has been used in traditional medicine as a mild diuretic to increase urine flow.
sideEffects: Considered non-toxic but not well-studied.
regionsFound: Native to Europe, Asia, and North Africa; found in fields and waste grounds.
preparation: A tea can be made from the aerial parts of the plant.
detailedExplanation: Shepherd's Needle is a wildflower named for its incredibly long, needle-like seed pods that resemble a comb. It is more commonly considered a weed of arable land than a medicine. While it has a minor place in folk medicine, it is not a plant that is widely used or recognized in modern herbal practice. Its primary interest is botanical, due to its unique fruit. Source: https://www.brc.ac.uk/plantatlas/plant/scandix-pecten-veneris

medicinalUses: This is a very effective herb to stop bleeding, especially heavy menstrual bleeding and nosebleeds. It helps to contract the uterus after childbirth and can also lower blood pressure.
sideEffects: Very safe. Has a mild, peppery taste.
regionsFound: Found worldwide as a common weed.
preparation: A tea is made from the fresh or dried aerial parts of the plant.
detailedExplanation: Shepherd's Purse is one of the most common weeds in the world, easily identified by its heart-shaped seed pods that look like tiny purses. It is a classic "first-aid" herb in many traditions. Its ability to stanch bleeding is well-regarded, and it is considered a specific remedy for cases of heavy menstruation with bright red blood and cramping. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5871205/

medicinalUses: This fern is primarily grown for its ornamental beauty in shady gardens. It has no well-documented history of medicinal use.
sideEffects: Non-toxic but not used for consumption.
regionsFound: Native to Europe and southwestern Asia.
preparation: Not used for medicine or food.
detailedExplanation: The Shield Fern is a lush, dark green fern with soft, finely divided fronds that form an elegant, shuttlecock-like shape. It is a favorite for woodland gardens and shady borders because it maintains its foliage throughout the year. While some ferns have medicinal properties, this species is valued almost exclusively for its ability to add texture and year-round interest to the landscape. Source: https://www.rhs.org.uk/plants/13225/polystichum-setiferum/details

medicinalUses: This mushroom is a powerful immune system booster. It helps the body fight infections and may have anti-cancer properties. It also supports heart health by helping to lower cholesterol levels.
sideEffects: Very safe when cooked. Some people may experience a temporary skin rash when they first start consuming it.
regionsFound: Native to East Asia; cultivated worldwide on hardwood logs.
preparation: The mushrooms are cooked in soups, stir-fries, and other dishes. Extracts are also available in supplement form.
detailedExplanation: Shiitake is one of the most popular and researched medicinal mushrooms in the world. It has been used in Traditional Chinese Medicine for centuries to promote vitality and longevity. Its rich, savory flavor makes it a culinary delight, while its beta-glucans and other compounds provide profound health benefits by modulating and strengthening the immune response. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4320875/

medicinalUses: Hair cleanser (natural shampoo), dandruff reduction, scalp tonic and mild antimicrobial for scalp infections.
sideEffects: Topical overuse can dry hair/scalp; usually safe in traditional forms.
preparation: Pods dried and powdered for hair-wash paste; decoction used as rinse.
detailedExplanation: Shikakai is a central traditional hair-care botanical in India, used as an effective mild cleanser and hair tonic for centuries. Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Acacia_concinna

medicinalUses: The leaves have anti-inflammatory and astringent properties. A tea or poultice made from them is used to soothe skin rashes, wounds, and sore throats.
sideEffects: Generally considered safe.
preparation: A tea is made from the leaves for gargling or drinking. A poultice is made from the crushed leaves for the skin.
detailedExplanation: Shinleaf is a delicate, low-growing plant of shady coniferous forests. Its name comes from its traditional use as a poultice for bruises and skin sores ("shin" injuries). It is a relative of the better-known Wintergreen (Gaultheria procumbens) and shares some similar soothing, aromatic properties. It is a gentle remedy for minor external and internal inflammations. Source: https://www.fs.fed.us/wildflowers/plant-of-the-week/pyrola_americana.shtml

medicinalUses: Used traditionally as anti-inflammatory, antidiarrhoeal, and for general tonic effects; leaves contain triterpenoids and flavonoids.
sideEffects: Possible GI upset if overused; allergic contact in sensitive individuals.
preparation: Leaf decoction, topical poultice from crushed leaves; berries sometimes used in remedies.
detailedExplanation: Ardisia elliptica produces bioactive flavonoids and triterpenes; regional folk medicine uses the aerial parts for digestive complaints and inflammation. Confirm local safety before internal use. Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ardisia_elliptica.

medicinalUses: This plant is primarily a beautiful wildflower and is not used for medicine. All parts of the plant are considered mildly toxic if ingested and can cause stomach upset.
sideEffects: Can cause digestive discomfort if eaten.
regionsFound: Native to North American prairies and woodlands.
preparation: NOT FOR CONSUMPTION.
detailedExplanation: The Shooting Star is a stunning spring wildflower whose unique, reflexed pink or white flowers look like tiny "shooting stars" falling from the sky. It is a sure sign of spring in native prairies and open woodlands. While it is not a notorious poison, it has no medicinal uses and should be appreciated for its remarkable beauty and its importance to native pollinators like bumblebees. Source: https://www.wildflower.org/plants/result.php?id_plant=DOME

medicinalUses: This is a premier adaptogen, meaning it helps the body cope with physical and mental stress. It increases energy, reduces fatigue, improves mental focus, and strengthens the immune system.
sideEffects: Very safe. May cause mild drowsiness in some people.
preparation: The root is dried and used in tinctures, capsules, or tea.
detailedExplanation: Siberian Ginseng is not a true ginseng (Panax), but it is a powerful and much more sustainable alternative. It was extensively studied in Russia for its ability to enhance the performance of athletes, cosmonauts, and workers under extreme stress. It is less stimulating than coffee but provides a sustained increase in energy and resilience without the crash. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK548440/

medicinalUses: The peas (seeds) are edible and nutritious, rich in protein and fat. The plant is primarily used for fodder and soil improvement, not medicine.
sideEffects: The seeds are safe when cooked. The raw seeds may be mildly toxic.
regionsFound: Native to Siberia and Manchuria; widely planted as a windbreak.
preparation: The seeds are cooked and eaten like peas or lentils.
detailedExplanation: The Siberian Pea Tree is an extremely hardy, drought-tolerant, and nitrogen-fixing shrub. It is often planted in permaculture gardens and as a hardy windbreak. Its abundant seed pods provide a reliable source of edible peas for both humans and livestock. While it is a valuable plant for food security and land rehabilitation, it does not have significant medicinal applications. Source: https://www.pfaf.org/user/Plant.aspx?LatinName=Caragana+arborescens

medicinalUses: Bitter tonic, digestive and carminative uses; some topical respiratory uses recorded.
sideEffects: Bitter GI upset if overused.
preparation: Leaf decoction or infusion as bitter tonic.
detailedExplanation: Artemisia laciniata occurs in temperate montane zones and is recorded in regional pharmacopeias for digestive and carminative use. Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artemisia_laciniata.

medicinalUses: The seeds are roasted and used as a coffee substitute. In traditional medicine, the leaves are used as a laxative and to treat skin fungus.
sideEffects: The seeds and leaves must be thoroughly roasted or cooked to destroy toxins. Raw, they are poisonous.
regionsFound: Native to the Americas; a pantropical weed.
preparation: Roasted seeds are ground and brewed like coffee. Leaves are used in poultices.
detailedExplanation: Sicklepod is a common agricultural weed with curved seed pods. Its roasted seeds have been used as a caffeine-free coffee alternative, similar to chicory. However, the plant contains potent toxins and should not be used without proper knowledge and preparation. Its medicinal use as a laxative is similar to its relative, Senna, but it is considered more dangerous. Source: https://www.cabi.org/isc/datasheet/108315

medicinalUses: The bark is used to make a tea that acts as a diuretic, reduces fever, and treats headaches. The cotton-like floss from the seed pods is used to stuff pillows and life jackets.
sideEffects: The bark tea is generally safe in moderation.
regionsFound: Native to tropical Americas, West Africa, and Southeast Asia.
preparation: A decoction is made from the bark. The seed floss (kapok) is harvested for stuffing.
detailedExplanation: The Silk Cotton Tree is a massive, majestic tree with a tall, straight trunk and large buttress roots. Its seed pods are filled with a water-resistant, silky floss that is too brittle for spinning but perfect for insulation and buoyancy. The tree is considered sacred in many cultures. While it has medicinal uses, it is more famous for its impressive size and its commercially valuable kapok fiber. Source: https://uses.plantnet-project.org/en/Ceiba_pentandra_(PROTA)

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for mild anxiety, nervous tension, and sleep support.
sideEffects: Rare mild digestive upset
preparation: Decoction, tea
detailedExplanation: Silk Tree bark and flowers are traditionally brewed in teas to help soothe nervous tension, promote relaxation, and support sleep. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Used for anxiety, insomnia, mild sedative
sideEffects: Rare allergy
preparation: Bark and flower decoction
detailedExplanation: Albizia julibrissin, an ornamental tree, has traditional uses in herbal medicine for calming effects and mild sedative purposes. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK92771/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for urinary support, mild anti-inflammatory, and skin tonic purposes.
sideEffects: Rare mild allergy
preparation: Tea, tincture
detailedExplanation: Silver Birch leaves and bark are used in teas and tinctures to support urinary tract health, reduce inflammation, and promote skin wellness. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for digestive support, mild antioxidant intake, and immune support.
sideEffects: Rare mild digestive upset
preparation: Berry tea, juice
detailedExplanation: Silver Buffaloberry fruits are consumed fresh, juiced, or brewed to support digestion, immunity, and provide antioxidant benefits. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for mild digestive discomfort, liver support, and antimicrobial effects.
sideEffects: Rare mild digestive upset
preparation: Decoction, infusion
detailedExplanation: Silver Ragwort leaves and flowers are brewed as teas to aid digestion, support liver function, and provide mild antimicrobial effects. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for liver and digestive support, mild anti-inflammatory, and antioxidant purposes.
sideEffects: Rare mild allergy
preparation: Decoction, tincture
detailedExplanation: Silver Thistle roots and leaves are used in decoctions or tinctures to support liver health, aid digestion, and reduce mild inflammation. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for digestive aid, mild anti-inflammatory, and to soothe minor skin irritations.
sideEffects: Rare mild allergy
preparation: Tea, poultice
detailedExplanation: Silverweed roots and leaves are brewed as tea or applied as poultices to aid digestion, reduce inflammation, and soothe skin irritations. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for mild digestive discomfort, anti-inflammatory, and urinary support.
sideEffects: Rare mild digestive upset
preparation: Decoction, infusion
detailedExplanation: Silvery Cinquefoil leaves and roots are brewed as teas to support digestion, reduce inflammation, and provide mild diuretic effects. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Anti-allergic, anti-asthmatic
sideEffects: None reported
preparation: Bark decoction
detailedExplanation: Albizia lebbeck treats allergies and respiratory issues in Ayurveda. Important note: Shade tree. Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Albizia_lebbeck

medicinalUses: Fiber used in ropes, leaves in traditional medicine
sideEffects: None widely reported
preparation: Fiber extraction, leaf application
detailedExplanation: Agave sisalana is mainly cultivated for fiber production; leaves have minor medicinal applications. Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agave_sisalana

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for digestive support, mild diuretic, and general tonic purposes.
sideEffects: Rare mild digestive upset
preparation: Decoction, root consumption
detailedExplanation: Skirret roots are traditionally cooked or brewed to aid digestion, provide mild diuretic effects, and act as a general tonic. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for mild anxiety, nervous tension, and sleep support.
sideEffects: Rare digestive upset
preparation: Tea, tincture
detailedExplanation: Skullcap leaves and stems are brewed to promote relaxation, reduce nervous tension, and improve sleep quality. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4003790/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for mild respiratory support, anti-inflammatory, and diuretic purposes.
sideEffects: Rare mild digestive upset
preparation: Decoction, infusion
detailedExplanation: Skunk Cabbage roots and leaves are traditionally brewed as tea to support respiratory health, reduce inflammation, and provide mild diuretic effects. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Digestive aid, mild anti-inflammatory, nutrient-rich
sideEffects: Rare
preparation: Cooked leaves, decoction
detailedExplanation: Amaranthus viridis is a wild leafy vegetable traditionally used for digestion and mild inflammation. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK92771/

medicinalUses: The inner bark becomes a slippery, soothing gel when mixed with water. This gel coats and protects sore throats, stomach ulcers, and irritated skin. It also helps with coughs and diarrhea.
sideEffects: Very safe. Rarely, it may slow down the absorption of other medicines.
preparation: The powdered bark is mixed with water to make a soothing drink or paste.
detailedExplanation: Slippery Elm is a tree whose inner bark is a famous soothing medicine. When water is added, it creates a thick gel (mucilage). This gel lines the throat and stomach, protecting them from irritation and acid. It is a very gentle and effective remedy for many types of inflammation in the digestive and respiratory systems. Source: https://www.mountsinai.org/health-library/herb/slippery-elm

medicinalUses: The fruit (sloes) are very rich in antioxidants. They are used to make a syrup for colds and flu. The flowers make a mild laxative tea.
sideEffects: The fruit is very sour and astringent (dries the mouth) when raw.
preparation: The berries are cooked with sugar to make jam or syrup. The flowers are used for tea.
detailedExplanation: Sloe is a thorny shrub that produces small, dark blue fruits. These fruits are too sour to eat raw but become delicious in jams and drinks like sloe gin. The plant is also a medicine; the berry syrup helps the body fight sickness, and the flower tea gently helps with constipation. Source: https://www.woodlandtrust.org.uk/trees-woods-and-wildlife/british-trees/a-z-of-british-trees/blackthorn/

medicinalUses: Digestive aid, anti-inflammatory, diuretic
sideEffects: None reported
preparation: Leaf decoction
detailedExplanation: Ajuga parviflora is used in traditional medicine in NW Himalayas for digestion and inflammation. Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ajuga_parviflora

medicinalUses: This plant is used to stop diarrhea and to help heal wounds faster when applied to the skin. It tightens tissues and reduces bleeding.
sideEffects: Very safe for external use.
regionsFound: Europe, Asia; introduced in North America.
preparation: A strong tea is made from the plant to use as a skin wash or gargle.
detailedExplanation: This small, common weed is a powerful astringent. Astringent plants work by tightening and drying out tissues. This makes it useful for stopping minor bleeding from cuts, calming diarrhea, and soothing a sore throat when used as a gargle. Source: https://www.pfaf.org/user/Plant.aspx?LatinName=Geranium+pusillum

medicinalUses: Bitter tonic and topical uses in regional medicine; used as adjunct in digestive formulas.
sideEffects: Typical bitter-herb GI effects if overused.
preparation: Aerial-part decoction.
detailedExplanation: Artemisia parviflora appears in hill medicinal systems as a supportive bitter herb for digestive and febrile complaints. Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artemisia_parviflora.

medicinalUses: A warming herb used in liniments and plasters to relieve arthritis and muscle pain. It increases blood flow to the area, which helps reduce pain and stiffness.
sideEffects: The fresh plant can irritate the skin. Always use it diluted.
regionsFound: Temperate regions worldwide, in wet areas.
preparation: The dried herb is infused in oil or alcohol to make a pain-relief rub.
detailedExplanation: Smartweed has a sharp, peppery taste. When applied to the skin, it creates a warming sensation. This helps to distract the brain from deeper pain and brings more blood to the area, which can help heal sore muscles and stiff joints. Source: https://www.pfaf.org/user/Plant.aspx?LatinName=Polygonum+hydropiper

medicinalUses: Digestive aid, anti-inflammatory, high nutritional value
sideEffects: Rare
preparation: Cooked leaves, decoction
detailedExplanation: Amaranthus hybridus is a wild leafy vegetable used for digestion, anti-inflammatory purposes, and nutrition. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK92771/

medicinalUses: Diuretic, anti-inflammatory, wound healing
sideEffects: Rare
preparation: Leaf decoction, paste
detailedExplanation: Alternanthera paronychioides is a widely distributed herb used in India for inflammation, diuresis, and wound care. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK92771/

medicinalUses: Pain relief, fever reduction
sideEffects: Toxic if misused
preparation: Root decoction (carefully diluted)
detailedExplanation: Aconitum laeve is a Himalayan medicinal herb traditionally used for analgesic and antipyretic purposes with caution. Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aconitum_laeve

medicinalUses: The red berry clusters are used to make a tart, pink tea that is very high in Vitamin C. This tea helps fight colds and sore throats. It also acts as a mild diuretic.
sideEffects: Very safe. Do not confuse with Poison Sumac, which has white berries.
preparation: The berries are soaked in cold water to make a refreshing drink.
detailedExplanation: Smooth Sumac is a common shrub with fuzzy, red berry clusters that remain on the plant through winter. The berries have a sour, lemony taste. Making a tea from them is an excellent way to get Vitamin C, which is crucial for a strong immune system. It is an important native plant for wildlife. Source: https://www.fs.usda.gov/database/feis/plants/shrub/rhugla/all.html

medicinalUses: The fruit and seeds are used to treat fever, headaches, and skin diseases. It is also a mild laxative and is believed to help control blood sugar levels.
sideEffects: The raw fruit is bitter and may cause stomach upset. It is always cooked before eating.
preparation: The young fruit is cooked as a vegetable. The seeds and roots are used in traditional medicine.
detailedExplanation: Snake Gourd is a long, twisted vegetable that is common in Asian cuisines. In traditional medicine, almost every part of the plant is used. It is considered a cooling food that can help reduce fevers and cleanse the body. Modern research is looking into its potential for diabetes. Source: https://uses.plantnet-project.org/en/Trichosanthes_cucumerina_(PROTA)

medicinalUses: This plant is highly poisonous. It has no safe medicinal use. Drinking milk from a cow that ate this plant caused "milk sickness," which was often fatal in the past.
sideEffects: All parts are toxic. Causes tremors, vomiting, and can be deadly to humans and livestock.
preparation: NOT FOR MEDICINAL USE.
detailedExplanation: This plant grows in shady woods and has clusters of small white flowers. It was responsible for the death of Abraham Lincoln's mother. The toxin in the plant can pass into the milk of animals that eat it. It should be identified and avoided. Source: https://www.poison.org/articles/2015-mar/white-snakeroot

medicinalUses: Digestive aid, anti-inflammatory, anti-diabetic
sideEffects: Rare gastrointestinal upset
preparation: Rhizome decoction, paste
detailedExplanation: Alpinia calcarata, native to Western Ghats, is used traditionally in Ayurveda to treat digestive issues, inflammation, and diabetes. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK92771/

medicinalUses: This plant is grown only for its beautiful and unique flowers. It has no well-known medicinal benefits and is not used for medicine.
sideEffects: Not considered edible.
preparation: Not used for medicine or food.
detailedExplanation: Snapdragons are popular garden flowers known for their "dragon-shaped" blooms that snap open and closed when you squeeze them. They come in many bright colors. Their value is purely decorative, adding beauty to gardens and bouquets. They are not a medicinal plant. Source: https://www.britannica.com/plant/snapdragon

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for mild cold and respiratory issues; also to stimulate sneezing and clear nasal passages.
sideEffects: Rare mild nausea
preparation: Decoction, dried leaves
detailedExplanation: Sneezeweed leaves and flowers are brewed to relieve mild respiratory discomfort, act as a nasal stimulant, and help clear congestion. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for mild digestive support and as a general tonic.
sideEffects: Rare mild digestive upset
preparation: Decoction, powder
detailedExplanation: Snoutbean seeds and pods are used in decoctions or powdered form to support digestion and provide mild tonic effects. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used externally for skin conditions and mild anti-inflammatory purposes.
sideEffects: Toxic sap; can irritate skin
preparation: Poultice, topical
detailedExplanation: Snow-on-the-Mountain leaves and stems are applied externally as poultices to reduce inflammation and soothe minor skin irritations. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used externally for skin irritations, wounds, and mild inflammation.
sideEffects: Internal use may be toxic
preparation: Poultice, topical
detailedExplanation: Snowberry berries and leaves are applied externally in poultices to soothe skin irritation, reduce inflammation, and support minor wound healing. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used in mild nervous disorders and as a stimulant in small doses.
sideEffects: Toxic if overdosed
preparation: Extract, tincture
detailedExplanation: Snowdrop bulbs and flowers contain alkaloids used carefully in traditional medicine to support nervous system health and mild cognitive stimulation. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used as mild antiseptic and for skin cleansing.
sideEffects: Rare mild skin irritation
preparation: Poultice, wash
detailedExplanation: Soap Plant bulbs are crushed to produce a soapy lather for cleaning skin and minor antiseptic applications. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Hair cleanser, anti-dandruff, antimicrobial
sideEffects: Eye irritation
regionsFound: Native to Central and South India, common in forests
preparation: Pod powder
detailedExplanation: Acacia concinna pods are a natural shampoo in Ayurveda, promoting hair growth and fighting infections. Important note: No-foam cleanser. Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Acacia_concinna

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for mild skin cleansing, digestive aid, and respiratory support in folk medicine.
sideEffects: Rare mild digestive upset
preparation: Decoction, topical wash
detailedExplanation: Soapbark bark and extracts are used to cleanse skin, soothe mild digestive discomfort, and support respiratory health. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used as mild antiseptic, skin cleanser, and hair tonic.
sideEffects: Rare mild allergy
preparation: Decoction, powder, soap
detailedExplanation: Soapberry fruits are traditionally used in decoctions, powders, or soap preparations for skin cleansing, hair tonic, and antiseptic purposes. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for skin cleansing, mild respiratory support, and gentle anti-inflammatory effects.
sideEffects: Rare mild allergy
preparation: Decoction, poultice
detailedExplanation: Soapwort roots and leaves are brewed or applied externally to cleanse skin, soothe mild respiratory issues, and reduce inflammation. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Anti-inflammatory, antimicrobial, antioxidant
sideEffects: Rare
preparation: Leaf decoction, poultice
detailedExplanation: Ardisia solanacea is used in traditional medicine in Western Ghats for inflammation, infections, and antioxidant support. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK92771/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for joint health, mild anti-inflammatory, digestive aid, and skin support.
sideEffects: Rare mild digestive upset
preparation: Decoction, poultice
detailedExplanation: Solomon's Seal rhizomes are brewed or applied externally to support joint health, reduce mild inflammation, aid digestion, and soothe skin issues. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Local astringent and topical wound remedies reported in ethnobotanical sources.
sideEffects: Limited toxicology data; use topical with care.
preparation: Local bark decoction for topical application.
detailedExplanation: Acacia suma is regionally used in folk medicine in parts of western India; references are localized in regional floras and herbarium records. Source: https://powo.science.kew.org/

medicinalUses: A nutritious grain that is gluten-free. It is a good source of energy, fiber for digestion, and antioxidants.
sideEffects: Very safe. A staple food for millions.
preparation: The grain is ground into flour for flatbreads (roti) or cooked like rice.
detailedExplanation: Sorghum is one of the top five cereal crops in the world. It is very drought-tolerant, making it a crucial food source in dry areas. It is a healthy, whole grain that provides steady energy and helps keep the digestive system running smoothly. Source: https://www.britannica.com/plant/sorghum-grain

medicinalUses: The leaves have a sour, lemony taste. They are a good source of Vitamin C and can be used to make a refreshing tea that helps with digestion.
sideEffects: Eating very large amounts can cause stomach upset due to oxalic acid (like in spinach).
regionsFound: Native to Europe; grown in temperate gardens.
preparation: Young leaves are eaten raw in salads or cooked like spinach. A tea is made from the leaves.
detailedExplanation: Sorrel is a common garden herb with a sharp, tangy flavor. The sour taste comes from oxalic acid. In small amounts, it is a healthy green that stimulates digestion. It has been used to make a "spring tonic" tea to cleanse the body after winter. Source: https://www.britannica.com/plant/sorrel

medicinalUses: The leaves have a sour taste. A tea from the leaves can help reduce fevers and has been used as a diuretic. The tree is famous for its high-quality honey.
sideEffects: Very safe in moderation.
preparation: A tea is made from the dried leaves.
detailedExplanation: The Sorrel Tree is a beautiful native tree with brilliant red fall colors. Its leaves are sour to taste, similar to garden sorrel. The tea was used in folk medicine to treat fevers and to help the body get rid of excess water. The honey from its flowers is considered a delicacy. Source: https://www.wildflower.org/plants/result.php?id_plant=OXAR

medicinalUses: The juice is famous for reducing muscle pain after exercise. It also helps with arthritis pain and can improve sleep quality because it contains natural melatonin.
sideEffects: Very safe. The fruit is sour, so it is often sweetened or cooked.
regionsFound: Native to Europe and Southwest Asia; cultivated.
preparation: The juice is drunk, or the fruit is eaten in pies, jams, and supplements.
detailedExplanation: Sour cherries are different from sweet cherries. They are too tart to eat fresh but are packed with compounds that fight inflammation. Drinking the juice regularly can help people with gout and arthritis, and it helps athletes recover faster. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5872786/

medicinalUses: The fruit is eaten for its Vitamin C. In traditional medicine, the leaves are used in tea to help you relax and sleep. It is also studied for other properties.
sideEffects: The seeds are poisonous and must not be eaten. The leaf tea should be used in moderation.
regionsFound: Native to tropical Americas; cultivated in tropics.
preparation: The pulp of the fruit is eaten or juiced. A tea is made from the leaves.
detailedExplanation: Soursop is a spiky green fruit with soft, sweet, white pulp inside. It is very popular in the tropics. The leaf tea is a common home remedy for calmness and sleep. However, claims about its use for more serious conditions are not proven by science. Source: https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/cam/hp/graviola-pdq

medicinalUses: The bark is used in traditional medicine to reduce anxiety and stress, similar to magnolia supplements. It may also help with allergies and digestion.
sideEffects: Very safe in normal amounts.
preparation: The bark is used in herbal supplements and teas.
detailedExplanation: The Southern Magnolia is a majestic tree with large, fragrant white flowers and glossy leaves. The bark contains compounds that are used in herbal medicine to help calm the mind and body, reducing the effects of stress. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3746285/

medicinalUses: The strong-smelling leaves are used to repel moths and insects. A tea from the leaves can help stimulate digestion and regulate menstrual cycles.
sideEffects: The essential oil is strong and should not be taken internally.
regionsFound: Native to Southern Europe; cultivated in gardens.
preparation: The leaves are dried and placed in closets. A weak tea is made for medicine.
detailedExplanation: Southernwood is a shrub with fine, feathery leaves that have a sharp, lemony scent. It has been used for centuries as a natural insect repellent. As a medicine, it is a bitter digestive tonic and was traditionally used for women's health issues. Source: https://pfaf.org/user/Plant.aspx?LatinName=Artemisia+abrotanum

medicinalUses: The young leaves are a nutritious wild edible, rich in vitamins and minerals. The milky sap has been used on the skin to treat warts.
sideEffects: The plant is safe to eat when young. The milky sap can be a skin irritant for some.
preparation: Young leaves are boiled or eaten raw in salads. The sap is applied directly to warts.
detailedExplanation: Sow Thistle is a common garden weed that looks like a dandelion. It is not a true thistle. The young leaves are a good source of food, and the plant has a history of folk use for skin problems, though this is not scientifically proven. Source: https://www.ediblewildfood.com/sow-thistle.aspx

medicinalUses: A complete source of plant protein. It can help lower bad cholesterol and reduce menopausal symptoms like hot flashes. It is also rich in healthy fats and fiber.
sideEffects: Very safe as a food. Some people may be allergic.
regionsFound: Native to East Asia; cultivated worldwide.
preparation: Eaten as tofu, tempeh, soy milk, and edamame (young beans).
detailedExplanation: Soybeans are one of the most important food crops in the world. They are used to make countless products. The plant compounds (isoflavones) in soy can act like a weak estrogen in the body, which is why they help with menopause symptoms and bone health. Source: https://www.hsph.harvard.edu/nutritionsource/soy/

medicinalUses: The root contains saponins, which can be used as a natural soap. It has been used to treat arthritis and joint pain by reducing inflammation.
sideEffects: The root is not for eating. The sharp leaf tips can cause injury.
preparation: The root is crushed and mixed with water to make a soapy lather for washing.
detailedExplanation: Spanish Bayonet is a tough, desert plant with very sharp, pointed leaves. The root can be mashed in water to create a soapy foam for cleaning. Some Native American tribes used it to wash hair and to make a poultice for sore joints. Source: https://www.wildflower.org/plants/result.php?id_plant=YUAL

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for mild diuretic support and digestive aid.
sideEffects: Rare mild digestive upset
preparation: Decoction, tea
detailedExplanation: Spanish Dagger leaves are brewed as tea in folk medicine to support urinary health, mild diuretic effects, and digestive comfort. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used externally for skin soothing and as a mild antiseptic.
sideEffects: Rare mild skin irritation
preparation: Poultice, topical
detailedExplanation: Spanish Moss fibers are applied externally or infused in poultices to soothe minor skin irritations and support mild antiseptic effects. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Used as a local stimulant and sialagogue (promotes saliva production) for toothaches and sore throats. Also used as a circulatory stimulant and aphrodisiac in traditional medicine.
sideEffects: Can cause severe irritation, burning, and numbness in the mouth if used in excess. Not to be swallowed.
regionsFound: Native to the Mediterranean region and North Africa.
preparation: The root is dried and powdered. A small amount of powder is held in the mouth or applied to gums for toothache.
detailedExplanation: Spanish Pellitory, also known as Akarkara in Ayurveda, is a powerful medicinal root, not to be confused with Pellitory-of-the-wall. Its primary use is as a topical remedy for oral pain, where it produces a intense warming, tingling sensation and stimulates saliva flow, which can help cleanse the area. It has been used for centuries in both European and Ayurvedic traditions for its stimulant properties, which are believed to extend to the entire body and reproductive system. Source: https://www.researchgate.net/publication/267227187_Simarouba_glauca_An_Overview

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for mild urinary, digestive, and anti-inflammatory support.
sideEffects: Rare digestive upset
preparation: Decoction, infusion
detailedExplanation: Spatterdock roots and rhizomes are brewed as teas or decoctions to support urinary tract health, aid digestion, and reduce mild inflammation. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for digestive support, mild nausea relief, and respiratory comfort.
sideEffects: Rare mild allergic reaction
preparation: Tea, essential oil
detailedExplanation: Spearmint leaves are brewed as tea or used as essential oil to support digestion, relieve mild nausea, and soothe respiratory passages. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4003790/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for mild respiratory relief, digestive aid, and anti-inflammatory purposes.
sideEffects: Rare mild digestive upset
preparation: Tea, decoction
detailedExplanation: Speedwell leaves and flowers are brewed to help relieve mild coughs, support digestion, and reduce inflammation. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for digestive support, mild anti-inflammatory, and general tonic purposes.
sideEffects: Rare mild allergy
preparation: Decoction, tea
detailedExplanation: Spice Wood bark and leaves are brewed as teas or decoctions to aid digestion, reduce inflammation, and act as a mild tonic. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for digestive aid, mild anti-inflammatory, and respiratory support.
sideEffects: Rare mild digestive upset
preparation: Tea, decoction
detailedExplanation: Spicebush leaves and berries are brewed to support digestion, reduce inflammation, and promote respiratory comfort. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for mild respiratory support, anti-inflammatory, and diuretic purposes.
sideEffects: Rare mild digestive upset
preparation: Decoction, poultice
detailedExplanation: Spider Lily bulbs and leaves are brewed or applied externally to aid respiratory health, reduce inflammation, and support mild diuretic effects. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for mild anti-inflammatory, digestive aid, and wound care.
sideEffects: Rare mild skin irritation
preparation: Decoction, poultice
detailedExplanation: Spiderwort leaves and stems are brewed or applied externally to reduce inflammation, support digestion, and aid minor wound healing. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for mild stress relief, nervous system support, and sleep aid.
sideEffects: Rare mild digestive upset
preparation: Decoction, powder, essential oil
detailedExplanation: Spikenard roots are used in decoctions, powders, or essential oils to reduce stress, support nervous system health, and improve sleep quality. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: An extremely nutritious leafy green. It is rich in iron for healthy blood, Vitamin K for strong bones, and antioxidants for eye health.
sideEffects: Eating very large amounts may interfere with certain medicines due to high Vitamin K and oxalates.
preparation: Eaten raw in salads, cooked as a side dish, or blended into smoothies.
detailedExplanation: Spinach is a popular vegetable known for its health benefits. It provides a wide range of vitamins and minerals that support energy, vision, and bone strength. It is a true superfood for everyday health. Source: https://www.britannica.com/plant/spinach-plant

medicinalUses: This plant is poisonous and has no safe medicinal use. The berries and bark are very toxic if eaten.
sideEffects: Causes severe stomach pain, vomiting, and can be dangerous.
preparation: NOT FOR MEDICINAL USE.
detailedExplanation: The Spindle Tree is known for its stunning pink and orange berries. While it is beautiful, especially in autumn, every part of the plant is poisonous to humans and many animals. It should be enjoyed for its looks only. Source: https://www.woodlandtrust.org.uk/trees-woods-and-wildlife/plants/wild-flowers/spindle/

medicinalUses: The young leaves are a nutritious wild edible, rich in iron and vitamins. A tea from the root is used to treat diarrhea and heavy menstrual bleeding.
sideEffects: The plant has sharp spines, so handle with care.
preparation: Young leaves are cooked and eaten. A tea is made from the root.
detailedExplanation: This common weed has sharp thorns at the base of its leaves. Despite its tough appearance, the young leaves are a valuable and healthy food. In traditional medicine, it is also used to treat problems with bleeding and digestion. Source: https://uses.plantnet-project.org/en/Amaranthus_spinosus_(PROTA)

medicinalUses: Diuretic, digestive aid, anti-inflammatory, laxative, nutrient-rich.
sideEffects: Rare or None significant
preparation: Cooked leaves, decoction/ Leaves cooked. Root decoction/paste for external application.
detailedExplanation: Amaranthus spinosus is a wild leafy vegetable used in traditional medicine for digestion and urinary support. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK92771/  Amaranthus spinosus provides vitamins and treats urinary issues. Important note: Edible greens. Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amaranthus_spinosus

medicinalUses: Historically, it was used to make a tea for coughs, asthma, and spleen disorders (hence the name). It was thought to clean the body.
sideEffects: Considered non-toxic but not a common modern remedy.
regionsFound: Found on rocks and walls in temperate regions worldwide.
preparation: A tea is made from the whole fern.
detailedExplanation: This small, delicate fern grows in rocky places. Its name comes from the old belief that it could treat diseases of the spleen, an organ that filters blood. It was a traditional remedy for respiratory problems. Source: https://www.pfaf.org/user/Plant.aspx?LatinName=Asplenium+trichomanes

medicinalUses: Similar topical uses to other Arnebia species for wound healing and skin disorders; local antiseptic/anti-inflammatory preparations.
sideEffects: Possible local irritation/allergy.

medicinalUses: This plant is mainly grown for its beautiful leaves in shady gardens. It is not a major medicinal herb, but it is related to other plants used for soothing skin.
sideEffects: Non-toxic.
regionsFound: Europe, Asia; grown in gardens worldwide.
preparation: Not commonly used for medicine.
detailedExplanation: Spotted Dead-nettle is a popular garden plant because its variegated leaves brighten up dark areas. It is not a stinging nettle. While it is not a primary medicine, a poultice of the leaves could be used to soothe minor cuts, similar to its relatives. Source: https://www.rhs.org.uk/plants/10017/lamium-maculatum/details

medicinalUses: This plant is an invasive weed and has no well-known medicinal benefits. It harms farmland and natural areas.
sideEffects: Not used for medicine.
regionsFound: Native to Europe; invasive in North America.
preparation: Not used for medicine or food.
detailedExplanation: Spotted Knapweed is a plant with pinkish-purple flowers that has spread aggressively in many regions. It releases chemicals into the soil that prevent other plants from growing. Its impact on the environment is negative. Source: https://www.invasive.org/weedcd/pdfs/wow/spotted-knapweed.pdf

medicinalUses: This plant is poisonous. It has been used in very small, controlled amounts by professionals as a strong heart stimulant and diuretic, but it is too dangerous for home use.
sideEffects: All parts are toxic. Causes vomiting, dizziness, and heart problems.
preparation: NOT FOR HOME USE.
detailedExplanation: Spreading Dogbane is a native plant with pretty pink flowers. Its milky sap contains powerful compounds that affect the heart. While it has a history of use, the line between a medicine and a poison is very thin. It should never be used without expert guidance. Source: https://www.fs.fed.us/database/feis/plants/forb/apoand/all.html

medicinalUses: The small, potato-like roots (corms) are edible and can be cooked or eaten raw. They are a nutritious wild food.
sideEffects: Non-toxic and safe to eat.
preparation: The roots can be dug up, washed, and eaten like tiny potatoes.
detailedExplanation: Spring Beauty is one of the first wildflowers to bloom in the spring woodlands. Its roots are a traditional food for Native Americans and foragers. They are a pleasant, mild-tasting source of starch and can be found in large patches. Source: https://www.ediblewildfood.com/spring-beauty.aspx

medicinalUses: This plant is mainly grown to improve soil quality because it adds nitrogen. The seeds are edible when cooked, but other parts may be mildly toxic in large quantities.
sideEffects: The seeds must be cooked. Eating a lot of the plant may cause a nervous system disorder.
regionsFound: Europe, Asia, North Africa; naturalized elsewhere.
preparation: The seeds are cooked and eaten like peas.
detailedExplanation: Spring Vetch is a common plant in fields and roadsides. It is related to the pea and bean family. It is very useful for farmers as a "cover crop" to make the soil healthier. The seeds can be eaten, but caution is advised. Source: https://www.pfaf.org/user/Plant.aspx?LatinName=Vicia+sativa

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for respiratory support, mild antiseptic, and joint pain relief.
sideEffects: Rare mild allergy
preparation: Decoction, essential oil
detailedExplanation: Norway Spruce needles and resin are used in decoctions or oils to support respiratory health, relieve mild joint pain, and provide antiseptic benefits. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for respiratory ailments, mild anti-inflammatory, and immune support.
sideEffects: Rare mild allergy
preparation: Decoction, tea
detailedExplanation: White Spruce needles and resin are brewed or infused to relieve mild respiratory discomfort, support immune health, and reduce inflammation. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used externally for warts, skin lesions, and mild anti-inflammatory purposes.
sideEffects: Toxic if ingested
preparation: Poultice, topical
detailedExplanation: Spurge sap is applied externally to treat warts, minor skin lesions, and reduce mild inflammation. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for digestive support, mild anti-inflammatory, and urinary tract health.
sideEffects: Rare digestive upset
preparation: Cooked, juice
detailedExplanation: Squash fruits and seeds are consumed cooked or juiced to aid digestion, reduce inflammation, and support urinary health. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for mild anti-inflammatory and joint support.
sideEffects: Rare mild allergy
preparation: Decoction, poultice
detailedExplanation: Squaw Vine stems and leaves are used in decoctions or applied as poultices to reduce inflammation and support joint comfort. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for mild respiratory support, heart tonic, and diuretic purposes.
sideEffects: Toxic if overdosed
preparation: Decoction, tincture
detailedExplanation: Squill bulbs are used in carefully prepared decoctions or tinctures to support respiratory health, act as a heart tonic, and provide mild diuretic effects. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for mild anti-inflammatory, pain relief, and nervous system support.
sideEffects: Rare mild digestive upset
preparation: Decoction, poultice
detailedExplanation: Squirrel Corn roots are brewed or applied externally to reduce inflammation, relieve mild pain, and support nervous system health. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for mild depression, anxiety relief, and wound healing.
sideEffects: Rare mild digestive upset
preparation: Decoction, tincture
detailedExplanation: St. Andrew’s Cross leaves and flowers are brewed or used in tinctures to relieve mild depression, support relaxation, and promote wound healing. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for liver support, mild digestive aid, and anti-inflammatory purposes.
sideEffects: Rare mild allergy
preparation: Decoction, infusion
detailedExplanation: St. Benedict's Thistle leaves and roots are brewed to support liver health, aid digestion, and reduce mild inflammation. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for mild depression, anxiety relief, and nerve support.
sideEffects: May cause photosensitivity
preparation: Decoction, tincture
detailedExplanation: St. John’s Wort flowers and leaves are brewed or prepared as tincture to support mood, relieve mild depression and anxiety, and support nerve health. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: The root and bark have been used in herbal medicine, but the berries are poisonous. It was used to cause vomiting, as a diuretic, and for skin conditions.
sideEffects: Berries are toxic and can cause vomiting, diarrhea, and drowsiness.
preparation: Not for home use due to toxicity.
detailedExplanation: This native vine is known for its beautiful orange-red berries that split open to show a red center. While the root has a history of medicinal use, the berries are dangerous if eaten. It is best to enjoy this plant for its beauty and for the birds that eat its berries. Source: https://www.poison.org/articles/bittersweet

medicinalUses: This plant is poisonous to livestock and has no safe medicinal use for humans. It can cause weakness, vomiting, and slow the heart.
sideEffects: All parts are toxic if eaten.
preparation: NOT FOR MEDICINAL USE.
detailedExplanation: Staggerbush is a native shrub with small, bell-shaped flowers. Its name comes from the "staggering" effect it has on animals that eat it. It should be appreciated in its natural habitat but not used as a medicine. Source: https://www.fs.usda.gov/database/feis/plants/shrub/lyomar/all.html

medicinalUses: The red berry clusters are used to make a tart, pink drink very high in Vitamin C. This helps fight colds and sore throats. It is also a strong antioxidant.
sideEffects: Very safe. Do not confuse with Poison Sumac, which has white berries.
preparation: The berries are soaked in cold water to make a refreshing "sumac-ade" or lemonade.
detailedExplanation: Staghorn Sumac gets its name from the fuzzy branches that look like deer antlers. Its fuzzy, red berry clusters are not poisonous and make a delicious, healthy drink that tastes like lemonade. It is a great source of Vitamin C. Source: https://www.ediblewildfood.com/staghorn-sumac.aspx

medicinalUses: The seed pod is a common spice. A tea made from it can relieve coughs, ease stomach cramps and gas, and help fight flu viruses.
sideEffects: Very safe in normal food amounts.
preparation: The dry star-shaped pods are used in cooking or to make tea.
detailedExplanation: Star Anise is the source of the flavor in many dishes and in the flu medicine Tamiflu. Its sweet, licorice-like taste makes a pleasant tea that can soothe a cough or an upset stomach. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3847409/

medicinalUses: The fruit is rich in Vitamin C and antioxidants. It is a healthy, low-calorie snack.
sideEffects: Dangerous for people with kidney disease. It contains a toxin that healthy kidneys remove, but sick kidneys cannot.
regionsFound: Native to Southeast Asia; cultivated in tropics.
preparation: The fruit is eaten raw, in salads, or as juice.
detailedExplanation: Star Fruit is a unique tropical fruit that, when sliced, forms perfect star shapes. It is juicy and refreshing. However, it contains a neurotoxin that can be fatal for people with kidney problems. Healthy people can enjoy it safely. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5357247/

medicinalUses: Antioxidant, digestive aid, vitamin-rich snack; used as mild diuretic and for general nutrition.
sideEffects: Contains oxalates and caramboxin — dangerous in kidney impairment (can cause neurotoxicity).
preparation: Fruit eaten fresh or juiced; leaves used occasionally in folk infusions.
detailedExplanation: Star fruit is nutritious but carries risks for renal patients; in healthy individuals it is consumed as a vitamin-rich fruit and used in folk dietary remedies. Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Averrhoa_carambola

medicinalUses: The root is a traditional remedy for stomach problems like colic, gas, and indigestion. It was also used for female reproductive issues.
sideEffects: Can cause stomach upset if the dose is too high. Not for use during pregnancy.
preparation: The root is used in tinctures or teas by herbalists.
detailedExplanation: Star Grass is a wildflower with a spike of white, bell-shaped flowers. Its bitter root has a long history of use for settling the stomach and for women's health. However, it is not a common herb today and should be used with care. Source: https://www.pfaf.org/user/Plant.aspx?LatinName=Aletris+farinosa

medicinalUses: This plant is highly poisonous. It has no safe medicinal use. All parts are toxic if eaten.
sideEffects: Causes severe stomach pain, vomiting, and irregular heartbeat.
preparation: NOT FOR MEDICINAL USE.
detailedExplanation: Star of Bethlehem is a common garden plant with pretty white star-shaped flowers. Despite its beauty, it contains powerful toxins that affect the heart. It is especially dangerous because it looks similar to wild onions. Source: https://www.poison.org/articles/star-of-bethlehem-203

medicinalUses: This plant is a beautiful wildflower and is not used for medicine. The bulbs were eaten by Native Americans as a food source.
sideEffects: Not known to be toxic, but it is a protected wildflower in some areas.
preparation: The bulbs were traditionally cooked and eaten.
detailedExplanation: The Star Tulip is a delicate and beautiful native wildflower. It is not a common medicine. Its main historical use was as a starchy food, similar to a potato. It should be admired, not harvested, from the wild. Source: https://www.calflora.org/cgi-bin/species_query.cgi?where-calrecnum=1301

medicinalUses: The plant is a natural anti-inflammatory. The oil from its seeds is rich in GLA, a fatty acid that helps with skin health (like eczema), rheumatoid arthritis, and hormone balance.
sideEffects: The fresh plant may contain small amounts of liver toxins. The seed oil is very safe.
preparation: The leaves and blue flowers are edible. The seed oil is taken as a supplement.
detailedExplanation: Borage has beautiful, star-shaped blue flowers and hairy leaves. It is a great plant for pollinators. The seed oil is a popular supplement for reducing inflammation throughout the body, which helps with skin and joint problems. Source: https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/agricultural-and-biological-sciences/borago

medicinalUses: This plant is grown only for its beautiful, long-lasting flowers. It is not used for medicine.
sideEffects: Not considered edible or medicinal.
preparation: Not used for medicine or food.
detailedExplanation: Statice is a popular flower for gardens and bouquets because its papery flowers keep their color and shape for a very long time after being dried. It has no known role in herbal medicine. Source: https://www.rhs.org.uk/plants/10033/limonium-sinuatum/details

medicinalUses: Traditionally used as a natural sweetener for blood sugar management and mild digestive support.
sideEffects: Rare mild digestive upset
preparation: Leaves, powder, extract
detailedExplanation: Stevia leaves and extracts are widely used to sweeten foods and beverages without raising blood sugar, also supporting mild digestive health. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/
