medicinalUses: Traditionally used externally for wound care and mild anti-inflammatory purposes.
sideEffects: Rare skin irritation
preparation: Poultice
detailedExplanation: Stickseed seeds and leaves are applied as poultices to reduce inflammation and support minor wound healing. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for lymphatic support, mild diuretic effects, and skin health.
sideEffects: Rare digestive upset
preparation: Decoction, poultice
detailedExplanation: Sticky Willy leaves and stems are brewed or applied externally to support lymphatic drainage, promote urinary health, and improve skin condition. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for digestive support, mild anti-inflammatory, and as a skin tonic.
sideEffects: Rare mild digestive upset
preparation: Decoction, poultice
detailedExplanation: Stillingia roots and leaves are prepared in decoctions or applied externally to support digestion, reduce inflammation, and maintain skin health. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for urinary support, joint health, allergy relief, and mild anti-inflammatory effects.
sideEffects: May cause skin irritation if handled raw
preparation: Tea, decoction, topical
detailedExplanation: Stinging Nettle leaves and roots are brewed or applied topically to support urinary health, relieve mild joint pain, reduce inflammation, and alleviate allergy symptoms. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Antifungal, antibacterial
sideEffects: Skin irritation
preparation: Leaf paste
detailedExplanation: Himalayan herb used to treat fungal and bacterial skin infections. Source: https://powo.science.kew.org/taxon/urn:lsid:ipni.org:names:833035-1

medicinalUses: Anti-inflammatory, digestive
sideEffects: Possible allergy
preparation: Flower infusion
detailedExplanation: Wild chamomile used for its soothing and digestive effects. Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anthemis_cotula

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for mild anti-inflammatory and wound healing applications.
sideEffects: Rare mild allergy
preparation: Decoction, poultice
detailedExplanation: Stinkwood bark and leaves are prepared as poultices or decoctions to reduce inflammation and support minor wound healing. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for mild respiratory support, digestive aid, and wound healing.
sideEffects: Rare mild digestive upset
preparation: Decoction, poultice
detailedExplanation: Stitchwort leaves and flowers are brewed or applied externally to relieve mild respiratory symptoms, support digestion, and promote wound healing. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used externally for skin conditions and mild anti-inflammatory purposes.
sideEffects: Rare skin irritation
preparation: Poultice, topical
detailedExplanation: Stonecrop leaves are applied externally to soothe skin irritation, support minor wound healing, and reduce inflammation. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for digestive support, urinary health, and mild anti-inflammatory effects.
sideEffects: Rare mild digestive upset
preparation: Decoction, tea
detailedExplanation: Stoneroot leaves and roots are brewed as decoctions or teas to aid digestion, support urinary tract health, and reduce mild inflammation. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for mild respiratory support, antiseptic purposes, and skin healing.
sideEffects: Rare mild allergy
preparation: Decoction, topical
detailedExplanation: Storax resin and leaves are used in decoctions or externally to soothe respiratory passages, support minor wound healing, and act as mild antiseptic. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: The young leaves are edible and nutritious. A tea from the plant has been used to stop minor bleeding and to treat stomach problems.
sideEffects: Very safe.
regionsFound: Native to the Mediterranean; found worldwide.
preparation: Young leaves can be eaten in salads. A tea is made from the aerial parts.
detailedExplanation: This is a common weed with small pink flowers and seed pods that look like a stork's beak. It's a useful plant for foragers and has a history in folk medicine for its mild astringent (tightening) properties, which can help with wounds and diarrhea. Source: https://www.ediblewildfood.com/storksbill.aspx

medicinalUses: The essential oil from Scented Geranium is used in aromatherapy to reduce stress and improve mood. The root of a specific type (Pelargonium sidoides) is a well-known medicine for bronchitis and sore throats.
sideEffects: The essential oil is for external use only. The root medicine is very safe.
regionsFound: Native to South Africa; cultivated worldwide.
preparation: The root is used in syrups and drops (like Umcka). Essential oil is used in a diffuser.
detailedExplanation: Geraniums are popular garden flowers. A special species from South Africa has a root that is a powerful remedy for respiratory infections. It helps to thin mucus and fight bacteria. The scented leaves are used for their calming fragrance. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK529585/

medicinalUses: Used traditionally as seasoning and mild medicinal herb
sideEffects: Rare
preparation: Raw or cooked
detailedExplanation: Endemic Himalayan Allium species used locally as spice and mild digestive aid. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK92771/

medicinalUses: The fruit is very rich in Vitamin C and antioxidants. These help boost the immune system, protect the heart, and keep skin healthy. The leaves can be used to make a mild tea for diarrhea.
sideEffects: Very safe. Some people may be allergic.
preparation: The fruit is eaten fresh. A tea is made from the dried leaves.
detailedExplanation: Strawberries are a delicious and healthy fruit. Their red color comes from antioxidants that fight cell damage. The leaves have astringent properties, making a tea that can help settle an upset stomach. Source: https://www.britannica.com/plant/strawberry

medicinalUses: The fruit is edible and high in Vitamin C. A tea from the leaves and bark is a strong astringent, used to treat diarrhea and urinary infections.
sideEffects: The fruit is bland and mealy when raw but is safe. Better when made into jam.
preparation: The fruit is used for jams and liqueurs. A tea is made from the leaves.
detailedExplanation: This tree has rough red bark and bumpy red fruits that look like strawberries. The fruit is not very tasty raw but makes good preserves. The leaves are a powerful herbal medicine for drying up secretions in the gut and urinary tract. Source: https://pfaf.org/user/Plant.aspx?LatinName=Arbutus+unedo

medicinalUses: Rich in antioxidants, digestive aid
sideEffects: Rare
preparation: Raw fruit, jam
detailedExplanation: Strawberry tree fruit is consumed for antioxidant properties and mild digestive support. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK92771/

medicinalUses: This plant is grown only for its beautiful, papery flowers that last a very long time when dried. It has no well-known medicinal uses.
sideEffects: Not used for medicine.
preparation: Used in dried flower arrangements.
detailedExplanation: Strawflowers are popular because their bright yellow, red, and pink flowers feel like paper and keep their color for years after drying. They are a favorite for crafts and winter bouquets. Source: https://www.rhs.org.uk/plants/18300/xerochrysum-bracteatum/details

medicinalUses: This plant is a source of a powerful heart medicine (ouabain), but it is highly poisonous and not for home use. It is used in very controlled doses to treat heart failure.
sideEffects: All parts are extremely toxic. Causes severe heart problems.
preparation: STRICTLY PHARMACEUTICAL. NOT FOR HOME USE.
detailedExplanation: This tropical vine was traditionally used to make poison arrows. The same toxin, in a purified and controlled dose, is used in modern medicine to strengthen the heartbeat. The raw plant is deadly. Source: https://www.britannica.com/plant/strophanthus

medicinalUses: Digestive aid, anti-inflammatory, nutrient-rich
sideEffects: Seeds toxic if ingested
preparation: Raw fruit, juice
detailedExplanation: Sugar apple or Sitaphal is used for digestive benefits and nutrition; seeds should not be eaten. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK92771/

medicinalUses: The delicious fruit is nutritious. The seeds are poisonous. In traditional medicine, the leaves are crushed and used on the skin to treat lice. The leaf tea is used for upset stomach.
sideEffects: The seeds are toxic if crushed and eaten. The skin of the fruit may cause irritation for some.
regionsFound: Tropical Americas; cultivated in tropics worldwide.
preparation: The fruit pulp is eaten fresh. A paste from the leaves is used on the skin.
detailedExplanation: Sugar Apple is a very sweet and popular tropical fruit with a green, scaly skin. The creamy white pulp inside is eaten with a spoon. While the fruit is a treat, other parts of the plant, like the leaves, have traditional medicinal uses. Source: https://www.cabi.org/isc/datasheet/5820

medicinalUses: The root is processed to make table sugar. As a whole vegetable, it is a source of energy, fiber, and folate (a B vitamin).
sideEffects: The sugar made from it is safe in moderation. Eating too much sugar is unhealthy.
preparation: The root is refined to make white sugar.
detailedExplanation: The Sugar Beet is a farm crop grown specifically for sugar production. It provides about 20% of the world's sugar. While the pure sugar offers only calories, eating the whole beet provides some vitamins and fiber. Source: https://www.britannica.com/plant/sugar-beet

medicinalUses: The sap is boiled down to make maple syrup. The syrup contains antioxidants and minerals like manganese and zinc. The inner bark was used for coughs.
sideEffects: Very safe. Maple syrup is a healthier sweetener than white sugar but should still be used in moderation.
preparation: The sap is tapped from the tree and boiled to make syrup.
detailedExplanation: The Sugar Maple is the famous tree whose sap is used to make maple syrup. This natural sweetener contains more beneficial compounds than refined sugar. The tree is also famous for its brilliant fall colors. Source: https://www.britannica.com/plant/sugar-maple

medicinalUses: Sap (sugar) nutritive; various parts used as demulcent, mild tonic; pith/tubers used for digestive complaints; sap fermented for traditional tonics.
sideEffects: Sap generally safe; raw parts need hygienic handling.
preparation: Palm sap (toddy) collected and consumed; fruit and pith cooked or processed.
detailedExplanation: Arenga pinnata (sugar palm) yields edible sap, fruit and starch-rich pith; traditional uses include nutritive tonics and supportive digestive applications. Sap is a seasonal product and nutritive profile supports tonic use. Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arenga_pinnata.

medicinalUses: The crushed stalk produces juice that is a quick source of energy. The raw juice contains iron and other minerals. The wax from the stalk is used in cosmetics and polishes.
sideEffects: The juice is safe. The refined sugar from it should be eaten in limited amounts.
regionsFound: Cultivated in tropical and subtropical regions.
preparation: The cane is crushed to drink the juice, or refined to make sugar and jaggery.
detailedExplanation: Sugarcane is a giant grass and the primary source of sugar worldwide. Drinking fresh sugarcane juice provides natural sugars, electrolytes, and antioxidants. However, the refined sugar made from it is a source of "empty calories." Source: https://www.britannica.com/plant/sugarcane

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for mild digestive support, anti-inflammatory, and wound healing.
sideEffects: Rare mild allergy
preparation: Decoction, poultice
detailedExplanation: Sulphur Cinquefoil leaves and roots are brewed or applied externally to aid digestion, reduce inflammation, and promote minor wound healing. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for digestive support, mild anti-inflammatory, and antioxidant effects.
sideEffects: Rare mild allergy
preparation: Tea, decoction
detailedExplanation: Sumac berries and leaves are brewed as teas or decoctions to support digestion, reduce inflammation, and provide antioxidant benefits. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: This herb is an excellent digestive aid that can relieve gas, bloating, and stomach cramps. It also has mild antiseptic properties and can be used to soothe a sore throat. Traditionally used for digestive aid, mild antibacterial, and respiratory comfort.
sideEffects: Very safe and commonly used as a culinary herb.
regionsFound: Native to the Mediterranean region; cultivated worldwide.
preparation: The fresh or dried leaves are used in cooking, especially with beans. A tea can be made from the leaves.
detailedExplanation: Summer Savory is a popular kitchen herb with a warm, peppery flavor similar to thyme. It is most famous for being the classic herb used in traditional bean dishes, as it helps to prevent the gas often associated with eating beans. Its gentle antiseptic properties make it a good all-around herb for supporting digestive and respiratory health. Source: https://pfaf.org/user/Plant.aspx?LatinName=Satureja+hortensis

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for mild digestive support, cooling effect, and hair/skin care.
sideEffects: Rare mild allergy
preparation: Tea, decoction, poultice
detailedExplanation: Sun Rose flowers and leaves are brewed in teas or applied externally to aid digestion, provide cooling effects, and improve skin and hair health. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for respiratory support, cough relief, and mild antimicrobial purposes.
sideEffects: Rare digestive upset
preparation: Decoction, tincture
detailedExplanation: Sundew leaves are prepared as decoctions or tinctures to relieve mild coughs, soothe the respiratory tract, and provide antimicrobial support. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for mild anti-inflammatory, skin health, and hormonal balance.
sideEffects: Rare digestive upset
preparation: Oil, decoction
detailedExplanation: Sundrops seeds are processed to produce evening primrose oil, or decoctions are made from leaves and flowers to support inflammation reduction, skin health, and mild hormonal regulation. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for mild anti-inflammatory, cardiovascular support, and skin health.
sideEffects: Rare mild allergy
preparation: Oil, seeds, decoction
detailedExplanation: Sunflower seeds and oil are consumed or applied externally to reduce inflammation, support heart health, and improve skin condition. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Anti-inflammatory, wound healing
sideEffects: Allergic reactions rare
regionsFound: Native to Northeast India and Himalayan foothills
preparation: Leaf decoction
detailedExplanation: Abelmoschus manihot treats inflammation and wounds in folk remedies, with mucilage aiding skin repair. Important note: Edible leaves in some regions. Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abelmoschus_manihot

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for mild anti-inflammatory and wound healing purposes.
sideEffects: Rare mild digestive upset
preparation: Poultice, decoction
detailedExplanation: Swamp Candleberry bulbs and leaves are prepared as poultices or decoctions to reduce inflammation and aid minor wound healing. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for mild anti-inflammatory, digestive, and wound care purposes.
sideEffects: Rare digestive upset
preparation: Decoction, poultice
detailedExplanation: Swamp Loosestrife leaves and stems are brewed or applied externally to reduce inflammation, support digestion, and aid wound healing. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for mild anti-inflammatory, cardiovascular support, and digestive aid.
sideEffects: Rare mild allergy
preparation: Decoction, poultice
detailedExplanation: Swamp Milkweed leaves and roots are prepared as teas, decoctions, or poultices to support heart health, reduce inflammation, and aid digestion. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for mild digestive support, skin care, and anti-inflammatory effects.
sideEffects: Rare mild allergy
preparation: Tea, decoction, poultice
detailedExplanation: Swamp Rose petals and leaves are brewed into teas or applied as poultices to soothe digestive discomfort, improve skin condition, and reduce inflammation. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for mild respiratory support, digestive aid, and skin care.
sideEffects: Rare mild digestive upset
preparation: Tea, poultice
detailedExplanation: Swamp Rose Mallow flowers are brewed or applied externally to relieve mild respiratory discomfort, aid digestion, and support skin health. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Widely used for digestive support, respiratory relief, anti-inflammatory, and immune boosting.
sideEffects: Rare mild allergy
preparation: Tea, decoction, essential oil
detailedExplanation: Sweet Basil leaves are brewed as tea, decoctions, or used as essential oil to improve digestion, relieve mild respiratory issues, reduce inflammation, and boost immunity. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for mild pain relief, anti-inflammatory, and urinary support.
sideEffects: Rare skin irritation
preparation: Decoction, tincture
detailedExplanation: Sweet Birch bark and leaves are used in teas or tinctures to relieve mild pain, reduce inflammation, and support urinary tract health. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for mild digestive aid, appetite stimulation, and respiratory comfort.
sideEffects: Rare mild digestive upset
preparation: Tea, decoction
detailedExplanation: Sweet Cicely leaves and seeds are brewed into teas or decoctions to support digestion, stimulate appetite, and provide mild respiratory relief. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for digestive support, cognitive enhancement, and mild anti-inflammatory effects.
sideEffects: Rare digestive upset
preparation: Decoction, powder
detailedExplanation: Sweet Flag rhizomes are prepared as decoctions, powders, or teas to aid digestion, support brain function, and reduce mild inflammation. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Digestive stimulant, anti-inflammatory, improves appetite, Carminative, cognitive enhancer, anti-spasmodic.
sideEffects: High doses may cause dizziness or nausea
preparation: Rhizome decoction, powder
detailedExplanation: Acorus calamus (Sweet flag) is widely used in Ayurveda and folk medicine for digestive problems and as a mild sedative. Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Acorus_calamus

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for mild digestive support, diuretic, and anti-inflammatory purposes.
sideEffects: Rare digestive upset
preparation: Decoction, infusion
detailedExplanation: Sweet Gale leaves and bark are brewed as teas or decoctions to aid digestion, act as mild diuretic, and reduce inflammation. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for mild anti-inflammatory, respiratory, and digestive support.
sideEffects: Rare mild allergy
preparation: Decoction, resin
detailedExplanation: Sweet Gum resin and leaves are used in teas or decoctions to reduce inflammation, support respiratory health, and aid digestion. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Rich source of Vitamin C, supporting immune function and collagen synthesis. Contains dietary fiber aiding digestion and flavonoids with antioxidant properties.
sideEffects: Acidity can trigger heartburn or gastroesophageal reflux in susceptible individuals. Excessive consumption may lead to abdominal discomfort or diarrhea due to high fiber and sugar content.
regionsFound: Cultivated globally in tropical and subtropical belts (e.g., Brazil, USA, India, Spain, China)
preparation: Eaten fresh, juiced, or used in marmalades and culinary dishes. The zest is used for flavoring.
detailedExplanation: The Sweet Orange is one of the world's most popular fruits, valued for its sweet, juicy pulp. Its high Vitamin C content historically helped prevent scurvy. The fruit's soluble fiber, pectin, helps regulate bowel movements and may lower cholesterol. Beyond nutrition, its essential oil is used in aromatherapy for its uplifting scent. It is a significant agricultural crop, forming the backbone of many regional economies. Source: https://www.britannica.com/plant/orange-fruit

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for mild digestive aid, urinary support, and skin care.
sideEffects: Rare mild allergy
preparation: Decoction, poultice
detailedExplanation: Sweet Pepperbush leaves and bark are brewed or applied externally to support digestion, urinary tract, and skin health. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Anti-inflammatory, digestive, tonic
sideEffects: Rare
preparation: Flower decoction
detailedExplanation: Amberboa moschata is grown in Kashmir and used traditionally for digestion and inflammation. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK92771/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for mild digestive support, aroma therapy, and mild diuretic effects.
sideEffects: Rare mild allergy
preparation: Tea, infusion
detailedExplanation: Sweet Vernal Grass leaves are brewed as tea or infusion to aid digestion, provide calming aroma, and support mild diuresis. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: A soothing remedy for dry, persistent coughs and sore throats. The flowers and leaves make a syrup or tea that helps to loosen chest congestion and calm irritation. It is also very gentle and safe for children.
sideEffects: Extremely safe. No common side effects.
regionsFound: Native to Europe and Asia; cultivated worldwide.
preparation: A soothing syrup is made from the flowers. The leaves and flowers can be used to make a tea.
detailedExplanation: Sweet Violet is a small, fragrant plant with heart-shaped leaves and deep purple flowers. It is a classic herbal remedy for respiratory problems, especially those involving thick, hard-to-cough-up mucus. Its soothing properties come from a natural gelatinous substance (mucilage) that coats and protects the throat. Source: https://www.botanical.com/botanical/mgmh/v/vioswe10.html

medicinalUses: This plant is grown exclusively for its beautiful, clustered flowers. It is not used in herbal medicine and should not be consumed.
sideEffects: Not considered edible.
regionsFound: Native to Southern Europe; cultivated in gardens worldwide.
preparation: Not used for medicine or food.
detailedExplanation: Sweet William is a popular garden plant prized for its dense, flat-topped clusters of small, brightly colored flowers with a spicy, clove-like scent. It is a classic choice for cottage gardens and borders. Its value is purely ornamental, and it has no role in herbalism. Source: https://www.rhs.org.uk/plants/5743/dianthus-barbatus/details

medicinalUses: When dried, this plant develops a sweet, hay-like scent and is used to flavor drinks and liqueurs. In traditional medicine, a mild tea was used to calm nerves and aid digestion, but it is not a common remedy today.
sideEffects: Contains coumarin, which can be toxic to the liver in very high doses. Use in very small amounts only.
regionsFound: Native to Europe, North Africa, and Western Asia.
preparation: The dried plant is used to flavor May wine and other beverages. A very weak tea can be made.
detailedExplanation: Sweet Woodruff is a low-growing plant that forms a dense mat in shady areas. It is famous for its use in German "Maibowle" (May wine). The sweet scent appears as the plant wilts and dries. While it has a history of folk use, its potential toxicity means it should be used sparingly and for flavor, not as a medicine. Source: https://www.britannica.com/plant/sweet-woodruff

medicinalUses: The fragrant leaves are used to make a tea that soothes stomach aches, diarrhea, and skin rashes. It is a strong astringent, meaning it helps to dry up and tighten tissues, reducing secretions and inflammation.
sideEffects: Very safe.
preparation: A tea is made from the dried leaves for drinking or applied to the skin as a wash.
detailedExplanation: Sweetfern is not a true fern but a shrub with narrow, fern-like leaves that release a wonderful spicy-sweet fragrance when crushed. It is a valuable and well-regarded folk remedy in North America for its powerful ability to calm an upset digestive system and soothe itchy skin conditions like poison ivy. Source: https://www.fs.usda.gov/database/feis/plants/shrub/comper/all.html

medicinalUses: This plant is not used for medicine. It is a very important native prairie grass used for soil conservation, as a biofuel crop, and as habitat for wildlife.
sideEffects: Not used for medicine.
preparation: Not used for medicine or food.
detailedExplanation: Switchgrass is a tall, tough grass that once covered vast areas of the North American prairie. It is a "keystone species" for ecosystem health, preventing soil erosion and providing food and cover for birds and animals. Today, it is also being developed as a sustainable source of bioenergy. Source: https://www.fs.usda.gov/database/feis/plants/graminoid/panvir/all.html

medicinalUses: The root (rhizome) has been used in traditional medicine to soothe sore throats and treat minor wounds and skin sores. However, it is not a common modern remedy.
sideEffects: Generally considered non-toxic, but not well-studied for internal use.
preparation: A decoction (strong tea) was made from the root for gargling. A poultice was made for the skin.
detailedExplanation: The Sword Fern is a large, common fern of the Pacific Northwest forests, with dark green, sharp-toothed fronds. Native American tribes used its root for various ailments. While it may have soothing properties, it is not a primary herb in modern herbal practice and is more valued for its ecological role and ornamental beauty in shade gardens. Source: https://www.fs.fed.us/database/feis/plants/fern/polmun/all.html

medicinalUses: This plant is a powerful and potentially dangerous hallucinogen and medicine. It contains MAO-inhibiting compounds and is used in traditional rituals, but it is very toxic and can be fatal if misused.
sideEffects: Causes severe nausea, vomiting, tremors, and dangerously high blood pressure. Can be fatal.
regionsFound: Native to the Middle East and Central Asia; invasive in other arid regions.
preparation: NOT FOR HOME USE. Used in very controlled traditional settings by experienced practitioners.
detailedExplanation: Syrian Rue is a small, shrubby plant of deserts and dry areas. Its seeds contain powerful alkaloids that affect the brain and nervous system. While it has a deep history in traditional medicine and spiritual practices, its extreme toxicity and narrow safety margin make it one of the most dangerous plants to experiment with. Source: https://www.poison.org/articles/syrian-rue

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for skin healing, anti-inflammatory, and mild pain relief.
sideEffects: Rare skin irritation
preparation: Resin, ointment
detailedExplanation: Tacamahac resin is applied topically or prepared as ointments to aid wound healing, soothe inflammation, and reduce mild pain. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for digestive support, mild anti-inflammatory, and respiratory aid.
sideEffects: Rare mild allergy
preparation: Tea, decoction
detailedExplanation: Tall Thistle leaves and roots are brewed as teas or decoctions to aid digestion, reduce inflammation, and support mild respiratory relief. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for skin care, mild anti-inflammatory, and oil production for external use.
sideEffects: Rare skin irritation
preparation: Oil, poultice
detailedExplanation: Tallow Tree seeds are processed for oil used externally, while leaves are made into poultices to reduce inflammation and improve skin condition. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for mild respiratory support, anti-inflammatory, and antiseptic purposes.
sideEffects: Rare skin irritation
preparation: Tea, decoction
detailedExplanation: Tamarack needles and bark are brewed as teas or decoctions to relieve mild respiratory issues, reduce inflammation, and provide antiseptic support. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for digestive aid, mild laxative, and antioxidant support.
sideEffects: Rare mild digestive upset
preparation: Pulp, decoction, paste
detailedExplanation: Tamarind pulp is consumed directly or in teas to improve digestion, act as a mild laxative, and provide antioxidant benefits. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for mild diuretic, anti-inflammatory, and digestive support.
sideEffects: Rare mild allergy
preparation: Tea, decoction
detailedExplanation: Tamarisk leaves and bark are brewed into teas or decoctions to support digestion, mild inflammation reduction, and diuretic effects. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for mild anti-inflammatory, digestive aid, and tannin extraction for external use.
sideEffects: Rare mild allergy
preparation: Decoction, poultice
detailedExplanation: Tanbark Oak bark is brewed or applied externally to reduce mild inflammation, support digestion, and utilize tannins for skin care. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for digestive support, mild anti-parasitic, and anti-inflammatory effects.
sideEffects: Rare nausea, vomiting if overused
preparation: Tea, decoction
detailedExplanation: Tansy leaves and flowers are brewed as teas or decoctions to support digestion, combat mild parasitic infections, and reduce inflammation. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Used for digestive disorders, anti-inflammatory, aromatic
sideEffects: Rare
preparation: Leaf/ rhizome decoction
detailedExplanation: Alpinia allughas is cultivated in Northeast India for medicinal uses including digestive and anti-inflammatory purposes. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK92771/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for digestive aid, mild anti-inflammatory, and nutritional support.
sideEffects: Rare mild allergy
preparation: Boiled, decoction, paste
detailedExplanation: Taro corms are boiled or prepared as decoctions to aid digestion, reduce mild inflammation, and provide carbohydrates and nutrients. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: A popular culinary herb that also stimulates appetite and aids digestion. It has a mild numbing effect that can relieve toothache and is used to promote restful sleep.
sideEffects: Very safe in culinary amounts.Generally safe culinary use; concentrated essential oils can irritate mucosa.
regionsFound: Native to Europe and Asia; cultivated worldwide.
preparation: The fresh or dried leaves are used in cooking, particularly in sauces. A tea can be made from the leaves.
detailedExplanation: Tarragon is a flavorful herb with a subtle anise-like taste, essential in French cuisine. Beyond its culinary use, it acts as a gentle digestive bitter, stimulating the production of saliva and digestive juices. Its mild sedative and analgesic properties have also been noted in folk medicine. Source: https://www.britannica.com/plant/tarragon

medicinalUses: The leaves are a primary source of eucalyptus oil, a powerful decongestant and antiseptic. Used in steam inhalations to clear sinus and bronchial congestion, and in topical rubs for muscle aches.
sideEffects: The essential oil is toxic if swallowed. Use in well-ventilated areas during inhalation.
regionsFound: Native to Tasmania and Southeastern Australia; cultivated worldwide.
preparation: The essential oil is diluted and used in steam inhalation or in topical balms.
detailedExplanation: The Tasmanian Blue Gum is a fast-growing tree famous for its menthol-like aroma. It is the main commercial source of the medicinal eucalyptus oil found in many over-the-counter cold remedies. Its powerful scent helps open up breathing passages and its antiseptic properties help fight respiratory infections. Source: https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/agricultural-and-biological-sciences/eucalyptus-globulus

scientificName: Tawa Nesbitt, Smith, Irmis, Turner, Downs & Norell, 2009
medicinalUses: This tree is primarily valued for its high-quality timber. The fruit is edible but not well-known for specific medicinal properties.
sideEffects: The fruit is safe to eat.
preparation: The fruit is eaten by native birds and was historically consumed by Māori people.
detailedExplanation: The Tawa tree is a dominant canopy tree in New Zealand's lowland forests. It produces a purple, plum-like fruit. While the tree is ecologically and culturally important, particularly for its strong, flexible wood, it is not a significant plant in global herbal medicine. Source: https://www.doc.govt.nz/nature/native-plants/tawa/

medicinalUses: The leaves are used to make a flavorful tea that is a natural pain reliever for headaches, muscle pain, and arthritis. The active compound (methyl salicylate) is similar to aspirin.
sideEffects: Very safe in tea form. The concentrated oil is toxic if ingested.
preparation: A tea is made from the dried leaves. The leaves can also be chewed for their flavor.
detailedExplanation: Tea Berry, or Wintergreen, is a low-growing plant with aromatic leaves and red berries. The leaves contain methyl salicylate, which gives them their characteristic "wintergreen" scent and pain-relieving properties. It was a common folk remedy and the original source of wintergreen flavoring. Source: https://www.fs.fed.us/database/feis/plants/shrub/gaupro/all.html

medicinalUses: The source of all true tea (green, black, white, oolong). Rich in antioxidants (catechins) that boost heart health, may help prevent cancer, improve mental alertness (due to caffeine and L-theanine), and support metabolism.
sideEffects: Contains caffeine, which can cause insomnia, nervousness, or stomach upset in sensitive individuals.
regionsFound: Native to East Asia; cultivated in tropical and subtropical highlands worldwide.
preparation: The leaves are processed in various ways (steamed, fermented, dried) to produce different types of tea.
detailedExplanation: The Tea Plant is the source of the world's most popular beverage after water. The way the leaves are processed determines the type of tea and its health properties. Green tea is highest in antioxidants, while black tea is fully oxidized. The combination of caffeine and L-theanine provides a unique, focused energy without the jitters of coffee. Source: https://www.britannica.com/plant/tea-plant

medicinalUses: The essential oil is a powerful, broad-spectrum antiseptic. It is used topically to treat acne, fungal infections (like athlete's foot), and to disinfect minor cuts, burns, and insect bites.
sideEffects: The essential oil is for external use only and must be diluted. It can cause skin irritation in some people.
preparation: The essential oil is diluted in a carrier oil (like coconut oil) and applied to the skin.
detailedExplanation: The Tea Tree is a small tree whose leaves are steam-distilled to produce a potent essential oil. It has been used for centuries by Indigenous Australians for its healing properties. It is a staple in natural medicine cabinets for its ability to fight a wide range of bacteria, viruses, and fungi. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK92777/

medicinalUses: The wood is one of the world's most valuable timbers, prized for its durability and water resistance. The leaves and bark have been used in traditional medicine to treat headaches, inflammation, and skin diseases.
sideEffects: The wood dust can cause allergic skin reactions.
regionsFound: Native to South and Southeast Asia; cultivated in tropics.
preparation: The wood is used for furniture, carving, and shipbuilding. A paste or decoction is made from the leaves and bark.
detailedExplanation: Teak is a massive tree famous for its golden-brown wood that is extremely durable, even in harsh weather. This makes it ideal for outdoor furniture and boat decks. While its primary value is timber, various parts of the tree have a place in Ayurvedic and other traditional medicine systems for their anti-inflammatory properties. Source: https://www.britannica.com/plant/teak

medicinalUses: The root is used in traditional medicine, particularly for treating Lyme disease, due to its potential antibacterial activity. It is also used for joint pain and as a diuretic.
sideEffects: Not well-studied for safety.
regionsFound: Native to Europe and Asia; introduced in North America.
preparation: A tincture or decoction is made from the root.
detailedExplanation: Teasel is a striking plant with prickly stems and egg-shaped flower heads that were historically used in the textile industry to "tease" or raise the nap on woolen cloth. In modern herbalism, it has gained attention as a supportive therapy for Lyme disease, though scientific evidence is limited. Source: https://www.pfaf.org/user/Plant.aspx?LatinName=Dipsacus+fullonum

medicinalUses: This plant is famous for its rapid leaf movements, not for medicine. It is grown as a botanical curiosity.
sideEffects: Not used for medicine.
regionsFound: Native to Southeast Asia and South Asia.
preparation: Not used for medicine or food.
detailedExplanation: The Telegraph Plant is a fascinating shrub whose small side leaflets move in slow, jerky circles over a period of minutes. This movement is thought to help the plant find the best position for sunlight. It has no significant history of medicinal use and is valued for its unique behavior. Source: https://www.britannica.com/plant/telegraph-plant

medicinalUses: The fragrant flowers are used in aromatherapy for their uplifting and calming scent. The bark and leaves have been used in traditional medicine to treat skin inflammation and as a laxative, but the milky sap is irritating.
sideEffects: The milky sap is toxic and can cause skin irritation and blindness if it gets in the eyes.
regionsFound: Native to Central and South America; cultivated in tropics worldwide.
preparation: The flowers are used to make fragrant leis and in perfumery.
detailedExplanation: The Temple Tree, or Frangipani, is renowned for its incredibly beautiful and fragrant flowers, which are used in Hawaiian leis and temple offerings. While it has a place in traditional medicine, its primary value is ornamental and cultural. The sap is a strong irritant and the plant should be handled with care. Source: https://www.britannica.com/plant/frangipani

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for mild digestive aid, anti-inflammatory, and diuretic support.
sideEffects: Rare mild allergy
preparation: Decoction, infusion
detailedExplanation: Texas Plume leaves and flowers are brewed as teas or decoctions to support digestion, reduce inflammation, and provide mild diuretic effects. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for mild respiratory relief, anti-inflammatory, and skin support.
sideEffects: Rare mild skin irritation
preparation: Decoction, poultice
detailedExplanation: Texas Sage leaves and flowers are brewed or applied externally to relieve mild respiratory discomfort, reduce inflammation, and support skin health. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for mild digestive support, anti-inflammatory, and antioxidant benefits.
sideEffects: Rare mild allergy
preparation: Tea, decoction, fruit consumption
detailedExplanation: Thimbleberry leaves and fruits are consumed or brewed as teas to aid digestion, reduce mild inflammation, and provide antioxidant support. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Like many thistles, the root has been used as a tonic and to support digestion. However, it is not a major medicinal herb.
sideEffects: The plant is very spiny and can cause physical injury.
regionsFound: Europe and Asia; in wet meadows and marshes.
preparation: Not commonly used.
detailedExplanation: The Marsh Thistle is a tall, spiny plant that thrives in wet ground. While it is not a primary medicinal plant, thistles in general have a history of use as gentle digestive tonics. Its main role is ecological, providing nectar for pollinators. Source: https://www.brc.ac.uk/plantatlas/plant/cirsium-palustre

medicinalUses: This is a premier liver-protective herb. It helps to regenerate liver cells, protect against toxins (like alcohol and mushrooms), and is used for hepatitis, cirrhosis, and gallbladder issues.
sideEffects: Very safe. May have a mild laxative effect in some people.
regionsFound: Native to the Mediterranean; found worldwide.
preparation: The seeds are ground and used in capsules, tinctures, or tea.
detailedExplanation: Milk Thistle is one of the most well-researched medicinal plants. Its seeds contain a group of compounds called silymarin, which are powerful antioxidants specifically for the liver. It can help the liver repair itself and filter out harmful substances. Source: https://www.nccih.nih.gov/health/milk-thistle

medicinalUses: This plant is primarily considered a noxious weed. It has no well-documented medicinal benefits and is a problem in pastures and natural areas.
sideEffects: The plant is very spiny.
regionsFound: Native to Europe and Asia; invasive in North America.
preparation: Not used for medicine.
detailedExplanation: The Musk Thistle is an invasive plant with large, nodding, pink flower heads. It forms dense stands that crowd out native plants and reduce pasture quality for livestock. Its impact is negative, and efforts are made to control its spread. Source: https://www.invasive.org/weedcd/pdfs/wow/musk-thistle.pdf

medicinalUses: This plant is primarily considered a noxious weed. It has no well-documented medicinal benefits and is a problem in pastures and natural areas.
sideEffects: The plant is very spiny.
regionsFound: Native to Europe and Asia; invasive in North America.
preparation: Not used for medicine.
detailedExplanation: The Nodding Thistle is the same plant as the Musk Thistle (Carduus nutans). It is named for its large flower heads that bend over ("nod") on their stems. It is a major agricultural pest. Source: https://www.cabi.org/isc/datasheet/10663

medicinalUses: This plant is primarily considered a noxious weed. It has no well-documented medicinal benefits and is a problem in pastures and natural areas.
sideEffects: The plant is very spiny.
regionsFound: Native to Europe and Asia; invasive in North America.
preparation: Not used for medicine.
detailedExplanation: The Plumeless Thistle is another invasive species closely related to the Musk Thistle. It is a problem in rangelands and disturbed areas, forming dense, prickly stands. Source: https://www.invasive.org/weedcd/pdfs/wow/plumeless-thistle.pdf

medicinalUses: The young shoots and leaves are edible and can be cooked as a leafy green vegetable. It is a hardy plant of arid environments.
sideEffects: The mature plant is very prickly and difficult to handle.
regionsFound: Native to Russia and central Asia; invasive worldwide.
preparation: Only the very young, tender shoots are harvested and cooked like spinach.
detailedExplanation: Russian Thistle is the plant that famously dries up, breaks from its roots, and tumbles across the landscape, scattering its seeds. While it is a notorious agricultural weed, the young plants are edible and nutritious. Source: https://www.cabi.org/isc/datasheet/108005

medicinalUses: The root has been used as a tonic and astringent. The young stalks and peeled stems are edible and nutritious.
sideEffects: The plant is covered in sharp spines that can cause physical injury.
regionsFound: Native to Europe and Asia; naturalized in North America.
preparation: Young stalks are peeled and eaten raw or cooked. A decoction can be made from the root.
detailedExplanation: The Scotch Thistle is a robust and very spiny plant that is the national emblem of Scotland. While not a major medicinal herb, it is a valuable wild edible if one can navigate its defenses. It is also an important plant for pollinators like goldfinches. Source: https://www.cabi.org/isc/datasheet/13466

medicinalUses: The root has been used as a tonic and astringent. The young stalks and peeled stems are edible and nutritious.
sideEffects: The plant is covered in sharp spines that can cause physical injury.
regionsFound: Native to Europe and Asia; naturalized in North America.
preparation: Young stalks are peeled and eaten raw or cooked. A decoction can be made from the root.
detailedExplanation: The Spear Thistle is another common name for the same plant as the Scotch Thistle (Cirsium vulgare). It is named for its spear-like spines. All its uses and characteristics are identical. Source: https://www.pfaf.org/user/Plant.aspx?LatinName=Cirsium+vulgare

medicinalUses: This plant is primarily considered a weed. It has no well-documented medicinal benefits and can be toxic to horses, causing a nervous disorder called "chewing disease."
sideEffects: The plant is spiny. Can be toxic to livestock.
regionsFound: Native to the Mediterranean; introduced elsewhere.
preparation: Not used for medicine.
detailedExplanation: The Star Thistle is a prickly plant with purple flowers surrounded by sharp, straw-colored spines that form a star-like shape. It is an invasive species in many regions and is known for its toxicity to horses. Source: https://www.cabi.org/isc/datasheet/12000

medicinalUses: This plant is not a major medicinal herb. It is sometimes considered a weed, though it is not as aggressively invasive as some other thistles.
sideEffects: The plant is spiny.
regionsFound: Native to Europe and Asia; introduced in North America.
preparation: Not commonly used.
detailedExplanation: The Welted Thistle has winged stems and nodding flower heads. It is less common than other invasive thistles. While it may have the general tonic properties shared by the thistle family, it is not a plant that is sought out for herbal use. Source: https://www.pfaf.org/user/Plant.aspx?LatinName=Carduus+crispus

medicinalUses: Traditionally used to stimulate digestion, support liver function, and aid mild detoxification.
sideEffects: Rare digestive upset
preparation: Tea, tincture
detailedExplanation: Blessed Thistle leaves and flowers are brewed into teas or tinctures to support digestion, liver health, and mild detoxification. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for digestive aid, mild anti-inflammatory, and diuretic support.
sideEffects: Rare mild allergy
preparation: Tea, decoction
detailedExplanation: Canada Thistle leaves are brewed as teas or decoctions to aid digestion, reduce inflammation, and provide mild diuretic effects. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for digestive stimulation, mild anti-inflammatory, and antimicrobial support.

sideEffects: Rare mild allergy

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for digestive stimulation, liver support, and mild anti-inflammatory effects.
sideEffects: Rare digestive upset
preparation: Tea, tincture
detailedExplanation: Holy Thistle leaves and flowers are brewed into teas or tinctures to support digestion, liver health, and reduce mild inflammation. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for digestive support, liver health, and mild anti-inflammatory effects.
sideEffects: Rare mild allergy
preparation: Tea, decoction
detailedExplanation: Woolly Thistle leaves and roots are brewed as teas or decoctions to improve digestion, support liver function, and reduce mild inflammation. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for respiratory relief, pain reduction, and mild sedative effects.
sideEffects: Hallucination, dizziness if overused
preparation: Tea, inhalation
detailedExplanation: Thorn Apple leaves and seeds are used in controlled preparations to ease respiratory issues, reduce pain, and provide mild sedative effects. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for digestive support, mild anti-inflammatory, and diuretic purposes.
sideEffects: Rare mild allergy
preparation: Tea, decoction, fruit consumption
detailedExplanation: Black Thorn leaves, flowers, and fruits are brewed as teas or decoctions or eaten as jams to aid digestion, reduce inflammation, and support urinary function. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for mild anti-inflammatory, digestive aid, and wound healing.
sideEffects: Rare mild allergy
preparation: Decoction, poultice
detailedExplanation: Christ's Thorn leaves and bark are brewed or applied externally to reduce inflammation, support digestion, and aid wound healing. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for anti-inflammatory, mild diuretic, and skin-care applications.
sideEffects: Rare mild allergy
preparation: Decoction, poultice
detailedExplanation: Jerusalem Thorn leaves and bark are used in teas or applied externally to reduce inflammation, support diuresis, and improve skin conditions. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for mild digestive aid, anti-inflammatory, and diuretic purposes.
sideEffects: Rare mild allergy
preparation: Tea, decoction
detailedExplanation: Thorny Olive leaves are brewed into teas or decoctions to support digestion, reduce mild inflammation, and provide diuretic effects. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for mild diuretic support, digestive aid, and anti-inflammatory purposes.
sideEffects: Rare mild allergy
preparation: Tea, decoction

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for mild fever reduction, digestive aid, and respiratory support.
sideEffects: Rare mild nausea
preparation: Tea, tincture
detailedExplanation: Thoroughwort leaves and flowers are brewed into teas or tinctures to help reduce mild fevers, aid digestion, and support respiratory health. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for digestive aid, anti-inflammatory, and mild antimicrobial support.
sideEffects: Rare mild allergy
preparation: Decoction, paste
detailedExplanation: Three-leaved Caper leaves and bark are brewed or applied externally to aid digestion, reduce inflammation, and provide mild antimicrobial benefits. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Anti-inflammatory, skin tonic
sideEffects: Rare
preparation: Leaf decoction
detailedExplanation: Traditionally used in Himalayan medicine for inflammation and skin care. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK92771/

medicinalUses: This plant is primarily grown for its ornamental beauty in rock gardens. It has no well-known medicinal uses.
sideEffects: Non-toxic but not used for medicine.
regionsFound: Coastal regions of the Northern Hemisphere.
preparation: Not used for medicine or food.
detailedExplanation: Thrift is a tough, low-growing plant that forms dense mounds of grass-like leaves and produces round, pink flower heads on long stalks. It is exceptionally tolerant of salty, windy coastal conditions. Its value is purely decorative and ecological, helping to stabilize coastal soils. Source: https://www.rhs.org.uk/plants/1533/armeria-maritima/details

medicinalUses: A powerful antiseptic for the respiratory system. The tea is excellent for treating bronchitis, whooping cough, and sore throats. It also relieves gas and supports healthy digestion.
sideEffects: Very safe in culinary and tea amounts.
preparation: The leaves are used in cooking or to make a strong tea.
detailedExplanation: Common Thyme is a staple culinary herb with a warm, pungent aroma. Its medicinal power comes from the compound thymol, which is a potent antimicrobial. It is one of the best herbs for fighting lung infections and calming a spasmodic cough. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC8568219/

medicinalUses: Similar to common thyme, it is used for coughs and as a digestive aid. It is also a popular ornamental groundcover.
sideEffects: Very safe.
preparation: The aerial parts are used to make a tea.
detailedExplanation: Creeping Thyme is a very low-growing species that spreads horizontally to form a dense mat. It is covered in tiny, aromatic leaves and flowers. It is often used in landscaping for its beauty and fragrance, and it can be used medicinally in the same way as common thyme. Source: https://www.fs.usda.gov/database/feis/plants/shrub/thyser/all.html

medicinalUses: Has a bright, lemony flavor and the medicinal properties of thyme. The tea can help with respiratory issues and digestion, and the scent is uplifting.
sideEffects: Very safe.
regionsFound: Cultivated hybrid; grown in gardens worldwide.
preparation: The leaves are used in cooking (especially with poultry and fish) or to make a refreshing tea.
detailedExplanation: Lemon Thyme is a delightful variety that combines the warm, medicinal qualities of thyme with a fresh, citrusy aroma from the compound citral. It is excellent in the kitchen and makes a pleasant-tasting tea for soothing a sore throat or calming the stomach. Source: https://www.rhs.org.uk/plants/91615/thymus-citriodorus/details

medicinalUses: A low-growing thyme used as a fragrant groundcover. It shares the antiseptic properties of common thyme and can be used in tea for coughs and digestive issues.
sideEffects: Very safe.
preparation: The aerial parts are used to make a tea.
detailedExplanation: Mother of Thyme is a mat-forming plant that creates a fragrant carpet of tiny leaves and pinkish-purple flowers. It is often planted between stepping stones. While it is mainly ornamental, it can be used medicinally like other thymes, offering a gentle remedy for respiratory and digestive discomfort. Source: https://www.rhs.org.uk/plants/91619/thymus-praecox/details

medicinalUses: Used as a tea for bronchitis, coughs, and flatulence. It is a gentle but effective antiseptic for the lungs and gut.
sideEffects: Very safe.
preparation: The aerial parts are used to make a tea.
detailedExplanation: Wild Thyme is the same species as Creeping Thyme. It is a hardy plant of heaths and grasslands. It has been used in European folk medicine for centuries as a remedy for chest complaints and children's coughs. It is considered slightly milder than common thyme. Source: https://www.botanical.com/botanical/mgmh/t/thywil16.html

medicinalUses: This small plant is not a major medicinal herb. It has been used in traditional medicine as a mild diuretic and to soothe skin irritations.
sideEffects: Considered non-toxic but not well-studied.
preparation: A tea can be made from the aerial parts. A poultice can be made from the crushed leaves.
detailedExplanation: Thyme-leaved Sandwort is a common, low-growing weed of dry, sandy soils. Its leaves are small and resemble those of thyme. While it has a minor place in folk medicine, it is not a plant that is widely used or recognized in modern herbal practice. Source: https://www.pfaf.org/user/Plant.aspx?LatinName=Arenaria+serpyllifolia

medicinalUses: The root is an extremely bitter digestive tonic. It stimulates appetite, improves the absorption of food, and supports liver and gallbladder function.
sideEffects: The intense bitterness can be overwhelming.
regionsFound: Himalayan region of Tibet and Nepal.
preparation: The root is used in small doses in tinctures or bitter tonics.
detailedExplanation: Tibetan Gentian is a high-altitude plant with a root that is one of the most bitter substances known. This bitterness is key to its medicinal value, as it powerfully stimulates the entire digestive process. It is a key herb in Tibetan traditional medicine for treating weak digestion and loss of appetite. Source: https://www.flowersofindia.net/catalog/slides/Tibetan%20Gentian.html

medicinalUses: This plant is not a major medicinal herb. Some species have been used in traditional medicine for skin problems and as a diuretic.
sideEffects: The seed pods are covered in tiny hooks that stick to clothing and animal fur.
regionsFound: Found in temperate and tropical regions worldwide.
preparation: Not commonly used.
detailedExplanation: Tick Trefoil is a plant best known for its small, flat seed pods that are covered in sticky hairs, allowing them to hitchhike on passing animals (and hikers). While some related plants are used in Chinese medicine, this genus is not a primary source of herbal medicine. Source: https://www.fs.fed.us/database/feis/plants/forb/descan/all.html

medicinalUses: This plant is highly poisonous and has no safe medicinal use. It was historically used by some tribes, but its toxicity is extreme.
sideEffects: All parts are toxic. Causes severe vomiting, low blood pressure, and can be fatal.
preparation: NOT FOR MEDICINAL USE.
detailedExplanation: Tickleweed is a tall, striking plant of mountain meadows. Despite its common name, it is a dangerous neurotoxin. It is famous for causing severe birth defects in lambs when eaten by pregnant ewes. It should be identified and strictly avoided. Source: https://www.poison.org/articles/tickleweed

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for mild digestive support, antioxidant benefits, and general wellness.
sideEffects: Rare mild allergy
preparation: Tea, infusion
detailedExplanation: Tickseed flowers are brewed as teas or infusions to support digestion, provide antioxidant benefits, and promote overall health. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for mild anti-inflammatory effects, digestive support, and immune wellness.
sideEffects: Rare mild allergy
preparation: Tea, infusion
detailedExplanation: Tickseed Sunflower petals and leaves are brewed into teas to reduce mild inflammation, support digestion, and promote immunity. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for respiratory relief, menstrual support, and mild anti-inflammatory purposes.
sideEffects: Rare mild allergy
preparation: Decoction, infusion
detailedExplanation: Tiger Lily bulbs and flowers are brewed into teas or decoctions to support respiratory health, ease menstrual discomfort, and reduce mild inflammation. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for immune support, anti-inflammatory effects, and digestive health.
sideEffects: Rare mild nausea
preparation: Tea, tincture
detailedExplanation: Tiger’s Claw bark and leaves are brewed or prepared as tinctures to strengthen immunity, reduce inflammation, and support digestive health. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used topically for skin healing, mild anti-inflammatory, and wound support.
sideEffects: Rare skin irritation
preparation: Poultice, topical paste
detailedExplanation: Tiger's Jaws leaves are applied externally as poultices to help heal minor wounds, reduce inflammation, and soothe skin irritation. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for relaxation, mild sedative effects, and respiratory relief.
sideEffects: Rare mild dizziness
preparation: Tea, infusion
detailedExplanation: Tilia flowers and leaves are brewed as teas or infusions to promote relaxation, ease mild anxiety, support sleep, and relieve mild respiratory discomfort. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for hay fever relief, mild diuretic support, and digestive aid.
sideEffects: Rare mild allergy
preparation: Tea, infusion
detailedExplanation: Timothy Grass leaves are brewed as teas to relieve mild allergy symptoms, support mild diuresis, and aid digestion. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for immunity boosting, anti-inflammatory effects, and digestive support.
sideEffects: Rare mild nausea
preparation: Decoction, juice
detailedExplanation: Tinospora stem and leaves are brewed into teas or consumed as juice to enhance immunity, reduce inflammation, and improve digestion. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Anti-inflammatory, used in rheumatism, wound healing
sideEffects: Rare allergic reaction
preparation: Leaf decoction, paste
detailedExplanation: Allophylus cobbe is a coastal medicinal shrub used traditionally in Ayurveda for rheumatism and wound care. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK92771/

medicinalUses: Nutritional fruit, mild antioxidant properties
sideEffects: None widely reported
preparation: Raw fruit consumption
detailedExplanation: Alectryon excelsus is cultivated in NE India for its edible fruits with nutritional and mild antioxidant benefits. Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alectryon_excelsus

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for mild anti-inflammatory effects and antioxidant support.
sideEffects: Rare mild allergy
preparation: Tea, decoction
detailedExplanation: Toad Lily leaves and flowers are brewed into teas to provide antioxidant benefits and reduce mild inflammation. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for mild diuretic, liver support, and digestive aid.
sideEffects: Rare mild allergy
preparation: Tea, infusion
detailedExplanation: Toadflax leaves and flowers are brewed as teas or infusions to support liver function, aid digestion, and promote mild diuresis. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: This plant is highly addictive and causes cancer, heart disease, and lung disease. It has no safe medicinal use. The nicotine in it is a powerful insecticide.
sideEffects: Addiction, cancer, heart disease, stroke, lung disease.
regionsFound: Native to the Americas; cultivated worldwide.
preparation: NOT FOR MEDICINAL USE.
detailedExplanation: Tobacco is a plant grown for its leaves, which are dried and used in smoking and chewing products. While nicotine has been studied for certain neurological conditions, the extreme health risks of any form of tobacco use far outweigh any potential benefits. It is one of the leading causes of preventable death worldwide. Source: https://www.who.int/news-room/fact-sheets/detail/tobacco

medicinalUses: The root has sedative properties similar to Common Valerian, used to calm anxiety and promote sleep. It was also an important food source for Native Americans.
sideEffects: Generally safe. May cause drowsiness.
preparation: The root can be cooked and eaten or dried for use as a sedative tea.
detailedExplanation: Tobacco Root is a relative of the common valerian. Its thick, starchy root was a staple food for some tribes, tasting like parsnip when cooked. When dried, the root develops sedative properties, making it a useful plant for both food and medicine in traditional cultures. Source: https://www.fs.fed.us/database/feis/plants/forab/valedu/all.html

medicinalUses: The fruit is a nutritious food, rich in vitamins and antioxidants. In traditional medicine, it is used to soothe sore throats and reduce fever.
sideEffects: The unripe fruit, leaves, and stem are toxic. Only the ripe fruit inside the papery husk is edible.
regionsFound: Native to Mexico; cultivated in warm regions.
preparation: The ripe fruit is eaten raw in salsas, cooked in sauces, or made into jam.
detailedExplanation: The Tomatillo is a key ingredient in Mexican green sauces. It grows inside a papery, lantern-like husk. The ripe, green or purple fruit is tart and flavorful. It is a healthy addition to the diet and has a history of folk use for common ailments. Source: https://www.britannica.com/plant/tomatillo

medicinalUses: A highly nutritious fruit rich in Lycopene, a powerful antioxidant linked to reduced risk of heart disease and certain cancers (especially prostate cancer). Also a good source of Vitamin C and potassium.
sideEffects: Very safe. The green parts of the plant are toxic.
regionsFound: Native to South America; cultivated worldwide.
preparation: Eaten raw in salads, cooked in sauces, soups, and stews.
detailedExplanation: The Tomato is one of the world's most popular vegetables (though it is botanically a fruit). Its red color comes from lycopene, which becomes more available to the body when the tomato is cooked. It is a cornerstone of a healthy diet. Source: https://www.britannica.com/plant/tomato

medicinalUses: The seeds contain coumarin, which has a sweet, vanilla-like scent and is used in perfumes. It is banned as a food additive in many countries because coumarin is toxic to the liver and kidneys in high doses.
sideEffects: Liver and kidney damage with high or prolonged use.
preparation: Not for consumption. Used in very small amounts in perfumery.
detailedExplanation: The Tonka Bean is a seed from a tropical tree known for its incredibly rich fragrance, a mix of vanilla, almond, and cinnamon. While it smells wonderful, the high concentration of coumarin makes it dangerous to eat. It is primarily a fragrance ingredient. Source: https://www.poison.org/articles/tonka-bean

medicinalUses: The flowers and leaves contain a powerful natural anesthetic. Chewing them causes a tingling, numbing sensation that provides fast, temporary relief from toothaches and gum pain.
sideEffects: The numbing sensation can be very intense and may cause excessive salivation.
regionsFound: Native to Brazil; cultivated in tropics.
preparation: A fresh flower head is chewed for a minute or two to relieve pain.
detailedExplanation: The Toothache Plant produces unique, button-like yellow and red flowers. Its active compound, spilanthol, is a powerful local anesthetic that has been used across many cultures as a natural remedy for oral pain. It is a fascinating and effective first-aid plant. Source: https://uses.plantnet-project.org/en/Acmella_oleracea_(PROTA)

medicinalUses: The bark is a potent circulatory stimulant and analgesic. Chewing the bark produces a tingling, numbing sensation that relieves toothaches and sore throats.
sideEffects: Causes a strong tingling and numbing sensation in the mouth.
preparation: The bark is chewed for toothache or made into a tincture or tea.
detailedExplanation: The Toothache Tree is a well-known medicinal plant whose bark contains alkylamides that create a powerful tingling and numbing effect. It was a key herb in 19th-century Eclectic medicine for treating rheumatic pain and poor circulation, as well as oral pain. Source: https://www.pfaf.org/user/Plant.aspx?LatinName=Zanthoxylum+americanum

medicinalUses: Used for kidney stones, angina, diuretic
sideEffects: Rare
preparation: Seed decoction
detailedExplanation: Ammi visnaga has been traditionally used for kidney stones and circulatory support in Indian herbal medicine. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK92771/

medicinalUses: The root has a sharp, peppery taste. It was used as a spring tonic to cleanse the blood and stimulate digestion. The leaves are edible and nutritious.
sideEffects: Very safe.
preparation: The root can be grated as a horseradish-like condiment. The leaves are eaten in salads.
detailedExplanation: Toothwort is an early spring wildflower of the forest floor. Its root has a pungent, spicy flavor similar to horseradish. It was traditionally eaten as a "spring tonic" to wake up the digestive system after a long winter and to provide a boost of Vitamin C. Source: https://www.ediblewildfood.com/toothwort.aspx

medicinalUses: This plant is grown exclusively for its stunning, torch-like flower spikes that attract hummingbirds and butterflies. It has no well-known medicinal uses.
sideEffects: Not considered edible or medicinal.
regionsFound: Native to South Africa; cultivated in gardens.
preparation: Not used for medicine or food.
detailedExplanation: The Torch Lily is a dramatic and architectural garden plant. Its flowers are arranged on tall, sturdy stalks and typically transition from red at the top to yellow at the bottom, resembling a glowing torch. Its value is purely ornamental. Source: https://www.rhs.org.uk/plants/93102/kniphofia-uvaria/details

medicinalUses: The wood is very resinous and is burned as incense. The resin and essential oil are used in perfumery and have been used in traditional medicine for their antiseptic and calming properties.
sideEffects: The essential oil should be diluted for topical use.
preparation: The resin is burned like incense. The essential oil is used in aromatherapy.
detailedExplanation: Torchwood is a small tree known for its dense, oily wood that burns with a bright flame, hence its name. The fragrant resin and oil, known as "West Indian Sandalwood," are used in high-end perfumes and have a warm, balsamic scent that is calming and grounding. Source: https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/agricultural-and-biological-sciences/amyris

medicinalUses: In traditional medicine, the fruit is used for its anti-inflammatory and anti-allergic properties. It is also used to treat nausea and vomiting.
sideEffects: The fruit is extremely sour, bitter, and unpalatable when raw. The plant is covered with sharp, sturdy thorns that can cause physical injury.
regionsFound: Native to Northern China and Korea; cultivated worldwide as a hardy rootstock and ornamental hedge.
preparation: Rarely consumed as food. Used in traditional preparations like decoctions, tinctures, or dried powder for medicinal purposes.
detailedExplanation: The Trifoliate Orange is renowned for its exceptional cold hardiness and is primarily used as a rootstock for grafting commercial citrus varieties to impart disease resistance and vigor. Its dense, thorny growth also makes it an effective barrier hedge. The small, fuzzy fruit is green, turning yellow when ripe, but remains intensely sour and filled with seeds and pulp. Its primary value is agricultural and horticultural, not culinary. Source: https://plants.ces.ncsu.edu/plants/poncirus-trifoliata/

medicinalUses: Helps promote sleep, reduce anxiety, and calm the nervous system naturally.
sideEffects: Drowsiness, vivid dreams, mild headache
preparation: Tea, capsule, tincture
detailedExplanation: Valerian root has been used for centuries as a natural remedy for insomnia and stress. Its calming effects make it a popular alternative to chemical sleep aids. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4394901/

medicinalUses: Aids digestion, lifts mood, and acts as a natural antioxidant.
sideEffects: Rare allergic reactions
preparation: Extract, infusion
detailedExplanation: Vanilla pods and extracts are used for flavor and mild medicinal benefits. It supports mood balance and reduces oxidative stress. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4997391/

medicinalUses: Used for headaches, fever, and mild pain relief.
sideEffects: Mild nausea
preparation: Infusion, poultice
detailedExplanation: Vanilla Leaf leaves are brewed or applied as poultices for headache and mild pain relief; sometimes used as mosquito repellent. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Source of urushiol, but resin is used in traditional medicine for ulcers and blood circulation.
sideEffects: Skin irritation (toxic if raw)
preparation: Processed resin
detailedExplanation: Although toxic raw, purified extracts of varnish sumac resin are used in traditional East Asian medicine to support blood circulation and treat ulcers. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for anti-tumor, liver health, and detoxification.
sideEffects: Skin irritation if unprocessed
preparation: Extract, decoction
detailedExplanation: The resin and bark are used in traditional Korean and Chinese medicine for detox and tumor suppression (only purified forms). Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6891453/

medicinalUses: Used for colds, coughs, and mild fever.
sideEffects: Mild dizziness
preparation: Tea, inhalation
detailedExplanation: The leaves are used as tea or for inhalation in treating colds and fever; the aroma helps clear sinuses. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Enhances mood, energy, and male fertility; used in Parkinson’s support.
sideEffects: Nausea, headache
preparation: Powder, capsule
detailedExplanation: Velvet Bean seeds are rich in L-Dopa, supporting dopamine levels and used in Ayurvedic medicine for vitality and Parkinson’s. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4388273/

medicinalUses: Traditionally used for minor skin irritation relief and respiratory soothing.
sideEffects: None known
preparation: Poultice
detailedExplanation: Velvet Grass leaves are sometimes used as poultices to relieve itching and minor inflammation. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Supports digestion, wound healing, and blood sugar balance.
sideEffects: Rare mild allergy
preparation: Powder, tea
detailedExplanation: Velvet Mesquite pods are ground for tea or powder, supporting digestion, wound healing, and maintaining balanced blood sugar. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6341152/

medicinalUses: Rich in Vitamin C, used for digestive issues and as an antioxidant.
sideEffects: Generally safe; excessive consumption may cause acidity.
preparation: Fruit pulp is eaten raw or made into drinks.
detailedExplanation: Velvet Tamarind is a tropical fruit tree prized for its sweet-and-sour pulp, which is often consumed fresh or used in beverages and desserts. The fruit is exceptionally rich in Vitamin C and antioxidants, which help combat free radicals in the body. In traditional medicine, it is used to alleviate digestive troubles and is believed to have antimicrobial properties. The bark is also sometimes used in decoctions for its astringent qualities. Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dialium_indum

medicinalUses: Seed and leaf extracts used in folk remedies as mild anti-inflammatory and for topical wound care; seeds sometimes used as demulcent in traditional communities.
sideEffects: Rare skin sensitivity; seeds raw not recommended. Large doses may cause digestive upset.
preparation: Poultice, topical; seed decoction (traditional). Leaves and seeds are used in teas and poultices.
detailedExplanation: Velvetleaf leaves are sometimes applied as poultices to soothe minor skin inflammations and abrasions. Seeds have been used in decoctions for a demulcent effect in some folk traditions. Source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3854494/

medicinalUses: Used for fever, digestive issues, urinary problems, and as a diuretic.
sideEffects: Generally safe in medicinal doses.
preparation: Roots and leaves are used in decoctions and powders.
detailedExplanation: Indian Velvetleaf is a significant medicinal plant in Ayurveda, known as "Patha." It is used for a wide range of conditions, including fever, diarrhea, dysentery, urinary disorders, and skin diseases. Scientific studies have shown that it possesses anti-inflammatory, antidiarrheal, and diuretic properties. The root is the primary part used, often formulated into traditional remedies. Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cissampelos_pareira

medicinalUses: Primarily used in homeopathy for nervous disorders and skin conditions.
sideEffects: No common side effects from homeopathic use.
preparation: Used in highly diluted homeopathic preparations.
detailedExplanation: The Venus Flytrap is famous for its carnivorous nature but has no significant history in Western herbal medicine. Its primary modern use is within homeopathy, where it is employed for conditions like nervous excitement, anxiety, and certain skin ailments. The plant contains compounds like naphthoquinones, which have shown antimicrobial properties in lab studies. Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venus_flytrap

medicinalUses: Diuretic and used for digestive support.
sideEffects: Not well-documented.
preparation: The plant is used to make herbal tea.
detailedExplanation: Venus' Looking-glass is a common wildflower named for its disk-like seeds. It has limited documented medicinal use but has been employed in folk traditions as a mild diuretic and digestive aid. The plant is related to species in the Campanulaceae family, some of which have similar traditional uses. It is not a major herb in any modern herbal practice. Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Triodanis_perfoliata

medicinalUses: Not well-documented for medicinal use.
sideEffects: Not well-documented.
preparation: Not typically used in preparation.
detailedExplanation: Venus's Navelwort is a small, flowering plant primarily known for its ornamental value. It is not a prominent feature in major herbal traditions like Ayurveda, Traditional Chinese Medicine, or Western herbalism. There is very little information available regarding its historical or modern medicinal applications. Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Omphalodes_linifolia

medicinalUses: Used for anxiety, depression, digestive issues, and as a diuretic.
sideEffects: Generally safe; may cause GI upset in large doses.
preparation: Aerial parts are used in teas, tinctures, and infusions.
detailedExplanation: Common Verbena has a long history in European folk medicine, where it was considered a sacred plant. It is primarily used as a nerve tonic for anxiety and mild depression, a digestive bitter to stimulate appetite, and a diuretic. It also has a traditional reputation for supporting wound healing when used as a poultice. Modern research is exploring its antioxidant and neuroprotective properties. Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Verbena_officinalis

medicinalUses: Traditionally used as a calming nervine, digestive carminative, mild liver tonic, and for menstrual cramps. Herbalists use verbena to encourage relaxation and mild sleep support.
sideEffects: Rare digestive upset, possible mild drowsiness
preparation: Tea, tincture
